title: End-of-Summer Business Reading: Dreamers and the Defiant
description: With just a week left before the unofficial end of what has been a relentless summer of business news  the fate of Greece, the economic woes of China and the market roller coaster in the United States  hopefully you might find the time to read a book.

title: U.S. Open 2015: Stars Take a Beating on a Topsy-Turvy Day
description: Amid a flurry of first-round upsets, Kei Nishikori had multiple chances  two, to be specific  to sidestep disaster at the United States Open on Monday.

title: 6 Players Get Probation in Sayreville, N.J., Football Hazing Case
description: Six of the seven teenagers charged with sexually abusing teammates in a football hazing scandal at the high school in Sayreville, N.J., last fall were sentenced to probation and 50 hours each of community service, a prosecutor said on Monday.

title: Clash Erupts During Raid by Israelis in West Bank
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Israeli soldiers clashed with Palestinian gunmen in one of the West Banks toughest refugee camps overnight Tuesday, as a raid that appeared to be aimed at arresting people suspected as Palestinian militants turned into an armed confrontation.

title: Supreme Court Says Kentucky Clerk Must Let Gay Couples Marry
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday refused to allow a county clerk in Kentucky who objects to same-sex marriage on religious grounds to continue to deny marriage licenses to all couples, gay or straight.

title: Japan Nears Test Flight for Long-Delayed Regional Passenger Jet
description: After several years of delays, Japans first commercial airliner in about half a century is scheduled for its first test flight  an hourlong ride out of Nagoya Airport.

title: California Defends Its Review Process in Appeal to Preserve Death Penalty
description: California on Monday asked a federal appeals panel to overturn a 2014 court ruling that  unless it is reversed  could bring a reprieve to the more than 740 inmates on death row in the state.

title: TV Dinners in a Netflix World
description: SOLON, Ohio  The pizza arrived, mozzarella melting on a red crushed tomato blanket dotted with brilliant green spinach aboard a crispy, irregularly shaped crust dusted here and there with ash.

title: Insights, and Redactions, in Latest Release of Hillary Clintons Emails
description: WASHINGTON  Chelsea Clinton warned her parents that international relief efforts in Haiti were a disaster and that major changes were needed in a memo released on Monday that offered a rare window into her role in Americas most prominent political family.

title: A Wild Month on Wall St. Ends Quietly
description: For several years, parking ones savings in the United States stock market seemed like a no-brainer. Not only did stocks steadily climb  giving investors far better returns than they could get from their bank accounts  the ride up was smooth.

title: Nelson Shanks, Who Painted the Prominent, Dies at 77
description: Nelson Shanks, a painter known for his portraits of political leaders and prominent figures in the arts, who earlier this year revealed that he had included a visual reference to the Monica Lewinsky affair in his portrait of Bill Clinton for the National Portrait Gallery, died on Friday at his home in Bucks County, Pa. He was 77.

title: Narcos Episode 7 Recap: The Trouble With Steve Murphy
description: Read all of our Narcos recaps.

title: 244 Immigrants With Criminal Records Face Deportation in California
description: LOS ANGELES  More than 240 immigrants with criminal records who are living in the United States illegally were taken into custody last week during a four-day sweep across Southern California, immigration authorities said Monday.

title: Most Nations Miss a Goal for Women in Leadership
description: UNITED NATIONS  The corridors of the United Nations hummed on Monday as hundreds of men, in polished wingtips and natty ties, arrived here for the annual conclave of lawmakers from around the world.

title: Wayne W. Dyer, Prolific Author of Self-Help Books, Dies at 75
description: Dr. Wayne W. Dyer, whose best-selling 1976 book decrying the vice of blame and preaching the virtue of self-reliance, Your Erroneous Zones, propelled him to a prolific multimedia career of advice-giving and spiritual counseling, died over the weekend in Maui, Hawaii. He was 75.

title: Murder Rates Rising Sharply in Many U.S. Cities
description: MILWAUKEE  Cities across the nation are seeing a startling rise in murders after years of declines, and few places have witnessed a shift as precipitous as this city. With the summer not yet over, 104 people have been killed this year  after 86 homicides in all of 2014.

title: Making American Mens Game Great Again: Ideas?
description: On Tommy Haass Twitter page, in an Aug. 22 posting to his roughly 157,000 followers, he wrote: Make America great again. Thoughts? Suggestions?

title: An Escalating Migrant Crisis and an Intensifying Search for Solutions
description: A mounting migrant crisis has forced members of the European Union to search for new ways to adequately house, feed and effectively screen thousands of people seeking asylum. The recent influx of migrants, mostly from the Middle East and Northern Africa, has overwhelmed some countries and exposed vulnerabilities in the continental blocs open-border policy.

title: Taxis of Yesterday and Today
description: From the Darracq to the Nissan NV200, a brief history of automobile models that have served as New York City taxis.

title: Tomorrow Arrives for New York Citys Yellow Cab Standard
description: The boxy yellow vehicle is a survivor. It won a competition to redesign New York Citys taxi. It endured a pothole-marred course in Arizona meant to replicate the citys rugged streets. And it prevailed in a legal battle and overcame the election of a new mayor who had been a vocal opponent.

title: An Analysts Seamless Injection Into ESPNs Rotation
description: Jessica Mendoza showed Sunday night that she belongs in ESPNs regular rotation of baseball game analysts, with a smart, understated stint in place of Curt Schilling.

title: 1993 Murder Conviction Vacated; Brooklyn Prosecutor Says Evidence Was Withheld
description: A man who had served 24 years on a murder conviction was released on Monday, after the Brooklyn district attorney admitted his office had withheld key evidence in the case against the man, Ruddy Quezada.

title: As Crowds for Bernie Sanders Grow, the Biggest Impact Comes in Iowa
description: BOONE, Iowa  The first person Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont met when he climbed out of a Dodge Journey here on a recent Saturday morning was Caleb Humphrey. It was for good reason.

title: Top Officials With New York City Police Are Angered by Escapes
description: The woman, arrested after she was accused of skipping out on her bill at a restaurant and shoplifting, was taken to the hospital. She had told the police that she was pregnant and feeling ill.

title: No Corrections: August 31, 2015
description: No corrections appeared in print.

title: 3,000 Miles From Denali,Ohio Fumes Over Renaming of Mount McKinley
description: To be clear, President William McKinley has one of the largest grave sites of any former American president, so perhaps a mountaintop was a bit superfluous.

title: Serena Williams Coasts Through First Round at U.S. Open
description: Serena Williams spent about an hour on a practice court in the late afternoon on Monday in preparation for her first-round match of the U.S. Open. She pounded groundstrokes and serves, smashed some overheads, punched home a few volleys and even chased a handful of drop shots.

title: Europe Must Reform Its Deadly Asylum Policies
description: The arrival of hundreds of thousands of refugees from war-torn regions of Africa and the Middle East, as well as economic migrants from Africa and Asia, is testing the European Union as no other recent crisis has. As the human toll mounts  more than 2,500 have died so far this year  so does the moral pressure on Europe to act. On Friday, after 71 people were found suffocated in a truck in Austria and 150 others drowned off the coast of Libya, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said he was horrified and heartbroken at the latest loss of lives.

title: Expert Says Manuscript Is Not Harper Lees Third Novel
description: A rare books expert who reviewed recently discovered manuscript pages by Harper Lee has concluded that they are from an early version of To Kill a Mockingbird, and not a possible third novel by the author.

title: White House Sidesteps Hubbub About Obamas Future Role at Columbia
description: A passing comment by the president of Columbia University on Monday touched off a flurry of expectations that President Obama would affiliate with the university, his alma mater, after he leaves office, but the White House said no decisions had been made.

title: U.S. Tennis Associations New Executive Waits Patiently for American Boys to Fill a Void
description: The shirt Andy Roddick was wearing when he won the 2003 United States Open was cool, so cool, with one sleeve black and the other white, and diagonal lines across the chest, and some more diagonals across the back, that Tommy Paul remembers wanting to do anything to get it.

title: Help From Above
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Just to mix it up a little, were going to begin with the constructors notes today.

title: At U.S. Open Match, a Sea of Bills Blue
description: It is not often that N.F.L. apparel provides a clue of a spectators allegiance to a tennis player. But as play at the U.S. Open began Monday morning on Court 7, several fans in Buffalo Bills attire rallied around the 21-year-old qualifier Jessica Pegula as she sought her first victory in the main draw of a Grand Slam event.

title: Narcos Episode 8 Recap: It Doesnt Have to End This Way
description: Read all of our Narcos recaps.

title: Mets Efficiency Pays Off in Latest Win Over Phils
description: When Michael Conforto, the Mets rookie left fielder, dug into the batters box in the fifth inning, he calmly processed the situation. The Mets were locked in a scoreless tie with the Philadelphia Phillies. The rookie Jerad Eickhoff had held the Mets to one hit, a single to Conforto, who punched a 1-2 pitch into right field in his first at-bat.

title: Mayor de Blasios Aide on Homeless Is Resigning Amid Crisis
description: At a time when New York has taken emergency measures to help homeless residents, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Monday night that the deputy mayor overseeing the citys response to the crisis will resign at the end of September.

title: Explosion at Chinese Chemical Plant Is Said to Kill at Least 1
description: BEIJING  An explosion at a chemical plant in Shandong Province late Monday night killed at least one person, according to a Chinese news media report.

title: Missed Opportunities Haunt the Yankees on a Frustrating Night in Boston
description: BOSTON  With the Yankees trailing by a run and down to their final out, but with the bases loaded, the crack of Didi Gregoriuss bat gave rise to hope in the visitors dugout as the ball soared toward deep right field.

title: 1945: Tokio Ruin Bares Toll of Bombers
description: April 18, 1942, marked the first air raid on Tokyo by the United States. Strikes continued until August 15, 1945, when Emperor Hirohito announced Japans surrender, which was made official on Sept. 2.

description: tribute  \tri-()byt, -byt\  noun

description: For $79 plus shipping, you can buy a reprint of a long-obsolete federal government publication.

title: Video Suggests Suspect in San Antonio Shooting Had Hands Raised When Shot
description: The fatal shooting of a Texas man by sheriffs deputies in San Antonio last week was captured on video that appears to show he had his hands up when the officers fired.

title: Rafael Nadal, Reinvigorated, Subdues a Rising Star
description: Rafael Nadal is still a long way from reclaiming the form that once made him the most feared player on the ATP Tour, but with a solid victory against a talented young player, he moved into the second round of the United States Open.

title: Whats On TV Tuesday
description: 6:05 A.M. (FLIX) MR. HOLLANDS OPUS (1995) An idealistic composer (Richard Dreyfuss, above with Alicia Witt) takes a teaching job that becomes his true opus. Mr. Dreyfusss taste for grandstanding could easily sink a tale of simple virtues, especially one about a music teacher who is often seen marching, dancing, conducting or otherwise registering emotions aimed at the bleacher seats, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. But in Mr. Hollands Opus, Mr. Dreyfuss gives a warm and really touching performance. Hes firmly in control of the films comic moments and just as comfortable delivering the films calculatingly Capraesque payoff: a good cry.

title: European Firms Team Up to Target Google in Civil Lawsuits
description: Google already faces antitrust charges from Europes competition authorities.

description: We thought we would be freed. They knocked out Saddam and brought a hundred Saddams.

title: Teenage Motherhood in France
description: PERPIGNAN, France  When Viviane Dalles decided to explore the dramatic increase in teenage pregnancy in Frances Nord-Pas-de-Calais region, she knew it would be difficult. Few publications were interested in the topic, while parents and their daughters were reluctant to grant permission.

title: Obama to Call for More Icebreakers in Arctic as U.S. Seeks Foothold
description: SEWARD, Alaska  President Obama on Tuesday proposed speeding the acquisition and building of new Coast Guard icebreakers that can operate year round in the nations polar regions, part of an effort to close the gap between the United States and other nations, especially Russia, in a global competition to gain a foothold in the rapidly changing Arctic.

title: When Bosses Schedule Hours That Just Dont Work
description: Gap announced last week that it would soon end the practice of on-call scheduling, which requires workers to call in before a shift to see if they are needed. By the beginning of next year, the companys five brands  Athleta, Banana Republic, Gap, Intermix and Old Navy  will give employees at least 10 to 14 days notice of their schedules.

title: Hillary Clinton, the Great Defender
description: Hillary Clinton has obviously had a bad summer. Shes losing in New Hampshire to Bernie Sanders, even among women. Shes barely leading him in Iowa. In a Quinnipiac poll of potential general election matchups, shes beating Donald Trump by only four points, 45 to 41, and shes beating Marco Rubio by only one point.

title: Psychology Is Not in Crisis
description: Boston  IS psychology in the midst of a research crisis?

title: Chinas Crackdown on Rumors Will Only Hurt Its Economy
description: Chinas effort to prop up its stock market has taken a dangerous turn. Officials are arresting people whom they accuse of spreading rumors about the market and the unrelated industrial explosions in Tianjin that killed scores of people last month.

title: Facing Choices About D.C.I.S. After Breast Screenings
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Donald Trump on the Couch
description: AS surprising as Donald J. Trumps political ascendance may be, it is not unprecedented. He is the latest in a long line of demagogues that have appeared throughout American history to point accusing fingers at blacks, foreigners, Masons, Jews, socialists, central bankers and others. Whats more mysterious are the roots of his vast insecurity  his compulsive need to trumpet his wealth, his smarts, his popularity. What is he compensating for?

title: Baylor, Football and the Rape Case of Sam Ukwuachu
description: On Aug. 21, a Baylor University football player named Sam Ukwuachu was sentenced to six months in the county jail and 10 years probation for sexually assaulting a freshman soccer player two years ago.

title: The Graying of the President
Marissa Mayer of Yahoo Says Shes Pregnant With Twins
description: Yahoos chief executive, Marissa Mayer, and her husband, Zachary Bogue, are expecting twin daughters, according to an announcement she made on Yahoos Tumblr.

title: News Qs | At MTV V.M.A.s, Celebrity Feuds, Miley Cyrus and Also Some Music
description: In At MTV V.M.A.s, Celebrity Feuds, Miley Cyrus and Also Some Music, Jon Caramanica writes his review of the 2015 Video Music Awards show.

title: In Case You Missed It: Augusts Top Real Estate Stories
description: Catch up on the most popular stories of the month.

title: Between Iraq and a Hawk Base
description: The first sign that the Republican Partys 17 presidential candidates might have trouble explaining what a conservative foreign policy should look like  beyond simply saying that it should not look like Barack Obamas  emerged on May 10. Thats when the Fox News host Megyn Kelly asked Jeb Bush a rather predictable question about the Iraq war: Knowing what we know now, would you have authorized the invasion?

title: The Politics of Distraction
description: We begin, as many discussions about politics today should, with an analogy to pro wrestling. Consider the foreign object routine: One combatant produces a concealed item, usually from under his tights  a pointed stick or some hand-size tool of menace  and proceeds to jab his opponent with it. He perpetrates this atrocity in full view of everybody except the referee, who remains oblivious because a complicit third party (perhaps a tag-team partner or a manager) is distracting him.

title: Did You Ever Have a Family by Bill Clegg
description: Catastrophe and misfortune are a novelists friends, dramatic devices that provide a plot and let characters demonstrate their range. Tragedies tunnel through life, and the suspense comes from seeing how these spaces will be filled. This is what excites us about books that begin with a sorrowful bang. Grief is sad  we know that  but what now? How will these particular characters respond? What else do you have to give us?

title: Instagram Exerts a Force in Beauty Trends
description: In days, New York Fashion Week will inspire a burst of beauty trends. But are the runways still the best place to source fresh ideas?

title: Should Schools Give Students Body Report Cards?
description: In an effort to fight childhood obesity, more schools are keeping track of their students weight and sending reports home to update students and families.

title: An Unanswered Call for Help at Rikers Island
description: Over the years, reports of brutality and neglect at the Rikers Island jail complex have become routine. And while the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio has been working to improve conditions at New York City jails, the death of Carlos Mercado shows that the problems of the past could haunt the city for years to come.

title: Foraging for Fashion
description: A bounty of warm-weather looks at the Union Square Greenmarket.

title: Countdown to Death at Rikers Island
description: Carlos Mercado, 45, who was diabetic, died after 15 hours at the New York jail. Surveillance video shows him collapsed while officers step over him.

title: Foraging for Fashion
description: Summer was in full bloom at the Union Square Greenmarket last week. There was a bounty of ripe tomatoes, sweet corn and smartly dressed shoppers, who took a break from their grocery shopping to discuss their warm-weather looks.

title: The Girl in the Spiders Web by David Lagercrantz
description: There are many ways to continue a series after its authors death. One is to wait a long time, until the original material has achieved classic status, and then find an established heavyweight willing to step up, like a great actor taking on his third King Lear. Examples would be John Banville reviving Raymond Chandlers Philip Marlowe, or Jill Paton Walsh giving us more of Dorothy L. Sayerss Lord Peter Wimsey. As readers we approach such attempts cautiously, with style points and degrees of difficulty in mind, as if we were judges at an Olympic diving competition, and therefore, however good the execution may be, these books will always remain to some extent interesting curiosities.

title: As Chinas Economy Falters, Military Parade Offers Chance to Burnish Image
description: BEIJING  Few things distract an anxious nation in economic trouble quite like a jaw-dropping military parade featuring a cavalcade of gleaming high-tech weaponry, 12,000 goose-stepping soldiers and fighter jets filling the skies with synchronized plumes of candy-colored smoke.

title: A 2nd Suspect Is Arrested in Bangkok Shrine Bombing
description: BANGKOK  The head of Thailands military government, Prayuth Chan-ocha, said on Tuesday that security forces had arrested a man they believe planted the bomb that killed 20 people in Bangkok two weeks ago.

title: New York Today: Last of the Dog Days
description: Updated 9:59 a.m.

title: Train Station in Budapest Cuts Off Service to Migrants
description: BUDAPEST  The Keleti train station in Budapest, which has emerged as a setting in the tumultuous drama of Europes escalating migration crisis, cut off service to migrants on Tuesday as European countries remained bitterly divided and confused over how to handle the thousands trekking northward.

title: GE Capitals Australian Units Said to Be Receiving Final Bids From 3
description: SYDNEY, Australia  GE Capital has three final participants in the final round of an auction of its Australian commercial lending and leasing businesses, said a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

title: Lawyer Who Advised Churches in China Faces Secretive Detention
description: HONG KONG  A Chinese lawyer who has opposed a government campaign to tear down churches and church crosses faces up to six months in secretive detention after the police detained him and accused him of threatening state security, his colleague said on Tuesday.

title: Today in Politics: Jeb Bush Is Still Waiting for Polling to Catch Up With Fund-Raising
description: Good Tuesday morning. Though the political world will be poring over the latest batch of emails from Hillary Rodham Clintons time as secretary of state, Jeb Bushs campaign is hoping a new month will help bridge the sustained gap between his success in fund-raising and his lagging poll numbers.

title: Blue Hill, a Literary Enclave, Grows in Downeast Maine
description: Rain lashed the pine boughs outside Jonathan Lethems summer home in East Blue Hill, Me., in June as an unseasonably chilly fog rolled among birches and firs. Inside a book-lined office, the author brushed away a tear.

title: Louisiana Lays Bare Difficulty in Push to Cut Planned Parenthood Funding
description: NEW ORLEANS  Dr. Stephanie Taylor recently showed off the private community health center here, newly built on the site of a womens clinic wrecked by Hurricane Katrina a decade ago, pointing out the colorful furnishings, germ-resistant flooring and, in the sunny lobby, a welcoming Tree of Life mural. So it was a tad incongruous when she added, Were at ground zero for sexually transmitted infections.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Aug. 25-31, 2015
description: Have you been following the news?

title: Morning Agenda: David Einhorn Surveys Investors
description: DAVID EINHORN SURVEYS INVESTORS | David Einhorn has a reputation as one of the savviest stock pickers on Wall Street, but even he has not been spared in the recent market turmoil. This year is shaping up to be one of the worst in the history of his hedge fund. People briefed on the matter say the Greenlight Capital fund was down 5.3 percent in August and down 14 percent for the year. And Mr. Einhorn has been trying to find out what his investors think about the fund, Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein report in DealBook.

description: The night belonged to those who shocked without needing to perform.

title: Popcast: 2015 MTV Video Music Awards
description: At the 2015 MTV Video Music Awards on Sunday night, it was the most theatrically transgressive of times, and the most honestly transgressive of times. Miley Cyrus, pops enfant terrible, hosted the event, but she was hardly the most shocking part of the nights festivities, despite her best efforts. Those included outfits that looked like they had been drawn with a thin pencil, rather than cut from actual fabric (to say nothing of the moment Ms. Cyrus seemingly wore nothing at all); jokes that poked fun at her extreme persona, with little effect; and the surprise announcement of a new album, which she released just after the show.

title: Kentucky Clerk Denies Same-Sex Marriage Licenses, Defying Court
description: MOREHEAD, Ky.  Defying the Supreme Court and saying she was acting under Gods authority, a county clerk in Kentucky denied marriage licenses to gay couples on Tuesday, less than a day after the court rejected her request for a delay.

title: Former Apple Music Executive Ian Rogers Moves to LVMH
description: Ian Rogers, the music executive at Apple who stunned the industry last week with news of his departure, has revealed his new job: chief digital officer at LVMH, whose brands include Louis Vuitton and Mot & Chandon.

title: Migrants Stranded at Station in Budapest
description: Crowds of people waiting to board trains to Austria and Germany early Tuesday at the Keleti train station protested after the station shut down temporarily.

title: 2020 Olympics Logo Is Discarded After Plagiarism Accusations
description: TOKYO  Organizers of the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo said on Tuesday that they were abandoning a logo recently chosen for the Games, bowing to a public outcry following accusations that it had been plagiarized.

title: Baiting a Hook in Minneapolis, Bernie Sanders Was Torn Between Herring and Bagels
description: In Tuesdays paper, we look at how the crowds Senator Bernie Sanders is drawing around the country help him in Iowa.

description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Gravity
description: Now thats fun: Adam Davidson tells us about trade in the ancient Near East, as documented by archives found in Kanesh  and reports that the volume of trade between Kanesh and various trading partners seems to fit a gravity equation: trade between any two regional economies is roughly proportional to the product of their GDPs and inversely related to distance. Neat.

title: Obama Urges Action on Climate Change
description: At a meeting of foreign ministers in Anchorage on Monday, the president said that world leaders must come to an agreement on the issue before its too late.

title: What Should Obama Do Next on Iran?
description: As Congress returns to Washington after Labor Day, the vote on the Iran nuclear deal will be its most important since the decision to go to war in Iraq in 2003. While Republicans dominated the debate in July, Democrats regained lost ground in recent weeks with a flurry of endorsements in both houses of Congress. I testified in favor of the agreement before four congressional committees, and talked with many members individually during July and August. It now appears almost certain that President Obama has the votes to prevail in Congress.

title: Two Exciting New Fall Shows for Richard Long
description: The trailblazing British artist Richard Long, renowned for his large-scale creations made using stone, driftwood and, in some cases, nothing more than his own footprints, is being celebrated in two exhibitions this fall. In the 70-year-olds hometown of Bristol, the retrospective at the Arnolfini Gallery, Richard Long: Time and Space, features a number of his trademark mud murals and dry-stone sculptures. And in New York, at Sperone Westwater, Crescent to Cross will include a striking photograph of Aconcagua Circle, a ring of jagged rocks that the Turner Prize winner constructed during a 17-day trek in the Andes in 2012, as well as a new drawing created from red clay mud.

title: The Most Wonderful Time of the Year
description: TIMES INSIDER  The summer has sped by, but even with fall approaching, we still have plenty to celebrate:

title: Suicide Bomber in Pakistan Attacks Government Office, Killing 4
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  At least four people were killed and 50 others were wounded on Tuesday when a suicide bomber detonated his explosive-laden vest in the middle of a crowd lining up to enter a government building in northwestern Pakistan, officials said.

title: Sharp Denials After Arrest of Vice News Journalists in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  Terrorism charges in Turkey against three Vice News journalists were denounced Tuesday as baseless by media advocacy groups and a lawyer for the men.

title: 1940: Pilot Is Saved by Cup of Tea
description: AN AIRDROME IN SOUTHEAST ENGLAND  A cup of tea saved a young British Hurricane pilot from Nazi vengeance here today [Sept. 1] when three Messerschmitt Jaguars, painted with British markings which fooled ground defenses, swept in and bombed his machine in a corner of the field. A few minutes earlier the pilot had landed to have an oil leak plugged after shooting down a Dornier 117 into marshland near the coast. He had intended to wait in the cockpit while the mechanics worked on his plane, but instead accepted the commanding officers offer of a cup of tea. It probably saved him from death or serious injury.  New York Herald Tribune, September 2, 1940

title: Alexander Sokurov: Russia as Allegory for Art and Life
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  Alexander Sokurovs 2002 film Russian Ark, a single 90-minute unedited Steadicam shot that weaves through the State Hermitage Museum here, is an elliptical meditation on art, power and nostalgia. In his latest film, Francofonia, which will debut in competition at the Venice International Film Festival on Friday, this Russian director turned his camera on the Louvre for a reflection on cultural patrimony during wartime and Russias vexed relationship with Europe.

title: Daily Report: Hotel Chains Get Tough With Travel Websites
description: Hotel chains are mad as you-know-what at travel websites and they are not going to take it anymore.

title: Tests, Near and Far, for Sebastian Coe, Tracks New Chief
description: BEIJING  For a sport in crisis, the world track and field championships that ended in Beijing on Sunday provided some unexpected relief.

title: A Temporary Answer to a Foster Childs Biggest Question: Am I Going to School?
description: It rained the day we picked up our 3-year-old foster son, whom we call BlueJay, and brought him home to live with us four months ago. More accurately, it began unexpectedly pouring just moments before we opened the door of the apartment complex where he had been living and eyed up our car, parked a fair distance down the street.

title: For Bernie Sanders, Brooklyn Roots Pose a Test, History Shows
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont may be making inroads against Hillary Rodham Clinton when it comes to recent polling, injecting his Brooklyn accent into the presidential campaign discourse. While voters seem to be increasingly gravitating to his message, his candidacy raises another question: Is the nation finally ready to embrace a politician from New York Citys most populous borough?

title: Austria Discovers Syrian Travel Documents in Truck Where Bodies Were Found
description: VIENNA  The law enforcement authorities in Germany indicated on Tuesday that two suspects held in Hungary in connection with the deaths of 71 people found in a truck near Vienna on Thursday had been known to them for earlier crimes, including the smuggling of migrants to Bavaria just over a month ago.

title: Not Just Any White Shirt
description: In honor of Charvets legendary shirtmaking, one man takes a sartorial journey.

title: A Call for a Free Market
description: The worldwide turbulence of recent days is a strong indication that government intervention alone cannot restore the economy and offers a glimpse of the risk of completely depending on it. It is time to give the free market a chance.

title: 1965: Rusk Letter Admits Spying
description: WASHINGTON  An embarrassed State Department conceded today [Sept. 1] that Secretary of State Dean Rusk had apologized to the government of Singapore in 1961 over a Central Intelligence Agency operation that went bad. Only yesterday, the State Department had firmly denied an accusation by Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew in Singapore that an American CIA agent had been arrested in 1960 for trying to buy state secrets in Singapore. Mr. Lee said that he asked $33 million in foreign aid from the United States in return for his governments silence and the release of the agent, but that he was offered only $3 million and turned it down as an insult.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 2, 1965

title: Portugal, Missing Deadline for Novo Banco Sale, Turns to Second Bidder
description: MADRID  Portugal is having trouble selling the bank salvaged from the wreckage of one of the countrys biggest private lenders.

title: Review: Janet Jackson, on Unbreakable Tour, Shows Off Her Demure Side
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  A newly demure Janet Jackson started her Unbreakable World Tour at Rogers Arena here on Monday night. She was dressed in white and covered, like her dancers and musicians, from shoulders to shoes. And she avoided one big subset of her songwriting: her salacious, sometimes kinky whispers. That left Ms. Jackson, 49, to play the many other, less titillating roles that have given her major hits and made her an enduring influence across pop and R&B.

title: Protesters Storm Ministry in Beirut
description: Protesters took over the office of Lebanons environment minister in the capital on Tuesday, calling on him to resign for failing to find a solution to the garbage crisis.

title: Jeb Bush Video Takes Aim at Donald Trumps Manhattan Mind-Set
description: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida is pulling no punches with Donald J. Trump, assailing him in a new online advertisement as a fake conservative.

title: How the Shooting Occurred
description: A video of a fatal shooting by police officers in San Antonio last week appears to show a man putting his hands up before they fired.

title: Aftermath of Suicide Bombing in Pakistan
description: At least four people died in an attack on a government office in the tribal region of Jamrud, Pakistan.

title: Emails Show How Hillary Clinton Valued Input From Sidney Blumenthal
description: WASHINGTON  As secretary of state, Hillary Rodham Clinton had access to the latest information and analysis from the nations premier intelligence agencies, from a corps of seasoned diplomats reporting back from every corner of the world, from a range of foreign policy experts in and out of government. And from Sidney Blumenthal.

title: French Publisher Wont Print Book on Moroccan King After Authors Arrest
description: PARIS  A major French publishing house has decided not to publish a book critical of King Mohammed VI of Morocco after its two authors were arrested last week in Paris and charged with blackmail and extortion on accusations they demanded 2 million euros, or about $2.3 million, to keep the book unpublished.

title: The Wait
description: If you can wait in New York City, you can wait anywhere.

title: Vice Media Lands Carmelo Anthony for New Sports Channel
description: Carmelo Anthony is Vice Medias newest teammate.

title: Arabic Sesame Street Returns for First Time Since Gulf War
description: Elmo and the Cookie Monster are returning to the Persian Gulf for the first time in 25 years.

title: Scott Walker Shows His Aggressive Side
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin called himself aggressively normal in the first Republican presidential debate  and saw his poll numbers go backward.

title: 2015 Fantasy Football: Tight End Preview and Rankings
description: Tight end is traditionally the thinnest of the four offensive fantasy football positions, and there seems to be even more uncertainty than usual regarding the position heading into 2015.

title: California Agrees to Overhaul Use of Solitary Confinement
description: LOS ANGELES  California has agreed to an overhaul of the use of solitary confinement in its prisons, including strict limits on the prolonged isolation of inmates, as part of a landmark legal settlement filed in federal court on Tuesday.

title: Second Bomb Suspect Arrested in Bangkok
description: A police spokesman, Lt. Gen. Prawut Thavornsiri, speaks about one of three suspects connected to the bombing of a shrine in Bangkok.

title: Prisoner Who Escaped From Manhattan Hospital Is Back in Custody
description: The woman who escaped from police custody while she was in a Manhattan hospital was captured on Tuesday on the Upper West Side, the police said.

title: Jesse Kamms Laid-Back Approach to Life  and Looks
description: This year, the Los Angeles-based designer Jesse Kamm  whose languid, Annie Hallish separates are cult items among the creative class on both coasts  celebrates 10 years in business. Its no small feat considering she is the companys sole employee and refuses to collaborate with big brands as a matter of principle. Instead, the former model has slowly built a following for her signature silhouettes  including dramatically high-waisted, perpetually sold-out sailor pants, which are being reissued in early September in new colors to commemorate the lines anniversary. (A video celebrating the pants in all their splendor debuts here.)

title: Superiority Burger
description: Vegetarian medium fast food in the East Village.

title: Restaurant Review: Superiority Burger in the East Village
description: We all know restaurants where the menu changes daily. Last week at Superiority Burger, a vegetarian medium-fast-food outfit in the East Village, it changed in the middle of my meal.

title: Pope Francis to Pass Through Central Park in Ticketed Event
description: Pope Francis is coming to Central Park, but you will need a ticket to see him.

title: Googles Driverless Cars Run Into Problem: Cars With Drivers
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Google, a leader in efforts to create driverless cars, has run into an odd safety conundrum: humans.

title: Injured Vitalia Diatchenko Shows Retirement Has Its Perks
description: Vitalia Diatchenkos hobbled performance Monday night against Serena Williams  which ended when she retired in the second set with a foot injury  stole some energy from the opening night of the United States Open and provoked more debate about how award money is handled for injured players.

title: Ford and Fiat Chrysler Post Surprising Sales Gains in August
description: Even as auto sales have returned to prerecession levels, one kind of vehicle has been left behind: the family sedan.

title: The U.S. Icebreaker Gap is About Arctic Needs, Not About Chasing Russia
description: Way back in the Cold War, the United States fixated on a missile gap with the Soviet Union. You may remember this even devolved into a mineshaft gap in Dr. Strangelove.

title: Bloomberg News, Refocusing Its Coverage, Will Lay Off About 90
description: Bloomberg News laid off as many as 90 journalists on Tuesday in its newsrooms in New York, Washington and across the world, part of a plan to refocus the organizations coverage on business, finance, economics, technology and politics.

title: At Wharton, Donald Trumps Marketing Skills Make the Grade
description: Donald J. Trump has made a few things clear to voters as he has barnstormed the country making his case for the presidency. He will build a wall; he is very rich; and he went to Wharton  the University of Pennsylvanias prestigious business school.

title: The Healing Power of Hugs
description: One day several years ago, I spontaneously hugged a patient of mine, Gretchen. It was during a moment in which her despair and distress were so intense that it seemed cruel on a human level not to reach out my arms to her, in the event that she might derive some relief or comfort from an embrace. She hugged me for dear life.

title: A Stew of Peppers Dresses Up Brown Rice
description: In summer and early fall, when local sweet peppers are truly sweet and have great depth of flavor, theres nothing I like better than a comforting stew of peppers: a simple mix of onion, garlic, peppers, tomatoes and basil cooked slowly in olive oil.

title: The End of the Republican Party?
description: My Sunday column on Trump ended with a rather dire forecast: That if the G.O.P. fails to adapt to some of the crucial reasons for his success, the pressure the Donald has tapped will continue to build  and when it bursts, the G.O.P. as we know it may go with it. Erick Erickson, in part of a longer series of posts,invokes my column while making an even grimmer forecast: That the RepublicanParty is dying, that what were watching is the beginning of the end. And Ben Domenech, in yesterdays edition of The Transom, writes the following:

title: The Fantastic Man Editors on Their Five Favorite Magazines
description: Jop van Bennekom and Gert Jonkers, the Dutch duo also behind The Gentlewoman and Butt, share their all-time favorite publications.

title: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 10 | Finding Freedom and Self-Love Through Running
description: For 10 weeks this summer we asked students the question, What interested you most in The Times this week? Below, we announce our favorite responses for the 10th and final week of our Sixth Annual Summer Reading Contest.

title: Fung Tu Keeps Cooking, Even With Gas Shut Off
description: The gas went out at Fung Tu on July 9, a Thursday, the busiest night of the week for a Manhattan restaurant in summer.

title: The Neverending Fight to Save Social Security
description: A trial balloon now being inflated by Republicans in Congress needs to be popped before it gets any bigger.

title: Stocks Dive as Worries About Asia Reverberate
description: Keep the seatbelts on.

title: Review: Chrissie Hyndes Reckless Details a Rockers Life
description: Way to go, Akron, Ohio, for giving the world Chrissie Hynde, a malcontent for the ages  or, at a minimum, for the post-punk era  with a look to match: kohl-rimmed eyes, a low hedgerow of bangs, the best sneer since Elviss.

title: Serena Williamss Links to a Pioneer Keep Growing Clearer
description: As Serena Williams left the interview room Monday evening and walked down a long corridor, I asked her if she had seen the Althea Gibson documentary that is making the rounds.

title: Is Everyone Qualified to Be a Critic?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Adam Kirsch and Charles McGrath discuss what it takes to pass judgment on the arts.

title: Undercover Activist James OKeefe Plans to Step Up Political Stalking
description: Campaign rallies are crawling with hidden cameras these days as opposition researchers from rivals, activist groups or political action committees spare no expense in hopes of finding a gaffe or, ideally, signs of unlawfulness.

title: Saucy in Brooklyn Isnt Just for Catering
description: Saucy Przemek Adolf started with savory jams and chutneys four years ago. They quickly became the platform for his catering company, Saucy by Nature. And now he has a restaurant, Saucy. Its been a bit of a ride, he said. He figured that having a restaurant in tandem with a catering company would permit him to reduce waste by using surplus ingredients, distributing leftovers and composting. Though hes not going to the extremes of sustainability like the experiment this year by Dan Barber of Blue Hill, serving carrot peelings and fish-head tartare, he said he would dabble in it, and turn radish leaves into pesto. The restaurant is fast casual, with counter service for soups, salads and sandwiches to eat in or take out at lunchtime, and heartier fare, like Moroccan chicken, for dinner: 884 Fulton Street (Washington Street), Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, saucybynature.com.

title: Robert Rodriguez, Film Director and El Rey Founder, on Creating a Hispanic Network
description: Back when he was participating in clinical drug trials to help raise the original $7,000 budget for his 1993 breakthrough film El Mariachi, Robert Rodriguez never dreamed he would one day be running his own cable channel. Now hes the founder and chairman of the El Rey Network, an outlet he started in 2013 specializing in the grindhouse fare he favors as the director of movies like Sin City and Machete. Usually as a filmmaker, all you can do is make product, and you have to go find a distributor, Mr. Rodriguez said. When you are the distributor, you have a direct pipeline into homes, and you can try things you wouldnt get to do otherwise. You can build a network from the ground up. El Rey now reaches 40 million households in the United States and is available on such services as DirecTV, Dish Network and Sling TV.

title: Obama Nears Needed Votes on Iran Nuclear Deal
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama all but clinched victory for his Iran nuclear deal on Tuesday, as two Democratic senators threw crucial support behind the landmark accord.

title: Big Leaps for Parental Leave, if Workers Actually Take It
description: Some corners of corporate America have a new message for new parents: Put down that laptop and pick up your baby instead.

title: Police Clear You Stink Protesters From Ministers Offices in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Demonstrators from the You Stink movement, protesting a garbage pileup and political dysfunction, occupied the offices of Lebanons environment minister in downtown Beirut on Tuesday, declaring that they would stay until he resigned.

title: Donald Trumps Shaky Grasp on Immigration
description: When Donald Trump was reaching adulthood in the mid-1960s, the United States was a less diverse place. By 1970, the share of the population born overseas had shrunk to 4.7 percent, the slimmest on record. Only about 0.4 percent of the population had been born in Mexico.

title: The Triumph of Backward-Looking Economics
description: We dont get to do many controlled experiments in economics, so history is mainly what we have to go on. Unfortunately, many people who imagine that they know how the economy works go with what they think they heard about history, not with what actually happened. And Im not just talking about the great unwashed; quite a few well-known economists seem not to have heard about FRED, or at least havent picked up the habit of doing a quick scan of the actual data before making assertions about facts.

title: In Asheville, a Fall Tour That Includes Farms and Wine
description: In response to guests asking innkeepers in the Asheville, N.C., area what to do beyond exploring the Blue Ridge Parkway, the Asheville Bed & Breakfast Association has created a Fall Farms and Artisans Tour Package that takes visitors along the roads less traveled. The 16 inns have partnered with three western North Carolina farms, a vineyard and five artisans in the 200-year-old farming community of Sandy Mush in Leicester, situated amid rolling hills 20 minutes northwest of Asheville.

title: In West Bank, Speculation Abounds Over Mahmoud Abbass Plans
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Mahmoud Abbas, the aging Palestinian president, may be paving the way for his exit from political life  or he may be trying to consolidate power by crippling all his rivals.

title: Bad Ideas Down Under
description: Im heading off to Sydney, for the Festival of Dangerous Ideas. Blogging will be limited due to travel, plus blood rushing to my head from standing upside down when I get there.

title: Inside Amazon: Reporters Notebook
description: Last January, when we began interviewing Amazon veterans about what it is like to work at the company, we realized that we were stepping into a heated private debate.

title: Pope Francis Eases Path to Absolution for Abortion
description: ROME  Pope Francis announced Tuesday that all Roman Catholic priests would be empowered to offer absolution for the sin of abortion during the churchs Holy Year of Mercy, which begins in December.

title: Idris Elba, Called Too Street to Play James Bond, Gets an Apology
description: To fans, Idris Elba would make the perfect James Bond. Theyve been clamoring for years to cast the actor as the smooth action hero. So when the author of a forthcoming Bond novel dismissed Mr. Elba as too street for the part, the backlash was immediate, and now comes the apology.

title: Shakespeare Gets Hip-Hop Treatment With App
description: Eminem called himself a modern-day Shakespeare in 2001. Now the Royal Shakespeare Company is trying to further bridge the gap between rap and the writer: Theyve created an app with Samsung, RE: Shakespeare, which remixes Shakespeare through a hip-hop lens.

title: Review: The Black Panthers Captures a Militant Movements Soul and Swagger
description: The beginning of The Black Panthers, Stanley Nelsons excellent new documentary, includes a television news report on tensions between black citizens and the police in American cities. If not for the fuzzy, monochrome images and the voice-overs unironic use of the word Negroes, the clip could have been broadcast last week, instead of almost 50 years ago. And if Mr. Nelson doesnt strain to establish the present-day relevance of the story he has to tell, its partly because he doesnt have to. The problems of poverty, police brutality and economic plunder that gave birth to the Panthers are with us still.

title: Same-Sex Couple Confronts Kentucky Clerk
description: Kim Davis, the clerk of Rowan County, Ky., turned away David Ermold and David Moore, who were seeking a marriage license. Ms. Davis said she was acting under Gods authority.

title: God vs. the Constitution in Kentucky
description: Apparently, you can appeal a Supreme Court ruling to a higher authority.

title: Fox Lake Police Open Manhunt for 3 Shooting Suspects
description: CHICAGO  With helicopters buzzing overhead and police dogs searching on the ground, the authorities in northern Illinois conducted a sprawling manhunt Tuesday evening for three people suspected in the fatal shooting of a Fox Lake police lieutenant that morning.

title: At Auschwitz, a Summer Precaution Is a Grim Reminder to Some
description: It was intended to provide relief from the extreme summer heat in Poland. But instead, a suspended hose that sprays visitors to Auschwitz with a fine mist is reminding some of the concentration camps grim history.

title: Pope Asks Bullied Girl to Sing for Him
description: After learning that Valerie Herrera, 17, used music to cope with being bullied for a rare skin condition, Pope Francis said he would like to hear her sing. Be courageous, he added with a smile.

title: British Employers Who Skirt Living Wage Will Face Tough Fines, Cameron Says
description: LONDON  As the push for higher minimum pay builds momentum on both sides of the Atlantic, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain on Tuesday threatened companies with tough fines if they fail to pay what he called a national living wage.

title: Real Madrid and Manchester United Trade Jabs After Transfer Fails
description: MADRID  Major soccer transfers almost always involve secretive talks among clubs, players and their agents haggling over large sums of money. The outcome is ultimately made public if a deal is reached, but often in trite statements in which the buying club welcomes the arrival of a top player while the seller thanks him for his contribution. Rarely is there a mention of exactly how much cash was exchanged.

title: Phillips and Sothebys Announce Strategic Moves
description: Phillips and Sothebys auction houses are taking steps to strengthen their businesses.

title: Marco Rubio Faults Donald Trump on Make America Great Again Slogan
description: CARSON CITY, Nev.  The slogan is now synonymous with Donald J. Trumps campaign: Make America Great Again. It is embroidered on the hats he sells for $25 and often seen printed on homemade T-shirts and signs at his rallies across the country.

title: Uber Rolls IntoMarthas Vineyard and Finds Some Resistance
Missouri Teenagers Protest a Transgender Students Use of the Girls Bathroom
description: A transgender high school student in Missouri is facing backlash from her peers after requesting to use the girls bathrooms and locker room.

title: Menstruation Innovation: Lessons from India
description: In recent months, a wave of period-positivity has captured headlines  from Kiran Gandhis bold free-bleeding run of the London Marathon, to the successful repeal of Canadas national tampon tax. Donald Trump catapulted menstruation smack into the middle of the Republican presidential debate when he ridiculed Megyn Kellys inquiry about his prior sexist rants, telling CNN she had blood coming out of her wherever.

title: Mr. Obamas Urgent Arctic Message
description: A presidential trip has enormous power to focus attention on a place and an issue, and President Obamas trip to Alaska has been minutely choreographed with visits to glaciers, threatened Inuit villages and the like to provide a stunning and alarming context to his message on the urgent need to address climate change.

title: Five Poets Receive Lucrative Fellowships
description: Five poets received unusually lucrative good news on Tuesday, as the Poetry Foundation and Poetry magazine announced the recipients of the 2015 Ruth Lilly and Dorothy Sargent Rosenberg Poetry Fellowships.

title: The Black Panthers in Pictures
description: Images from the documentary The Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution.

title: Readers Recommend Where to Go Around Lake Michigan
description: One of our recent articles, A Tour of Lake Michigan, My Inland Sea, about the writer Rich Cohens travels around the lake, inspired more than 290 comments on nytimes.com/travel. Mr. Cohen, who grew up in Glencoe, Ill., about a mile from the shore, made stops in Chicago; Benton Harbor, Mich.; Ludington, Mich.; Mackinac Island and Milwaukee; just to name a few.

title: Los Angeles to Be U.S. Bidder to Host 2024 Olympics
description: LOS ANGELES  Eight months after finishing as the runner-up to Boston, Los Angeles has officially been chosen as the United States candidate for the 2024 Olympics, city officials announced Tuesday.

title: Pictures of the Day: Hungary and Elsewhere
description: Hungary and More  Pictures of the Day

title: U.S. Remains the Great Satan, Hard-Liners in Iran Say
description: TEHRAN  Flexing their muscles, some of the toughest anti-American voices in Iran said on Tuesday that the United States remains their countrys top enemy, guilty of uncountable crimes. Their remarks hinted at a developing struggle over domestic influence because of the nuclear deal with world powers.

title: A Recipe From the Newly Relaunched Aldea
description: On Aug. 24, the chef George Mendess ultramodern, Iberian-inspired restaurant, Aldea, shut its doors for 10 days. Six years after its opening (and five years after receiving its first Michelin star), the time had come, he explains, for some long-awaited updates. The relaunch itself has probably been on my mind for the past year and a half to two years, he says. I wanted to take this on full force  what started out as a need for wear-and-tear renovations became an opportunity, in the summer months, to close down, do a complete renovation from head to tail, make changes at the bar and revisit the menu.

title: September 1, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Hungary, India, Ukraine and Cuba.

title: Vice Urges Release of Its Journalists
description: A member of the Vice News team and a lawyer for the detainees called for the release of two British Vice News journalists and their Iraqi news assistant, who were arrested by the Turkish police.

title: Building for Future, Ithaca Remakes Town Square
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  On Saturday, as Ithaca celebrated the official opening of its newly designed outdoor pedestrian mall, the Commons, Mayor Svante Myrick strolled through the crowd on the plaza, collecting congratulations every few feet.

title: Union Accused of Betraying Migrant Carnival Workers
description: RICHMOND, R.I.  At summer carnivals like the Washington County Fair recently held here, migrant laborers spend long days running the Whip, the Orbiter, the Polar Express and other popular rides.

title: Google Antitrust Inquiries Spread Over Globe, With India the Latest Problem
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google is quickly becoming the company government regulators around the world love to investigate.

title: Review: Big Blue Live Searches for Marine Life
description: Big Blue Half-Live might have been a more accurate title, and only the humpback whales seem to have gotten the memo for the initial East Coast broadcast, but at least give PBS credit for trying something different.

title: A Fellow Outsider, Ben Carson Rivals Donald Trump in Polls, if Not in Pomp
description: The spotlight rarely found Ben Carson this summer. While other presidential candidates shot flaming arrows at rivals and sometimes the news media, the soft-spoken Mr. Carson seemed to struggle to be noticed. Well, thank you, he told moderators in the first Republican debate. I wasnt sure if I would get to speak again.

title: Maria on Sesame Street, Sonia Manzano, Tells of Her Own Childhood
description: Talking to Sonia Manzano feels like catching up with an old friend.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week.

title: Explaining the Strange, Stinky Appeal of the Corpse Flower
description: A little more than a week after crowds at the Denver Botanic Gardens welcomed the smelly bloom of its resident titan arum, known as the corpse flower, another of the flowers failed to give visitors at the Chicago Botanic Garden a similar, smelly show.

title: Questions Raised About Vietnam War Photos
description: Images by North Vietnamese war photographers that were featured in a book and exhibit have been found to have been manipulated.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: In Black Mass, Whitey Bulger Acquires a Glimmer of Humanity
description: LOS ANGELES  Books about the unsavory alliance between the Boston mobster James (Whitey) Bulger and a corrupt F.B.I., including the best-selling Black Mass, serve up one horrific detail after another: a man stabbed 38 times with an ice pick, drive-by machine gun shootings, a young woman who is strangled with bare hands, the digging up of rotting corpses.

title: A Conversation With Janno Lieber
description: Mr. Lieber, 53, is the president of the World Trade Center Properties division of Silverstein Properties, overseeing the developers four World Trade Center buildings.

title: Fireball Fight in El Salvador
description: Participants in Nejapa gathered to throw gasoline fireballs at one another in an annual tradition that celebrates St. Jeronimo and has links to a 1658 volcanic eruption.

title: Uber Rebuffed by Judge in Ruling on Drivers Suit
description: A federal judge granted class-action status on Tuesday to a lawsuit that questions the employment classification of Uber drivers, paving the way for a legal challenge that could strike at the heart of the ride-hailing companys business model.

title: Kathleen Hanna Revisits Her Riot Grrrl Past
description: When the riot grrrl pioneer Kathleen Hanna recently dug up some of her earliest work  the first demo cassette she recorded in 1991 with her band Bikini Kill, which has been remastered and is being reissued this month as Revolution Girl Style Now  she was a little nervous. I thought I was going to hate it. I thought I was going to be like, Oh, God, this is so embarrassing, she says with a laugh. These were the first songs we ever wrote; and that tape was made primarily to send to promoters, to try to get shows. It wasnt even made as a product that we were trying to sell in stores.

title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Sleep Arrives in Open Fields
description: With the path long, perilous, and occasionally obstructed by guards or crossed by barbed wire, refugee families like the Majids must manage their wounds along the way.

title: How Can America Fight Unfair Work Schedules?: Reader Q&A
description: American workers need protection from unfair scheduling practices like on-call shifts, the editorial board argued on Tuesday. Below, Teresa Tritch, editorial writer on economic issues, responds to reader questions and comments about unfair scheduling and how to address it.

title: Pessimism Pervades Mexico as Economic Promises Fall Short
description: MEXICO CITY  Jess Rascn embodies the sort of success story that was supposed to epitomize Mexicos moment.

title: Donald Trump Meets With Javier Palomarez, Head of U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce
description: Donald J. Trump has been ruffling feathers with Hispanics with his tough talk on immigration, but on Tuesday the Republican presidential candidate took a step to try to smooth things over.

title: CNN Alters Debate Criteria, Which Could Help Carly Fiorina
description: CNN announced on Tuesday that it would amend the criteria for picking candidates for the next Republican debate, scheduled for Sept. 16. The move followed criticism from supporters of Carly Fiorina and others that she was being unfairly excluded.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Rashomon on the West Bank: Israelis and Palestinians Debate Images of Soldier and Child
description: Not much of what happened last Friday during a demonstration near the West Bank village of Nabi Saleh is in doubt. But in thousands of social media arguments since then, Israelis and Palestinians, and supporters of the two sides around the world, have interpreted one charged encounter in very different ways.

title: Qaeda-Affiliated Group Overruns African Union Base in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Fighters from the Shabab militant group overran an African Union military base in southern Somalia on Tuesday morning in an attack that included a suicide bombing and an intense firefight, witnesses and officials said.

title: SFX Cancels One Tribe Festival, Citing Weak Ticket Sales
description: SFX Entertainment, the beleaguered promoter of dance music events, has canceled the One Tribe festival outside Los Angeles, the companys first business casualty in the face of mounting financial problems in recent weeks.

title: Representative Hakeem Jeffries Says He Will Vote for Iran Nuclear Deal
description: Representative Hakeem Jeffries, the Brooklyn Democrat known for his close ties with pro-Israel advocacy groups, announced on Tuesday that he will vote in support of President Obamas nuclear deal with Iran.

title: Review: Creep, a Horror Film With the Look of Found Footage
description: The actor and director Mark Duplass has come a long way from his mumblecore days, when he appeared in modest, low-budget movies like Hannah Takes the Stairs, often collaborating with his brother, Jay. Now hes an indie stalwart, who helped create, and stars in, Togetherness on HBO. But he still has a taste for bare-bones filmmaking, as evidenced by Creep, a horror two-hander in which he stars, directed by Patrick Brice.

title: Sony Altered Concussion Film to Prevent N.F.L. Protests, Emails Show
description: When Sony Pictures Entertainment decided to make a movie focusing on the death and dementia professional football players have endured from repeated hits to the head  and the N.F.L.s efforts toward a cover-up  it signed Will Smith to star as one of the first scientists to disclose the problem. It named the film bluntly, Concussion.

title: Preparing for a Military Parade, China Deploys a Troop of Monkeys
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government has countless worries about mishaps that might besmirch its quest for a perfectly staged military parade.

title: Review: A Walk in the Woods, With Robert Redford, Is a Scenic Trek Spoiled
description: Theres a scene in A Walk in the Woods, a low-impact amble through hill, dale and cinematic nostalgia, when our two crusty trekkers face down a pair of bears. The men  Robert Redford and Nick Nolte  are slumbering in their tents when the bears descend and begin tearing into the hikers food, which they have failed to properly stash. The bears roar and the men thunder back, flapping uvulas and arms to chase off the animals. Its a mildly funny scene, partly because of its light physical comedy and sight gaggery, although also because Mr. Nolte, his signature growl now often at sepulchral depths, has been doing a fair impression of a wild beast for years.

title: Agency Reduces Estimate of Faulty Airbag Inflaters in the United States
description: A federal regulator said on Tuesday that it was still grappling with the size of the airbag crisis at Takata, the Japanese supplier, and that it expected to outline new steps in the recall process at a public meeting this fall.

title: TV Producers of 2016 Oscars Are Selected
description: LOS ANGELES  The producers for the next Oscar ceremony will be Reginald Hudlin, a filmmaker schooled in urban comedy, and David Hill, a television producer with credits on American Idol and the 2011 World Series broadcast, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Tuesday.

title: Kuwait: 26 Accused of Iran-Linked Plot
description: The judicial authorities in Kuwait have charged 25 Kuwaitis and an Iranian with illicit arms possession and secretive contacts with Iran and its ally Hezbollah, the Shiite Lebanese militant group, Kuwaits official news agency reported Tuesday. The agency quoted a statement by Dherar al-Asousi, the public prosecutor, as saying all 26 were implicated in what it described as a terrorist plot to destabilize the country. Twenty-three of the defendants have been arrested, the statement said. It did not name any but said all were accused of having illegally obtained explosives, machine guns, firearms, ammunition and tapping devices. Kuwaits Sunni monarchy is a strong ally of Saudi Arabia, which regards Iran as its main regional rival.

title: After a Killing, Body Cameras Are Expanded in San Antonio
description: SAN ANTONIO  One day after a bystanders cellphone video was released that appeared to show sheriffs deputies fatally shooting a Hispanic man who had his hands raised in surrender, officials here voted Tuesday to finance additional body cameras for deputies in the field, as federal authorities said they had opened an investigation into whether the mans civil rights had been violated.

title: Preservationists Fight Bill Setting Time Limit on Landmarks Decisions in New York
description: What if Grand Central Terminal, the Empire State Building and the theater at Radio City Music Hall were not New York City landmarks?

title: Can a Novelist Be Too Productive?: Q. & A. With Stephen King
description: Stephen King took questions from readers about writing and creativity based on his Sunday Review essay, Can a Novelist Be Too Productive? Here are his responses.

title: F.D.A. Warns 5 Producers of Powdered Caffeine
description: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday that it had sent warning letters to five producers of pure powdered caffeine, in what consumer advocates said was a long overdue move against the product and the industry that makes it.

title: Ruling in Uber Case
description: The ruling by Judge Edward M. Chen will allow a jury to decide whether Uber drivers should be considered employees or 1099 contract workers, named after a tax designation, which does not require the company to pay payroll taxes or apply minimum wage and overtime laws to the drivers.

title: A Lesson in Sincerity, Trump Style
description: Please hold for Mr. Trump, the voice said on the telephone.

title: Paring His Bucket List, Obama Relishes Hiking at an Alaskan Glacier
description: KENAI FJORDS NATIONAL PARK, Alaska  President Obama hiked alone up a gravel path toward Exit Glacier, gazing at a mass of flowing ice as it melted into the plain below.

title: Micklethwait Memo
description: On Tuesday, the editor in chief of Bloomberg News, John Micklethwait, outlined a slew of changes  some organizational, some visual, and some editorial  and the thinking behind them in a lengthy email to the staff.

title: Icelanders Use Facebook to Open Door to Refugees
description: Responding to a growing international crisis, thousands of Icelands residents have taken to social media to put pressure on their government to take in more migrants.

title: With Technology, Avoiding Both Ads and the Blockers
description: When Allrecipes unveiled a revamped website on Tuesday, it billed the move as part of a broader transformation into a social network for food lovers. Among other new capabilities available to them, the sites millions of users can now follow other cooks and share what they have made on Facebook.

title: Narcos Episode 9 Recap: The Two Faces of Pablo Escobar
description: Read all of our Narcos recaps.

title: New York Attorney General Reaches Deal to End Litigation at Cooper Union
description: After a year of negotiations with warring parties at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, New York States attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, is expected on Wednesday to announce that his office has reached a settlement that would end litigation and create an independent monitor of the colleges management and finances.

title: Kim Davis, a Local Fixture, and Now a National Symbol
description: MOREHEAD, Ky.  Before she ignited a firestorm over same-sex marriage, Kim Davis was known, for decades, as a woman behind the counter of a small county clerks office: a mild-mannered conduit for auto tag renewals, lien releases, land records and marriage certificates.

title: Price of Crude Oil Tumbles After Soaring for 3 Days
description: HOUSTON  After three days of spiking oil prices, a barrel of crude tumbled back nearly 8 percent on Tuesday, renewing despair in the oil patch. At the same time, ConocoPhillips announced it was cutting its global work force by 10 percent.

title: President Otto Prez MolinaIs Stripped of Immunity in Guatemala
description: MEXICO CITY  Guatemalas Congress voted on Tuesday to strip President Otto Prez Molina of his immunity from prosecution, a unanimous decision that acknowledged the outpouring of citizen demands for an end to entrenched impunity.

title: Donald Young Comes From Behind by Not Looking Back
description: Gone are the days when Donald Young was considered the future of American tennis. In the 12 years since he turned professional, at 14, Young has lost more matches than he has won. He has battled nerves, critics and opponents. He has become an unabashed reader of self-help books  and pretty much anything else that might help him deal with adversity.

title: Roger Federer, an Old Hand With a New Move, Keeps Everyone Guessing
description: Serena Williams was working out on Practice Court 1 on Monday, and between shots she glanced over at Roger Federer on the adjacent court to see for herself.

title: Historical Symbols in Midst of a Purge Moment
description: WASHINGTON  In 1861, Union soldiers who were camped out in the Senate chamber attacked the desk of Jefferson Davis with a bayonet. Eager to destroy the symbol connected to Davis, who had resigned from the Senate to become president of the Confederacy, they were halted by an aide who insisted that the desk belonged to the government and that the military was sent here to protect, not destroy.

title: Many Paths to Finding Peace
description: Maha Rose in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, offers traditional therapies, such as yoga and meditation, but also unconventional ones, like crystal bowl sound baths and tarot card readings.

title: Free Your Mind
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  This offering from Kevin Christian and Brad Wilber rocked me out of my midweek blahs. In my view, its a sassy, bluesy grid that was a lot of fun to solve. This puzzle is the solving equivalent of sipping your third Scotch in a dark blues club after midnight. All you know is that youre having a good time and the band is playing all your favorites.

title: After Playing Down a Homeless Crisis, Mayor de Blasio Changes His Tone
description: In mid-July, facing a swelling public outcry over street homelessness in New York City, Mayor Bill de Blasio suggested that residents eyes were deceiving them. Homelessness is not going up, thank God, he said.

title: Jets Put Jace Amaro on Injured Reserve With Shoulder Injury
description: Jace Amaro was placed on injured reserve with a torn labrum in his shoulder, costing the Jets a receiving threat at one of their weaker positions.

title: Azerbaijan: Journalist Critical of Leader Is Sentenced to 7 1/2 Years in Prison
description: Khadija Ismayilova, an Azerbaijani investigative journalist, was sentenced Tuesday to 7 1/2 years in prison on charges including embezzlement and tax evasion. The sentence was handed down by the Court on Grave Crimes in Baku, the capital. Ms. Ismayilova is a contributor to Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, which is funded by the United States, and is known for reports questioning the sources of wealth of Azerbaijans president, Ilham Aliyev, and his family. During the trial, Ms. Ismayilova, 39, who was arrested in December, said she was innocent and accused the government of lies. Isabel Santos of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europes Parliamentary Assembly, said in a statement that with every journalist, human rights defender and civil society leader it harasses or jails, Azerbaijan distances itself further and further from democratic values.

title: Clashes Over Draft Constitution Kill 5 in Nepal
description: KATHMANDU  Violent protests over a draft of a new constitution broke out Tuesday in Nepals southern plains, the latest strife to imperil the new charter and draw accusations of police brutality from local leaders.

title: Police and Pastors Seek to Curb Violence as Hartfords Homicide Rate Soars
description: HARTFORD  On a sunny Sunday in August, the Salvation Armys small North End congregation held its weekly worship service outside.

title: Obamas Alaska Tour Continues
description: On Tuesday, the president visited a melting glacier in the Kenai Mountains and bought some pastries at an Anchorage cafe.

title: Yankees Betances Escapes Trouble, and Pineda Picks Up 10th Win
description: BOSTON  If many of his teammates had to be indoctrinated into the rich history between the Yankees and Red Sox, Dellin Betances, who grew up in Washington Heights, was steeped in it.

title: New York City Reaches Deal With Bus Drivers Union on Safety Law
description: After clashing repeatedly this year over a new traffic safety law, Mayor Bill de Blasio and the citys major bus drivers union came to a fragile truce this week.

title: For Thousands of Exhausted Migrants, a Journeys End in Munich
description: MUNICH  The journey for more than 2,000 migrants, who overcame border crossings, deprivation and erratic enforcement of European migration policies on a land route through southeastern Europe, ended Tuesday when the trains that had carried them from the Hungarian capital rolled into Munichs vast main station.

title: Mets Sudden Crowd Comes Up Empty
description: The Mets clubhouse resembled a traffic jam on the Grand Central Parkway on Tuesday.

title: Blondell Cummings, Dancer of Lifes Everyday Details, Dies at 70
description: Blondell Cummings, a modern dancer and choreographer who mined quotidian experiences like washing, cooking and building to yield works celebrated for their rich characterizations and dramatic momentum, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 70.

title: Nikolaus Lehnhoff, German Opera Director, Dies at 76
description: Nikolaus Lehnhoff, a German opera director who staged Salome at the Metropolitan Opera in New York and Wagners Ring cycle in San Francisco in the 1980s, but who was best known for his productions in Europe, died on Aug. 22 at his home in Berlin. He was 76.

title: U.S. Stock Markets End Higher Though Global Concerns Linger
description: Stocks in the United States bounced back on Wednesday, a day after another sell-off on the global markets, even as worries about economic growth persisted.

title: Fans, Lights and Andy Murray Beat Nick Kyrgios at U.S. Open
description: It did not take much to set off the volatile Australian Nick Kyrgios on Tuesday night at the U.S. Open. Troubled by the late-arriving fans, the positioning of the lights and the defensive range of Andy Murray, Kyrgios began to unravel. Quickly. It was precisely the sort of entertainment the crowd at Arthur Ashe Stadium was hoping to see.

title: Noah Davis, 32, Artist and Founder of Underground Museum in Los Angeles, Dies
description: Noah Davis, a painter and installation artist who founded the Underground Museum, an exhibition space in a working-class neighborhood of Los Angeles that provides free art shows, died on Saturday at his home in Ojai, Calif. He was 32.

title: Puerto Rico Electric Utility Is Said to Be Near Debt Deal
description: With a deadline approaching Tuesday night, the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority was close to an agreement with a group of bondholders for a restructuring of up to $5.7 billion of debt, according to two people with knowledge of the talks. The terms under consideration included a bond exchange, which would mean a permanent loss for participating bondholders, along with measures to increase the likelihood that the bondholders would be repaid on the new debt, those people said. By improving the utilitys creditworthiness, Prepas borrowing costs would also go down. The total face value of Prepas outstanding debt is about $8.1 billion; of that, about $2.4 billion has been insured. The negotiations cover only the remaining $5.7 billion. Prepa and its bondholders have been in restructuring talks for more than a year, and during that time its creditors agreed not to take any legal action to enforce their claims. The agreement was scheduled to expire at midnight on Tuesday, but people with knowledge of the talks said they expected that a deal would be announced early Wednesday.

title: Whats On TV Wednesday
description: 10 P.M. (TCM) BARRY LYNDON (1975) An Irish rogue (Ryan ONeal, above right, with James Magee) gambles, fights and seduces his way to the apex of 18th-century British society in Stanley Kubricks adaptation of William Makepeace Thackerays first novel. His undoing comes at the hand of a widowed beauty (Marisa Berenson), whose high station gives her license to be boring. This comedy of manners is so long and leisurely, so panoramic in its narrative scope, that its as much an environment as it is a conventional film, Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. Its austerity of purpose defines it as a costume movie unlike any other youve seen. The film is part of a tribute to the Oscar-winning composer Leonard Rosenman, starting at 8 with A Man Called Horse.

title: Questions Raised About Vietnam War Photos
