description: The New York Times film critics review A Walk in the Woods, The Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution and Steve Jobs: The Man in the Machine.

title: Classical Listings for Sept. 4-10
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Theater Listings for Sept. 4-10
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Transmissions at MoMA Explores an Era When Art Upended Tradition
description: A visit to Transmissions: Art in Eastern Europe and Latin America, 1960-1980, a big, spirited group show that opens on Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art, is like walking into a party of extremely personable strangers conversing on subjects you cant quite make out. For every name you recognize, there are 10 you dont. Multiple languages  Czech, Romanian, Slovak, Spanish, Portuguese, as well as English  fill the air. As for topics discussed, art, poetry, film and theater seem to be getting about equal time.

title: Movie Listings for Sept. 4-10
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: The Boy on the Beach
description: Why this boy?

title: Comedy Listings for Sept. 4-10
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Sept. 4-10
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Donald Trump Stumbles and Bristles During Foreign Policy Interview
description: Donald J. Trump revealed gaps in his mastery of international affairs during a radio interview on Thursday, appearing to mistake the Quds Force, an Iranian military group, for the Kurds, a Middle Eastern people, and growing testy over questions about foreign leaders.

title: Dance Listings for Sept. 4-10
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Opus Hypnagogia
description: Art that is born of the state between sleep and wakefulness at the Morbid Anatomy Museum, Brooklyn

title: Review: The Morbid Anatomy Museum Presents a View From the Subconscious
description: Hypnagogia is an unfamiliar word for a common mental experience. Coined in the 19th century, it refers to the transition period between wakefulness and sleep, when, while still conscious, you might find yourself seeing images, having thoughts or hearing things that make little logical sense. This is the gateway to lucid dreaming and, possibly, astral traveling and divine revelation.

title: Sensational Murder Case in India Stirs Media Frenzy Fed by Police Leaks
description: NEW DELHI  In the middle of last week, with the arrest of the former media executive Indrani Mukerjea on suspicion of involvement in her daughters death, Indias crime reporters embarked on their latest bender.

title: To Pledge or Not to Pledge?
description: On Thursday, Donald Trump signed a pledge to support the eventual Republican presidential nominee, weeks after saying he wouldnt. Not everyone agreed with his change of heart.

title: Drawing a Bead
description: Sue Grafton ignored her own rule when she chose an abbreviated title for the 24th of her popular alphabet mysteries. Unlike the other books in this series, which began in 1982 with A Is for Alibi, X (Putnam, $28.95) is the big cheese that stands alone. Having made that radical change to her reliable formula, perhaps shell make an even bolder move and just keep writing when she reaches the end of the alphabet.

title: Facebook Takes a Step Into Education Software
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebook, which transformed communication with its social networking service, now wants to make a similar impact on education.

title: Candidates Respond to Kim Davis Case With Varying Intensity
description: The fast-developing story of Kim Davis, the Kentucky county clerk ordered to jail on Thursday for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, continued to divide the Republican presidential field.

title: In Syrias Struggle, Memories of the Soviet Union
description: Sergey Ponomarevs trips to Syria reminded him of his native Soviet Union: from the government security forces that kept track of his movements to destroyed areas that looked like the Battle of Stalingrad.

title: Palestinian Expects Flag Will Fly at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS  The Palestinian ambassador to the United Nations said Thursday that he expected to raise the Palestinian flag at the gates of United Nations headquarters in time for the annual meeting of world leaders here at the end of the month.

title: The Truth of Black Lives Matter
description: The Republican Party and its acolytes in the news media are trying to demonize the protest movement that has sprung up in response to the all-too-common police killings of unarmed African-Americans across the country. The intent of the campaign  evident in comments by politicians like Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky  is to cast the phrase Black Lives Matter as an inflammatory or even hateful anti-white expression that has no legitimate place in a civil rights campaign.

title: One Worker Dies and 2 Are Injured in Wall Collapse at Brooklyn Construction Site
description: One worker was killed and two others were seriously injured when a wall collapsed on them at a construction site in Brooklyn on Thursday, officials said.

title: Endre A. Balazs, Doctor Who Found a Lubricant for Arthritic Knees, Dies at 95
description: Dr. Endre A. Balazs, who transformed a syrupy natural lubricant derived from rooster combs into a palliative for arthritic knees and a skin protectant that made eye surgery routine, died on Aug. 29 at a hospital near his summer home in St. Tropez, France. He was 95.

title: The Hague: Warlord Offers a Defense
description: The Congolese militia leader Bosco Ntaganda, whose trial on war crimes charges opened on Wednesday at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, told his judges on Thursday that I am not a criminal but a trained officer who always protected civilians. Mr. Ntaganda was allowed to address the court briefly after teams of prosecution and defense lawyers had each delivered their opening presentations on the charges he faces related to attacks in 2002 and 2003 in which villagers in Ituri, a Congolese mining area, were killed or raped. Mr. Ntaganda, 41, who was born in Rwanda, said he had joined the Tutsi forces in Rwanda that put an end to that countrys genocide in 1994, then later moved across the border to Ituri. The word had gone out to kill all the Tutsis in Ituri, or those who looked like them, he said. His role was to protect civilians, he said in court. I ask you to make a distinction between a revolutionary rebel and a criminal. Earlier, the prosecutor had called him a notorious and powerful fighter who enriched himself and used children as his foot soldiers and henchmen and as sexual slaves for his troops. The trial will resume on Sept. 15.

title: Philip Falcone, Former Head of Vast Fund, Tries a 3rd Act
description: Philip A. Falcone, the brash hedge fund titan who once managed $26 billion before stumbling and running afoul of regulators, is pressing ahead on a new comeback effort, his second.

title: 3 Corrections Deputies in California Charged With Murder in Death of Mentally Ill Inmate
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  In a rare step, the sheriff of Santa Clara County on Thursday arrested and filed murder charges against three corrections deputies who work for her, after the discovery last week that a mentally ill inmate had bled to death in his cell as a result of a blunt force trauma, according to the local coroners office.

title: Friendship Between Putin and Xi Becomes Strained as Economies Falter
description: BEIJING  They have met more than a dozen times and stood shoulder to shoulder during Thursdays military parade here. But the once-vaunted relationship between the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, and Russias leader, Vladimir V. Putin, has come under strain as the economies of their countries have faltered.

title: A Terrifying Matchup Even Before It Materializes
description: How intimidating is it to stand on a court across from Serena Williams, one of the greatest tennis players in history?

title: Indian Automaker Tata Aims to Restore Jaguars Cachet in U.S.
description: DETROIT  When Tata Motors of India acquired the Jaguar and Land Rover brands in 2008, the deal added a new twist to the rapid globalization of the auto industry.

title: Health Care Rules Proposed to Shield Transgender Patients From Bias
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration proposed a rule Thursday that would forbid most health insurers and medical providers to discriminate against transgender patients, including by prohibiting insurers from categorically denying coverage of care related to gender transition.

title: Guard for Donald Trump Hits Protester
description: In a tussle outside Trump Tower on Thursday, a member of Donald J. Trumps security team responded to a protester, who had grabbed him from behind, by hitting him in the face.

title: Liberia: Ebola-Free, for a Second Time
description: The World Health Organization declared Liberia free of Ebola for a second time on Thursday, several months after it was first thought to have halted the virus in May, only to experience a brief resurgence of cases that puzzled epidemiologists. Today the World Health Organization declares Liberia free of Ebola virus transmission in the human population, said Dr. Alex Gasasira, the organizations representative in Liberia. But the Ministry of Health called for 90 days of heightened surveillance around the country to watch for any new cases. Dr. Gasasira applauded the government and Liberian communities for their quick response to the May outbreak, which left two people dead. The government has urged all Liberians to continue observing preventive measures like washing hands and is strengthening its monitoring efforts across the country, said Dr. Francis Ketteh, Liberias chief medical officer. More than 4,800 people have died in Liberia because of the Ebola crisis, according to the World Health Organization.

title: Judge Who Jailed Kentucky Clerk Is No Stranger to Controversy
description: Long before he ordered a county clerk to jail on Thursday for refusing to issue same-sex marriage licenses, David L. Bunning first drew attention as a federal judge for a ruling on gay rights.

title: For His Arrogance in Tom Brady Ruling, Roger Goodell Pays the Price
description: Ah, Roger, being king isnt what it used to be.

title: A Back-to-School List With Cameras, Bulletproof Walls and More Deadbolts
description: In his Cold War childhood, Bill Ferguson and his schoolmates at St. Elizabeths in Ozone Park, Queens, drilled for air raids that never came. You hid under the desk, or went to certain places in the building, laid down and covered your eyes, he said.

title: Something to Slow-Dance To
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  When we last saw David C. Duncan Dekker (a name that is incredibly fun to say out loud, unless a tour of the New York Times building is passing by your desk, in which case its best not to do that, not that I would know), he was doing some mighty heavy lifting, construction-wise, in a pangrammatic Saturday puzzle from March of this year.

title: At 41, Jason Gore Brings a Different Look, and Sensibility, to the FedEx Cup Playoffs
description: NORTON, Mass.  At the Plainfield Country Club in New Jersey, Jason Gore outdrove his playing competitor, Dustin Johnson, by 13 yards on the second hole, a 445-yard par 4. Gore, who is four inches shorter than Johnson and easily 50 pounds heavier, flexed his right biceps. Gores gesture last week during the third round of the Barclays, the first event of the FedEx Cup playoffs, elicited laughter from Johnson, who is built like a 6-foot-4 small forward to Gores 250-pound beer league shortstop.

title: Veterinary Student Expelled Over a Pet Loses a Court Fight With Cornell
description: In the eyes of his human companion, Shandor was a playful puppy and Alpha Male of the household, court papers said, known to all to protect his caretaker and be at ease among strangers.

title: Hotel That Inspired The Shining Builds on Its Eerie Appeal
description: ESTES PARK, Colo.  When a young Stephen King checked into the Stanley  Hotel here in 1974, he had a nightmare that inspired him to write The Shining, the novel that went on to become Stanley Kubricks 1980 cult classic film.

title: Shooting at Sacramento City College Leaves One Dead and 2 Injured
description: A shooting on the grounds of Sacramento City College left one person dead, two others injured and the campus on lockdown Thursday night, the Sacramento Police Department said.

title: Leon A. Gorman, Who Made L.L. Bean a Household Name, Dies at 80
description: Leon A. Gorman, who transformed L. L. Bean from his grandfathers folksy store and catalog business into a billion-dollar global outdoor-gear retailer and made its signature rubber-soled hunting boot as synonymous with Maine as lobster, died on Thursday at his home in Yarmouth, Me. He was 80.

title: Illinois: Chicago Mayor Weighs Major Property Tax Increase
description: Chicagoans may face a significant tax increase next year as the city, the nations third largest, is required to start making larger payments to some of its underfunded pension funds. Mayor Rahm Emanuel, who is expected to issue details of his budget plan for 2016 later this month, acknowledged to reporters on Thursday that he was weighing a property tax increase, which has long been expected here. Its going to be fair and progressive, he said. The Chicago Sun-Times reported that the mayor was poised to raise property taxes by $500 million. He would need approval from Chicagos City Council.

title: Smokeless Tobacco Use Found Higher Among Student-Athletes
description: Very active high school athletes use chewing tobacco and other smokeless tobacco products at higher rates than students who do not participate in sports, but they smoke less, according to a report issued Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In 2013, about 6 percent of students who did not play sports used smokeless tobacco, compared with 12.5 percent of students on three or more sports teams. In contrast, 21 percent of students who did not play sports smoked cigarettes, compared with 15.8 percent of students on three sports teams.

title: Jets Finally See Tebow Throw Touchdown Pass, but Its for Eagles
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Philadelphia Eagles are expected to put up a lot of points this season, so when their third-team offense scored against the Jets second-team defense just before halftime Thursday night, it should not have stunned many on either sideline.

title: Egypt: American Soldiers Are Wounded
description: Six international peacekeepers stationed in Egypt, including four American soldiers, were wounded by two improvised explosive devices on Thursday, according to the Defense Department. The peacekeepers were part of the Multinational Force and Observers, a mission stationed in Egypts restive Sinai Peninsula to support the 1979 peace treaty between Egypt and Israel. The six wounded soldiers were airlifted to a medical facility where they were being treated for injuries that were not life-threatening. The safety and security of U.S. forces remains our top priority, and we are committed to taking necessary steps for their protection, said Jeff Davis, a Navy captain who is the director of press operations for the Defense Department, which provided no further information on the soldiers injuries or what had happened.

title: Aylan Kurdis Death Resonates in Canadian Election Campaign
description: OTTAWA  While the photograph of a 3-year-old Syrian boys body quickly focused the worlds attention on the migrant crisis in the Middle East and Africa, it has taken on a particular resonance in Canada with the discovery that the boys family had been unable to obtain immigration visas.

title: Giants Game No Match for News Off the Field
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The Giants and the New England Patriots completed regular-season preparations on Thursday night with a preseason finale at Gillette Stadium that was insignificant compared with off-field news.

title: California Lawmaker Is Focus of House Ethics Panel Inquiry
description: The House Ethics Committee is investigating allegations that Representative Mike Honda, Democrat of California, may have improperly used his government office staff to help his re-election efforts over the last four years, the committee confirmed Thursday, as it released a preliminary report on the inquiry. The initial review, conducted by the Office of Congressional Ethics, found that his staff appeared to have researched a potential campaign opponent, prepared materials for the campaign, used information from the congressional office for campaign purposes and discussed campaign matters during official meetings, in the lawmakers district office and at a staff retreat. Mr. Honda has denied that he formally broke the rules, but his aides have conceded that he could have done a better job separating political and government business. The Ethics Committee said it would continue to investigate the matter, but it put no deadline on its inquiry.

title: Colorado: Pro-Marijuana Activists Pull Back on Ballot Measure
description: Pro-marijuana activists campaigning to allow the drug to be used legally in adults-only businesses like nightclubs or bars said on Thursday they were withdrawing a ballot measure that would have put the issue before voters in Denver in November. Activists said they were pulling the initiative because they believed they could reach a compromise with city officials and business groups that would result in local legislation to allow some limited social use of marijuana in Denver. When Colorado voters in 2012 became the first in the nation, along with Washington State, to legalize marijuana for recreational use, they did so with a caveat: No public use. But advocates said the restrictions on public use were too strict and had prohibited marijuana everywhere except private homes and a handful of marijuana-friendly bed-and-breakfasts scattered around the state. The ballot proposal would have allowed people to eat edible marijuana or inhale vaporized forms of marijuana indoors, but would have relegated smoking to outdoor areas blocked from public view. Organizers said that it was still too early to know what might be included in a compromise ordinance, and that if the effort stalled, they might reintroduce the ballot measure next year.

title: Suspect and Witness Are Sought in Fatal Brooklyn Fight
description: The two men stood outside the restaurant and bar in Bushwick, Brooklyn, last month, arguing. Then the disagreement escalated into a physical fight, leaving the police to find one of them on the sidewalk critically injured.

title: Drone Crashes Into Seats at Armstrong
description: An unauthorized drone crashed into a section of empty seats at Louis Armstrong Stadium about 8:30 p.m. Thursday during a second-round match between Flavia Pennetta and Monica Niculescu, causing a brief delay and some fear and confusion.

title: Dr. J. Donald Millar, 81, Dies; Led C.D.C. Mission That Helped Eradicate Smallpox
description: Dr. J. Donald Millar, a physician and former public-health official whose work helped eradicate smallpox in Africa and with it, the world, died on Sunday at his home in Murrayville, Ga. He was 81.

title: Plane Crashes in New Jersey, Injuring 2 Pilots
description: A Coast Guard plane crashed in a field in northern New Jersey on Thursday afternoon, seriously injuring the pilot and co-pilot, officials said.

title: A Defeat. Retirement. Then a Win. All in a Day.
description: The last point of Lisa Raymonds career seemed as if it might go on forever. The ball went back and forth over the net on Court 6, allowing Raymond numerous chances to hit a final forehand, a last backhand or a farewell volley.

title: ESPN Extends Curt Schillings Ban
description: ESPN suspended Curt Schilling, one of its Sunday Night Baseball analysts, for the rest of the regular season and the postseason wild-card playoff game  extending punishment that had already been imposed for sharing a Twitter meme last month about extremist Muslims and Nazis. Schilling was suspended from one Little League World Series game and last Sundays prime-time Major League Baseball game.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | wispy
description: wispy  \wis-pe\  adjective

title: Transition in Guatemala
description: In a Guatemala City courtroom on Thursday, former President Otto Prez Molina said he intends to face up to allegations. Meanwhile, his vice president, Alejandro Maldonado, was sworn in.

title: Lleyton Hewitt Exits Final Open Showing the Tenacity That Defined His Career
description: It looked at first like a pure mercy killing. In what he has called his final United States Open, in the last working year of the intimate setting known as the Grandstand, Lleyton Hewitt was absorbing a routine beating at the hands of Bernard Tomic, his 22-year-old countryman.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) AMERICAN MASTERS: ALTHEA Arthur Ashe may have been the first African-American man to win Wimbledon, in 1975. But Althea Gibson (1927-2003), above, broke the color barrier nearly two decades earlier, in 1957, becoming the first African-American woman to win that tournament as well as the United States Nationals (the precursor of the United States Open). This documentary from Rex Miller traces the life of Ms. Gibson, the daughter of a South Carolina sharecropper who as a young child moved with her family to Harlem, where she progressed from paddle tennis on the streets to tennis at the Cosmopolitan Club and on to Florida A&M with the help of the bandleader Buddy Walker, the boxer Sugar Ray Robinson and two African-American doctors, Hubert Eaton and Robert W. Johnson. In the 1950s, she emerged as the queen of a sport that was still highly segregated and went on to win 11 Grand Slam titles, including six in doubles. The Wimbledon champions Billie Jean King (an executive producer of the film) and Dick Savitt; Jeanne Moutoussamy-Ashe, Mr. Ashes widow; and Angela Buxton, Ms. Gibsons doubles partner, among others, offer perspective.

title: ATP Weighs Clearer Discipline for Players Comments
description: Sergiy Stakhovsky, who plays his third-round match Friday at the United States Open against Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, has spent a week in restrained silence  or as close as Stakhovsky can get to silence.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Now I dont want anything. Even if you give me all the countries in the world, I dont want them. What was precious is gone.

title: Corrections: September 4, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: In Syrias Struggle, Memories of the Soviet Union
description: PERPIGNAN, France  Sergey Ponomarevs first visit to Syria in 2009  as a tourist  triggered memories of his childhood in the Soviet Union: such as when government security officers questioned him and his girlfriend when they bought tickets at bus stations in Damascus.

title: After Beijings Military Parade, Blue Skies Yield to Gray
description: Just hours after Chinas Victory Day extravaganza on Thursday, when splendid blue skies framed a parade of thousands of troops marching through central Beijing to celebrate the end of World War II, the citys air was filling again with dirt. An independent air-quality monitoring site showed pollution levels rising sharply from midnight.

title: Cheeseburger, Hold the Salmonella
description: Americans eat more than 50 pounds of beef per person each year. Thats a lot of beef. Its also a lot of risk, because about half  or more than two billion pounds  is ground beef, which can too easily harbor dangerous bacteria. There is always an uproar after serious outbreaks of illness like the Jack in the Box case in 1993, when 700 people were sickened and four children died after eating tainted hamburgers. But as a new report points out, there is more the Department of Agriculture and the Food and Drug Administration can do to keep Americans safe and some simple things consumers could do themselves.

title: Refugee Crisis in Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: G.E., Finish the Job on the Hudson
description: Hudson River update, September 2015: The river is still contaminated and its still General Electrics fault. Toxic industrial waste is still flowing down nearly 200 miles of river from north of Albany to New York City. And though the company has spent the last six years digging up the PCBs that it dumped into the river decades ago, it is about to walk away from an unfinished job. It is getting ready to dismantle its dredging operation this fall, and leave 136 undredged acres for others to worry about.

title: Doctor-Patient Talks About Sex
description: To the Editor:

title: Does Down Syndrome Justify Abortion?
description: Villanova, Pa.  IT was the most heart-wrenching moment of our lives, and all I could do was stare at the tissue box.

title: Ronald Reagan, Heretic
description: In just under two weeks, the Republicans who want to be president will gather in Simi Valley, Calif., at the presidential library of Ronald Reagan for their second debate. You can expect much brown-nosing, bloviating and outright fabricating in homage to the patron saint of all true conservatives, the charming 40th president.

title: Disband the Benghazi Committee
description: Washington  NOT long after it was formed last year, members of the Select Committee on Benghazi gathered to meet privately with family members of the four Americans killed on that dreadful night in Libya in 2012. The meetings were emotional, and the chairman assured those present that the committee would be scrupulously nonpartisan and devoted to finding out the truth of what had happened.

title: The New Romantics in the Computer Age
description: Just once Id like to have a college student come up to me and say, I really wanted to major in accounting, but my parents forced me to major in medieval art. That probably wont happen. It always seems to be the parents who are pushing their children in the practical or mercenary direction.

title: Other Peoples Dollars, and Their Place in Global Economics
description: Sydney, Australia  Soon after arriving here, I stopped at an A.T.M.; I needed some dollars, and all I had were dollars.

title: History Purged or Exposed?
description: To the Editor:

title: For Teens in Crisis, the Next Text Could Be a Lifesaver
description: The message to the Crisis Text Line was answered by Aaron Amrich, a volunteer crisis counselor based in California. It was sent by a 19-year-old woman who wrote that she was feeling hopeless and beginning to give up on life. Amrich, a veteran who served in Afghanistan and Iraq, has himself suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder and depression. He understood the feeling.

title: News Qs | Backpack Makers Rethink a Student Staple
description: In Backpack Makers Rethink a Student Staple, Hiroko Tabuchi reports on how the backpack is being redesigned for electronics and the needs of living on the go.

title: Online Gambling Firm Bwin.Party Favors GVC Holdings Bid
description: LONDON  The battle for Bwin.Party Digital Entertainment took another turn on Friday as the online gambling company said its board of directors would now recommend that shareholders approve an offer from its rival GVC Holdings over a previously agreed-to deal with 888 Holdings.

title: How the Co-op Crumbles
description: For three decades, Todd Selbert has lived in a sunny one-bedroom on the Upper East Side, surrounded by books, his vast jazz record collection and several abstract oil paintings. A former advertising executive, Mr. Selbert, 75, owns the top floor of a four-story co-op at 150 East 78th Street.

title: Exploring Havasu Falls
description: Havasu Falls are at the bottom of a narrow gorge near the southwest corner of the Grand Canyon National Park.

title: Boise State Faces the Coach Who Helped It Grow
description: BOISE, Idaho  The words blue collar are painted in large block letters along one wall of Boise States football weight room. This would seem to be a perfectly appropriate ethos for Boise States football program, given that its identity is so closely tied to blue  the color of the Broncos quirky playing surface.

title: What We Learned From Summer Love
description: We know love blooms in New York City in the summer; after all, we live here. But as the Metro staff of The New York Times traveled the five boroughs for our Summer Love series, we got some surprises.

title: Remarrying the Ex: Ilze Thielmann and Aitken Thompson Try Again
description: During Aitken Thompson and Ilze Thielmanns many years together, they have been through all kinds of relationship stages and permutations: platonic best friends; girlfriend and boyfriend; ex-girlfriend and ex-boyfriend sharing an apartment; husband and wife; divorced; friendly, sometimes flirtatious, co-parents; and exes who go on a date together.

title: Within the Grand Canyon, the Lure of Havasu Falls
description: One has only to lay eyes on a picture of the incandescent pools of Havasu Falls, somewhere between beryl and cerulean, to feel its pull. The vibrant basins of the rippling natural pool are a study in contrast with the stunning force of the waterfall that crashes into them, spilling 90 feet over red rocks. It is, simply, beatific. And the falls, at the bottom of a narrow gorge near the southwest corner of the Grand Canyon National Park, are about a two-mile hike north of Supai Village in one of the most remote indigenous-American enclaves in the country.

title: Rihm to Replace Boulez as Lucerne Academy Director
description: The German composer Wolfgang Rihm will succeed Pierre Boulez next summer as the artistic director of the Lucerne Festival Academy, which trains young musicians, composers and directors in music of the 20th and 21st centuries, the festival announced on Friday.

title: Conducting a Field Test on Pheromones
description: In a room full of strangers, who are you drawn to? I enjoy rueful laughter, and thus, in any given setting, will gravitate toward a man who looks like Jeff Goldblum or a woman with a throaty Sambuca rasp.

title: Learning to Live With Vitiligo
description: Everyone has a sort of avatar, a mental image of an ideal self that sits in the corner of your consciousness, sneering or smiling, as you surf the day. You, walking the city streets. You, skulking out of the movies. You, riding the mechanical bull at Gilleys.

title: Billy Eichner, Off the Street and Into the Museum of Sex
description: This is like a terrible Sex and the City episode, said the comedian Billy Eichner, standing in the lobby of the Museum of Sex on a recent afternoon while peering at pleasure devices both manual and electric, metal and plastic, large and small, contoured and classically cylindrical.

title: Exodus of Syrians Highlights Political Failure of the West
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Arresting images of desperation on the Wests doorstep have brought Syria, for the moment, back to worldwide attention: refugees cramming into train stations and climbing border fences; drowned Syrian toddlers washing up on beaches, a girl in polka dots, a boy in tiny shoes.

title: What Heroic Acts Have You Performed or Witnessed?
description: Last month, the account of three men subduing a gunman on a Paris-bound train made headlines around the world.

title: Star Wars Fans Flock to Midnight Store Openings for New Toys
description: Unlike the typical costumed characters in Times Square, these Stormtroopers did not ask for money.

title: Yoda, as a Toy
description: Hundreds of toys are hitting the market in a huge marketing push for the coming Star Wars movie. This interactive Yoda doll from Spin Master ($180) says it will teach children to be a Jedi.

title: Chinese Company to Buy Avolon in $7.6 Billion Deal
description: HONG KONG  Bohai Leasing of China plans to buy the Irish aircraft leasing firm Avolon in a deal with worth $7.6 billion, the companies said.

title: Jobs Report Gives Ammunition to Both Sides of Fed Rate Debate
description: Despite disappointing job growth last month, the unemployment rate fell to its lowest level since early 2008, sharpening the debate within the Federal Reserve over whether to raise interest rates when policy makers meet in two weeks.

title: Migrants Cross Austria Border From Hungary
description: NICKELSDORF, Austria  Thousands of migrants who have been bottled up in Hungary, demanding passage to the West, will be allowed into Austria and Germany, the Austrian chancellor said late Friday. Early Saturday, the first buses carrying them arrived at the Hungary-Austria border.

title: Bayer to List Polymer Business Covestro in 4th Quarter I.P.O.
description: LONDON  The German drug maker Bayer said on Friday that it planned to list its newly spun-off polymer business, Covestro, in an initial public offering in Germany this year.

description: Our morning travel news digest, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

description: Stephen A. Schwarzman ought to be a satisfied man.

description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of preparations for the Popes arrival, the Pepsi-Cola sign in Long Island City, and more summer love.

description: Updated 9:37 a.m.

title: Teenagers in The Times | August 2015
description: We present the August edition of Teens in The Times, a monthly feature that rounds up recent articles about young people that have appeared in The Times.

title: London Theater Journal: A Scorching Momma Rose
description: LONDON  The small, determined woman who is sharing her obsessions so enthrallingly from the stage of the Savoy Theater here is unmistakably a product of the United States. Shes as American as apple pie  or perhaps the homemade blueberry kind she says shes so tired of; as American as the Great Depression, marathon dancing and another desperate soul who took his countrys myth of success too much to heart, Willy Loman from Death of a Salesman.

title: Germany and Sweden Are Said to Help Make Afghan Kill Decisions
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two European allies of the United States have been directly participating in so-called kill decisions against insurgents in Afghanistan despite rules prohibiting them from doing so, according to two senior Western officials with knowledge of the operations.

title: Exploring Runmaro and Other Swedish Islands
description: Runmaro is one hour away from Stockholm but accessible only by boat.

title: The Moon
description: This poem, translated from the original Spanish, unfolds as a litany of the many ways the moon has been described. One long, complex sentence links all the previous iterations, while a second, much shorter sentence isolates the image of yet another moon. The prose-poem form seems to contain the patch of night sky from which that new apprehension  the moon reflected in the vision of a solitary witness, the poems speaker  arrives.

title: The 8.16.15 Issue
description: RE: CREATIVE CLASS

title: Tianjin Homeowners Demand Compensation
description: Video provided by Yuan Ping, a protester, shows a demonstration by Tianjin homeowners on Aug. 27 demanding that the government buy their apartments, which were damaged in the explosions.

title: How to Fight Fires From a Plane
description: Your job is to slow the fire down and buy time for the firefighters on the ground, says John Gallaher, a pilot who travels the country dropping fire retardant from the air. Every morning, check out of your hotel, and be prepared to check into another one thousands of miles away at days end. Always keep your packed bags loaded in the plane.

title: Today in Politics: Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton Have an Island All to Themselves
description: Good Friday morning. Donald J. Trump had a big day on Thursday, but on Friday, other candidates, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Hillary Rodham Clinton, will find themselves in Puerto Rico at the same time. And Mr. Rubio is wasting little time previewing his idea of what the general election might look like.

title: The Intruder
description: My friend Pierre recently bought a house in Popenguine, a small seaside town in Senegal. Determined to mold the house into more of his dream and less of its previous owners, he has gutted and remodeled its interior, broken up the pavement outside, replaced the wiring (after he was electrocuted in the shower) and even uprooted and transplanted full-grown trees.

title: Morning Agenda: Markets Slide Ahead of U.S. Jobs Report
description: MARKETS SLIDE AHEAD OF U.S. JOBS REPORT | Markets were cautious on Friday ahead of the latest United States labor market report, Reuters reports. Asian markets extended their losses on Friday morning, with the Nikkei 225 closing down 2.15 percent. Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday. European stocks were also down in early trading.

title: How Economists Can Be Just as Irrational as the Rest of Us
description: Retailers know that the items they place at eye level of store shelves will sell faster than those that are down low. The top headline on a news website will usually be clicked more often than the ones down lower. So maybe it shouldnt be surprising that the same logic applies to economics research, with long-lasting implications for what ideas are propagated.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Fanny Packs
description: My maternal grandmother, Helen, was a fashion icon of her own making. The daughter of a master tailor, she became an eager seamstress herself. Once, as a teenager, sneaking into her fathers sewing room to whip together a fancy dress, she was so overcome with enthusiasm that she ran a needle straight through her finger. In later years, she abandoned dresses for velour track suits, which made her look like an early-80s M.C., except she covered hers with every single item in stock from Michaels Arts & Crafts  floral appliqu, rhinestones, puffy paint, embroidery, ribbons, sequins, confetti, Proudest Grandma patches. If she could have decorated her clothes with fresh fruit, I think she would have.

title: The Fight to Save a Prairie Chicken
description: EAGLE LAKE, Tex.  Every spring during mating season, the few dozen remaining male Attwaters prairie chickens gather to perform an elaborate courtship ritual.

title: On Stockholms Islands, Chasing Insects and Literary Inspiration
description: I came to Runmaro to meet a peculiar entomologist with a gift for digression, and to try to understand the secret life of the Baltic island he has lived on for nearly 30 years  a place just one hour away from Stockholm but accessible only by boat, whose complicated natural and literary history is encoded in a landscape of deceptively simple beauty.

title: Weeks After Tianjin Blasts, Many Residents Await Compensation for Damaged Homes
description: The chemical blasts that rocked the northeastern port city of Tianjin last month damaged an estimated 17,000 homes, shattering windows, overturning furniture and knocking down walls. But more than three weeks after the explosions, many Tianjin residents have yet to receive compensation for their losses, and some say they have been pressured into dropping their claims.

title: New Widows Have Another Concern: Their Finances
description: SINCE her husband died in November 2013, Janice M. Eiler, 58, has been juggling a life without his income as well as his companionship, even as she struggles to save enough money so she can retire comfortably in a decade.

title: Finding a Soulmate, Twice

description: MOREHEAD, Ky.  Gay and lesbian couples waded through a throng of protesters and journalists Friday and emerged from the courthouse here as the first in Rowan County to be issued licenses for marriage between people of the same sex.

title: The English Countrysides New Breed of Bucolic Retreats
description: Gone are the days when Downtonesque grandeur was the only option for a stay in the English countryside. A surprisingly diverse new breed of bucolic retreats  from upscale woodcutters cabins to remodeled pig shelters  are reinventing down-on-the-farm hospitality.

description: The owners of Stone and Sawyer share a home in the Catskills.

title: A Colonial-Style Home in the Catskills, Built to Look Old

title: Arcade Fire Seeks More Than a Rockumentary With The Reflektor Tapes
description: No matter how much I love a band, Win Butler said, I still find concert films a little boring.

title: Friends at Work? Not So Much
description: ONCE, work was a major source of friendships. We took our families to company picnics and invited our colleagues over for dinner. Now, work is a more transactional place. We go to the office to be efficient, not to form bonds. We have plenty of productive conversations but fewer meaningful relationships.

description: Givenchy says: Come on down!
