description: With a warm approach to Modernist ideals, the duo behind Apparatus studio seem to have one bright idea after another.

title: 1915: Maker of Tape Machine Dies
description: LONDON  In newspaper offices, in clubs and in large hotels, is kept a little wizard under a glass case, and it is called a tape machine. All night through it sings a metallic song about things that have happened at the ends of the earth  and in the street round the corner. To people without the mechanical faculty this machine is a perpetual wonder, for the wheels that seem to hesitate and change their mind about a letter appear to hide a divinity. But the only divinity is that of the operator at the central office, where all news is gathered and tapped out. The man who perfected this instrument, Mr. Frederick W.H. Higgins, has died at his house at Stamford Hill, London.  The New York Herald, European Edition, September 5, 1915

title: Inside the Inspired Home of Two Brooklyn Lighting Designers
description: With a warm approach to Modernist ideals, the duo behind Apparatus studio seem to have one bright idea after another.

title: A Positive Jobs Report Keeps the Fed in a Tricky Spot
description: The latest numbers on the job market, which the government released Friday morning, are good pretty much all around. But that is not really a surprise; the jobs numbers have been consistently good for at least the last year.

title: Desire Adapts Tennessee Williamss Stories Into Short Plays
description: We are all familiar with Tennessee Williams the dramatist, among the foremost playwrights America has produced. But like his idol, Anton Chekhov, Williams was also a prolific producer of short fiction. His Collected Stories runs more than 500 pages and spans nearly half a century of work, from 1928 to 1977.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Penny Arcade
description: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from Penny Arcade  the writer, actress and performance artist, whose works, including Bad Reputation, have come to be seen as landmarks of New Yorks avant-garde  who shares her picks exclusively with T.

title: Fannie Mae Revamps Mortgage Program
description: Fannie Mae is overhauling its mortgage program for low- to moderate-income households to better accommodate todays financial and familial realities.

title: Fondly, Collette Richland Emerges From Collaboration of Wacky and Weird
description: When the playwright Sibyl Kempson brought a very rough draft of a new script, Fondly, Collette Richland, to the theater company Elevator Repair Service, it didnt look much like a play.

title: With a Revamped Apple TV, Company Hopes to Camp in Your Home
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple is finally getting serious about pushing into our living rooms.

title: After Being Fired Upon, Officers Shoot Man in Brooklyn
description: The police shot a man in the leg in Brooklyn early on Friday after he opened fire on another man and then on the officers, striking an unmarked patrol car, the authorities said.

title: Kevin Spacey and Cal Ripken Jr. to Team Up for Fund-Raising Gala
description: SO far, the closest encounter that Kevin Spacey has had with the Baltimore Orioles was during the second season of the Netflix series House of Cards, when his character, Frank Underwood, worried about throwing out the first pitch at an Orioles game. Mr. Underwood, the vice president of the United States, feared embarrassing himself in front of tens of thousands of fans.

title: Migrants Face Police in Hungary
description: Hundreds of migrants on a train headed to an area near the Austrian border were stranded in Bicske, Hungary, in a standoff with the police.

title: A Layout Experiment for the U.S. Open Preview
description: For this years United States Open preview section, The Timess print designers suggested using a gatefold layout, traditionally used for advertisements. Editors from the Sports desk took the idea and ran with it. Here is a look at how it all came together.

title: A Surreptitious Courtroom Video Prompts Changes in a Georgia Town
description: An explosion of cellphone videos has brought renewed attention to police practices, provoking criticism, indictments and talk of criminal justice overhaul. Courtroom videos of judges in action, however, are far rarer.

title: Apple Kuchen for a Sweet Jewish New Year
description: Aunt Edith was the best cook I knew when I was a boy. Everything that came from her kitchen was sensational. Dinner at her house was unlike other dining, better than most restaurants. The food was so intoxicatingly delicious, and so abundant, I always ate and ate like there was no tomorrow. And oh, my, could this lady bake.

title: A Critics Guide to New York Citys Best Climbing Trees
description: A few ideas on where to hang out during the waning days of summer.

title: Ann Beatties The State Were In
description: Ann Beatties first collection of new short stories in a decade is mostly set in the state Im in. This means I read The State Were In: Maine Stories with the kind of suspicious diligence one uses in scouring a dog for ticks: looking for regional missteps, out-of-tune phrasings, any sign she had committed the special literary felony of getting Maine wrong. That she had committed the kind of sins summer people  one of which Beattie, who divides her time between Key West and Maine, has long been  might be prone to commit. You know, throwing out the Cabot Cove ayuhs while the curtains at the cottage windows billow in the shore breeze and the colorful lobster buoys bob in the harbor.

title: Prose on Poetry
description: THE OCEAN, THE BIRD, AND THE SCHOLAREssays on Poets and PoetryBy Helen Vendler444 pp. Harvard University, $35.

title: Inside the Walls
description: We should not be tolerating overcrowding in prison, President Obama said in July. Against the backdrop of a growing national debate about incarceration rates in America, Phaidon is republishing Danny Lyons Conversations With the Dead, a book of photographs taken inside six Texas prisons in the late 1960s.

title: A Clue to the Exit, by Edward St. Aubyn
description: Those of us who are dying, Charlie Fairburn writes toward the end of this sparkling and morbid confession of a novel, as opposed to those who are lounging around in their studies making dinner engagements, and then reluctantly disconnecting the phone for 20 minutes in order to browse through a medieval textbook and look up some realistic details  those of us who are really dying havent got time to ponder the past. The present is scintillating with horror and precision.

title: The Wake, by Paul Kingsnorth
description: What happens after the end? Since the portrayals of world-destroying deluges in early writings (Gilgamesh, the Matsya Purana, Genesis, the Timaeus), narratives of apocalypse have structured our understanding of time and history. Religious eschatology looks to the end of days as a prelude to the absolute finality of the kingdom of God. Secularized as the Singularity, a similar idea drives the imagination of Silicon Valley entrepreneurs and cybernetic doomsayers, who believe we are approaching a technological punctum beyond which humanity as we know it will no longer exist. In the face of economic crisis and anxiety about climate change, postapocalyptic science fiction, long a genre staple, is undergoing one of its cyclical peaks of popularity. Our screens and pages are crowded with survivors, grimly coping with the aftermath of plagues, wars, natural disasters, zombie attacks and alien invasions.

title: The Making of Asian America, by Erika Lee
description: Early in Erika lees sweeping The Making of Asian America: A History she suggests that Asian-Americans constantly cycle between being labeled good Asians versus bad Asians, depending on the shifting and often contradictory politics behind their immigration and settlement. We were a despised minority when Asian immigrants threatened 19th- and early-20th-century white labor, yet since the Cold War weve been described as a model minority, valorizing the promise of American meritocracy. The capricious ease with which those labels get swapped highlights how our precarious social position rests on our perceived utility: as cheap labor, as anti-Communist soldiers, as overachievers meant to success-shame other communities of color. In doing all of this work, Lee argues, Asian-Americans have redefined not only immigration politics and racial categories but also the very essence of what it means to be American.

title: Trigger Mortis: A James Bond Novel, by Anthony Horowitz
description: James Bond is a synchronic spy. From the day that the first Bond thriller, Casino Royale, was published in 1953, all the way through to this years forthcoming Spectre movie, Bond has always been thoroughly modern, with all the latest toys. In Trigger Mortis: A James Bond Novel, however, Bond ventures somewhere Ian Fleming, or the movie producer Albert Broccoli, would never go: back, into the past.

title: You Too Can Have a Body Like Mine, by Alexandra Kleeman
description: Edgar Allan Poes unnamed narrator in The Man of the Crowd sits in a coffee shop referred to as D, looking toward the street and its never-ending stream of passing strangers. At nightfall, amid the multitude, he spots a man who absorbs his attention. He decides to pursue him, until at last the sun begins to rise again and the narrator realizes that he has been following nothing but a man of the crowd  a man, the reader suspects, who mirrors the narrator in his banal pursuit of others and in his incapacity for being alone.

title: Inside the List
description: The 11th Coming: The Nature of the Beast, Louise Pennys 11th novel about the Qubcois detective Armand Gamache, hits the hardcover fiction list at No.3. Penny started the series in 2005 after two decades as a CBC radio host, and its popularity caught her by surprise. Its difficult to learn from success. Ive learned more from my mistakes, she told the author and critic Joel Yanofsky in 2013. Fortunately, Im capable of manufacturing my own problems. In her 20s and early 30s those included a battle with alcoholism, and later a five-year bout of writers block that was, according to Yanofsky, mainly spent watching Oprah, eating gummy bears and lying to everyone, including her husband, about how well her writing was going. Things have improved since then. Now I know that if Im not in the top five on the Times best-seller list, Im going to feel like a failure, she said in the same interview. No worries here! But that doesnt mean Pennys life is challenge-free: In the past few years shes had to care for her husband as he slides into dementia. I find now that the writing is a safe harbor, she told The Vancouver Sun last month. Its a place I go to that is mine. You have to wonder if Penny had her husbands condition in mind when she quoted Yeatss The Second Coming in the new book  thats the poem about things falling apart and the center not holding, which concludes, And what rough beast, its hour come round at last,/Slouches towards Bethlehem to be born? Maybe. But mostly, Penny told The Sun, the beast is ourselves.

title: Ask Well: What Diseases Can You Get from a Water Fountain?
description: Question:

title: Donald Trump Golf Course Seeks to Ease Tax Bite With Lower Valuation
description: For Donald Trump, it is typically good business to be optimistic about the worth of his extensive portfolio of golf courses and real estate developments. But in one instance, the Republican presidential hopeful is apparently seeing benefits in minimizing the value of a property.

title: Donald Trumps Gomorrah Problem
description: This past week, in an effort to make his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination seem less somnolent, Jeb Bush released an ad attacking Donald J. Trump. Using years-old footage of interviews with Mr. Trump, the ad intends to show us that the Republican presidential campaigns current front-runner is an ideological phony  an espouser of liberal beliefs who has variously declared himself in favor of abortion rights, single-payer health care and more aggressively taxing the very rich. (This last position is one he hasnt even tried to conceal, given that as recently as two weeks ago, he appeared on Face the Nation arguing that current tax policy left hedge funders getting away with murder.)

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: The Key Role of Conservatives in Taxing Carbon
description: This summer, a friend sent me a remarkable headline from The Seattle Times:  Green Alliance Opposes Petition to Tax Carbon.

title: Maria Gaidar, a Scion of a Famous Russian Family, Switches Loyalty to Ukraine
description: ODESSA, Ukraine  BEHIND a barred metal gate, the dilapidated two-story buildings dreary hallways led to worn but neat playrooms decorated with dour socialist realist art and a few SpongeBob SquarePants appliqus. Divided by age, groups of girls and boys up to 7 played in the heat, wearing only underpants.

title: A Day After 71 Migrants Died, 81 Escaped the Back of a Truck in Austria
description: EISENSTADT, Austria  Smugglers whose callous negligence killed 71 refugees found in an abandoned truck last week at the side of an Austrian highway risked the death of scores more just a day later, the police said on Friday. But those migrants saved their lives by breaking open a truck door with a crowbar and were eventually abandoned near a traffic circle in eastern Austria.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE STORY OF THE LOST CHILD. Book 4, The Neapolitan Novels: Maturity, Old Age, by Elena Ferrante. Translated by Ann Goldstein. (Europa Editions, paper, $19.) Friends confront age and lifes meaning in the stunning final book of this series.

title: Upper East Side Penthouse for $20.69 Million
description: A second penthouse combination at the Charles, a 32-story glass-and-limestone condominium designed by Ismael Leyva on the far Upper East Side, has sold  just days after the closing of an assembled quadruplex directly above it  and at $20,695,000 was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Funeral Held for Galip and Aylan Kurdi
description: The father of two Syrian boys, who drowned with their mother as they were trying to reach Greece, spoke before they were laid to rest in the Syrian town of Kobani.

title: Traces of Parkour
description: Several practitioners of the sport are photographed in motion with their dust trails behind them.

title: Seeking a Fair Distribution of Migrants in Europe
description: German and European Union leaders have called for European countries to share the burden of absorbing the hundreds of thousands of migrants who have poured into the continent this summer.

title: Greenpeace India Says It Will Continue Environmental Campaign
description: NEW DELHI  Greenpeace India said Friday that it would continue campaigning for clean air and against coal mining in protected forests in the country even though the government had revoked its permission to receive foreign donations.

title: Daily Report: A Push for Diversity in the Tech Industry
description: By now, its well known that the tech industry lacks diversity. At Google, for example, the tech work force is 60 percent white and 1 percent black. But what is not as well known are efforts to change that.

title: Hillary Clinton Adviser Spends 7 Hours Before Benghazi Panel
description: WASHINGTON  Hillary Rodham Clintons closest foreign policy adviser, Jake Sullivan, testified for seven hours on Friday before the House committee investigating the 2012 attacks in Benghazi, Libya, about the State Departments response to the events and Mrs. Clintons personal email account.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Coaxing a Printer to Work With Windows 10
Showing Parkour as Dust in the Wind
description: Several years ago, Ben Franke, a photographer, became interested in parkour, a sport that has roots in training designed for French commandos and that involves running, jumping over objects and doing flips off surfaces.

title: Court Says Chevron Can Be Pursued in Canada Over Ecuadorean Damage
description: The Supreme Court of Canada ruled on Friday that a group of Ecuadoreans can use an Ontario court in an attempt to collect billions of dollars from Chevron for environmental damage.

title: Gay Couple Receives License in Kentucky
description: A deputy clerk at Rowan County Courthouse issued a same-sex couple a marriage license on Friday. The husband of the clerk said his wife would continue to defy the law despite being jailed.

title: In Minnesotas Iron Range, Midwestern With a Modern Twist
description: Pengilly is so small it doesnt show up on most maps. But this town of about 400 on Minnesotas Iron Range just got an unusual addition. Sarah Master, a Minneapolis-area chef who was a semifinalist on The Taste, on ABC, has moved back to her hometown and bought one of its two restaurants.

title: Venice Hotel Is a Hideaway for All to See
description: Doubles from $185.

title: Biden on Whether Hell Seek Presidency
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said Thursday that he was unsure whether he would run and that his decision would depend on whether he and his family had the emotional energy for a bid.

title: And the City Makes Three: Readers Stories of Summer Love
description: Readers share their stories of love, lust and loss in the hot season, with New York as a backdrop.

title: The Real Story of Race and Police Killings
description: Some readers of our editorial The Truth of Black Lives Matter took exception to the idea that black Americans are disproportionately killed in encounters with the police. One commenter pointed us to an article in The Washington Times describing an analysis by Peter Moskos, assistant professor at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice at the City University of New York. The analysis purports to show that white people are more likely than black people to be killed by the police.

title: Salman Rushdie on His New Novel, With a Character Who Floats Just Above Ground
description: Salman Rushdie was a teenager when he first learned that his last name was invented rather than inherited.

title: Migrants in Hungary Walk Toward Germany
description: Footage showed migrants  frustrated with the Hungarian authorities, who have blocked their way by rail  starting the walk from Budapest toward Germany. Others remained in a standoff with the police.

title: Dusty Fifth Avenue Tower to Return as Condos
description: For years, dust and mystery shrouded 212 Fifth Avenue, an office building facing Madison Square Park. Owned by members of the Ring family, longtime New York landlords sometimes described as reclusive, it sat mostly empty while the neighborhood around it boomed.

title: American Express May Get Same Treatment as Microsoft From ValueAct Capital
description: American Express may be facing its Microsoft moment.

title: Roast Chicken With Plums
description: In this recipe for roast chicken, Melissa Clark uses sumac as part of a garlicky spice rub to season the birds (there are two), along with allspice, cinnamon and black pepper.

title: Roast Chicken With Plums Gets a Touch of Spice for Rosh Hashana
description: Its one thing to wish your family and friends a sweet new year. But at Rosh Hashana, Jews bring the sentiment to the table throughout the meal.

title: Paperback Row
description: FROG MUSIC, by Emma Donoghue. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $17.) Donoghues 2010 novel Room followed a mother and child who develop a loving and imaginative existence despite their punishing captivity. Here, the author reimagines a real-life unsolved murder from 1870s San Francisco. Blanche, a French prostitute, befriends Jenny, a cross-dressing vendor of frogs legs. After Jenny is murdered in the room they share, Blanche suspects that she herself was the intended target.

title: The Composer Andrew Lippa on the Upper West Side
description: Five photographs of Andrew Lippa and his husband, David Bloch, hang in the foyer of the couples apartment on the upper reaches of the Upper West Side.

title: What I Love | Andrew Lippa and David Bloch
description: Mr. Lippa, the composer and lyricist, lives with his husband, Mr. Bloch, on the Upper West Side.

title: Israeli Terrorists, Born in the U.S.A.
description: Jerusalem  ON July 31, in the West Bank village of Duma, 18-month-old Ali Dawabsheh was burned alive in a fire. All available evidence suggests that the blaze was a deliberate act of settler terrorism. More disturbingly, several of the alleged instigators, currently being detained indefinitely, are not native-born Israelis  they have American roots.

title: 1940: Call to Action from Pope Pius XII
Inside The New York Times Book Review: Bill Cleggs Debut Novel
description: This week, Bill Clegg talks about Did You Ever Have a Family; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Kathryn J. Edin discusses "$2.00 a Day; feedback from readers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: The Glam-Rock Suit Returns to the Spotlight
description: Play it loose with slightly subversive underpinnings.

title: Toyota to Finance $50 Million Intelligent Car Project
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation announced on Friday an ambitious $50 million robotics and artificial intelligence research effort, in collaboration with Stanford University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, to develop intelligent rather than self-driving cars.

title: European Ministers on the Migrant Crisis
description: Gathering in Luxembourg, Foreign Ministers from European countries discussed how they plan to tackle the ongoing refugee crisis.

title: A 3-Year-Old Syrian Refugees Life Cut Short
description: To the Editor:

title: Houthi Rebels Kill 45 U.A.E. Soldiers in Yemen Fighting
description: SANA, Yemen  The United Arab Emirates said on Friday that 45 of its soldiers were killed fighting Houthi insurgents in a province east of Yemens capital, in a major setback for the coalition of Arab forces that have been trying for months to vanquish the rebels.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Did You Ever Have a Family
description: This week, Bill Clegg and Kathryn J. Edin.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a colonial in New Canaan, Conn., and house on the water in Long Beach, N.Y.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York region:

title: Insane Things Republicans Say: Ted Cruz Edition
description: Donald Trump is so outrageous and noisy that its easy to forget about Senator Ted Cruz of Texas. So we Googled him this morning and we were rewarded.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Key Senate Democrat Announces Opposition to Iran Nuclear Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Benjamin L. Cardin, the senior Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee and a prominent Jewish voice in Congress, said on Friday that he would oppose the Iran nuclear deal, increasing the chance that President Obama will have to use a veto to prevent it from being scuttled.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties include a condo in Harlem, a co-op on the Upper West Side, and a house in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn.

title: Eagle Snacks
description: TK

title: Book Review Podcast: Bill Cleggs Debut Novel
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Kaui Hart Hemmings reviews Bill Cleggs first novel, Did You Ever Have a Family. Ms. Hemmings writes:

title: Blocked by Rail, Migrants Set Out for Germany on Foot
description: Hundreds of migrants who had been stranded at a train station in Budapest began walking toward Germany.

title: Blue Claws: The Tasty Embodiment of Crabby
description: At first glance, an adult blue claw crab is a creature with claws and spines at every joint  with a few extras thrown in for good measure. It does not seem to have many good moods and is inclined to fits of anger, which it expresses like a cartoon Tasmanian devil: blood-crazed and claw-waving.

title: How I Spent My Summer: With Bernstein and Stravinsky
description: Given that Stravinskys The Rite of Spring has long been a staple of orchestra programs, its hard to convey how radical this 1913 shocker was still considered to be during the mid-1960s, when I was a high school student. The score was thought to be playable only by major orchestras equipped to grapple with its difficulties. In contrast, most conservatory ensembles today can perform it capably.

title: Hillary Clinton on Bernie Sanders: Waving Your Arms Doesnt Mean a Lot
description: In the third sit-down national TV interview of her presidential campaign, Hillary Rodham Clinton said the candidacy of Donald J. Trump was a bad development for our American political system, rejected the implication that her campaign was irrevocably damaged by the email controversy and took a veiled jab at Senator Bernie Sanders, whose populist message has drawn big crowds and given him a lift in recent polls in Iowa and New Hampshire.

title: Carbon Cuts So Sharp Even California Democrats Are Divided
description: SACRAMENTO  With President Obama back from a trip to Alaska in which he portrayed the fight against climate change as an urgent international priority, California is showing how hard it can be  even in a state overwhelmingly controlled by Democrats  to get an ambitious carbon reduction bill passed.

title: Giants Cut Weatherford, One of the Last of Their Super Bowl Winners
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants on Friday released punter Steve Weatherford, a popular player and one of the few remaining links in the locker room to the franchises last Super Bowl-winning team. Giants Coach Tom Coughlin had been sparse in his praise of Weatherford this preseason and frequently hinted that the team might be in the market for a new punter.

title: Obama and Saudi King Sidestep Dispute Over Iran Nuclear Deal
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and King Salman of Saudi Arabia moved to put their differences behind them on Friday in a long-delayed White House meeting amid months of tension over the nuclear agreement with Iran and a continuing schism over the way forward in Syria.

title: A Lamp That Brings the Cosmos Indoors
description: This lamp is called Helios and seems to conjure celestial bodies in motion. The sun is a naked bulb, burning bright or barely glowing, depending on how you deploy the dimmer or position the 12-inch hand-spun brass dish that serves as a planetary lampshade  angled in front, it creates a full eclipse. Designed by Robert Highsmith, a co-founder of the Brooklyn-based Workstead studio, known for a spare, industrial aesthetic warmed by luxurious materials (they did the interiors of the Wythe Hotel in Williamsburg), the lamps luminous components hover above a 4-inch cube base, available in three types of stone: pale Italian Carrara, deeply veined green Connemara and creamy gray travertine. Tethered yet flexible, it would have looked at home in Galileos lab.

title: Grandpa Woodstock Spreads Peace and Love on a Village Green
description: Peace and love, repeated Grandpa Woodstock. I spread peace and love, thats what I do.

title: Judges Ruling Offers Peek Into Private Equitys Secret World
description: Infiltrating the supersecret world of private equity is difficult, so any glimpse into how these firms operate is worth highlighting.

title: A Notorious 19th-Century Kidnapping in Brooklyn
description: Q. I am trying to locate the residence of a Brooklyn judge where two burglars were once gunned down.

title: Rikers Island Captain and Officer Are Charged With Beating Inmate, 18
description: A Rikers Island captain and a correction officer were charged on Friday with assaulting a teenage inmate in a storage room where there were no video surveillance cameras, and then filing false paperwork to conceal their actions.

title: Piercing the Denial on Refugees
description: Photographs of a lifeless little boy, dressed in a red shirt and dark shorts, lying face down on a beach, and then, minutes later, cradled in the arms of a police officer, have taken the world by storm. These heartbreaking images of 3-year-old Aylan Kurdi, who drowned when the rubber dinghy that was to carry him and his Syrian family to safety in Greece capsized off the coast of Turkey on Wednesday, have succeeded, finally, in bringing home the terrible human cost of Europes failure to deal with a surging refugee crisis.

title: Obama Meets With Saudi King
description: The president and King Salman of Saudi Arabia met at the White House to discuss topics including the Iran nuclear deal and the conflict in Syria.

title: Ernest Logans Sunday Routine Goes From Church Back to School
description: While New York Citys principals, assistant principals and district supervisors rinse off the sand and sunblock to get their schools student-ready this week, the head of their union, Ernest A. Logan, is on call. A former Brooklyn principal, Mr. Logan, 64, has led the 6,500-member Council of School Supervisors and Administrators for the past 10 years. He lives in Brooklyns Crown Heights North Historic District with his wife, Beatrice Logan, 68, a retired guidance counselor. For them, Sunday is all about church, a daylong event filled with prayer, song and service. I encounter a lot of crazy stuff on this job, Mr. Logan said. I have to stop and pause.

title: National Humanities Medal Winners Include Larry McMurtry and Alice Waters
description: The authors Larry McMurtry, Annie Dillard and Jhumpa Lahiri are among the 10 recipients of the National Humanities Medal, which will be bestowed by President Barack Obama at a White House ceremony on Thursday.

title: Restaurants Take the Din Out of Dining
description: From the outside, Untitled looks like one of those places where intimate conversation gets lost in the din.

title: New Books on the City After War and After Buffalo
description: Father Duffys monument is in the middle of Times Square, but its unfamiliar to most New Yorkers and few can identify its honoree. Thats just one of many reasons to read New York and the First World War: Shaping an American City (Ashgate).

title: Peoria Settles Suit Over Parody Twitter Account That Mocked Mayor
description: Public officials are easy targets for parody accounts on Twitter.

title: Chinese Navy Ships Entered U.S. Waters Legally, Pentagon Says
description: WASHINGTON  Five Chinese Navy ships that sailed this week off the coast of Alaska entered United States territorial waters, but they have since left the area, Pentagon officials said on Friday.

title: Emails Give Insight Into National Youth Theater Leader Decision to Cancel Play
description: LONDON  An email sent by the artistic director of the National Youth Theater, that has been made public offers insight into why his company abruptly canceled its production of Homegrown  a play about young Islamic State recruits  before its planned opening in August.

title: College Football Games to Watch This Weekend
description: Saturday

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
Food Choices Expand Near Grand Central
description: A permanent new indoor food hall on Vanderbilt Avenue next to Grand Central Terminal is set to open Sept. 14. Its from UrbanSpace, which runs outdoor pop-up markets of vendors (not just the food type) in London and New York. This time, its all food. Kiosks from about 20 producers line the perimeter, with some booths, including Red Hook Lobster Pounds, in the center. There are communal tables. Whet your appetite for Robertas pizza, Tobys Estate Coffee, La Palapa tacos and Amali Mou for wines by the glass: UrbanSpace Vanderbilt, 230 Vanderbilt Avenue (45th Street), 646-747-0822, urbanspacenyc.com.

title: U.N. Official Urges Stronger Action by Peacekeepers in Central African Republic
description: GENEVA  United Nations peacekeepers should take tougher action against armed groups to restore stability to the crisis-torn Central African Republic, the United Nations human rights chief said Friday, but they need to be reinforced with more men and attack helicopters to fulfill their mission.

title: The Many Pitfalls of Private Student Loans
description: Mallory Rego, the first member of her family to attend college, says she now sees that she put too much blind faith in the power of education.

title: The Narcissist in Chief
description: WITH the presidential campaign in full swing, a perennial question has resurfaced: How much weight should voters give to candidates personalities? The political rise of Donald J. Trump has drawn attention to one personality trait in particular: narcissism. Although narcissism does not lend itself to a precise definition, most psychologists agree that it comprises self-centeredness, boastfulness, feelings of entitlement and a need for admiration.

title: Think Like a Doctor: The Quarterbacks Headache Solved!
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 15-year-old boy with the worst headache of his life. I thought it was a fascinating case and apparently so did many of you. More than 120 readers offered some very thoughtful possibilities and nearly two dozen of you got it right.

title: On Beyoncs Birthday, a Bey Day Celebration Fit for a Queen
description: For most Americans, its merely the Friday before Labor Day weekend, a dull smattering of hours that stands between them and a hard-won three days off.

title: New Type of Drug-Free Labels for Meat Has U.S.D.A. Blessing
description: As meat companies scramble to eliminate antibiotics from their products to address consumer and regulatory concerns, the federal Agriculture Department has quietly opened a new front in the debate over the use of drugs in the livestock and poultry industries.

title: Talk in G.O.P. Turns to a Stop Donald Trump Campaign
description: Quiet conversations have begun in recent weeks among some of the Republican Partys biggest donors and normally competing factions, all aimed at a single question: How can we stop Donald Trump?

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: France and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Scott Boras and the Mets Disagree About Matt Harveys Innings Limit
description: MIAMI  Over the winter, as the Mets prepared for Matt Harveys first season back from Tommy John surgery, General Manager Sandy Alderson and Scott Boras, Harveys agent, discussed how the Mets would handle Harveys health.

title: September 4, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from France, Spain, India and Hungary.

title: BlackBerry to Buy Good Technology, Getting Deeper Into Security
description: OTTAWA  As part of its shift away from phones toward software, BlackBerry announced on Friday that it would buy a rival, Good Technology, for $425 million.

title: For College Students, Choosing a Bank Account Can Be a Minefield
description: Students heading to college are often barraged with offers to open special accounts to manage their money. But they should be aware that not all the accounts are alike.

title: Nissan Recalls 300,000 Versa Sedans
description: Under pressure from federal regulators, Nissan is recalling almost 328,000 of its Versa sedans because a trim piece on the center console could snag the drivers foot and interfere with braking or accelerating.

title: New Bars in New York City Explore Spirits of Latin America
description: The many spirits pouring out of Central and South America will continue to fill New Yorkers cocktail glasses this fall.

title: Review: Arthur & George and the Longest Case Ever
description: Not content to be the American home of Sherlock, PBS is cornering the market in Holmesiana with the debut on Sunday night of Arthur & George, a three-part British series that puts Arthur Conan Doyle in the role of master detective.

title: Iowans Question G.O.P. Talk on Illegal Immigration
description: MUSCATINE, Iowa  Like many voters in Iowa, Ben Hoopes has been listening closely to all the tough talk about illegal immigration coming from the Republican presidential candidates who have crisscrossed his state every week.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: At Visa Pour lImage Festival, Photojournalists at the Ramparts
description: PERPIGNAN, France  The prestigious World Press Photo contest caused an uproar in March and damaged its standing when it bestowed, then revoked, a top prize to an Italian photographer who had misrepresented the location of an image. Amid an intense debate about the line between photojournalism and art photography, many photojournalists were outraged that images in which the photographer, Giovanni Troilo, had intervened  by using a remote-control flash, for example  had been categorized as reportage.

title: New Health Care Rule Offers Key Protections for Transgender Americans
description: In a major step forward, the Department of Health and Human Services on Thursday proposed a rule barring health care providers and insurers from discriminating against transgender patients.

title: In Los Angeles, a Downtown Believer
description: LOS ANGELES  Huffing and puffing, Andrew Meieran burst into a fifth-floor office here in mid-July. He was running 20 minutes late.

title: 1999 | Painting a Publisher in His Twilight
description: A president. A pope. A princess. A prime minister.

title: Treetop Falls in Bryant Park, Injuring 5
description: With the workweek meandering to a close and a long holiday weekend ramping up, the lawn and walkways of Bryant Park in Midtown Manhattan were abuzz late Friday afternoon. Friends gathered to chart the evening ahead. Others, alone, found respite in books.

title: Islamist Rebels and the Police Clash in Tajikistan, Killing 17
description: MOSCOW  Long-simmering unrest and infighting in the leadership in Tajikistan flared on Friday when the government accused a deputy defense minister of siding with Islamists in clashes with the police that killed 17 people.

title: Were All Artists Now
description: OUR best selves are merely one doodle away.

title: Lost in One Burglary: Heirlooms, a Wedding Ring and a Sense of Security
description: Bit by bit, the 28-year-old bride-to-be absorbed the telltale signs of the burglary of her Brooklyn apartment: The gouge in the doorframe where the intruder had shoved a crowbar to get inside, the police officers talking in the dining room and, beyond them, her ransacked bedroom with the contents of her dresser drawers piled on the bed.

title: Astronauts Welcomed Aboard Space Station
description: Crew members at the International Space Station gave new arrivals from the Russian Soyuz spacecraft a warm welcome on Friday.

title: Double Digits
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  I have never met Patrick Berry in person, but I am reasonably sure that he has taken some sort of dislike to me. Thats the only explanation I have for 28 Across in todays puzzle.

description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: North Woods Law Offers a Gentler View of Law Enforcement (and More Bears)
description: RANGELEY, Me.  Are you filming? the first boater pulled over on Rangeley Lake here asked. He had recognized the two Maine game wardens who were maneuvering their boat abreast on a sunny August Saturday.

title: Mark Teixeira Limps to D.L., but Yankees Dont Break Their Stride
description: Returning home after a six-game trip, the Yankees found that the interior design of their clubhouse had been altered. Four temporary lockers belonging to recent call-ups were set up in the middle of the room, away from those lined against the walls.

title: Venice Film Festival Offers a Chance to Watch Suffering, Then to Quaff Champagne
description: VENICE  The things of this world reveal their essential absurdity when they are put in the Venetian context. So wrote Mary McCarthy in her charming, philosophical travel essay Venice Observed. It can be argued that the essential absurdity of movies is never really in doubt, but the Venice Film Festival  the oldest such event in this world  puts its own stamp on the marvelous, magical and perhaps fundamentally preposterous activities of making, displaying and watching movies.

title: Alleviating Pain, Delivering Love
description: A photojournalist learns what it is like for a family to care for a critically ill child while spending time at a pediatric palliative care program.

title: Evening Hours | Glamour Kids
description: The Childrens Literacy Initiative benefited from a Polo Ralph Lauren childrens fashion show.

title: Bill Cunningham | Late Summer Scenes
description: Around Labor Day, the colors of the outdoor market at Union Square take on more autumnal hues.

title: Bill Cunningham | Late Summer Scenes
description: Around Labor Day, the colors of the outdoor market at Union Square take on more autumnal hues. Shoppers light summer clothes were often replaced with black pieces. Also sighted: one of the artist Priscilla Snyders animal bags, made of thread. Cascades of hydrangeas surrounded houses along the Eastern Seaboard. Zinnias, dahlias and sunflowers added their vibrant colors.

title: Review: Zhang Huoding Makes American Debut in Two Operas
description: For New Yorkers who basked in regular productions of Chinese opera at the tiny Taipei Theater of the Taiwanese Chinese Information and Culture Center in the 1990s, it has since been feast or famine. Mostly famine.

title: Refugees Who Could Be Us
description: WATCHING the horrific images of Syrian refugees struggling toward safety  or in the case of Aylan Kurdi, 3, drowning on that journey  I think of other refugees. Albert Einstein. Madeleine Albright. The Dalai Lama.

title: The Stylish Men of Tumblr
description: A visit with the employees of the short-form blogging platform at their Manhattan office.

title: Review: Two Bergman Films, Adapted on a Philadelphia Stage
description: PHILADELPHIA  The performers bodies were slick with sweat, and so were ours. It wasnt a sexy, dewy dampness, either. These were rivulets of perspiration, soaking through hair and bleeding through clothes in wide, dark patches.

title: Second City Cancels More Shows After Fire
description: The Chicago comedy theater and school Second City has canceled or moved all of the performances on its Mainstage, e.t.c. and UP Comedy Club theaters through Sept. 20 because of damage from a fire in its building last week, it announced on its website Friday.

title: Race Pulls Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton to Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  It is an unusual sight, these presidential candidates sweating under the sweltering late summer sun of the Caribbean, rather than jetting to Iowa, New Hampshire and other swing states.

title: Unionization Important to Closing Racial Wage Gap, Study Says
description: A study released on Friday, noting the gains made by black union workers in New York City, said that raising the rate of unionization among black workers across the country would help narrow the racial pay gap.

title: John McEnroe Saw Talent, and Now Ingrid Neel Is Fulfilling a Dream
description: The first question for Ingrid Neel  or at least the first one John McEnroe would have asked five years after she intrigued and even amazed him as a tennis-playing 12-year-old  would be whether she was still daring to be different.

title: Young Methodists Plant Churches With Environmental Gospel
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Growing up in nearby Eden Prairie, Minn., Tyler Sit felt called to be a minister. But he was not sure what kind.

title: Aretha Franklin Thwarts Screening of Documentary Featuring Concert Footage
description: TELLURIDE, Colo.  Aretha Franklin prevailed on Friday in an 11th-hour legal bid to stop the Telluride Film Festival from screening Sydney Pollacks posthumous documentary Amazing Grace, which shows the making of Ms. Franklins album of the same name more than four decades ago.

title: The Fed Should Remember the 90s
description: Im (a) having a good time (b) jet-lagged to the point of madness, so posting limited. But I do want to weigh in on the latest job report and the Fed.

description: To the Editor:

title: For Labor Day Drivers, Lowest Gasoline Prices in 11 Years
description: HOUSTON  Despite the recent tumult in global stock and energy markets, American travelers can count on bargains at the pump this Labor Day weekend, with prices for gasoline at their lowest levels in 11 years.

title: Treatment of Migrants Evokes Memories of Europes Darkest Hour
description: BUDAPEST  In Hungary, hundreds of migrants surrounded by armed police officers were tricked into boarding a train with promises of freedom, only to be taken to a reception camp. In the Czech Republic, the police hustled more than 200 migrants off a train and wrote identification numbers on their hands with indelible markers, stopping only when someone pointed out that this was more than a little like the tattoos the Nazis put on concentration camp inmates.

title: New Orleans Mayor May Face House Arrest in Pay Dispute
description: NEW ORLEANS  A judge here on Friday threatened the mayor with house arrest if the city did not quickly reach an agreement with the firefighters union over millions of dollars owed in back pay and benefits.

title: Renovation at Javits Center Alleviates Hazard for Manhattans Birds
description: For years the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center loomed over a desolate stretch of the West 30s in Manhattan, its dark facade and severe angles earning it the nickname Darth Vader. For bird lovers, the appellation was apt since the building was a major site of bird fatalities, as the unwitting creatures smashed into the mirrorlike facade.

title: Nepali Women in Queens Challenge Tradition, Taking Lead With Quake Aid
description: Cooks, nannies and college students walked through the red door, painted the color of Nepals flag. Men and women alike, they came to this agency in Queens on a recent weekday seeking legal help that could allow them to visit family in Nepal after the devastating earthquake there.

title: Venus Williams, Long in Shadow, Is Not to Be Forgotten
description: Serena Williams has a big sister who plays tennis.

title: Bank of America Board Under Fire for Combining Chairman and Chief Jobs
description: Momentum is building toward forcing Bank of America to undo its decision last year to name the banks chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, as chairman as well.

title: At West Point, Annual Pillow Fight Becomes Weaponized
description: For generations, freshmen cadets at the United States Military Academy have marked the end of a grueling summer of training with a huge nighttime pillow fight that is billed as a harmless way to blow off steam and build class spirit.

title: Eugenie Bouchards Star Returns to Its Lofty Trajectory
description: Eugenie Bouchard had not been enjoying the most fruitful year of her professional tennis career. At one point, she lost 10 of 11 matches. Entering the United States Open, she had not won consecutive matches since March.

title: The Minimum Wage: Getting to $15
description: The debate over the federal minimum wage in the nascent presidential campaign is really two debates: one among Democrats and one among Republicans.

title: The New Jersey Psychic With a Box of Swiss Gold
description: Detectives entered a Wells Fargo branch in Cliffside Park, N.J., in April with a search warrant authorizing them to open safe deposit box No. 679. The boxs contents led them to Manhattans diamond district, uptown to a frail womans apartment in Washington Heights, then back across the river, revealing a multilayered, multistate network of deception and crime.

title: Kentucky Clerks Stance Tests County Where Opposing Views Are Welcomed
description: MOREHEAD, Ky.  As the protesters faced off outside the Rowan County courthouse, one sign held by gay-marriage supporters read, Law of the Land. Another, held by opponents, read, Welcome to Sodom and Gomorrah. The amplified voice of a preacher described, in terse but explicit terms, a homosexual act. Is that a little too graphic for you? he asked, as if to provoke.

title: Ouster of Don Orsillo, Beloved TV Announcer, Fuels a Red Sox Firestorm
description: BOSTON  Emily Elmore stood by her seat along the third-base line at Fenway Park on Wednesday holding a simple sign that signified the latest twist in a miserable Boston Red Sox season.

title: A Chance to Fix Parole in New York
description: On Tuesday, the New York Court of Appeals, the states highest court, will hear oral arguments in a case that may provide a rare chance to reform New Yorks antiquated, ineffective and unfair parole system.

title: Many Obstacles Are Seen to U.S. Taking in Large Number of Syrian Refugees
description: WASHINGTON  In late spring, with the war in Syria grinding into its fifth year amid an ever-deepening humanitarian catastrophe for millions of refugees, 14 United States senators wrote a letter to President Obama urging that at least 65,000 of the displaced Syrians be allowed to resettle in the United States.

title: Jason Day and Jordan Spieth Moving in Opposite Directions
description: NORTON, Mass.  The argument about which comes first, confidence or results, misses the point. The work always comes first. Preparation is the security blanket, the calming influence, of any top performer.

title: Russian Moves in Syria Pose Concerns for U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Russia has sent a military advance team to Syria and is taking other steps the United States fears may signal that President Vladimir V. Putin is planning to vastly expand his military support for President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, administration officials said Friday.

title: Why Is Science So Straight?
description: Baltimore  MANY years ago, over lunch at our university cafeteria, I came out as gay to a colleague in the engineering department. I didnt realize you were so unconventional, he said. I tried explaining to him that being gay was innate and had nothing to do with wanting to subvert convention, but he refused to retract his label. Looking back, perhaps he was correct.

title: Thomas Sobol, 83, Dies; Education Advocate as New York State Commissioner
description: Thomas Sobol, a courtly railway workers son who became a leading educator and fervent advocate for imposing broad academic standards, subsidizing poor urban districts, empowering parents and teachers to make policy, and promoting a multicultural curriculum, died on Thursday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 83.

title: U.S. Open 2015: Serena Williams Survives; Rafael Nadal Does Not
description: Serena Williams and Rafael Nadal are two terrific champions who have won multiple major tournaments, Williams 21 and Nadal 14. At various times over the last decade, both have dominated their sport, but at this major event their fortunes appeared to have reversed.

title: Like Grenada, but Not Granada
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  I tend to travel, crossword-wise, in a sort of rarefied circle, in that most of my friends in the community are the super-solvers you see hoisting trophies over their heads at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.

title: Trades and the Tides of Time
description: As a kid, I was not a Dodgers fan by any stretch. In 1977 and 1978, Los Angeles knocked off my beloved Philadelphia Phillies in consecutive National League Championship Series. They went on to make a legend out of Reggie Jackson over two World Series while falling to the Yankees. But for me, there was no satisfaction in their defeat, because all I wanted was the Phillies to make it, to beat the Yankees and secure me bragging rights in the halls of Emerson Elementary School, in Teaneck, NJ.

title: The Tao of a Corncob Pipe
description: BUSHKILL, Pa.  EVEN now, when I conjure him and he deigns to come, I always see him the same way. Hes encircled in sweet blue smoke, standing on the cool stone of the walkway around midnight. A little man, ancient, almost swallowed by the vivid articles of clothing that his devoted daughter always bought for him. They were nothing like the slate-colored clothes my grandfather would have chosen for himself. But they covered him and kept him warm.

title: As Vote Looms, Some in Guatemala Foresee More Frustration
description: GUATEMALA CITY  Guatemalans united to force their powerful president to step down. But now, many who joined the demonstration movement worry that creating lasting change, and rewriting the rules of their fragile democracy, may prove even harder.

title: A Silver Lining to Brazils Troubles
description: Of all the BRICS, Brazil would seem, on the face of it, to be in the worst shape.

title: Mets Conundrum: Matt Harveys Health Versus a Playoff Run
description: ST. LOUIS  So many parties have a reason to want Matt Harvey pitching in October. The Mets and their fans yearn for a championship. Major League Baseball craves the chance to showcase a rising star. The competitor in Harvey surely burns to prove himself.

title: Worker Who Died in Wall Collapse Warned of Problems at Construction Site
description: The construction worker, a slim man of 18 who had arrived in New York City from Ecuador less than a year ago, returned to his home in Queens one day last month and told his mother about a close call.

title: Alberta Wright, Restaurateur and Soul-Food Pioneer, Dies at 84
description: Alberta Wright, the owner of Jezebel, which brought soul food with panache to Manhattans theater district and helped make sophisticated variations of Southern dishes a culinary trend, died on Friday in the Bronx. She was 84.

title: Labor Day Closings in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
description: Holiday Observed on MondayNEW YORK

title: Clinton Speaks on Puerto Rican Debt
description: At an event in San Juan on Friday, the Democratic presidential candidate said that Puerto Rico could not solve its current crisis through austerity alone.

title: On a Seesaw Night, Mets Teeter, Rally, Then Fall
description: MIAMI  On Friday, the Mets fell behind early, took the lead late, lost it, then tied the score when they were down to their final out.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) WILD (2014) Reese Witherspoon, in an Oscar-nominated performance, portrays Cheryl Strayed, who copes with the aftermath of her heroin use, her marital infidelity and the death of her mother by hiking the Pacific Crest National Scenic Trail, spanning more than 1,000 miles, from the Southern California desert to the forests of Oregon. Her routine  walking, thinking, pitching her tent at night and packing it up in the morning  is punctuated by montages of memories and encounters in the wilderness, mostly with men. Some are scary; others are kind; but almost all are intrigued by the presence of a solitary woman so far from civilization.  Wild may be full of natural beauty  Yves Blangers cinematography unostentatiously captures the infinite colors and vistas of the West  but it is also a celebration of the power of art, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about Jean-Marc Valles adaptation of Ms. Strayeds memoir, from a script by Nick Hornby. And the film has its shortcomings, he added, with too much montage in the middle and too much voice-over at the end, and maybe not quite enough detail about some of Cheryls relationships. But you wouldnt want a movie that celebrates imperfection, improvisation and the importance of mistakes to be slick or seamless. What makes its heroine worth caring about  what makes her a rare and exciting presence in contemporary American film  is not that shes tidy or sensible or even especially nice. Its that shes free.

title: Corrections: September 5, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Im as prejudiced as the day is long. Its a bad thing that all these illegal Mexicans are here. But theyre hard workers. Theyre doing jobs that lazy Americans wont do.

title: Player Ratings: United States (2) vs. Peru (1)
description: WASHINGTON  The United States mens national team responded well to its first test after a disappointing Gold Cup, coming from behind to defeat a strong Peru on a hot and humid night at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: Making Jobs Satisfying
description: What makes workers happy? Pay, meaningful work, flexible hours, personal responsibility.

description: Short on the sides, longer on top.
