description: The Juilliard School has one of the most prestigious acting schools in the United States, with a roster of alumni that includes Patti LuPone, William Hurt, Robin Williams, Christine Baranski, Kevin Spacey and Jessica Chastain.

title: Why Do We End Summer So Early?
description: There are rules, at least unofficial ones, dictating that summer ends this weekend.

title: A Basketball Arena Battles for San Franciscos Heart
description: Prosperity is the sound of jackhammers and pile drivers in the morning.

title: Bucking a Trend, Some Millennials Are Seeking a Nuns Life
description: SUMMIT, N.J.  Its been a rough year for the mechanicals at the Dominican Monastery of Our Lady of the Rosary. The lawn mower died, along with the chaplains car, the compressor for the kitchen refrigerator and one of the new washers (that is, a machine bought sometime in the mid 80s).

title: Hillary Clinton Relying on Southern Primaries to Fend Off Rivals
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign is methodically building a political firewall across the South in hopes of effectively locking up the Democratic nomination in March regardless of any early setbacks in the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted by @nytimes took Instagram followers from the waters of Resurrection Bay to Keleti train station in Budapest.

title: A Sharing Economy Where Teachers Win
description: What kind of tunes do you think Iago, the villain in William Shakespeares Othello, would listen to if he had an iPhone?

title: Seneca Art and Culture Center to Open in October
description: Seneca Center The Seneca Art and Culture Center opens Oct. 24 at Ganondagan State Historic Site in Victor, N.Y., 20 miles southeast of Rochester. The center is built on the site of the original Seneca settlement, destroyed in 1687. The gallery will offer changing exhibitions conveying the story of the Seneca and Haudenosaunee (also known as Iroquois) people through centuries of artistic and historical artifacts and will also include work from contemporary Native American artists.

title: Germans Welcome Migrants After Long Journey Through Hungary and Austria
description: MUNICH  Germans waving welcome signs in German, English and Arabic came to the train station here Saturday to greet the first group of what is expected to be about 8,000 migrants to arrive in Germany by early Sunday, after an arduous and emotional journey through Hungary and Austria.

title: Is Trump the Candidate Reform Conservatives Are Seeking?
description: For the last few years, a small but prominent group of conservative writers and thinkers has urged the Republican party to rethink its economic agenda with a greater focus on the needs of the middle class. The so-called reform conservatives have criticized the G.O.P.s economic prescription of cutting entitlement programs and tax rates (especially on high earners) as unresponsive to the concerns of workers earning stagnant wages.

title: Hillary Clintons Beijing Speech on Women Resonates 20 Years Later
description: Just days after Hillary Rodham Clinton left her post as secretary of state in early 2013, she assembled a group of longtime female aides to discuss what she wanted to do as she contemplated another presidential run.

title: Mike and Quentins Week in Tech: Amazons Offline Game Changer
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the industry. Mr. Manjoo is off this week, so Mr. Isaac is conversing with fellow tech reporter Quentin Hardy.

title: Migrants Journey
description: Thousands of migrants arrived in Austria on Saturday morning after Hungary helped them travel in safety.

title: A University of Illinois Professor Joins the Fight
description: Bruce M. Chassy, now a professor emeritus at the University of Illinois, is another academic who was recruited to help out with GMO Answers.

title: A Florida Professor Works With the Biotech Industry
description: Kevin Folta, chairman of the horticultural sciences department at the University of Florida, began to correspond regularly with executives at Monsanto in early 2013. He soon teamed up with the company and other industry representatives to defend their genetically engineered crop technologies as they lobbied Congress and other government authorities. Dr. Folta has said he worked as an independent scientist. But Monsanto helped cover his costs.

title: Washington State Professor Allies With Organics Industry
description: Charles M. Benbrook, formerly the chief scientist at the Organic Center, left the nonprofit organization in 2012 after concluding that he could get more traction for his research, which has questioned G.M.O. crop safety, by joining a university.

title: A Mississippi State Administrators Ties to Monsanto and Dow
description: David R. Shaw, vice president for research and economic development at Mississippi State University, has received a steady stream of research support from Monsanto, as well as grant money. Monsanto and Dow Chemical have asked him to help move their agendas in Washington, emails show.

title: Opera School Noise Complaints
description: No Fan of Singing School

title: Food Industry Enlisted Academics in G.M.O. Lobbying War, Emails Show
description: WASHINGTON  At Monsanto, sales of genetically modified seeds were steadily rising. But executives at the companys St. Louis headquarters were privately worried about attacks on the safety of their products.

title: As Germany Welcomes Migrants, Some Wonder How to Make Acceptance Last
description: BERLIN  As tens of thousands of asylum seekers now pour into Germany, their desired destination, they will be met here by bowls of steaming soup and bread rolls, working bathrooms and an efficient bureaucracy to move them to temporary housing and, possibly, legal immigration status.

title: 1915: Fashion Fancies
description: The hitherto unpublished drawings by M. Drian, which the Herald is reproducing today through the courtesy of M. Lucien Vogel, the director of the Gazette du Bon Ton, in which paper they will appear this week are wittily and fancifully illustrative of the latest fashions.

title: Nissan May Repeat Recall Over Airbags
description: Federal regulators have indicated they are worried that Nissans recall last year of almost one million vehicles did not correct a malfunction of the passenger airbag, raising the possibility that the automaker might have to recall the vehicles again.

title: Kathleen Finch: Get Better Ideas With a Pile On Meeting
description: This interview with Kathleen Finch, chief programming officer of HGTV, Food Network and Travel Channel, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Variety: A Hard-Working Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Well, this acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon got me all riled up. I am a card-carrying member of a union, and now I want to march or hold up a placard or something. Happy Labor Day weekend, everyone.

title: Uneasy Truce on Gay Marriage Is Shaken by Kentucky Clerks Defiance
description: WASHINGTON  Kim Davis did more than register a protest when she went to jail last week after defying a federal court order to issue marriage licenses to gay couples. Ms. Davis, the clerk in Rowan County, Ky., also helped unravel an uneasy dtente in the nations culture wars that had prevailed since the Supreme Court declared a constitutional right to same-sex marriage in June.

title: Brian Wilcox: A Voice for Car Lovers
description: Brian Wilcox, 30, is a customer service specialist for K40 Electronics, in Elgin, Ill.

title: When to Tell a Prospective Employer That Youre Pregnant
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Smart Workers Seek Out Advice, Study Suggests
description: Every day, employees have the opportunity to learn new information that could improve their performance, yet many fail to take advantage of it. They are afraid to ask for advice.

title: T. Eugene Thompson Dies at 88; Crime Stunned St. Paul
description: T. Eugene Thompsons paid obituary on Tuesday nebulously described him as a multifaceted person and concluded with a quotation from Oscar Wilde: Every saint has a past, and every sinner has a future.

title: Notre Dame Football Job Requirement: Fiery Spirit, if Not Beard
description: The most distinctive trait of the person who becomes the Notre Dame leprechaun mascot is not the ability to leap, tumble, scream, orate or mug for the camera.

title: Joy Golden, Who Made Ads With Punch Lines, Dies at 85
description: Joy Golden, an advertising executive who wrote copy for Maidenform bras and Talon zippers during the Mad Men era but found her true calling in the 1980s when she created the humorous radio spots for Laughing Cow cheese, died on Aug. 29 in Manhattan. She was 85.

title: Rutgers Kicks 5 Players Off Team, Then Wins Its Opener
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Minutes before the start of its season-opening 63-13 victory against Norfolk State on Saturday afternoon, Rutgers announced the dismissals of five players. Two days earlier, they had been arrested and indefinitely suspended from the program after an investigation into separate cases by the Middlesex County Prosecutors Office and the New Brunswick Police Department.

title: For Andy Murray, Supporting British Tennis Is Important Role
description: In his latest conversation with The New York Times, Andy Murray spoke about his support for lower-ranked players, following tennis in his free time, and how to improve the reputation and results of British tennis. Murray plays Thomaz Bellucci in a third-round match Saturday night.

title: A Collector Sees the Potential in a Humble Paper Clip
description: James Ward began collecting office supplies about 10 years ago, but he has always loved pens, pencils and paper. They remind him of walking into class at the beginning of the school year with a brand-new pencil case and at that moment everythings perfect. To this day, empty notebooks beckon to him with their potentiality.

title: Cucumbers Recalled in Salmonella Outbreak
description: A California distributor has begun recalling cucumbers imported from Mexico after they were linked to a salmonella outbreak that has killed one woman and sickened at least 285 others, health officials said.

title: U.S. Warns Russia Over Military Support for Assad
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State John Kerry told his Russian counterparton Saturdaythat the United States was deeply concerned by reports that the Kremlin may be planning to vastly expand its military support for President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, warning that such a move might even lead to a confrontation with the American-led coalition, the State Department said.

title: Unrest Mounts in Southern Syria After Druse Cleric Dies in Blast
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  An unusual wave of unrest mounted Saturday in a normally quiet southern Syrian province, according to residents and activists there, after a double car-bombing killed a prominent Druse cleric who had challenged the government by supporting young men who refused to serve in the national army.

title: Robert Whaley
description: Robert Whaley is a professor of finance at Vanderbilt Universitys Owen Graduate School of Management and the developer of the two major so-called fear indices  the VIX and VXN on the Chicago Board Options Exchange  that are used to make bets on market volatility.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: The Architecture of Segregation
description: Fifty years after the creation of the Department of Housing and Urban Development  and nearly that long after the passage of the Fair Housing Act of 1968  the fight against the interlinked scourges of housing discrimination and racial segregation in America is far from finished. Economic isolation is actually growing worse across the country, as more and more minority families find themselves trapped in high-poverty neighborhoods without decent housing, schools or jobs, and with few avenues of escape.

title: Rising to Your Level of Misery at Work
description: EVERYONE has heard of the Peter Principle: Managers rise to the level of their incompetence. Today, however, a whole class of hyper-competent Americans will never find their level of incompetence. Instead, they will suffer a similar principle in which they rise to their level of misery.

title: Foreign Journalists Under Fire
description: A kangaroo court in Egypt recently sentenced three journalists from the Al Jazeera English network to three years in prison for committing journalism.

title: Getting a Grip on Football
description: Deflategate always sounded so childish: Did the star quarterback know that air had been secretly leaked from footballs he was throwing to help him win a big game? Theres still no firm answer to that question after an exhaustive court fight. But here comes the National Football League season nevertheless, and there is the star quarterback, Tom Brady, free to throw footballs again for the New England Patriots, having prevailed last week against an attempt by the league commissioner, Roger Goodell, to suspend him for four games.

title: Blessed Be My Freshly Slaughtered Dinner
description: COULD you look through a rifles scope into the long-lashed eyes of an elk and pull the trigger if it would be the only meat you ate for the year? Would your conscience be more or less troubled if instead you slit the necks of animals you planned to eat after they were nurtured like adored pets on an idyllic farm?

title: The Refugee Crisis Isnt a European Problem
description: THOSE of us outside Europe are watching the unbelievable images of the Keleti train station in Budapest, the corpse of a toddler washed up on a Turkish beach, the desperate Syrian families chancing their lives on the night trip to the Greek islands  and we keep being told this is a European problem.

title: The Internet of Way Too Many Things
description: At a design conference recently, I was introduced to Leeo, a new product that I initially understood to be a reboot of something really in need of a redesign: the smoke detector. As the designer explained his process, I quickly came to understand that Leeo was nothing of the sort. It was a gadget, a night light that listens for your smoke detector to go off and then calls your smartphone to let you know your house might be on fire.

title: Who Failed Aylan Kurdi?
description: THE image of a dead Syrian boy washed up on a Turkish beach has inspired a wave of Western soul-searching, with much talk about how the world failed 3-year-old Aylan Kurdi, who drowned along with his mother and brother while trying to escape their countrys civil war.

title: The Myth of Quality Time
description: EVERY summer for many years now, my family has kept to our ritual. All 20 of us  my siblings, my dad, our better halves, my nieces and nephews  find a beach house big enough to fit the whole unruly clan. We journey to it from our different states and time zones. We tensely divvy up the bedrooms, trying to remember who fared poorly or well on the previous trip. And we fling ourselves at one another for seven days and seven nights.

title: Awash in Data, Thirsting for Truth
description: Mark Twain complained about lies, damned lies and statistics more than a century ago. Figures often beguile me, he wrote, particularly when I have the arranging of them myself.

title: A Doctor at His Daughters Hospital Bed
description: Omaha  IVE been watching the monitor for hours. Natalies asleep now and Im worried about her pulse. Its edging above 140 beats per minute again and her blood oxygen saturation is becoming dangerously low. Im convinced that shes slipping into shock. She needs more fluids. I ring for the nurse.

title: The Collateral Victims of Criminal Justice
description: SINCE the financial crisis, complaints that corporate wrongdoers suffer light penalties have become routine. One reason is the Department of Justices longstanding policy that prosecutors must consider the collateral consequences that pursuing a corporation might have on innocent employees, shareholders, pensioners and even the financial system at large.

title: Australian Leader, Opposing Gay Marriage, Faces Party and Family Opposition
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Even the prime ministers sister is unhappy with him.

title: Times Magazine Editor on Creative Apocalypse Article
description: Are creative artists thriving in the digital age? A recent magazine cover story makes the case that they are, and that a creative apocalypse never happened, despite fears and predictions that it would.

title: Adult, Autistic and Ignored
description: TWO months before she died of pancreatic cancer in November 2010, my normally strong, stoical mother broke down weeping in my arms over the fate of my autistic older brother.

title: A.F.C. East Teams on a Quest to Dethrone the Patriots
description: Before becoming the Miami Dolphins executive vice president for football operations, Mike Tannenbaum joined the organization as a consultant. He traveled to Europe to research how professional soccer teams use science to optimize performance, and now the Dolphins monitor sleep patterns, revitalize players with customized smoothies and employ a director of sports performance.

title: With a Paddle, Tennis Stars Find Theyre Up the Creek
description: With his fluid, rhythmic strokes, it is clear that Sam Querrey has a knack for table tennis. But when he hits a backhand with two hands, as he does on the tennis court, it becomes obvious that it is not his sport of choice.

title: Wealthy Gulf Nations Are Criticized for Tepid Response to Syrian Refugee Crisis
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Arab nations of the Persian Gulf have some the worlds highest per capita incomes. Their leaders speak passionately about the plight of Syrians, and their state-funded news media cover the Syrian civil war without cease.

title: A King of Sliders Surmounts a Fall
description: A recent player poll in Baseball America judged Chris Archer, the young ace of the Tampa Bay Rays, to have the best slider in the American League. Archer, a right-hander, has used the pitch to establish himself as an All-Star, and last month he fired a one-hit shutout with 11 strikeouts against the Houston Astros.

title: Weary Migrants Show Relief as They Reach Austria Safely
description: NICKELSDORF, Austria  The safer they finally felt, the calmer the thousands of refugees who crossed into Austria from Hungary on Saturday became.

title: A Spurt of No-Hitters May Not Be All That Exceptional
description: When Jake Arrieta of the Chicago Cubs threw a no-hitter last week, it was the sixth in 81 days and the 250th no-hitter of the modern era. The major league record for no-hitters in a single season is seven.

title: U.S. Open 2015: Once Again, a Late Burst Propels a Spotlight Grabber
description: Saturdays matches at Arthur Ashe Stadium began around 11:10 a.m., about 10 hours after Rafael Nadal and Fabio Fognini departed it.

title: Confederate Flags Crash Nascars Plan for a Homecoming
description: DARLINGTON, S.C.  Throwback paint schemes on racecars and retro logos and signs welcomed Nascar fans when they arrived at Darlington Raceway this weekend for the Bojangles Southern 500 Sprint Cup race. The marketing campaign was designed to make one of the most storied tracks on the circuit look like the early 1970s all over again.

title: Nathan Eovaldis Shaky Inning Proves Too Damaging as Yanks Offense Stalls
description: Before his first pitch at Yankee Stadium on Saturday afternoon, starter Nathan Eovaldi scooped up a rosin bag and patted it against his arms, creating clouds of powder. He then vigorously dug in with his foot around the pitching rubber and kicked dirt in the air, ruining the layout of a mound that was perfectly manicured just moments earlier.

title: Jets Cut 2 Quarterbacks, Leaving Rookie as Backup
description: The Jets released both of the veterans who had been vying for the backup quarterback job, for now leaving the rookie Bryce Petty as the only healthy option behind Ryan Fitzpatrick for next weeks season opener against Cleveland.

title: The Pirates Winning Path Is Blocked by a Familiar Foe
description: ST. LOUIS  Francisco Cervelli was raised by the Yankees, who traded him to the Pittsburgh Pirates last fall after parts of seven seasons in the majors. Cervelli reported to his new team in spring training, and it was as if nothing had changed.

title: In Case You Missed It: Top Articles of the Week
description: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from Aug. 28 to Sept. 3.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Rhoda Lerman, Writer Who Defied Labels, Dies at 79
description: Rhoda Lerman, whose critically praised novels melded history with contemporaneity, mythology with social criticism, feminism with a Jewish sensibility and snark with seriousness, died on Aug. 30 at her home in Port Crane, N.Y., near Binghamton. She was 79.

title: Hillary Clinton Urges Cooperation on Inquiry Into Her Emails, as She Finds Joy Elsewhere
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  Hillary Rodham Clinton said Saturday that everyone involved in the investigation into her email practices as secretary of state should cooperate and insisted that she was running her campaign with joy even as questions persist around why she conducted government business on a private server.

title: Ben Kuroki Dies at 98; Japanese-American Overcame Bias to Fight for U.S.
description: Ben Kuroki, a decorated Japanese-American gunner in the Army Air Forces of World War II, who was hailed on the American homeland at a time when tens of thousands of Japanese-Americans were confined to internment camps as supposed security risks, died on Tuesday in Camarillo, Calif. He was 98.

title: On the Trail of a Mentally Ill Brother, Lost in Brooklyn
description: Ever since they were children, Aukejshia Boyce-Gaskins made sure to look out for her younger half brother, Birshon Daley.

title: Scenes of Departure and Arrival
description: On Saturday, migrants in Vienna crowded onto trains headed for Munich.

title: Pope Francis Visit to U.S. Is His First Ever, for Several Reasons
description: During his first private meeting with Pope Francis in the Vatican two years ago, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan said, the pope took out an atlas with a map of the United States and asked Cardinal Dolan, the archbishop of New York, to point out the various regions and cities and talk about how they differed.

title: Matt Harvey Weighs In (Gingerly) Over Talk of His Being Shut Down
description: MIAMI  Dr. James Andrews, the surgeon who performed Tommy John surgery on Matt Harvey in 2013, called him recently to check in. Andrews had been in contact with Scott Boras, Harveys agent, and he told Harvey that he was now recommending limiting him to 180 innings this season, his first full year back pitching after the surgery.

title: Powerful Auburn Overcomes Its Quarterbacks Misadventures
description: ATLANTA  Auburns defense was a marauder for three quarters on Saturday.

title: Rickie Fowler, at Four Shots Back, Relishes Thrill of the Chase
description: NORTON, Mass.  If Rickie Fowler did not have two more rounds to play at TPC Boston, he would be perfectly at home at Jumptown, a sky-diving club in Orange, Mass., about an hour west of Boston. Fowler is an adrenaline seeker, and when his golf game is in high gear, the rush he gets rivals any feeling he experienced on the motorcycle dirt tracks or Pacific wave sets of his youth.

title: Guatemalans Ousted President Otto Prez Molina. Now What?
description: GUATEMALA CITY  Sergio Bacini is a music producer, a tattoo artist and a D.J. When the five-month protest movement that swept out Guatemalas president last week seemed to flag during the summer, he knew how to revive it: He organized a rock concert.

title: Womens Films Do Not Tell the Whole Tale of Telluride
description: TELLURIDE, Colo.  Film festivals have sharply different personalities. The one that got underway here on Friday is wealthy and white, and it is the Tiffany of festivals, as its promotional materials accurately maintain.

title: Michael Mmoh Is a Rising Hope for Several Countries
description: Novak Djokovic was a little late to his hitting date with the young American player Michael Mmoh at Wimbledon in July. But Boris Becker, Djokovics coach, was there, and he and Mmoh reminisced while waiting for Djokovic to arrive.

title: Pope Francis U.S. Visit Schedule
description: Daily events during the popes East Coast trip.

title: Mets Bartolo Colon Extends Scoreless Streak With Shutout of Marlins
description: MIAMI  Bartolo Colon sat on a bench in the Mets dugout and smiled as his teammates celebrated and showered Wilmer Flores with pats on the helmet. Colon looked like a proud father.

title: News Quiz: What You May Have Missed This Summer
description: This was a summer when the news did not stop. Test your knowledge about important international events that you may have missed.

title: Playoff Pursuit Is the Mets, but the Career Is Matt Harveys
description: Matt Harvey has the stuff and the strut of an ace. He pitches like a leading man and carries himself that way. The Mets seem bound for the postseason, and nobody should crave that stage more than Harvey.

title: Julissa Mejia, Marcos Ortiz Jr.
description: Julissa Mejia and Marcos Orlando Ortiz Jr. are to be married Sunday at Jellyfish Restaurant in Punta Cana, the Dominican Republic. Cristian Castillo, a cousin of the groom who is a councilman of the Peravia Province of the Dominican Republic, is to officiate.

title: Rebecca Morrow, Matthew Farrell
description: Rebecca Morrow, the daughter of Eve Morrow and Dr. Richard B. Morrow of Searingtown, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Matthew Thomas Farrell, a son of Dr. Deborah M. Farrell and Dr. Leo D. Farrell of Mechanicsburg, Pa. Caroline Z. Bazzini, who was appointed by Brookville, N.Y., as the villages marriage officer, is to officiate at the Glen Cove Mansion in Glen Cove, N.Y.

title: Meredith Wing, Michael Lazar
description: Meredith Allison Wing, the daughter of Joan W. Wing and Darman A. Wing of Boxford, Mass., was married Saturday evening to Michael Eric Lazar, a son of Carol A. Lazar and Dr. Harold L. Lazar of Chestnut Hill, Mass. Rabbi Albert Axelrad officiated at the Crane Estate in Ipswich, Mass.

title: Erica Beal, John Barnhardt
description: Erica Mae Beal, the daughter of Valerie Lancaster Beal and Bernard Beal of New York, was married Saturday to John Anthony Barnhardt, a son of Diana S. Barnhardt and Michael J. Barnhardt of Lake Hallie, Wis. The brides father, a Baptist minister, officiated at Pippin Hill Farm and Vineyards in North Garden, Va.

title: Sophia McKinley, Gregory Jordan
description: Dr. Sophia Kim McKinley and Gregory Eric Jordan are to be married Sunday at the Mass Audubon Habitat Education Center and Wildlife Sanctuary in Belmont, Mass. Dr. Jessica Hu, a friend of the bride who received a one-day solemnization certificate from Massachusetts, is to officiate.

title: Emily Pitlick, David Mallen
description: Emily Rachel Pitlick and David Jay Mallen are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Lyle Fishman at the Park Hyatt Hotel in Washington.

title: Noah Drezner, Oren Pizmony-Levy
description: Noah Daniel Drezner and Oren Pizmony-Levy are to be married Sunday evening at the Brooklyn Grange, a rooftop farm in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Rabbi Lauren Grabelle Herrmann is to officiate.

title: Susan Lieu, Marvin Kim
description: Susan Lieu, a daughter of Tom Lieu of Santa Rosa, Calif., and the late Jennifer Ha, was married Saturday to Bukyung Kim, a son of Okjin Kim and Jeong Bon Kim of Waterloo, Ontario. Gayle Hasley, a friend of the bride and a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Ballard Bay Club in Seattle.

title: Danielle Weisberg, Adam Heller
description: Danielle Merriah Weisberg, a daughter of Gabrielle A. Weisberg and Donald J. Weisberg of Chicago, was married Saturday evening to Adam Robert Heller, the son of Cathy S. Heller and Lloyd J. Heller of New York. Rabbi Michael Sternfield officiated at the Bridgeport Art Center in Chicago.

title: Rebecca Kendrick, Gioele Mancini
description: Rebecca Linsey Kendrick, a daughter of Karen V. Grant and Kendall Kendrick Jr. of Freeport, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Gioele Mancini, the son of Cesaria Ratano Mancini and Luigi Mancini of Offenburg, Germany. Sean Lofton, a minister of the Christian Congregation of Jehovahs Witnesses, is to officiate at the NoMad Hotel in New York.

title: Brooke Smith and Umut Ozaydinli: The Trans-Atlantic Acid Test
description: Brooke DeVard Smith and Umut Hilmi Ozaydinli were married Monday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Edwina Townes, a staff member of the New York City Clerks office, officiated.

title: Christina Chennat,  Ravi Goel
description: Christina Megan Chennat and Dr. Ravi Desh Goel were married Saturday in Marlton, N.J. Pandit Sudhir Jha performed a Hindu ceremony at the Indian Cultural Center of South Jersey.

title: Caitlin Boyce, Michael Naft
description: Caitlin Ryan Boyce and Michael Jaison Naft were married Saturday at the Harvard Club in New York. Anna Saulwick, a friend of the couple who became a minister of the Universal Life Church for the occasion, officiated.

title: Emma Glidden-Lyon and Derek Birkner
description: Emma Glidden-Lyon, a daughter of Katharine H. Lyon and William T. Glidden Jr. of Topsham, Me., was married Saturday to Derek James Birkner, the son of Nancy Halpin-Birkner of Moneta, Va., and the late James R. Birkner. The Rev. Raymond Clothier performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Bridgton, Me.

title: Meimay Law,  Ryan Moreno
description: Meimay Liu Law and Ryan James Moreno were married Saturday at Montgomery Place, a house museum in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. Bobby Moreno, a cousin of the groom who became a minister in the American Fellowship Church for the occasion, officiated.

title: Kerry Minchinton, Brian Tucei
description: Kerry Ann Minchinton and Brian Matthew Nichols Tucei were married Saturday. The Rev. Michael P. Hilbert performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York, where he is an associate pastor.

title: Christina Seib and Jonathan Eccles
description: Christina Dacey Seib, a daughter of Joan Dacey Seib and Karl E. Seib of New York, is to be married Sunday in Ketchum, Idaho, to Jonathan Andrew Eccles, a son of Leni Eccles and Marriner C. Eccles of Belvedere, Calif. The brides father, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate at the Sun Valley ski resort. He will lead the bride in her vows; the grooms father will take part in the readings and lead his son in his vows.

title: Samantha Leyco, Paul Zamudio
description: Samantha Ramos Leyco, a daughter of Violeta R. Leyco and Virgilio A. Leyco of Middle Village, Queens, was married Friday to Dr. Paul Anthony Jimenez Zamudio, the son of Marilyn J. Zamudio and Romeo N. Zamudio of Jamaica Estates, Queens. The Rev. Theophane Cooney, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Immaculate Conception Church in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Chelsea Reed, Jon Radler
description: Chelsea Reed and Jon Ian Radler were married on Friday at the Broward County Circuit Court in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where Mark A. Speiser, the administrative judge in the courts probate division, officiated.

title: Kerry Brennan and John Lee II: Their Love Went South, Then North
description: Kerry Jane Brennan and John Joon Lee II were married Saturday by the Rev. Thomas A. Enneking at Nativity of Our Lord Catholic Church in St. Paul.

title: Stevie Glaberson, Eduardo Ortiz
description: Stephanie Kaufman Glaberson, the daughter of Judith A. Kaufman and William B. Glaberson of Scarsdale, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Eduardo Francisco Ortiz, the son of Cristalia A. Blanco of Silver Springs, Md. Evan Glaberson, a Universal Life minister and the brother of the bride, is to officiate at Camp Kinder Ring in Hopewell Junction, N.Y.

title: Charlene Ong and Amar Dhand
description: Dr. Charlene Jennifer Ong and Dr. Amar Dhand are to be married Sunday. Harris Bloom, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Soho Grand Hotel in New York.

title: Ann Vale, Benjamin Schmidt
description: Dr. Ann Sheridan Vale, the daughter of Elizabeth S. Vale and Anthony C.H. Vale of Haverford, Pa., was married Saturday at her parents house to Benjamin Moshe Schmidt, the son of Susan E. Schmidt and Azriel Schmidt of Bryn Mawr, Pa. They were joined under Pennsylvanias self-uniting marriage statute.

title: Lindsey Healy,  Stephen Lambers III
description: Lindsey Catherine Healy, a daughter of Donna M. Healy and Christopher J. Healy of Troy, Mich., was married Monday to Stephen Lambert Lambers III, a son of Marion G. Lambers and Mr. Lambers Jr. of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. Earl Bolam, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Detroit Boat Club, where the couple met six years ago.

title: Andrea Nixon, George Wilson II
description: Andrea Nicole Nixon and George Stephen Wilson II were married Friday evening at Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J. Kim Kirkley, a Universal Brotherhood minister, led a Christian ceremony.

title: Monica Arcila, Scott Grant
description: Monica Melissa Arcila and Dr. Scott Bryan Grant are to be married Sunday in Shrewsbury, N.J. The Rev. Idida Rodriguez, a minister ordained by the OneSpirit Interfaith Seminary, is to officiate at Shadowbrook at Shrewsbury, an event space.

title: Timothy Neumann and Thomas Mershon
description: Timothy Carter Neumann and Thomas William Mershon were married Saturday in the Preserved Smith Memorial Chapel of the Rowe Camp & Conference Center in Rowe, Mass. The Rev. Douglas Wilson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Deborah Rogal, Wei Hu
description: Deborah White Rogal, a daughter of Margaret W. Rogal and Owen S. Rogal of Hancock, Vt., was married Saturday to Wei Hu, the son of Melly Hu and Shen G. Hu of Manhattan. The Rev. Charlotte White, a minister of the United Church of Christ and an aunt of the bride, led a nondenominational ceremony at Audreys Farmhouse Bed and Breakfast in Wallkill, N.Y.

title: Alexandra Moreland and Donald Isaac Jr.
description: Alexandra Marie Moreland, a daughter of Cynthia J. Moreland and Ira L. Moreland of Atlanta, and Donald Lee Isaac Jr., the son of Denise L. Isaac and Donald L. Isaac Sr., of Washington ,are to be married Sunday by the Rev. Raphael G. Warnock, the senior pastor at the Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta.

title: Kelsey Johnson, Andrew Miller
description: Dr. Kelsey Ann Johnson, a daughter of B. Kristine Johnson and Robbin S. Johnson of Wayzata, Minn., was married Saturday to Dr. Andrew Frederick Miller, the son of Mary Helen Dye Miller of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late David H. Miller. The Rev. Gary L. Langness, a Lutheran pastor, officiated at the home of the brides parents.

title: Jaclyn Gilman  Benjamin Reich
description: Jaclyn Falice Gilman and Benjamin Douglas Reich are to be married Sunday at Temple Beth Elohim in Wellesley, Mass. Rabbi Henry Zoob is to perform the ceremony.

title: Abigail Feuer, Daniel Blum
description: Abigail Eve Shanus Feuer and Daniel Jason Blum are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Jeffrey Segelman at the Boscobel House and Gardens, a museum in Garrison, N.Y.

title: Peri Rosenstein, Jeffrey Yaffa
Brooke Raphael, Jeffrey Gewirtz
description: Brooke Silver Raphael and Jeffrey Brian Gewirtz are to be married Sunday evening by Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz at Temple Adath Yeshurun in Syracuse.

title: Pooja Badlani, Tom Chuaypradit
description: Pooja Gopal Badlani and Tom Chuaypradit are to be married Sunday. Madhu Sharma, the Hindu chaplain at Duke University, will officiate at the Lofts at Union Square, an event space in High Point, N.C. In August, the couple had a Thai marriage ceremony at the Vajiradhammapadip Temple in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Grace Lo and Kevin Kim
description: Dr. Grace Chuoyan Lo, a daughter of Joanne Lo and Yue-Kai Lo of Shanghai, is to be married Sunday to Kevin Daejin Kim, a son of Soonbin Kim and Jae Deok Kim of Brooklyn. Drew Hyun, a pastor affiliated with the Evangelical Covenant Church, is to officiate at the Roundhouse at Beacon Falls, in Beacon, N.Y.

title: Erin Murray, John Manning
description: Erin McInerney Murray, a daughter of Catherine M. Murray and Edward F. Murray of Cheyenne, Wyo., was married Friday to Dr. John Daniel Manning, a son of Lee A. Manning and James G. Manning of Bozeman, Mont. The Rev. Carl Beavers performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Mountains Catholic Church in Jackson Hole, Wyo.

title: Eliza Swift and Andrew Welborn:The One Who Didnt Get Away
description: Eliza Anne Swift and Andrew Michael Welborn were married Friday evening on the rooftop of Lacuna Artist Studio Lofts in Chicago. J. F. Harris, a Universal Life minister, stand-up comedian and friend of the groom, officiated.

title: Thailands Military Junta Rejects Draft Constitution
description: BANGKOK  Thailands military junta on Sunday extended its rule by at least seven months when its handpicked reform council rejected a constitution written by its own drafting committee.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: This has to be an eye-opener on how messed up the situation in Europe is now.

title: Editors Note: September 6, 2015
description: BOOK REVIEW

title: Flicker of Hope for Children With Rare and Devastating Disease
description: LEESBURG, Ala.  Once a year, Crystal and Jonathan Bedford drive 1,000 miles from their home in Texas to rural Alabama, their three children in tow. Beside a wooded lake, they huddle with other families whose children have the same extremely rare genetic disorder that their 5-year-old daughter, Marley, has.

title: Hope for Rhizo Kids
description: Parents of children with RCDP, a very rare, terminal form of dwarfism, hope a potential new drug originally developed to treat Alzheimers will help their kids, too.

title: As Europe Grasps for Answers, More Migrants Flood Its Borders
description: HEGYESHALOM, Hungary  Throughout the day on Sunday, train after packed train arrived at this border town from Budapest, the passengers smoothly shifting to a gleaming Austrian train on the opposite side of the platform and being whisked on to Vienna and beyond  13,000 of them in the first 36 hours after Hungary allowed throngs of refugees and migrants to travel toward Germany.

title: On the Barbecue Patrol, a Summer Ritual for New York Police
description: After hours of checking on boisterous barbecues and other loud gatherings in the Bronx, making sure none grew out of control, Officers Joseph Helgerson and Edwin Vega stopped alongside their lieutenants car to check in. It was 11:07 p.m. on a Saturday.

title: Steve Jobs Receives Warm Reception at Telluride Film Festival
description: TELLURIDE, Colo.  Before the world premiere of his new film on Saturday night, Danny Boyle told a crowd of 650 here at the Telluride Film Festival not to expect a representational biopic. Rather, he said, his Steve Jobs is a meant to be a direct signal from inside the Apple co-founders mind, with all of its wonders and all of its horrors.

title: Migrants on the Move Across Europe
description: The decision by Austria and Germany to throw open their borders and take in thousands of refugees does not seem to have stilled the movement or refugees across the continent.

title: Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Head of D.N.C., Backs Iran Nuclear Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz, the chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, announced on Sunday that she will support the nuclear agreement with Iran that has roiled many in her Florida district.

title: Family Balks at Talk by Russia to Move Rachmaninoffs Remains
description: VALHALLA, N.Y.  It was quiet beneath the mountain laurel shrubs shielding the grave of the composer Sergei Rachmaninoff from the late-summer sun. The furor is 4,500 miles away, in Russia, its indelible voice in every melodic line he wrote  a different Russia, a different sensibility, a different life, different time.

title: Ousted as Gay, Aging Veterans Are Battling Again for Honorable Discharges
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  When the Army discharged Pvt. Donald Hallman in 1955 for being what it called a Class II homosexual, the 21-year-old was so scared of being an outcast that he burned all his military records, save for a single dog tag he hid away.

title: Netanyahu Rejects Calls for Israel to Accept Syrian Refugees
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday rejected calls from opposition politicians for Israel to accept refugees from Syria, saying that Israel was a very small country that lacks demographic and geographic depth. He also said that plans to construct a fence along the eastern border with Jordan would go ahead.

title: 1940: United Regime Is Antonescus Rumanian Goal
description: BUCHAREST Following the abdication this morning [Sept. 6] of King Carol II in favor of his eighteen-year-old son, Prince Michael, Rumania has been thrown into a state of wild excitement, and the general feeling here is that anything may happen within the next forty-eight hours.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (13) ARTHUR & GEORGE In the time it took to puff on his pipe, Sherlock Holmes would have discerned everything: the eavesdropper at the private club, as well as his name, political persuasion and birthplace  all from the dust on his shoes. But Arthur Conan Doyle? Shockingly oblivious, a detractor declares in this three-part Masterpiece Mystery! presentation. If you pursue your interest in the Edalji case, youll be judged by his high standards, and judged harshly, the man chides Holmess creator. But if you fall short, as you are bound to do, youll taint not only yourself but the worlds favorite consulting detective. Edalji is the titular George, an Anglo-Indian solicitor imprisoned for mutilating livestock  and threatening schoolgirls with worse  in 1903 Staffordshire. He longs to be exonerated for crimes he maintains he did not commit, and Conan Doyle wagers his reputation that Edaljis conviction was racially motivated. Martin Clunes, above, and Arsher Ali star in this adaptation of Julian Barness fact-based novel, which unveils Conan Doyles personal life as he contemplates a future with his true love after his wifes death. Charles Edwards plays Conan Doyles secretary, Alfred Wood  in other words, his Dr. Watson. Theres just enough Sherlockian fun  Conan Doyles deductive abilities being compared unfavorably with those of his creation, Woods alarm when Conan Doyle considers a false beard as a disguise  to make the case for Arthur & George, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times.

title: For Now, Taubman Sale Means No Gift for Detroit Museum
description: Few institutions have benefited more from the generosity of A. Alfred Taubman, a businessman from Michigan, than the Detroit Institute of Arts, where a wing bears his name. Before his death in April, Mr. Taubman, a philanthropist and shopping-mall magnate who at one point was the principal owner of the auction house Sothebys, provided the museum with tens of millions of dollars and about two dozen artworks that are part of its permanent collection.

title: Alleviating Pain, Delivering Love
description: Casey Barnes was born with multiple life-limiting conditions, among them quadriplegia cerebral palsy. She cannot move, suck, swallow, gag or blink. To the untrained or uncomprehending eye, she looks uncommunicative, inert, a small person with extreme breathing problems (her airway must be suctioned every 15 minutes or so). When we met, I had no idea how to interact with or even how to be around her, let alone how to approach her with a camera.

title: Vienna Welcomes Refugees
description: Austrians received refugees with food, drinks and applause as they arrived by train from Hungary this weekend.

title: 1890: Whisky and Tea Drinkers Worried
description: Western distillers are protesting against the increases made by the Senate on imported liquors. They fear the next step will be a rise of the internal revenue tax on domestic whiskies, in order to meet a possible deficit in the revenues of the Government. The Senate to-day adopted an amendment to the Tariff bill offered by Mr. Evarts as follows. It relates to stock held in London particularly:  All teas the growth or produce of countries east of the Cape of Good Hope when imported from places west of the Cape of Good Hope shall pay duty 10 per centum ad valorem. Teas entered for consumption or for warehouse in any country intermediate between the country of export and the United States shall be treated as teas imported from such intermediate country and berated for duty accordingly.  The New York Herald, European Edition, September 7, 1890

title: Republicans Criticize Hillary Clinton and Discuss Kentucky Clerks Case
description: It was a relatively quiet Sunday on the talk shows, with candidates likely saving their energies (or enjoying a holiday) before a burst of activity on Labor Day, the traditional start of the campaign season. In truth, the presidential campaign has been blowing at near gale force for months.

title: Montreal Symphony Orchestra Plans U.S. Tour
description: The Montreal Symphony Orchestra will embark in March on its most extensive tour of the United States in 25 years, the ensemble announced on Sunday, with concerts planned in 10 cities from coast to coast under the baton of its music director, Kent Nagano.

title: Workers Organize, but Dont Unionize, to Get Protection Under Labor Law
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  Jorge Porras used to report to his carwash job here most mornings at 8:15 a.m., but he said that his boss often did not let him clock in until 11, when customers frequently began streaming in. Many days he was paid for just six hours, he said, even though he worked nine and a half hours.

title: Lynn Walker Huntley, Lawyer in Prominent Civil Rights Issues, Dies at 69
description: Lynn Walker Huntley, a lawyer who was deeply involved in a wide spectrum of civil rights cases and causes, including capital punishment, race relations and employment discrimination, died Aug. 30 at her home in Atlanta. She was 69.

title: Talibans New Leader in Afghanistan Moves to Quash Dissent
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In one of the first tests of his leadership, the head of Afghanistans Taliban militants is moving aggressively against a breakaway faction in the south of the country, according to Afghan and Taliban officials.

title: At New York Live Arts, Thomas O. Kriegsmann Is Ready to Take Risks
description: Maverick. Radical. Transformer. Socialist. Re-animator.

title: Carrie Brownstein, Carly Rae Jepsen and Others on First-Time Cultural Experiences
description: What would you see for the first time, all over again? The critics have already weighed in. The Times asked cultural figures, as well as readers, for their choices. Read about their first encounters with The Rite of Spring, dinner at Momofuku and . . . cat videos.

title: Review: Lauren Groffs Fates and Furies Features a Wife Whos Full of Surprises
description: Fates and Furies is Lauren Groffs third novel, and its sure to be regarded as her most approachable book thus far  if only as some measure of the others extreme peculiarity. In The Monsters of Templeton, she wrote a genealogical mystery about a thinly disguised version of Cooperstown, N.Y. (Ms. Groffs birthplace), and put a dead, 50-foot-long prehistoric monster in the local lake for good measure. Arcadia followed a hippie commune, mostly through the 1960s and 70s, so vividly that the smells of the place wafted off the page.

title: Buzzr Presents the Evolution of Game Shows and Ourselves
description: A new channel called Buzzr might seem to have the fairly modest aim of catering to viewers who enjoy watching old game shows, but a programming stunt it is running this week suggests a much more ambitious purpose. This channel, if inadvertently, is documenting a startling acceleration in the pace of human evolution.

title: Review: The Odyssey Takes a Populist Turn as a Musical
description: A selfie with a celebrity has replaced the autograph as a coveted prize, but a selfie with a legendary hero, the great Greek warrior Odysseus? Well, that would beat Beyonc, hands down. A lucky young prince gains such a digital trophy in the brash, funny and heart-stirring musical version of Homers The Odyssey being presented by the Public Theater at the Delacorte Theater through Monday night.

title: Steven Matz Has Strong Start, but Mets Fall to Marlins
description: MIAMI  Steven Matz, sweat dotting his forehead, marched off the mound and paced the infield grass. With a stern expression, he watched the ball clear the wall in left-center field, then returned to the mound.

title: Sherpa and Winter on Fire Display Good Timing at Telluride Film Festival
description: TELLURIDE, Colo.  There is something spooky about Sherpa and timing.

title: Eugenie Bouchard Withdraws From U.S. Open
description: Eugenie Bouchards entry into the second week of the United States Open was supposed to have coincided with the return of her new coaching consultant, Jimmy Connors, who had planned to rejoin her if she reached the fourth round.

title: West Indian American Day Parade Comes Together One Costume at a Time
description: Reisha Maynard-Holder meticulously cut patterns for a collar out of foam rubber as a fan whirred in the sweltering heat. Next, she turned her attention to feathers, attaching them to the collars one at a time with a glue gun. It was another grueling evening in a monthslong effort to create some of the most elaborate and spectacular costumes seen on the streets of New York.

title: Marin Cilic, an Unsung Champion, Finds His Rhythm and Reaches the Quarterfinals
description: Marin Cilic is the defending United States Open champion. Remember that.

title: Having Debts
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Happy Labor Day! Wordplay wishes everyone a relaxing holiday.

title: Serena Williamss Victory Sets Up a Showdown With Her Sister
description: At age 35, Venus Williams has been making a gallant effort to win an eighth major tennis title, her last one coming seven years ago at Wimbledon. But if she is to do it at this years United States Open, it will come at a heavy cost. She will have to deny her younger sister the rare opportunity to win a Grand Slam.

title: Jeb Bush Recommends Tony Campos for a White House Job
description: In the 1980s, Jeb Bush encountered a number of local Republicans in South Florida who were eager to eager to be associated with him and his powerful family, including Tony Campos.

title: The Bushes Thank Tony Campos
description: In 1999, two members of the Bush family wrote to Tony Campos to share their appreciation for his plans for a tribute to Dorothy Walker Bush.

title: Dorothy Walker Bush Honored as a Great Floridian
description: Tony Campos sought and gained a special recognition from the state of Florida for Dorothy Walker Bush, Jeb Bushs grandmother, about a decade after her death.

title: Review: Electric Zoo, a Menagerie Designed for Dancing
description: The seventh annual Electric Zoo, the Labor Day weekend electronic dance music festival on Randalls Island, was billed as Electric Zoo: Transformed. The sound-and-lights superstructure of its redesigned main stage was shaped like a phoenix. Actually, it was Electric Zoo persevering and slightly shrunken, with fewer performers, fewer stages and shorter schedules on most of them  a lineup of 85 acts, not the more than 100 at Electric Zoos since 2011.

title: Ivan Nova Leads Yankees Over Rays
description: During the 2013 off-season, Yankees scouts homed in on Brian McCann, envisioning a plethora of home runs off his bat soaring into the short right-field porch in Yankee Stadium.

title: Electric Zoo
description: Scenes from the music festival on Randalls Island.

title: Apple Unveils New Products, and Stephen Colbert Returns to Late Night
description: China reports a basket of monthly data this week that is expected to provide a clearer picture of how much its economic growth is slowing. On Tuesday, it will release trade figures for August; exports have been flat so far this year, and imports declined 15 percent in the first seven months of 2015. Other reports include inflation figures on Wednesday and industrial output, investment and retail sales on Saturday. Investors will also be watching on Monday for August data on Chinas foreign exchange reserves. While still the worlds largest, Chinas reserves are expected to have declined after the surprise devaluation last month of its currency, the renminbi, which has raised concerns over capital outflows.  Neil Gough

title: Jeb Bush, Family Ties and a Museum That Never Materialized
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla.  When Jeb Bush set out to build a political base of his own in South Florida three decades ago, he did not lack for new friends. He was a magnet for a long line of Republicans eager to be associated with him and his powerful family, including a Cuban immigrant and former corrections officer named Tony Campos.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 7
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

title: Productivity and Pay
description: Still in Sydney (next stop Tokyo), where its much too beautiful a day to sit inside blogging. But I did want to flag an excellent report by Josh Bivens and Larry Mishel on the productivity-pay gap.

title: Judd Winicks Age-Appropriate Return to Comic-Strip Roots
description: Judd Winick is ready for his reboot.

title: Caijing Journalists Shaming Signals Chinas Growing Control Over News Media
description: HONG KONG  When the Chinese Ministry of Public Security arrested nearly 200 people at the end of August for spreading rumors, one of the most prominent targets was Wang Xiaolu, a reporter for the respected business magazine Caijing.

title: New Apple TV Is Said to Focus on Games, Challenging Traditional Consoles
description: Apple stumbled into the games business almost by accident not long after it released the iPhone in 2007, igniting a new multibillion-dollar mobile games industry in the process.

title: A Train Journey From Communism to Freedom, Almost Ended in Hungary
description: More than three decades ago, my mother, grandmother and I boarded a train in communist Romania, armed with the papers my mother had painstakingly gathered in an effort to give me a better life. I was 5 years old, and I had been told we were going on a holiday to Paris. I realized something was wrong when my surrogate grandfather Tata Geo (Father Geo) broke into sobs as we left the house.

title: Chinas Military Cutbacks
description: China announced that it would cut 300,000 troops, its largest reduction in nearly two decades.

title: Celebrating Bud Collins, a Tennis Treasure Told in Words and Pants
description: Across the decades, Bud Collins had a standard line for when someone  typically a newspaper competitor  would rush over and wonder if he had a moment to answer a question. He would cheerily look up from his keyboard and say, Ask two.

title: German Quota System Highlights Possible Path and Pitfalls for Handling Crisis
description: MUNICH  Rania al-Hamawi had gone to sleep on Saturday on a clean, bright blue cot alongside her three sons and another 1,700 people who had made the arduous journey to the Bavarian capital from Syria and other strife-ridden countries. But when she woke on Sunday, half the beds in the cavernous conference center-turned-migration camp were empty.

title: Out of Perceived Weakness Is Born an Act of Aggression
description: Hit to your opponents backhand. For generations, that was considered the most foolproof tactic in tennis.

title: The Crowding-Out Effect of Gargantuan Movies
description: Hollywood had one of its best summers ever at the domestic box office, but it was a sharply lopsided victory. Studios either thrived or withered, an outcome that reflects the winner-take-all nature of the mass-appeal movie business.

title: Another Hot Stroke: The Drop Shot
description: The inside-out forehand is not the only high-risk, high-reward shot in vogue on the ATP Tour. The drop shot has also become a weapon of choice.

title: Greenlands Farmers Torn Over Tapping Pristine Land for Mineral Riches
description: QASSIARSUK, Greenland  Carl and Ellen Frederiksen gazed anxiously at a spot on the snow-flecked mountain behind their village. The sheepdogs had been running back and forth, and they feared a lamb was trapped on one of the slopes.

title: Activists Say Police Abuse of Transgender People Persists Despite Reforms
description: New Years revelers clamored outside the window of Shagasyia Diamonds apartment in the Bronx the day she was arrested.

title: Time Warner Cable Plans Channel Dedicated to Pope Francis Visit
description: Pope Francis will not be hard to find on television during his visit to the United States.

title: When Finding Housing Is a Job in Itself
description: Six years ago I went into the New York City shelter system. For 11 months, I searched for apartments like crazy. I had few options. I had just come out of a psychiatric hospital. I had a 4-year-old son and was pregnant with my daughter. I had a housing voucher and was living off of Supplementary Security Income (a Social Security program) and food stamps. I went in and out of real estate offices until I found an apartment at the western edge of the Bronx, in the River Park Towers.

title: Experts Reject Official Account of How 43 Mexican Students Were Killed
description: MEXICO CITY  An international committee of experts reviewing the case of 43 missing college students whose disappearance last fall traumatized Mexico said Sunday that there was no evidence to support the governments conclusion that the students were executed by a drug gang that then burned the bodies to ashes in a garbage dump.

title: Threat to Arizonas Salt River Horses Spurs New Battle Over Western Lands
description: PHOENIX  Soon after federal officials announced the imminent capture of 100 or so horses within the boundaries of a national forest near here  to be sold at auction, condemned and destroyed, or otherwise disposed of  a resourceful cadre of self-appointed guardians issued a desperate call for action.

title: Visiting 99 Counties in Iowa Doesnt Get Candidates as Far as It Used to
description: ROCK RAPIDS, Iowa  In a state that prizes retail campaigning, nothing is more revered than the full Grassley  a politicians visit to all of Iowas 99 counties, named for the states peripatetic senior senator, Charles E. Grassley.

title: Yoenis Cespedes Wows the Mets Underhand, Overhand and Many Other Ways
description: During spring training in 2012, when Yoenis Cespedes had just arrived in the United States from Cuba and was still getting to know his teammates on the Oakland Athletics, he started doing a trick they had never seen: He would throw the ball underhand with stunning velocity, movement and accuracy. Like a softball player.

title: Appeal Filed in Kim Daviss Contempt Ruling
description: Lawyers for Ms. Davis, the Kentucky county clerk who was jailed last week, filed a notice of appeal on the grounds that her right to due process had been violated.

title: Jailed Kentucky Clerk Starts Federal Appeal
description: The Kentucky county clerk who was jailed for defying a federal court order to issue marriage licenses to gay couples has begun the process of appealing the judges ruling that landed her there, her lawyers said on Sunday.

title: Guatemalans Head to Polls Days After Presidents Ouster
description: MIXCO, Guatemala  Guatemalans voted on Sunday in presidential elections, disgusted by corruption and disheartened by their choices just five days after a wave of mass protests forced President Otto Prez Molina from office.

title: Matt Harvey Says He Will Pitch On
description: For three days, the debate over Matt Harveys innings limit raged on in the news media. His agent, Scott Boras, and his boss, General Manager Sandy Alderson, laid out their sides publicly, and Mets fans hammered Harvey on social media for not definitively saying, during a news conference Saturday, that he would pitch into the postseason.

title: Jean Darling, Child Actress in Our Gang Series, Dies at 93
description: Jean Darling, who appeared in the Our Gang comedy films as a child and performed in the original Broadway production of Carousel, died on Friday in Rdermark, Germany. She was 93.

title: Best Move for Matt Harvey: Shield Arm, and Ears
description: Good God, the kid has gone pusillanimous on us. A coward, a phony, a fugazi. As a wealthy 60-something tabloid columnist puts it, Mets pitcher Matt Harvey is quitting on his stool.

title: The Train to Germany
description: Syrian migrants took a train from Austria to their final destination: Germany.

title: Beyond 2 Black Champions, a Void for the U.S.T.A.
description: Identifying the next great African-American talent is tricky business for the United States Tennis Association.

title: U.S. Revamping Rebel Force Fighting ISIS in Syria
description: WASHINGTON  In an acknowledgment of severe shortcomings in its effort to create a force of moderate rebels to battle the Islamic State in Syria, the Pentagon is drawing up plans to significantly revamp the program by dropping larger numbers of fighters into safer zones as well as providing better intelligence and improving their combat skills.

title: Where Both Shredders and Sharpshooters Go to Shop
description: CHURUBUSCO, N.Y.  Three miles from the Canadian border, along a remote stretch of highway where giant wind turbines fill the sky, Dicks Country Store & Music Oasis is a hardy survivor. Better known as Dicks Groceries, Gas, Guns & Guitars, this North Country mainstay has been in business since 1962 thanks to its hybrid retail strategy and its role as a community hub.

title: Kendall Fullers Ties With Virginia Tech Are Rooted in Family
description: BLACKSBURG, Va.  Kendall Fuller said that his earliest experience playing football was the flag football league his parents put him in at age 6 or 7. To hear his parents tell it, though, it is not an unequivocally happy memory.

title: No. 1 Is Slipping From a Fading Rory McIlroy
description: NORTON, Mass.  It was like watching the tennis superstar Roger Federer practice hours before a night match at the United States Open, only every stroke that Rory McIlroy, a friend of Federers, took on Sunday morning counted. Several dozen fans made it to the first hole at TPC Boston in time to watch McIlroy, the world No. 1 for at least another 24 hours, begin his third round at the Deutsche Bank Championship.

title: No Foul Mouths on This Field: Football With a New Age Twist
description: RENTON, Wash.  Jimmy Graham, an all-star tight end, quickly learned things were different with the Seattle Seahawks after he arrived this spring from the New Orleans Saints in an off-season trade.

title: Andy Murray Keeps Winning, and Resting and Recuperating
description: As he marches through the United States Open while battling a cold, Andy Murray talks to The New York Times about rest, recuperation and recovery. Murray has defeated Nick Kyrgios, Adrian Mannarino and Thomaz Bellucci, and he plays Kevin Anderson in a fourth-round match Monday.

title: Masters of Sex Recap: Libbys Last Stand and Bills Admission
description: Season 3, Episode 9, High Anxiety

title: Shaped by Camp, Alumni Fight to Prevent Its Move
description: RED HOOK, N.Y.  They were teenagers spending a summer or two at sleepaway camp, but the memories never left them. Decades later, with those campers in middle and old age, the memories are stoking a fight to keep Camp Rising Sun where it is for other generations of youngsters.

title: Heisman Trophy Watch
description: A look at the top players in contention for college footballs highest honor.

title: Life on the Streets
description: Visits with dozens of homeless New Yorkers reveal how job losses, mental health issues, substance abuse and problems with the city shelter system drove many to the streets.

title: New Yorker Festival Announces Lineup
description: The 2015 New Yorker Festival will cover comedy, race and technology with some of the leaders in each field. Featuring interviews with Toni Morrison, Lin-Manuel Miranda, Billy Joel and Jason Segel, the 16th annual festival will run from Oct. 2 to 4 in New York and include live performances, film previews and a new tech conference.

title: Obama Orders Federal Contractors to Provide Workers Paid Sick Leave
description: BOSTON  President Obama signed an executive order on Monday requiring federal contractors to provide up to seven days of paid sick leave a year, even as he accused Republican congressional leaders of endangering the economy and Republican presidential candidates of undercutting American workers.

title: Pertussis Passed to Newborns From Siblings
description: A new study has found that siblings, not mothers, are now the most common source of pertussis infection in newborns.

title: Jets Sideline Injured Dee Milliner
description: The Jets placed cornerback Dee Milliner (wrist) on short-term injured reserve on Sunday. The move prevents him from practicing for six weeks and from playing for eight. Milliner would be eligible to return for theNov. 8game against Jacksonville.

title: Carl Edwards Wins at Darlington
description: Carl Edwards led for only 15 laps but won the Southern 500, a Nascar Sprint Cup race, at Darlington Raceway in South Carolina, edging Brad Keselowski and Denny Hamlin.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 8:15 P.M. (Cinemax) LOST IN TRANSLATION (2003) An American movie star (Bill Murray), cashing in on his celebrity to make a lucrative ad in Japan, meets a young woman (Scarlett Johansson, above, with Mr. Murray) who has been temporarily deserted by her husband (Giovanni Ribisi), in this comic melodrama written and directed by Sofia Coppola, who won an Oscar for best original screenplay. As they escape the confines of the Tokyo Hyatt, something like love ensues. Mr. Murray, who received an Oscar nomination, supplies the kind of performance that seems so fully realized and effortless that it can easily be mistaken for not acting at all, Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: For us, getting another month with your child or another year or another five years  thats kind of everything.

title: Corrections: September 7, 2015
description: No corrections appeared in print.

title: Removing Plastics From Our Lakes and Oceans
description: To the Editor:

title: Should Prostitution Be Legalized?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trump Is No F.D.R.
description: To the Editor:

title: Drugs and Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Reforms Follow Protests in Ferguson
description: It has been a year since the police shooting of an African-American teenager in Ferguson, Mo., ignited the community protest and street turmoil that ultimately laid bare local governments exploitation of citizens, particularly blacks. It is no small achievement that Missouri began enforcing a series of tough new court reforms last month aimed at ending one particularly flagrant abuse: the systematic fleecing of accused traffic offenders in a revenue scheme to bolster the budgets of local governments.

title: Help for the Way We Work Now
description: WITH the presidential race well underway, Labor Day is a good time to consider how our political leaders are grappling with the many challenges facing American workers. While the next president will confront a host of important labor and economic issues, one is poised to be a particularly significant factor in 2016 and beyond: the freelance economy.

title: You Deserve a Raise Today. Interest Rates Dont.
description: For most Americans, paychecks determine living standards. Unfortunately, wages in America have long stagnated or declined for most working people, including college graduates.

title: Trump Is Right on Economics
description: So Jeb Bush is finally going after Donald Trump. Over the past couple of weeks the man who was supposed to be the front-runner has made a series of attacks on the man who is. Strange to say, however, Mr. Bush hasnt focused on whats truly vicious and absurd  viciously absurd?  about Mr. Trumps platform, his implicit racism and his insistence that he would somehow round up 11 million undocumented immigrants and remove them from our soil.

title: Sexual Attraction and Fluidity
description: Recently, Miley Cyrus told Elle UK, Im very open about it  Im pansexual.

title: Patent Law Shouldnt Block the Sale of Used Tech Products
description: American patent law should not be used to prevent consumers from reselling, altering or fixing technology products. A federal appeals court will soon hear a case that could clearly establish this principle.

title: We Dont Need Kim Davis to Be in Jail
description: KIM DAVIS, the clerk in Rowan County, Ky., went to jail last week, and there was no good reason for her to be there. Americans can expect more conflicts over religious conscience and same-sex marriage if we dont find a way to coexist peacefully. Ms. Davis has become a symbol of what happens when we dont.

title: Tesco Sells South Korean Business Homeplus for Over $6 Billion
description: LONDON  Tesco, one of the biggest British grocery store chains, said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its South Korean operations to a consortium of investors led by the Asian private equity firm MBK Partners for more than $6 billion.

title: The Whitney Taps Frank Stella for an Inaugural Retrospective at Its New Home
description: Now that the Whitney Museum of American Art has left its longtime digs on Madison Avenue for an all-new, terrace-laden building in Chelsea, its fall schedule seems likely to be read as a mission statement. What does it mean, for instance, that Frank Stella, 79, the champion of abstract art, has been tapped for the inaugural retrospective at the new building? Perhaps abstract painting is hot again, or perhaps the Whitney has entered a mature phase, celebrating not just the rise of art stars but the feat of staying artistically elevated over the years.

title: Hotel Room Work Spaces Go Casual
description: As workers become less tethered to their desks, hotels are giving their old in-room work spaces the pink slip.

title: On The Muppets, Miss Piggy Has a Talk Show and a Chatty Staff
description: LOS ANGELES  Last winter, Miss Piggy found herself doing what many middle-aged actresses are forced to do when they hit the box office skids: looking for work.

title: Melting Ice Isnt Opening Arctic to Oil Bonanza
description: TERIBERKA, Russia  The warming Arctic should already have transformed this impoverished fishing village on the coast of the Barents Sea.

title: Unwelcome Mat Is Out at Some of New Yorks Privately Owned Public Spaces
description: Like many who work on Broadway, Peter Wolf, a stage manager for 25 years, hates the Great White Way packed as it is with tourists and traffic.

title: Lung Screening May Not Push Smokers to Quit
description: The results of an admittedly small but telling new study suggest that Medicare and other insurers could be spending billions of dollars on screening smokers for lung cancer that would be better spent on helping them quit and keeping others from starting.

title: Report on Toll From Shandong Blast Is Called Coldblooded
description: Read in Chinese |

title: A Steady Flow Staggers Into Europe, Outpacing Pledges of Shelter
description: ROSZKE, Hungary  Fraying tensions snapped along Hungarys southern border on Monday as thousands more migrants staggered into the country from Serbia while European leaders scrambled to figure out what to do with them and how to stanch the flow.

title: After Fatal Attack, Turkey Strikes at Kurdish Rebels
description: ISTANBUL  The Turkish military carried out airstrikes against Kurdish insurgents on Monday, a day after what appeared to be the deadliest rebel assault since the breakdown in July of a fragile peace process with the Turkish state.

title: Novak Djokovic: The Unloved Champion
description: Novak Djokovic has spent most of the last four years as the worlds No. 1 ranked tennis player, but he is not necessarily the peoples champion. Having finally overtaken the affable, urbane superstar Roger Federer and his longtime foil, Rafael Nadal (a popular underdog), Mr. Djokovic knows the crowd is not always on his side. But that has only steeled his resolve.

title: As the Complaint Box Fills, Mayor de Blasio Adopts a Mr. Fix-It Approach
description: New York City mayors have not generally taken kindly to criticism.

title: Pakistan Says Its Drone Killed 3 Militants
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan said on Monday that three high-profile militants had been killed in the countrys violence-plagued northwest in the first strike by a locally manufactured drone.

title: China, Trying to Bolster Currency, Taps Foreign Reserves
description: HONG KONG  China is burning through its huge stockpile of foreign exchange reserves at the fastest pace yet as it seeks to prop up its currency and stem a rising tide of money flowing out of the country.

title: Barclays Sells Loan Portfolio to Investor Group Led by Goldman Sachs
description: LONDON  Barclays said on Monday that it had sold a portfolio of loans that included its secured lending business in Britain to a consortium of investors led by Goldman Sachs.

title: Chinas Turmoil May Stall Rebound in Watch Sales
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  After nearly three years of government austerity and slow economic growth, sales of luxury watches in China are showing signs of rebound  although many factors, including the recent weakening of the renminbi and stock market turmoil, could stall that momentum again.

title: Review: On HitNRun Phase One, Prince Plays Well With Others
description: In 2010, Prince said the Internets completely over as a method for distributing his music. He has changed his mind.

title: A Family Heritage
description: Giorgia Mondani followed her father and mother into a career in the world of watches.

title: Dozing on the Train
description: Dear Diary:

title: For the Wrist
description: Atelier du Bracelet Parisien creates custom watch straps in Paris.

title: New Retro by De Grisogono, a Watch Worthy of Elegance Past
description: LONDON  Think The Thomas Crown Affair (the first one, with Steve McQueen) or Yves Montand or Alain Delon strolling through a Marbella Club room. The playboys of the 1950s and 60s didnt let humdrum reality get in their way when it came to exuding sophistication and sex appeal.

title: 36 Hours in Barcelona: Hidden Gems
description: 36 Hours, a television program inspired by The Timess 36 Hours column, airs Mondays at 8 p.m. Eastern on Travel Channel. The next episode on Barcelona dovetails with our column from last year.

title: Lightning Kills at Least 28 as Storms Batter India
description: NEW DELHI  At least 28 people, many of them agricultural workers in fields, were killed by lightning when storms lashed southern and eastern India, officials said on Monday.

title: European Leaders Grapple With Response to Migrant Crisis
description: The relentless stream of migrants continued to flow into Europe, prompting France, Germany and Britain to pledge more support.

title: Times Critics Guide: What to Do This Week
description: Looking to break out of a cultural rut?

title: Scented Leather Goods, Made the 17th-Century Way
description: The cult French perfumer Francis Kurkdjian, who co-founded his eponymous fragrance house in Paris in 2009, introduces his first line of leather goods today  and, unsurprisingly, they smell quite nice. Scented leather was very obvious to me since it is a direct link to the origins of perfumery, says Kurkdjian in a reference to the 17th century, when gloves were perfumed to mask the odors left behind from the tanning process. Back then, a mixture of fragrant spices, blooms and natural oils were rubbed into the leather repeatedly to ensure staying power. But for his debut collection of scented cardholders, Kurkdjian developed a long lasting, pure-oil-based formula.

title: Back-to-School Worries for Gay Parents
description: Oh, youre Mia, the camper from the other bunk said. Youre the one whos adopted and has two moms.

title: The Horses of the Salt River
description: Floating along with the current, kayakers and paddleboarders on the Salt River in Arizona might catch a glimpse of a special sight: a herd of wild horses out for a swim.

title: Israel in a Post-Deal World
description: HAIFA, Israel  THE day after six world powers reached a nuclear agreement with Iran in July, the Israeli Knessets foreign affairs and defense committee called on Israels government to continue to closely follow the precise and strict implementation of the agreement to ensure that Iran is not continuing to fool the international community as it did in the past, while strengthening the historic alliance between the United States and Israel.

title: Britain Says It Killed 3 ISIS Suspects in First Drone Strike in Syria
description: LONDON  Crossing a significant threshold in its battle with jihadist groups, Britain announced on Monday that it had conducted an armed drone strike for the first time inside Syria, killing three suspected members of the Islamic State, including two British citizens.

title: Anish Kapoor Work at Versailles Is Vandalized (Again)
description: The artist Anish Kapoors temporary installation at the Palace of Versailles was vandalized this weekend for the second time since June, this time covered in graffiti that included anti-Semitic slurs.

title: 1965: India and Pakistan Bombed
description: NEW DELHI  Jet bombers carried death and destruction to Indian and Pakistani cities today [Sept. 7] as the threat of all-out war spread across the vast subcontinent of 590 million people. Pakistan reported Indian bombers attacked cities in both East and West Pakistan, including Rawalpindi and Karachi. India said Pakistani planes attacked near Calcutta and several other cities. Thus the Indian-Pakistani confrontation  originally over the control of the small vale of Kashmir  had spread from Karachi, on the Arabian Gulf, to Calcutta, 2,000 miles east. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 8, 1965

title: Summery Cocktails From Bars Around New York City
description: Ts online managing editor Alainna Lexie Beddie celebrates the unofficial end of summer with seasonal drink recipes from bars around New York City.

title: U.S. Denies an Airstrike Killed 11 Afghan Narcotics Officers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An American airstrike may have mistakenly killed at least 11 narcotics officers in southern Afghanistan on Sunday night, Afghan officials said on Monday. But the American military denied that such an airstrike had taken place.
