description: More listings for the new season: Dance | Pop | Classical | Theater | Film | Television

description: The best stories and games are in Europe this week, but a Concacaf doubleheader on Tuesday night qualifies as must-see television for American fans.

description: Season 1, Episode 7: Whats In A Name?

title: Sun, Surf and Horses Thundering Hooves Keep a Tradition Alive in Spain
description: SANLCAR DE BARRAMEDA, Spain  Local fishermen first started racing cart horses on the beach here while waiting to unload the days catch from their boats.

title: Pop-Up Shop at Barneys to Feature a Billy Sullivan Drawing
description: It started with a casual lunch in Bridgehampton, N.Y. The textile designer Madeline Weinrib was hosting Billy Sullivan, an artist who has been a fixture of the New York art scene since the 1960s. He wanted to keep a visual diary of the scene, so he made some pastel drawings.

title: Pop and Jazz Listings and Albums for the Fall Season
description: More listings for the new season: Art | Dance | Classical | Theater | Film | Television

title: New York Chef Brothers Return Home to Detroit (and to Hot Dogs)
description: THIS IS THE TICKET, folks, says Eli Sussman. This is the jam right here. A coney has been placed in front of him on a table at American Coney Island, a red-and-white rockabillyish restaurant in downtown Detroit that could have easily doubled as the set of a White Stripes music video. In Michigan parlance, coney island essentially signifies a Greek diner, and a coney is a hot dog. And in this city, its only served one way: smothered in chili, yellow mustard and a fistful of raw white onions  no substitutions. When you look at it, you say, Oh, man, this is a terrible idea, says Elis older brother, Max. Then you eat it and youre like, I kind of want another one.

title: Cuomo Administration Lawyer Is Shot in Head Before West Indian Day Parade
description: The revelers were crowded onto Bedford Avenue in Brooklyn partaking in the annual West Indian American Day celebration early on Monday when the bullets began to fly in all directions.

title: Can You Crack the 24 Puzzle, and the 10 Puzzle That Went Viral in Japan?
description: This weeks puzzle was suggested byNishant Pappireddi, a seniorat the University of California, Berkeley, where he studies math as well asmolecular and cell biology. Id recently been introduced to Nishant by Ken Ribet, a professor at Berkeley famous for paving the way to a proof of Fermats Last Theorem. Ken considered Nishant to be one of his best students, so I asked Nishant if he had a favorite simple puzzle he might like to share on Numberplay. He responded with

title: Humanizing Technology: A History of Human-Computer Interaction
description: The march of progress in computing is a climb. Each big step forward is also a step up, so that communication is further away from the machine, more on human terms.

title: 1940: Berlin Takes Savage Attack
description: LONDON  Returning blow for blow and bomb for bomb with interest, the Royal Air Force countered with sledge-hammer attacks against Berlin early this morning [Sept. 7] in one of the heaviest raids that the focal point of Hitlerism has yet received. As the docklands of London were burning tonight in so-called retaliation raids, new forces of R.A.F. bombers swung off from their airdromes, heading eastward to let the Germans know that the fighting power of this country has only begun to make itself felt. The British bombers were still restricted by their belief that bombs should be dropped at least within the bomb sight of the target.  New York Herald Tribune, September 8, 1940

title: Exhibitions Where Moral Force Trumps Market Forces
description: The most important art events of the coming season are likely to be of a kind that dont appear on lists like this, because they arent announced far in advance. Their medium is surprise. I hope this year theyll include guerrilla actions by groups like Gulf Labor and Black Lives Matter aimed at shaking up a politically torpid art industry. I fear theyll include further assaults by ISIS on art itself. Constructive or destructive, these examples of politically motivated activism have one thing in common: They acknowledge, as our corporate-minded museums and art schools dont, that art is more than just market fodder. It is, or can be, a moral force.

title: Chosen by Mississippi Democrats, Shy Trucker Is at a Crossroad
description: JACKSON, Miss.  Only three people who had ever met this man, Robert Gray, knew that he was running in the primary for governor of Mississippi.

title: Experiencing Architecture Through Hippie Modernism and Retrospectives
description: In 1965, four artists bought seven acres in southeastern Colorado, intending to make live-in works of art. Their communal project came to be known as Drop City, where residents lived in zonohedron domes of their own creation, sometimes constructed of automobile roofs and other scavenged materials. One dome, made of a fluorescent-painted lattice filled in with Mylar panels, made the trip east in 1968 to the Brooklyn Museum, filled with a five-foot-wide, round, spinning, collaborative work of art  The Ultimate Painting  that changed composition when illuminated by strobe lights.

title: The Weeknd Tops the Billboard Charts
description: Abel Tesfaye, the once-shadowy Canadian R&B singer better known as the Weeknd, has completed his evolution from Internet triumph to full-blown pop star, hitting No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week.

title: Will Ryman Prepares His New Exhibition at Paul Kasmin Gallery
description: A recent visit to Will Rymans cavernous two-story sculpture studio on Bowery, upstairs from a restaurant supply store, delivered a jolt of drama from the first encounter, when the artist opened the door to a back room.

title: Museum of Food and Drink to Open Permanent Space in Brooklyn
description: The Museum of Food and Drink, which is opening its first brick-and-mortar location this fall, wants to change how you think about what you eat.

title: A Western Showdown With Mussels
description: COUTTS, Alberta  At an inspection station here on the border with Montana, a black dog in an orange vest briskly scoured the hull of a motorboat, her nose twitching as she investigated every crevice.

title: A Feast of Egyptian Treasures, Picasso Sculptures and Eye-Catching Toys
description: The fall exhibitions are looking very three-dimensional, and as David Letterman often used to say, I couldnt be more excited. Seriously. The shows that intrigue me most range from masterworks created in Middle Kingdom Egypt to Swedish wooden toys, the latest in Afropolitan architecture and beach-friendly kinetic sculptures. There should be a prize for anyone who sees every show.

title: National Sawdust Prepares for an Oct. 1 Opening
description: Paola Prestini, the creative and executive director of National Sawdust, stood in the spaces balcony one recent afternoon, looking over what would soon be a bustling concert hall. The speakers just came in, she said cheerfully, pointing at a rig hanging from the ceiling, still in its filmy protective covering. A geometric metal framework crisscrossed the rooms far wall, next to the hydraulic platforms that will make for a flexible stage.

title: The Tardigrade: Practically Invisible, Indestructible Water Bears
description: When scientists at the American Museum of Natural History mounted an exhibit about creatures that survive under conditions few others can tolerate, they did not have to go far to find the shows mascot.

title: Oughts Sun Coming Down: Polar Opposites, but Hand in Hand
description: Beautiful Blue Sky, a new song by the Montreal post-punk band Ought, might be the quickest way to understand what the group is all about.

title: Janet Jacksons Unbreakable Is Right on Time
description: Beyonc, Rihanna, Britney Spears, Janelle Mone, F.K.A. twigs, Tinashe, Kelela  theyd probably all admit that Janet Jackson established their 21st-century archetypes decades in advance. So in a way, Ms. Jacksons timing is appropriate for the release of Unbreakable, her first album since 2008 and the resumption of her collaboration with her longtime co-producers Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis.

title: Republicans Fear Donald Trump Is Hardening Partys Tone on Race
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans are growing increasingly concerned that Donald J. Trumps inflammatory language is damaging the party, fearing that his remarks are hardening the tone of other candidates on racial issues in ways that could repel the voters they need to take back the White House.

title: Premature Babies Study Raises Debate Over Risks and Ethical Consent
description: Two years ago, researchers in a clinical trial involving oxygen levels for the tiniest premature babies were accused by a federal watchdog agency of not properly disclosing the risks to families who participated.

title: Guatemala Comedian Wins First Round of Presidential Vote
description: GUATEMALA CITY  A comedian won the first round of voting in Guatemalas presidential election, five days after a wave of protests forced the countrys president from office.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Former Leader of Chad Hauled Into Court as Trial Resumes
description: PARIS  Shouting in protest, Chads former president was hauled by masked guards into a special court in Senegal on Monday as he began a new struggle with its judges over their right to try him on charges of crimes against humanity, torture and war crimes.

title: Flies Want Your Blood, Too
description: Q. Mosquitoes are seeking blood, but what do flies get out of biting people?

title: Networks and Cable Channels Go Mano a Mano
description: The confoundingly persistent fall television season is upon us, when the broadcast networks present their new shows like shiny toys, most of them soon to be lost or thrown away.

title: On Scream Queens and American Horror Story, Being Scary Is Terrifying
description: I can remember the last time television made me laugh, and the last time it made me cry. But I cant remember the last time a scripted TV show scared me, and that worries me, because I like a good scare. So do I have hopes for the fall season, which brings the high-profile newcomers Scream Queens and Ash vs. Evil Dead along with returning fright fare like American Horror Story?

title: Empire on Fox Has Become a Star Attraction
description: If your TV show is called Empire, there is no such thing as too much.

title: After Deflategate, the Sequel on Wheels
description: An important sporting event. Charges of impropriety involving deflation. Lots of references to pounds per square inch.

title: Jesse Plemons Moves On and On From Friday Night Lights
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Growing up in Mart, Tex., a small town of 2,000 outside of Waco, Jesse Plemons grew up on 34 acres roping and riding and playing football. But for the most part, from before he was old enough to walk, he lived life on the edge of his sofa, a play gun at his side, rewatching the mini-series Lonesome Dove, about Larry McMurtrys retired Texas Rangers and their epic adventure pushing cattle north. I was always kind of by myself wishing I was Gus, he said. The older I got I started to try and trace just how Robert Duvall and Tommy Lee Jones did what they did to me, how they made me believe they were those people. I bought every part of their world. I guess Ive sort of been chasing that honesty of theirs ever since.

title: Review: Stoned: A Doctors Case for Medical Marijuana
description: Two-legged or four-legged, some guinea pigs have more fun than others.

title: Big-Budget Blockbusters Dominate Fall Video Games
description: The twin rise of digital distribution and a robust independent scene has made video games more diverse, more rewarding and more unpredictable than at any time in the mediums history. Its usually hard to see much evidence of that, however, in the fall release schedule, which is dominated by big-budget blockbusters that too often play it safe.

title: Jets Geno Smith Is Up for Drills, but Not for Questions
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The last four weeks have given quarterback Geno Smith ample time to reflect  on his future with the Jets, on the Aug. 11 altercation that left him with a broken jaw, on his standing among his teammates  and he said he learned a valuable lesson.

title: London Theater Journal: Firebrands
description: LONDON  The plight of the immensely talented 17th-century dramatist Sister Juana Ins de la Cruz is, on one level, sadly familiar to female playwrights of today. Though it is widely acknowledged that she wrote wondrously witty and accomplished works, she could not get them produced.

title: The Detroit Graduates
description: Attention shifted away from Detroit after the bankruptcy. But for five high school students, life has moved on, sometimes in unexpected ways, as the city struggles to get back on its feet.

title: Fresh Face on TV:Yasmine Al Massri of Quantico
description: When Yasmine Al Massri read the part of Nimah Amin in Joshua Safrans Quantico, she was shocked.

title: Sandy Alderson Proposes Compromise for Mets Matt Harvey
description: WASHINGTON  Hours before the Mets began their biggest series of 2015 against the Washington Nationals on Monday, General Manager Sandy Alderson met with the teams ace, Matt Harvey, and outlined a compromise plan designed to keep Harvey as a viable, if less active, member of the starting rotation in the seasons final weeks.

title: Fresh Face on TV: Lee Jones of The Bastard Executioner
description: The key to a clean beheading, according to Lee Jones, is to come in at just the right angle. You want to come in flat, he said, so you dont have to go in and do extra chopping.

title: Fresh Face on TV: Jaina Lee Ortiz in Rosewood
description: That police officer hovering in the corner of a crime scene? In real life, hes the father of the actress Jaina Lee Ortiz. That salsa partner shes burning up a dance floor with? None other than her husband.

title: Oysters May Serve as Link in Transmission of Norovirus
description: Oysters appear to be an important link in the transmission of norovirus among humans, according to new research from China.

title: Prospect of Another Shutdown Looms as Congress Girds for Fights Over Spending
description: WASHINGTON  When Congress returns for business on Tuesday, lawmakers have scheduled a mere 12 legislative days to find a bipartisan compromise to keep the government open, vote on one of the most contentious foreign policy matters in a generation, reconcile the future of funding for Planned Parenthood and roll out the red carpet  and a few thousand folding chairs  to greet Pope Francis.

title: The Iran Nuclear Deal: Congress Has Its Say
description: At the top of the agenda for Congress this month is a resolution disapproving President Obamas nuclear deal with Iran. Democrats have enough votes to sustain a presidential veto of the resolution and ensure that the deal will go into effect, but the debate will still be heated about an agreement that eases economic sanctions against Iran in exchange for new limits on its nuclear program. Here are some nuts and bolts on the situation about to unfold on Capitol Hill.

title: Crowdfunding a $500 Million Ferris Wheel, With a Wall Street Spin
description: Investing in stocks is at times compared to a thrill ride  a rocket ship taking off, or a roller coaster rushing down.

title: Israeli Film Director Delves Into Killing of Yitzhak Rabin
description: JERUSALEM  In one scene, a group of Jews wrapped in prayer shawls begin reciting a mystical death curse known as the Pulsa Dinura. A man in a suit who has urged them to invoke the angels of destruction promises that their prime minister, Yitzhak Rabin, will be dead within a month.

title: Marketing to Sports Fans Online, With Help From Google and Social Networks
description: When the National Football League season begins on Thursday, Google will not be merely sitting on the sidelines.

title: Palestinian National CouncilMeeting Is Postponed Amid Boycotts
description: JERUSALEM  A conference of the Palestinian National Council that had been scheduled for next week has been indefinitely postponed amid boycotts by some political factions and debate about the agenda and structure of the meeting. The 700-plus-member council, which has not had a regular session since 1996, was slated to convene in the West Bank city of Ramallah next Monday and Tuesday to consider, among other things, the membership of the Palestine Liberation Organizations executive committee. The P.L.O. chairman, Mahmoud Abbas, who is also president of the Palestinian Authority, was to submit his resignation along with 10 of the executive committees 18 members, though it was unclear whether he and his colleagues would actually step down or stand for re-election. Whether Mr. Abbas truly plans to withdraw from political life or is trying to shake up the leadership in order to curtail criticism and consolidate power has been the subject of speculation for weeks.

title: Patrick Drahi Positions Himself to Be a Player in U.S. Cable
description: PARIS  When the French-Israeli billionaire Patrick Drahi bought a St. Louis cable TV company in May and was mentioned as a potential suitor for Time Warner Cable, it may have been the first time many Americans had heard his name.

title: Readers Summer Highlight Reel
description: The New York Times asked readers on Twitter and Facebook to finish the sentence, The best thing I did in New York City this summer was. Here is a selection of the responses.

title: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Compete For Union Support
description: NEWTON, Iowa  Bernie Sanders recalled his days on picket lines. Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke out against privatizing government jobs.

title: Companies Struggle to Comply With Rules on Conflict Minerals
description: A pink My Little Pony balloon does not usually evoke images of rifle-toting warlords in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Still, Party City Holdings, the decorations and costumes retailer, recently disclosed a possible link to securities regulators, helping to put it near the bottom of a list ranking companies on their compliance with laws against using minerals mined in war-torn regions across Africa.

title: Apple and Other Tech Companies Tangle With U.S. Over Data Access
description: WASHINGTON  In an investigation involving guns and drugs, the Justice Department obtained a court order this summer demanding that Apple turn over, in real time, text messages between suspects using iPhones.

title: Italys Highest Court Explains Decision to Clear Amanda Knox
description: ROME  Italys highest court said Monday that the case against the Seattle resident Amanda Knox and her former boyfriend  whose convictions in the 2007 murder of a British student were definitively overturned in March  was marked by culpable omissions of investigative activity and contradictory evidence that raised reasonable doubt of their guilt.

title: For Online Sports Videos, the Action Is No Longer on the Field
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Anyone who went to the Apple iTunes store to buy a movie in mid-August might have noticed that sitting in the digital queue, next to blockbusters like Mad Max: Fury Road, was the seemingly obscure title We Are Blood, which was not exactly a movie, but a video consisting mostly of skateboarders performing tricks.

title: FIFA Ruling Forces Ben Lederman Back to U.S.
description: Ben Lederman, the teenage soccer player whose career at Barcelona was cut short by FIFA transfer regulations, has returned to the United States and plans to enroll at the IMG Academy in Bradenton, Fla.

title: Jon Batiste Will Lead The Late Show With Stephen Colbert Band in a Style He Sees Fit
description: There comes a point in almost any scheduled performance by Jon Batiste when he pops up from the piano and strides into the crowd, tootling his melodica, a toylike wind instrument, with bandmates in tow. Its a trademark shtick that happens to carry a whiff of the authentic, given Mr. Batistes lifelong familiarity with New Orleans second-line parades. Naturally, it was one of the factors that led to his role as bandleader on The Late Show With Stephen Colbert, which makes its debut on CBS on Tuesday.

title: Mets David Wright Says It All: What a Game
description: WASHINGTON  David Wright rounded third base, chugging as fast as he could with a bad back, and saw Tim Teufel, the Mets third-base coach, swinging his left arm like a windmill, waving him on. The Mets had just built a two-run lead in the top of the seventh, and now Teufel, going for the kill, wanted to make it three.

title: Plague Cases in U.S. on the Rise
description: There have been 13 cases and three deaths from plague in the United States in the past five months, but researchers do not know why the disease appears to be on the rise.

title: Photo Zines Explore Singapores Identity
description: A series of zines produced by photographers in Singapore offer insiders views of the country, its history and its eccentricities.

title: Erica Jongs Fear of Dying Defies the Sunset of Sex
description: Two words have vexed Erica Jong for the last 42 years. The first is zipless, and the word that follows is not printable in this newspaper.

title: Sara Little, Peripatetic Product Designer, Dies at 97
description: Sara Little Turnbull, an innovative product designer who found inspiration for her work in geisha styles, a Kenyan game park, an American prison and other unlikely places, died on Friday at her home in Seattle. She was 97.

title: Martin Milner, Clean-Cut Star of Route 66 and Adam-12, Dies at 83
description: Martin Milner, an actor who broke out of supporting movie roles as the quintessential clean-cut young man to achieve television stardom as one of two road-hungry bachelors in Route 66 and later as a veteran police officer in Adam-12, died on Sunday at his home in Carlsbad, Calif. He was 83.

title: Review: Fortune Smiles, Stories From Dark Places, by Adam Johnson
description: Adam Johnson set his deeply affecting Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, The Orphan Masters Son, in the hermit kingdom of North Korea, where government oppression and propaganda combine to make daily life as strange and harrowing as anything dreamed up by a dystopian satirist on hyperdrive. Mr. Johnsons earlier writing  his 2002 story collection, Emporium, and his first novel, Parasites Like Us  also had a surreal, even sci-fi feel. And while many tales in his potent new collection, Fortune Smiles, have recognizable, contemporary settings, they, too, feature characters reeling from displacement, dislocation or emotional and cultural vertigo.

title: Affinity and Inflation
description: Brad DeLong marvels at Peter Schiff insisting to Josh Barro that US inflation is far higher than the official statistics acknowledge, and hence that the economy is actually shrinking. Incidentally, the independent Billion Prices index  which is internet-based, and places a higher weight on goods as opposed to services including housing  is actually showing deflation right now.

title: Timothy Snyders Black Earth Puts Holocaust, and Himself, in Spotlight
description: NEW HAVEN  When Timothy Snyders book Bloodlands: Europe Between Hitler and Stalin was published in 2010, it quickly established its author as one of the leading historians of his generation, a scholar who combined formidable linguistic skills  he reads or speaks 11 languages  with an elegant literary style, white-hot moral passion and a willingness to start arguments about some of the most fraught questions of the recent past.

title: Review: They Are Gone Is Kathryn Hamiltons Play About Protest and Apathy
description: A bare-breasted woman was gently beating a shirtless man with nunchaku sticks. Another woman was stapled to the wall by her hair, long strands of it wrapped across her eyes, mouth and throat.

title: Review: Satellite Collective Mixes Media and Messages at BAM Fisher
description: Satellite Collective is an admirably cooperative endeavor and a peculiar one. Its program at BAM Fisher on Thursday included a poetic monologue, a stop-motion film and three dance pieces, with and without video accompaniment. Everything had live musical accompaniment, and there were standalone musical selections, too. Seven composers, three choreographers, one filmmaker, two writers, one lighting designer and three costume designers contributed, with some of those people wearing multiple hats. Even for a sampler, thats a lot of creative voices.

title: Children Tossing School Lunch Fruits and Vegetables
description: You can lead a child to vegetables, but it appears you cant make him eat.

title: Expecting Little, Simona Halep Finally Reaches Round of 8
description: Simona Halep is the No. 2 seed at the United States Open, and she entered her round of 16 match with more hardcourt victories this year than any other woman in the main draw, having compiled a 35-5 record.

title: Plutonium Is Unsung Concession in Iran Nuclear Deal
description: At first glance, the metals that give atom bombs their destructive fury might seem interchangeable: Uranium and plutonium are both more valuable than gold. Both captivate would-be atomic powers. And both fueled bombs that leveled Japanese cities  uranium at Hiroshima and plutonium at Nagasaki.

title: West African Child Is Paralyzed by Vaccine-Derived Polio
description: A case of vaccine-derived polio has paralyzed a child in Bamako, the capital of Mali, and an emergency vaccination drive is being organized to forestall an outbreak, the World Health Organization announced Monday.

title: European Farmers Demand Aid as Produce Prices Sag
description: BRUSSELS  Thousands of farmers snarled traffic and pelted the police with eggs on Monday in a protest to demand emergency aid to offset falling prices for milk, pork and other agricultural products.

title: Migrant Influx May Give Europes Far Right a Lift
description: LONDON  As Europe basks in good feelings over its generosity to thousands of migrants and asylum seekers last weekend, critical voices from the political right and far right are poised to become among the biggest beneficiaries of the continuing flow.

title: Hillary Clinton: Puppy Mills Can be Cruel
description: NEWTON, Iowa  It was not the Iran deal, or her private email server, that a woman at a crowded coffee shop wanted to question Hillary Rodham Clinton about on Sunday.

title: Russia Answers U.S. Criticism Over Military Aid to Syria
description: MOSCOW  The Foreign Ministry here expressed surprise on Monday over an American warning to Russia against escalating the conflict in Syria, saying that the Kremlins Syrian policy  in particular furnishing military aid to help the government confront extremist forces  had been consistent for years.

title: Hillary Clinton to Show More Humor and Heart, Aides Say
description: There will be no more flip jokes about her private email server. There will be no rope lines to wall off crowds, which added to an impression of aloofness. And there will be new efforts to bring spontaneity to a candidacy that sometimes seems wooden and overly cautious.

title: The Fix, a Ribald Musical About Political Showmanship
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  Even against the backdrop of a circuslike election season replete with investigations of a private email account and mudslinging by a billionaire reality television star, the plot of the The Fix, a musical about the dark arts of campaigning, is sordid enough to give political operatives pause.

title: Greg Birds Walk Aids Yankees, and His Homer Wins Game
description: With the Yankees mounting a fifth-inning rally Monday, Greg Bird wanted to reach base by any means necessary. The Orioles Wei-Yin Chen threw Bird an inside pitch, and Bird, a 22-year-old rookie, winced as if he had been hit.

title: Mindy Kaling: By the Book
description: The actress, producer and author, most recently, of Why Not Me? secretly read in bed as a child. My parents encouraged reading, but they didnt anticipate me reading Michael Crichtons Sphere until 2 a.m. on a school night.

title: Dispute at Coke Bottling Plant Could Signal Labor Challenges for E.U.
description: FUENLABRADA, Spain  Can a Spanish court force a multinational company to bottle Coca-Cola against its will?

title: Raymond Kelly, Ex-Police Commissioner, Blames Mayor de Blasio for Rise in Killings
description: Former Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said last week that Mayor Bill de Blasios constraints on the stop-and-frisk strategy of the Bloomberg administration was to blame for the uptick in murders in New York City. Mr. Kelly also attributed the rise in homicides in other cities to a backlash to the killing last year of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo.

title: Indias Middle-Class Revolt
description: Protests by members of a relatively prosperous caste in India who want to be included in affirmative action programs highlight a major problem: India isnt creating enough good jobs. This is a big challenge to Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who has built his political career on promises to reform and modernize the stalled economy.

title: A Jogging Biden Hears Calls to Run, Joe, Run!
description: PITTSBURGH  The calls of encouragement could be heard on nearly every block as Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. jogged his way through the Labor Day parade here.

title: Serpico, Seeking Seat on Town Board, Sees Corruption and Pledges to Fight It
description: STUYVESANT, N.Y.  He no longer looks like the young, full-haired, wild-eyed officer played by Al Pacino in the 1973 film Serpico. But the real Frank Serpico, 79, was still energetic and loquacious as he headed from his secluded cabin in this small upstate town to visit the local county fair last week on its opening day.

title: A Los Angeles Plan to Reshape the Streetscape Sets Off Fears of Gridlock
description: LOS ANGELES  This city of fast cars and endless freeways is preparing to do what not long ago would have been unthinkable: sacrificing car lanes to make way for bikes and buses.

title: Palestinians Pay Homage to a 3rd Firebomb Victim
description: DUMA, West Bank  Palestinians in Duma held their third funeral in six weeks, as they buried victims of an arson attack in which Jewish extremists have been accused. First, they buried a toddler, Ali Dawabsheh, then his father, and on Monday, they buried his mother, Riham Dawabsheh, each dying of injuries sustained in the fire on July 31.

title: Clinging to Blinders, Victoria Azarenka Closes In
description: Oh, look, Victoria Azarenka won her fourth-round match on Monday at the United States Open, letting our vision of a final against Serena Williams live on.

title: What Are a Hospitals Costs? Utah System Is Trying to Learn
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Only in the world of medicine would Dr. Vivian Lees question have seemed radical. She wanted to know: What do the goods and services provided by the hospital system where she is chief executive actually cost?

title: Judy Carne, Sock It to Me Girl on Laugh-In, Dies at 76
description: Judy Carne, a sprightly British actress and comedian who rocketed to pop culture fame as the sock it to me girl on Rowan & Martins Laugh-In, a landmark of television zaniness, before her career was derailed by drug arrests and a near-fatal automobile accident, died on Thursday in Northampton, England. She was 76.

title: Decoding Steve Jobs, in Life and on Film
description: Nearly four years after Steve Jobs died, a debate is still raging.

title: Rehab, Degree, Playoffs. Two Down, One to Go.
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I.  Marcus Stroman cried when a doctor told him in March that he had torn his anterior cruciate ligament after falling in a spring training fielding drill. He called his father, his mother and Ryan Bahnsen, his best friend from high school on Long Island.

title: Rail Biking Arrives in Adirondacks, but Future of Track Is in Doubt
description: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y.  Hoots, hollers and laughter echoed through the air as passengers aboard a mechanical device, previously unknown to the Adirondacks, made their way through the woods.

title: Cardale Jones Settles Question and Ohio State Provides Exclamation Point
description: BLACKSBURG, Va.  The greatest trick play that Coach Urban Meyer has so far devised may have been letting all the focus be on who would start at quarterback when Ohio State opened the season against Virginia Tech on Monday night.

title: Second Review Says Classified Information Was in Hillary Clintons Email
description: WASHINGTON  A special intelligence review of two emails that Hillary Rodham Clinton received as secretary of state on her personal account  including one about North Koreas nuclear weapons program  has endorsed a finding by the inspector general for the intelligence agencies that the emails contained highly classified information when Mrs. Clinton received them, senior intelligence officials said.

title: Migrants Who Survived Shipwreck Are Grateful, but Disillusioned
description: SANDVIKEN, Sweden  As tens of thousands of migrants run the gantlet of dangers to reach Europe, Natanael Haile, a refugee from Eritrea now living in Sweden, is struggling to get over his nightmarish journey.

title: Andy Murray, Blanked in Tiebreaker, Falls at U.S. Open
description: Andy Murray had built a record of consistent excellence since the beginning of 2011. He had played in 18 major tournaments and reached the quarterfinals each time, winning twice, including at the 2012 U.S. Open.

title: Yazidis Settle in Nebraska, but Roots Run Deep in Iraq
description: LINCOLN, Neb.  They came to America seeking the freedom to pray and work in peace. But in death, many hoped to be buried among the hills of their homeland, in northern Iraq.

title: Rebecca Livengood, Nathaniel Wenstrup
description: Rebecca Jane Livengood and Nathaniel Christian Wenstrup are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Charles Kroloff at the vacation home of the brides parents in Culver Lake, N.J.

title: Rickie Fowler Edges Henrik Stenson as Playoff Field Narrows
description: NORTON, Mass.  The day before the start of the Deutsche Bank Championship, Collin MacDonald, a teenage volunteer, caught up to his favorite player, Rickie Fowler. He had met Fowler two years ago, when he carried a scoring standard for Fowlers group. He had returned to do the same job this year, and on Thursday he said he told Fowler, Maybe on Monday afternoon everything will click together.

title: Jouvert and the Annual West Indian Parade
description: Thousands of revelers line the streets in Brooklyn each year for the event, which celebrates Caribbean culture.

title: Somewhat Family-Friendly
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  The day that The Boy could go legally see a PG THIRTEEN movie with us was a happy day indeed. I dont even remember the movie. I just remember the distinct lack of whining when we didnt have to leave him behind.

title: Jason Pierre-Paul Visits Giants Two Months After Injury
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  About two months after a Fourth of July fireworks accident cost him his right index finger, Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul flew to the New York area on Monday to meet with the teams medical personnel. It was the first time the Giants had seen the damage to Pierre-Pauls hand.

title: Vulgar Videos Lead to Ouster of 2 Canadian Candidates From Ballot
description: OTTAWA  The governing Conservative Party of Canada on Monday dropped two of its candidates for the House of Commons because of embarrassing videos featuring them.

title: South Korea: North Agrees to Reunions
description: South and North Korea agreed Tuesday to arrange for hundreds of relatives separated during the Korean War to meet siblings and other family members next month in those families first reunions in more than six decades. The 1950-53 Korean War  which was halted by a truce, not by a formal peace treaty  left the Korean Peninsula divided and numerous Koreans separated from their relatives. The so-called separated family members have never been allowed to exchange letters or meet each other, unless both governments arranged occasional reunions limited to a few hundred people. The last such reunions took place in February last year. After an overnight negotiation at the border village of Panmunjom, the two Koreas signed an agreement on Tuesday to hold a new round of family reunions at the Diamond Mountain resort in the southeast of North Korea on Oct. 20-26. The nations agreed in principle to a new round of reunions during an Aug. 25 deal to defuse a military showdown along the border.

title: Whats On TV Tuesday
description: 11:15 A.M. (HBO Signature) GHOST TOWN (2008) After a near-death experience during a colonoscopy, Bertram Pincus (Ricky Gervais, in bed), a misanthropic Manhattan dentist, starts to see spirits  namely, Frank Herlihy (Greg Kinnear), a two-timing yuppie who was hit by a bus while avoiding a falling air-conditioner. He wants Bertram to befriend his widow, Gwen (Ta Leoni), and prevent her from remarrying. She hates Bertram, and then she doesnt. A latter-day hybrid of Topper and Blithe Spirit and a visual ode to autumn in New York, Ghost Town is a screwball comedy with no big surprises or hidden metaphors, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this romantic froth, directed by David Koepp. But instead of becoming mired in sentimentality like flies in molasses, the film tiptoes to the edge of that sticky mess, but it doesnt get caught there.

Perhaps I should mention that my colleague is from Japan.

title: When Congress Puts NASA on Hold, Planets Dont Wait
description: THE United States asks NASA to do an extraordinary amount with very little money. Explore Mars, document climate change, stop doomsday asteroids, find life on Europa  all for less than one-half of 1 percent of the federal budget. But budget uncertainties on Capitol Hill, including delays in federal appropriations legislation and temporary government shutdowns, measurably harm the American space program. Even the threat of a shutdown can have a far-reaching impact on scientific projects, often in unexpected ways.

title: The Stylish Men of Tumblr
description: Worker bees buzz through Tumblrs headquarters in the Flatiron district of Manhattan. With so many young employees, who move between glass-walled conference rooms and a rooftop patio, the place is vibrant. Founded by David Karp in 2007 as a medium for short-form blogs and acquired by Yahoo for $1.1 billion in 2013, Tumblr has hosted more than 115 billion posts. Its users, nearly half of whom are ages 13 to 34, according to the company, add 85 million more each day. People use their Tumblrs for all sorts of things, from old-fashioned cat appreciation to sad-kid blogging, but fashion is the platforms largest area of interest. We visited Tumblr recently in search of tech chic.

title: Camp for Migrants in Hungary
description: Several hundred people, including children, spent the night in tents at a reception center in an open field in Roszke, Hungary, after crossing into the country from Serbia.

title: Scott Shanes Objective Troy
description: Some of the most difficult political, legal and moral issues in counterterrorism involve the use by the United States of unmanned aerial vehicles, commonly known as drones, to kill suspected terrorists in faraway places. These issues arose in especially salient and acute form regarding Anwar al-Awlaki, who became the first American citizen since at least the Civil War to be hunted down and intentionally killed overseas by his own government without his cases ever being considered in a court. At the time he died in September 2011, Awlaki was probably the most prominent jihadi terrorist in the world apart from Osama bin Laden. The president who announced that death, Barack Obama, has become identified with drone strikes since they are the principal tool his administration has used to fight international terrorists. Scott Shanes Objective Troy (the title refers to the militarys code name for Awlaki) is a lucid and richly informed account of how these two men came to occupy their respective places in the history of the drone age.

title: Lauren Groffs Fates and Furies
description: Theres always the danger, with novels structured around a marriage, that theyll be perceived as centrally concerned not only with that particular relationship but with the nature of marriage itself. A domestic union set prominently in a work of fiction has the sometimes unfortunate capacity to obscure whatever else is going on. Yet Fates and Furies, Lauren Groffs remarkable new novel, explodes and rages past any such preconceptions, insisting that the examination of a long-term relationship can be a perfect vehicle for exploring no less than the nature of existence  the domestic a doorway to the philosophical.

It pains me to watch the same fate befall a third prime minister, my friend and comrade Alexis Tsipras.

Chinas trade slump deepened in August  an indication of a sharper industrial slowdown at home and weaker demand from overseas. Exports fell 5.5 percent in August and 1.4 percent in dollar terms in the first eight months of the year.

title: What Is the Point of College?
description: I gave my first university lecture in philosophy at the University of Ghana, Legon, when I was a freshly credentialed 21-year-old. My audience was a couple of hundred students gathered in a vast hall, with ceiling fans to move the hot and humid air. Above the murmur of the fans and the muttering of students, I tried to explain why Descartes thought the mere possibility that there was an Evil Demon deceiving their senses meant they couldnt know for sure that I was really there. Ah, Cartesian skepticism! I remember diagraming the structure of the argument in huge chalk letters on an enormous blackboard.

title: Is College Tuition Really Too High?
description: To understand the feeling of crisis that many see in higher education right now, its useful to start with some figures from 40 years ago. In 1974, the median American family earned just under $13,000 a year. A new home could be had for $36,000, an average new car for $4,400. Attending a four-year private college cost around $2,000 a year: affordable, with some scrimping, to even median earners. As for public university, it was a bargain at $510 a year. To put these figures in current dollars, were talking about median family income of $62,000, a house for $174,000 and a sticker price of $21,300 for the car, $10,300 for the private university and $2,500 for the public one.

title: Why Theres Disagreement Over Screening Every Child for Autism
description: Few would dispute that children who are exhibiting signs or symptoms of autistic spectrum disorder should be referred and tested. It is when we talk about screening every child for autism that the debate becomes heated.

title: Where Dracula Was Born, and Its Not Transylvania
description: From its quay in early summer, Whitby was a sun-scrubbed idyll, fluttering with the trimmings of a typical English seaside holiday. Souvenir shops hawked postcards and sand toys, pub bartenders poured midday pints of beer, and the smell of fish and chips hung on the breeze. Along the shore, a row of rainbow-hued beach huts sheltered swimmers brave enough to take a dip in the North Sea. A group of sunburned schoolchildren raced through cobblestone streets, past antiques shops and tearooms, toward the 199 steps ascending to a cliff. I followed them, listening as their excited chatter gave way to dead silence. Please, Miss, a little girl appealed to her teacher in an unnerved tone, I cant go up there.

title: In a New Show, Lanvins Process Comes Into Focus
description: Alber Elbaz is, perhaps, the least high-tech designer working in fashion today. You know, I dont drive, I dont have computers, I dont use the Internet, the 54-year-old Lanvin designer says. Technology brings everything to us fast, but I find it makes things more flat  you dont hear the voice, you dont know the truth. Because of this, Elbaz says he finds clothes today more flat than ever: hard edges, bright colors, prints  things that look good in the 2D. But, he emphasizes, fashion is a 3D art: Its not only about the front and back. Its everything in between.

title: 1940: East End Poor Suffer in Raids
description: LONDON  For nearly ten miles in the East End of London there was a scene of devastation today such as is not often seen in the course of history. It is the result of the hellishness which broke loose yesterday afternoon and last night, when mass formations of Nazi bombers dropped load after load on military objectives in the dock areas and civilian homes alike. For every military objective hit, there are two or three civilian buildings smashed to smithereens. The grim thing about this war is that the poor people are getting the worst of it. For it is the working-class people, living and toiling for a couple of pounds a week, who live in the dock areas behind the factories and warehouses and gas and oil tanks which the Nazis are attempting to destroy.  New York Herald Tribune, September 9, 1940
