description: Reflections of 1983

title: More Change at New York Philharmonic as Marketing Chief Leaves
description: The turnover at the New York Philharmonic is continuing: David Snead, the vice president in charge of marketing, is leaving the orchestra after 14 years to become president and chief executive of the Handel and Haydn Society in Boston.

title: Andrew Bolton, Museum Visionary
description: The understated curator of the Mets Costume Institute marries a love of beauty with a taste for the perverse.

title: Japanese Premier Wins a New Term
description: Shinzo Abe, the prime minister of Japan, on Tuesday won a new term as president of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party after no challengers filed applications to run against him.

title: Kim Davis,Released From Kentucky Jail, Wont Say if She Will Keep Defying Court
description: GRAYSON, Ky.  After five nights in jail for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, Kim Davis, a Kentucky county clerk, walked free Tuesday to a roar of cheers from thousands of supporters, but she and her lawyer would not say whether she would continue to defy court orders and try to block the licenses.

title: 4 More Senators Back Iran Deal, Assuring Cushion for White House
description: WASHINGTON  Four Democratic senators announced on Tuesday that they would back President Obamas nuclear deal with Iran, apparently securing the White House enough votes so Mr. Obama will not be forced to veto a Republican resolution disapproving the accord.

title: Dick Cheneys and Hillary Clintons Competing Versions of U.S.-Iran History
description: WASHINGTON  To hear Dick Cheney tell the tale, he and President George W. Bush were slowly but surely squeezing Iran into submission until President Obama and his team came along and recklessly let up the pressure.

title: Kylie Jenners Beauty Routine: How She Keeps It Real
description: At 18, Kylie Jenner, the reality TV and social media star (33.3 million Instagram followers and counting), has already made an impression on the beauty zeitgeist. In fact, this fall she will introduce a beauty website on which she plans to offer advice and makeovers. Here, from contouring to lip filler, she holds forth on what her beauty regimen is really like away from the Instagram cameras.

title: Setting Aside Shame and Blame in Financial Decisions
description: Im a huge advocate of the no shame, no blame rule when it comes to money. But I think theres some confusion about how the rule works. Its not that you wont feel guilt. Its also not about avoiding responsibility. Instead, its about recognizing the zero-sum game of relying on shame and blame to make better money decisions.

title: Dick Cheney Criticizes Iran Nuclear Deal
description: Former Vice President Dick Cheney criticized the nuclear deal with Iran as being historically and dangerously unique, and said it would make the Unites States less safe; a protester responded.

title: First Days of School, Decade by Decade
description: With classes beginning in New York City on Wednesday, The Times looks back at education in the city  from air raid drills to standardized tests.

title: Kim Davis Contempt Order Lifted
description: Five days after jailing Ms. Davis, the Rowan County, KY., clerk, for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, Judge David L. Bunning of Federal District Court signed an order releasing her from behind bars.

title: Woman Injured in Virginia TV Shooting Is Out of the Hospital
description: The woman who was injured as two television journalists were shot and killed while on air in Virginia last month has been released from the hospital, a statement and a hospital spokesman said on Tuesday.

title: Leaders Call for E.U. to Help Migrants
description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and Prime Minister Stefan Lofven of Sweden say the European Union needs to have a collective response to the ongoing migrant crisis.

title: On the Front Lines of an Outbreak
description: Doctors Without Borders received a Lasker award for efforts to turn back the Ebola epidemic in West Africa.

title: DNAs Defenses
description: Evelyn M. Witkin and Stephen J. Elledge received a Lasker award for insights into how cells respond to damaged DNA.

title: Targeting Tumors
description: James P. Allison received a Lasker award for research into how the immune system could be unleashed against cancer.

title: Business Lessons of Matt Harvey Dilemma Go Beyond Mets
description: The controversy that has seized the attention of baseball fans, over how the Mets should handle Matt Harvey, may seem to be a debate over money, ego and the integrity of the ligaments in his pitching elbow.

title: Britain Tries to Deter Migrants, Even as It Lets More In
description: SHEFFIELD, England  It may be the dreamed-of destination for many migrants in the wave now traveling through Europe, but Britain remains among the stingiest of European countries toward asylum seekers, and is even planning new measures to deter the flow of people determined to come here.

title: On Second Serve, Federer Attacks
description: During a practice session in Cincinnati last month, Roger Federer began fooling around with a variation on a chip-and-charge move.

title: Hillary Clinton Announces Campaign Finance Overhaul Plan
description: In a plan intended to upend a political system hijacked by billionaires and special interests, Hillary Rodham Clinton presented a set of proposals on Tuesday to curb anonymous political donations and bolster the influence of small donors through a federal matching program.

title: Roger Goodell Open to Changing Role in N.F.L. Disciplinary Process
description: After a series of stinging legal defeats, Roger Goodell, the commissioner of the N.F.L., said he would consider changing his role in governing the leagues personal conduct policy.

title: Obama Honors N.C.A.A. Basketball Champs
description: President Obama congratulated this years N.C.A.A. champions, the Duke Blue Devils, joking that he understands the struggle of being opposed no matter what you try to do.

title: Aretha Franklin Documentary Will Not Be Shown at Toronto Festival
description: LOS ANGELES  A documentary about the making of the Aretha Franklin album Amazing Grace, which was prevented by a court order from screening at the Telluride Film Festival last week, will not be shown as scheduled at the Toronto International Film Festival this week either.

title: The Hookah Affair
description: A Kurdish migrant takes momentary refuge in the familiar taste of a hookah, which he has carried for weeks while traveling on the precarious trail from Greece to Hungary.

title: Verbatim: Harry Reid on Donald Trump Helping Democrats
description: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, telling CNN that Mr. Trumps candidacy has increased the Democrats chances of winning the Senate in 2016.

title: JPMorgan Hires Tech Banker Greg Mendelson From Bank of America Merrill Lynch
description: As part of Wall Streets race to advise the technology industry, JPMorgan Chase has hired a banker from one of its big rivals.

title: Lawyer Discusses Kim Daviss Release
description: Mathew D. Staver, the lawyer for the Kentucky clerk Kim Davis, spoke on Tuesday about his clients release after she was jailed for defying a courts order that she issue same-sex marriage licenses.

title: Long-Lost Stravinsky Work Rediscovered
description: One of Stravinskys earliest works, long thought lost, has been rediscovered amid masses of papers at the St. Petersburg Conservatory, a Russian musicologist announced at a conference centering on the composer.

title: Black Mass Resurrects Bostons Long Memories of Whitey Bulger
description: Whitey Bulger, the Boston crime boss who is the subject of Black Mass, Scott Coopers new movie starring Johnny Depp and opening on Sept. 18, is probably the most mythologized gangster since Al Capone. Mr. Cooper, who took over the project from Barry Levinson, said recently that he had been fascinated by the Whitey story for years, and that in 2011, when Mr. Bulger was discovered hiding in Santa Monica, Calif., of all places, it seemed like a filmmakers godsend. I was gobsmacked, he said. And to think he had been living just miles from my house.

title: Twyla Tharps Rehearsal: Here and Now Forever
description: Twyla Tharp is writing about rehearsing, touring and creating new work, 50 years after her first dance concert.

title: Inside Joan Jonass SoHo Loft
description: The artist takes T on a tour of where she lives and works.

title: Review: Bill Cleggs Did You Ever Have a Family Heaps One Tragedy Upon Another
description: Bill Cleggs first novel, Did You Ever Have a Family, has been longlisted for the Man Booker Prize, a big deal in the book world. Critics have arranged warm reviews around it like tea candles.

title: Review: Welcome to Leith, a Documentary About a Town Fighting a Racist Takeover
description: There are a few moments in Welcome to Leith, a documentary about a North Dakota town that resists being taken over by white supremacists, when the film might be mistaken for a horror movie about an alien invasion. Only one business operates in this village of 24 residents, mostly farmers and ranchers, in Grant County. Three years ago, a scruffy gray-bearded stranger with beady eyes appeared and began buying properties in the area. When his real estate spree ended, he had accumulated at least a dozen plots of land.

title: Facts & Figures: Cutting Carbon Could Save Cities Almost $17 Trillion
description: The worlds citiescould save nearly $17 trillion between now and 2050 by adopting a variety of carbon-cutting strategies like improving public transit and investing in efficient lighting and heating systems, according to a report by The New Climate Economy.

title: Inside the Artist Joan Jonass SoHo Loft
description: It was in 1974 that Joan Jonas, the American artist who represented the U.S. at the 56th annual Venice Biennale this May with the triumphant multimedia installation They Come to Us Without a Word, moved into a vast, light-filled loft on Mercer Street. And for the past 40-something years, it has served the many purposes you might imagine for an artists space in SoHo: a home, a studio, a theater stage (Jonas would perform for a room full of friends and artists in the 70s)  even a film set, on which her dogs have been known to wander randomly and end up as part of the final product. My dogs are all a bit mystical, Jonas says about the three she has owned over the course of her career, while her current dog, a dashing white poodle named Ozu, sleeps on a large green pillow nestled in front of a small library reserved for Jonass absolute favorite books.

title: Philadelphia Hotel Gets New Life
description: Plans for the Divine Lorraine Hotel, which has become a symbol of urban decay, include 109 new apartments, ground-floor restaurants and retail outlets.

title: Kim Davis Speaks After Release From Jail
description: Ms. Davis, the Rowan County, Ky., clerk, spoke at a rally after she was ordered freed, saying: I just want to give God the glory. His people have rallied, and you are a strong people.

title: Students in South Africa Protest Slow Pace of Change
description: CAPE TOWN  It was only when he landed at the University of Cape Town, a bastion of the fight against apartheid, that Ramabina Mahapa became truly conscious of his race.

title: The Season's Coolest Coats, Modeled by Musicians
description: Indie musics fastest rising stars warm up.

title: A Billboard of Blight in Philadelphia Acts as a Catalyst for a Revival
description: PHILADELPHIA  A Victorian apartment building and hotel that once housed the wealthy but later became a symbol of urban decay will be reborn as a residential complex in a project aimed at reviving a long-neglected North Philadelphia neighborhood.

title: At Moschino in SoHo, a Tweety Bird Sweater and Other Charms
description: My brother Ned had spent eight hours painting crates on a Chinatown roof in 94-degree heat when I picked him up to go shopping.

title: Mike Huckabee (Not Ted Cruz) Captures Spotlight at Kim Davis Event
description: Mike Huckabee captured the political spotlight on Tuesday, rallying to the side of Kim Davis, the Kentucky clerk who went to jail for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, and casting her fight as a choice between tyranny and religious freedom.

title: Dick Cheney Is Interrupted by Protester
description: Former Vice President Cheney was criticizing the Iran nuclear deal when a banner-wielding protester interrupted.

title: Huckabee Speaks in Support of Kim Davis
description: The Republican presidential candidate Mike Huckabee spoke to crowds in Kentucky about Kim Davis, the clerk who was jailed for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples.

title: The League, on FXX, Kicks Off Its Final Season
description: When you have been one of televisions raunchiest shows for six seasons and have announced that the seventh will be your last, what can you do to start things off that will be truly shocking? That is the problem facing The League, an FXX comedy about six friends in a fantasy football league, which returns on Wednesday night.

title: Pictures of the Day: Hungary and Elsewhere
description: Hungary and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Andrew Bolton Chosen to Lead the Mets Costume Institute
description: After 14 years of overseeing ambitious, crowd-pleasing shows like Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty in 2011 and the recent China: Through the Looking Glass, which have helped put the Metropolitan Museum of Art at the crossroads of glamour, fashion, scholarship and art, Harold Koda is retiring as curator in charge of the museums Costume Institute. On Tuesday the Met board chose Andrew Bolton, his fellow curator, to succeed him.

title: September 8, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Hungary, Greece, Yemen and Gaza.

title: When Fashion Shows Were Fun
description: Naomi Campbell wore backless chaps. Have I got your attention?

title: A Painful Lesson for the Jets Geno Smith, but What Did He Learn?
description: Geno Smiths journey as the Jets quarterback of the future was seriously derailed in August when his jaw was broken by Ikemefuna Enemkpali in the teams locker room over an unpaid debt. Enemkpali was sent packing the same day. But while the perpetrator was banished, the episode raised questions about whether Smith has what it takes to be an important part of the Jets future, or whether he will turn out to be just the latest quarterback passing through. I wonder whether the injury and the events leading up to it have been a wake-up call.

title: Nancy Harms Celebrates Duke Ellington
description: A royal-blue night sky and twinkling stars: the perfect moment. With those words, the complicated jazz singer Nancy Harms introduced her rendition of Prelude to a Kiss on Sunday evening at the Metropolitan Room, where she sang a program of Duke Ellington-related songs titled Ellington at Night.

title: In a New Paris Bistro, Daniel Rose Dishes Out Comfort Food
description: The French-trained American chef Daniel Rose recently celebrated his 17th year in France, and today debuts his first new project since the first iteration of Spring, his much-venerated restaurant, shook up the Paris food scene nine years ago. With La Bourse et La Vie, his new 29-seat eatery located between La Bourse, the citys former stock exchange building, and the Palais Royal, Rose applies his experience and skilled precision to the most comforting of French dishes: pot au feu, artichoke salad with foie gras (the first dish Rose ate when he moved to Lyon for cooking school), whole roasted chickens and steak-frites. Consider it an ode to the bistro. Were doing a lot of the fundamental dishes that we learned about in cooking school but didnt think were very interesting at the time, Rose explains. The reality is, these are the traditional recipes that many people travel to Paris for but which have become harder to find  or at least, hard to find executed with any care.

title: Hillary Clinton, Citing Her Mistake, Apologizes for Private Email
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton acknowledged on Tuesday that her use of a private email server while she was secretary of state was a mistake, and apologized directly for it, uttering words that many of her allies have waited to hear from her in hopes that she can quell a controversy that has dogged her presidential candidacy for months.

title: Restaurant Debuts That Stand Out Above the Rest
description: The list of riches on these pages may seem as intimidating as a zillion-course tasting menu. To get started, let me tell you which new developments intrigue me the most.

title: The Fall Restaurant Preview
description: These days, restaurants open in New York throughout the year, but fall still brings scores of fresh choices and a blast of energy. Florence Fabricant sizes up the seasons highlights, from pizzerias to formal dining rooms. (Dates may change.)

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Raw Fish Finds a Spot on Chinese Menus
description: Sure, you can find sushi alongside General Tsos chicken in cheap neighborhood places. But this season, some high-end Chinese menus in New York will include raw seafood in many forms.

title: In New Restaurants, the Faces Are Increasingly Female
description: Women have been running influential kitchens and restaurants in New York for quite a while, but not all that many. This season, the roster of women behind the most anticipated new and reinvented places is especially long.

title: Pile High the Chicken and Biscuits
description: All the talk in New York these days is about bagels, but theres just as much to get excited about in kitchens where the gold standard is the biscuit. Southern staples like pimento cheese, shrimp and grits, and fried chicken with waffles recently arrived at Marcus Samuelssons Streetbird in Harlem; Burnside Biscuits in Astoria, Queens; Birds & Bubbles on the Lower East Side; and Arrogant Swine in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

title: United C.E.O. Is Out Amid Inquiry at Port Authority
description: The chief executive and two senior officials of United Airlines resigned on Tuesday amid a federal investigation into whether the airline had traded favors with the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Japanese Restaurants Focus on Specialties
description: The finer Japanese restaurants, taking their lead from the mother country, often have a narrow focus: Rather than serving a mixed bag, they zero in on, say, ramen or sushi or tempura. Its an approach that showcases expertise, and its in full swing this season in New York.

title: In the Heights: Hamilton Reaches Top Tier at Broadway Box Office
description: As improbable as it may sound, a musical about the nations first Treasury Secretary last week bested Aladdin, The Book of Mormon and Wicked to become the second-highest-grossing show on Broadway.

title: Harry Reid Defends Iran Deal
description: The Democratic Senate leader spoke in support of the nuclear deal with Iran in a speech at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

title: New Cholesterol Drugs Are Vastly Overpriced, Analysis Says
description: Two powerful new drugs that can sharply lower cholesterol are vastly overpriced based on the value they provide, according to a new analysis by an independent organization that evaluates pharmaceutical costs.

title: Yahoo Rethinking Alibaba Spinoff After Getting No I.R.S. Guidance
description: Yahoo is reconsidering its plan to spin off its $23 billion stake in Alibaba after federal tax authorities declined to rule in advance on whether the transaction would mean huge capital gains taxes for Yahoo or its shareholders.

title: Womens Voices Theater Festival Celebrates Female Playwrights
description: WASHINGTON  Ordinarily, plays written by men dominate stages in the nations capital, just as they do in the rest of the country  an imbalance that female playwrights have been agitating to change for a while. But for the next couple of months here, the usual rules will not apply.

title: Nearly 8,000 Killed in Ukraine Conflict, U.N. Says
description: GENEVA  Nearly 8,000 people have died in the conflict in eastern Ukraine, the United Nations said Tuesday in a report blaming the continuing influx of fighters and weaponry from Russia as the major obstacle to peace.

title: Dentist Who Killed Lion Returns to Work
description: Dr. Walter Palmer, the dentist who killed Cecil the lion on a hunt in Zimbabwe last month, returned to work on Tuesday amid protests in Bloomington, Minn.

title: Trademark Collaborates With William Wegman
description: When Pookie and Louisa Burch, the designers behind Trademark, set out to create images for their fall collection, they had a goal in mind: to work with William Wegman, the photographer famous for his pictures of Weimaraners. Their collaboration, which releases exclusively here and which will be installed in their flagship store this week, features Wegmans two dogs modeling a bright red single-breasted coat, tasseled loafers, pajama tops and turtlenecks. My dogs Flo and Topper  sensing Pookie and Louisas high expectations of them  were eager to perform, Wegman told T in an email. They loved the attention and seemed to like the clothes but we cant be sure of that. What we can be certain of is that they enjoyed the collaboration, as did I.

title: Review: The Taming of the Shrew Is Given a Self-Reliant Update
description: It takes gumption to stage a play like Shakespeares The Taming of the Shrew at a time when gender inequality is a growing concern. (And thats before you take into account the challenges of performing it in Bryant Park in Manhattan, with passing planes overhead, fickle microphones and crowd noises from the Bryant Park Grill.) After all, this comedy, at least on its face, is about a husband breaking the will of his hot-tempered wife. But the Drilling Company (the troupe behind Shakespeare in the Parking Lot) has taken it on and sweetened some of its aftertaste.

title: Review: Annie Gosfield Makes Machines Hum in Electric Sweepers and Vacuum Creepers
description: The motorized vacuum cleaner, most would agree, is a useful device. Its sound has practical applications, too, as many new parents can confirm who have soothed fussy babies with its milky white roar. But when it comes to making music, vacuums have mostly had to suck it up and wait.

title: A Conversation With David L. Shorenstein
description: Mr. Shorenstein, 34, is a founder and principal of Silvershore Properties, a New York-based company that acquires, repositions and develops multifamily rentals and mixed-use properties in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens.

title: Corporate Efforts to Address Social Problems Have Limits
description: There is something appealing about the concept of shared value.

title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Youre the Worst, on FX, Extends Its Subversive Rom-Com Arc
description: If youve heard that FXs Youre the Worst is a smutty and subversive take on the relationship sitcom, but you havent watched it yet, you might be in for a surprise. The show is both takedown and loving, detailed celebration  no series on TV more closely mimics the structure and rhythms of the classic romantic comedy. Its 10-episode first season was haunted by the ghosts of Hepburn and Grant, Ryan and Hanks, Zellwegger and the other Grant.

title: Nick Nixon: Photographing Slowly for Forty Years
description: Nick Nixon has worked methodically to create images using a view camera and printing in the darkroom. A new retrospective of his work reminds him of the importance of slowing down.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: A White Poet Borrows a Chinese Name and Sets Off Fireworks
description: This years edition of the anthology Best American Poetry has come under criticism for including a poem by a white poet writing under a Chinese pseudonym, touching off intense online debate about diversity, inclusion and racial entitlement in the poetry world.

title: Aferim!, an Oscar Contender, Explores the Enslavement of the Roma
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  The slow black-and-white scenes in which two horsemen ride through vast, bleak landscapes in Radu Judes latest movie, Aferim!, could have come straight out of a classic American western, as could the central theme of injustice. Yet the movie is set in 19th-century Wallachia, part of modern-day Romania, where for almost 500 years ending in 1856, the Roma (or Gypsies, as they have been more commonly known) were viewed as property to be bought and sold.

title: Review: Richard Gere in Time Out of Mind, a Life Adrift on the Margins
description: Every so often, George Hammond gets a look on his face that suggests hes about to figure something out, and perhaps share his newly found insight. But those moments are fleeting, and the longed-for epiphany never arrives. Usually Georges features are slack, his sentences mumbled and incomplete, his eyes cloudy under heavy brows. His vague personality seems to reflect drifting circumstances; he is a creature of negative space.

title: As New Mexico Scandals Grow, Democrats Hope to Tarnish Governor
description: ALBUQUERQUE  Once an integral part of the Republican Partys rise to power under Gov. Susana Martinezs stewardship in this Democratic stronghold, the secretary of state, Dianna Duran, has now been abandoned by her party, threatened with impeachment by her political opponents and called on to resign by one of the states leading newspapers.

title: Atop the Guggenheim, a Tiny, Secret Installation
description: When New Yorks Guggenheim Museum closes its exhibition Storylines tomorrow, theres one artwork the art handlers wont be packing up. Few are even aware of its existence; its creator is listed in some of the exhibition materials, but not in others. It is a permanent commission that will be a presence within the museum in perpetuity, but no photos of it exist  and until a persistent journalist got her way, no one outside the artists cadre had even seen it.

title: Hungarian Journalist, Petra Laszlo, Fired for Kicking Migrants on Camera
description: An Internet television channel associated with Hungarys far-right Jobbik party fired a camera operator on Tuesday after images of her kicking and tripping migrants spread across social networks.

title: Corduroys New Energy
description: The fabric exits the lecture hall and struts onto the runway.

title: Review: In Coming Home, a Family Rocked by the Cultural Revolution
description: Zhang Yimou and Gong Li constitute one of the great director-actress pairings in movie history. In the 1980s and 90s they worked together on a remarkable run of movies  including Red Sorghum, Raise the Red Lantern, Shanghai Triad and To Live  that were central to the resurgence of Chinese cinema and made international stars of both of them. Ms. Gong, noble, fragile and indomitable, was for Mr. Zhang a muse, an alter ego and an emblem of Chinas suffering and resilience at important moments in the nations history.

title: A Gentlemans Guide to Love and Murder to Close on Broadway in January
description: In the end, there was only one way to save the doomed DYsquiths: Close their show.

title: Corduroy: Not Just for Professors Anymore
description: All too often, corduroy is relegated to the professor type. Think of the English instructor in an ill-fitting suit of chocolate brown, as immortalized by Donald Sutherland in the 1978 film National Lampoons Animal House.

title: Venezuelas U.N. Envoy Defends Crackdown Along Border With Colombia
description: The Venezuelan ambassador to the United Nations offered an impassioned defense on Tuesday of his countrys border closings with Colombia, arguing that illicit trafficking of domestic fuel, food and other goods by Colombian smugglers accounted for 35 percent of all Venezuelan economic output.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Caring for the Other Refugees
description: The worlds attention has been riveted on the refugee crisis unfolding in Europe, and on the shift in Europe as leaders, finally, take steps to deal with it. But one of the reasons Syrians are risking their lives to reach Europe is that life has become unbearable in the countries closer to home where many have taken refuge.

title: An Art-World Fortress of Solitude Comes to New York City
description: To tell you the truth, Im not interested in the story of Kandor, the capital of the fictional planet Krypton, remarked the late artist Mike Kelley in 2008. For those unfamiliar with DC Comics lore, the arch-villain Brainiac shrinks the heros megalopolis to be housed inside of a glass bottle  which Superman later intercepts and keeps in his Fortress of Solitude. Anyway: Im not a fan of Superman comics, Kelley continued. I just like the idea of being burdened with ones past.

title: 26-Point Game Propels Unseeded Italian Roberta Vinci
description: Roberta Vinci and Kristina Mladenovic were locked in a marathon game in the third set of their United States Open quarterfinal at Arthur Ashe Stadium on Tuesday afternoon.

title: Michigan: New Sentencing for Teenager in Sex Crime
description: A judge has vacated the sentence of Zachery Anderson, whose arrest on a charge of having sex with a 14-year-old girl when he was 19 prompted a call to change sex offender registries. Judge Dennis M. Wiley of Berrien County District Court said in a ruling dated Thursday that a different judge would resentence Mr. Anderson. Mr. Anderson said he believed the girl was 17 and above the age of consent in Michigan when they met online and subsequently had a single sexual encounter in December. Mr. Anderson, a resident of Indiana, pleaded guilty to fourth-degree criminal sexual conduct and was sentenced to 90 days in jail and probation, but he was told that he would spend the rest of his life on the states sex offender registry. He was also ordered not to use the Internet or smartphones for five years, forcing him to abandon computer science studies at a community college. Mr. Andersons lawyer said he hoped that a new judge would grant his client a special status under Michigan law for youthful offenders, which would mean he would not be required to be on the states sex offender registry.

title: N.F.L. Cheerleaders Wage Fight Gains Momentum
description: Lacy Thibodeaux grew up in southern Louisiana, football country in all of its humid and insane passions.

title: Andrew Kohut, Pew Pollster Who Shed Light on Public Opinion, Dies at 73
description: Andrew Kohut, a leading pollster who for three decades mined the publics views on subjects like sex, race and religion but who, as an impartial professional, rarely revealed his own, died on Tuesday in Baltimore. He was 73.

title: Parents Spending Less on Back-to-School Season Despite Growing Lists of Supplies
description: As a young student, Tom McMahon never had to bring scissors to school.

title: Cuomo Pledges Advice and Assistance to Puerto Rico
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo completed a daylong tour to Puerto Rico on Tuesday by promising to offer advice, technical assistance and summitry to a territory facing some $72 billion in debt.

title: Dewey & LeBoeuf Chairmans Lawyer Cites Fantasy Fraud
description: The lawyer for Steven H. Davis, former chairman of Dewey & LeBoeuf, told a state jury on Tuesday that the criminal case against his client was a fantasy fraud brought by prosecutors in Manhattan with fanciful theories about the spring 2012 collapse of the once-prominent law firm.

title: Kevin Andersons Breakthrough Has a Small Cost
description: Kevin Andersons long-awaited Grand Slam breakthrough to the quarterfinals of the United States Open came at a price: $400.

title: Strike by Seattle Teachers Adds to School Turmoil in State
description: SEATTLE  The union representing about 5,000 teachers and other workers in the Seattle public schools said Tuesday night that contract talks had broken down and that the first teachers strike here in 30 years would begin on Wednesday, which had been the first scheduled day of classes.

title: Trial Ordered for Ex-Leader of Guatemala
description: GUATEMALA CITY  A Guatemalan judge ordered former President Otto Prez Molina on Tuesday to stand trial on charges of bribery, customs fraud and conspiracy, and returned him to detention.

title: Investment Strategies Meant as Buffers to Volatility May Have Deepened It
description: On Wall Street, a cure is proving to be nearly as bad as the disease.

title: Across Town, Another Arm Rests for the Long Run
description: He is a hard-throwing, homegrown, 20-something New York pitcher with a serious elbow operation in his past, a pennant race in his present and no long-term contract to cover his future. Sometimes he must rest to protect his prized right arm.

title: Perdue Buys Niman Ranch, as It Expands in Specialty Meat Business
description: Perdue, the big, family-owned poultry company, ended weeks of speculation on Tuesday when it announced that it was the buyer of Niman Ranch, a specialty meats business.

title: Youth Movement Takes a Detour at the Presidents Cup
description: Jay Haas, the United States Presidents Cup captain, held up a finger to gauge which direction the wind was blowing and somehow missed the gales of change that swept through the PGA Tour in 2015, toppling the established stars and allowing 20-something players like Rickie Fowler, Jordan Spieth, Rory McIlroy and Jason Day to grow toward the spotlight.

title: Violence Casts a Shadow Over Jouvert Celebration in Brooklyn
description: For the many thousands who flood the streets of central Brooklyn in the darkness of the first hours of Labor Day, it is a release: a chance to celebrate, in costume or out, and dance to melodies and rhythms of the Caribbean.

title: 3 Nomura Traders Accused of Deceiving Customers About Mortgage Bond Prices
description: A wide-ranging government investigation into Wall Street bond trading practices has produced new charges against three traders who worked in New York for a large Japanese financial firm.

title: Novak Djokovic and Marin Cilic Advance to the Semifinals
description: Ever since 2008, Novak Djokovic and Marin Cilic have played tennis against one another in Asia and the Middle East, in France, Canada, Ohio and New York. They have played in major tournaments, ATP events and the Davis Cup; on grass, clay and hardcourts.

title: U.S. Moves to Block Russian Military Buildup in Syria
description: WASHINGTON  The United States on Tuesday moved to head off preparations for a suspected Russian military buildup in Syria as Bulgaria agreed to an appeal from the Obama administration to shut its airspace to Russian transport planes. The planes destination was the Syrian port city of Latakia.

title: New York State Lawyer Shot in Head Is Praised for His Drive
description: In a life full of milestones, Carey W. Gabay went from picking up litter on Bronx streets as a teenager to being president of the student government at Harvard.

title: Joaquin Andujar, All-Star Who Pitched 82 Cardinals to Title, Dies at 62
description: Joaquin Andujar, a Dominican right-hander who made four National League All-Star teams and pitched in two climactic World Series games for the St. Louis Cardinals, winning one and being ejected from the other, died on Tuesday in the Dominican Republic. He was 62.

title: China Flexes Tech Muscles Before a State Visit
description: HONG KONG  As President Xi Jinping of China prepares for his first state visit to the United States this month, Washington has warned that it could hit Chinese companies with sanctions over digital attacks for trade secrets. Beijing is now pushing back in an unorthodox way: by organizing a technology forum to demonstrate its own sway over the American tech industry.

title: Hillary Clinton Dances With the Stars (Ellen DeGeneres, Amy Schumer, Pink)
description: D.J. tWitch had his work cut out for him.

title: Brad Anderson, Creator of Marmaduke, Dies at 91
description: Brad Anderson, the cartoonist who created Marmaduke, the widely syndicated comic about a mischievous but lovable Great Dane, died on Aug. 30 in The Woodlands, Tex. He was 91.

title: John Perreault, Art Critic (and Artist) Who Championed the New, Dies at 78
description: John Perreault, an art critic at The Village Voice and The SoHo Weekly News who was an early champion of feminist art and the craft-oriented pattern and decoration movement in the 1970s, and who later held senior curatorial positions at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island and the American Craft Museum, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 78.

title: Makes Every Bite Better
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE Theres a mini-meta of sorts in Michael Hawkinss puzzle. Out of the six television shows that he lists in his theme, Will Shortz has appeared as himself in two of them: in the episode Robots vs. Wrestlers on How I Met Your Mother and, in a more two-dimensional form, in the episode Homer and Lisa Exchange Cross Words on The Simpsons.

title: Serena Williams Withstands Venus Williams, Continuing Grand Slam Bid
description: It felt like a full-circle match and moment at the U.S. Open. As the large crowd milled outside Arthur Ashe Stadium full of anticipation on a steamy Tuesday night, it was hard not to flash back to the beginnings for Venus and Serena Williams.

title: N.B.A. Shifts Seeding Format for Playoffs
description: The N.B.A. Board of Governors voted to seed playoff teams based solely on their regular-season records, the league announced Tuesday, effectively removing the importance of division titles.

title: Stephen Colbert Remains Stephen Colbert in Late Show Taping
description: During the taping of his first show as host of The Late Show on CBS, while interviewing Jeb Bush, Stephen Colbert explained how he, the real Stephen Colbert, was different from the character he had played for nearly 10 years on The Colbert Report.

title: British Airways Jet Catches Fire at Las Vegas Airport
description: An engine on a British Airways jet caught fire during takeoff from Las Vegas on Tuesday, injuring seven passengers and disrupting air travel in the West, according to the airline, the airport and federal safety regulators.

A different kind of Republican! And hes hoping to jump-start his campaign by winning the endorsement of  Stephen Moore, Larry Kudlow, and Steve Forbes.

title: As Yankees Fall in Ninth, Questions Surround Rotation
description: As Adam Warren, the forgotten man of the Yankees pitching staff, was surrounded by a group of reporters on Tuesday, reliever Dellin Betances walked past and chimed in plaintively: Dont go, Adam. Dont go.

description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The goals left no doubts. The result, only more questions.

Then they sat at their lockers, still buzzing, and waited until Kirk Nieuwenhuis came off the field from his postgame interview.

description: ARLINGTON, Va.  The Pentagon will press its effort to build ties with the nations scientists and engineers at a three-day conference this week in St. Louis that will highlight a range of future technologies and serve as a forum to promote collaboration across diverse science and technology fields.

title: Roger Goodell Says Changes to His Role May Be Coming
description: After a series of stinging legal defeats, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said he would consider changing his role in governing the leagues personal conduct policy. Goodell said Tuesday on the ESPN Radio program Mike & Mike that a discipline officer or a panel making the initial decision on whether to suspend a player would make for a better system. But he said the league was against having a third-party arbitrator  something other leagues use  because the standards of the N.F.L. are important to uphold and we dont want to delegate that responsibility or standard.

title: Failure of Yahoos Alibaba Spinoff Would Have Messy Consequences
description: Yahoo informed its shareholders on Tuesday that the Internal Revenue Service had decided not to issue a private letter ruling on its proposal to spin off its $23 billion stake in Alibaba. Such a ruling would have ensured that the spinoff would be tax-free to Yahoo and its shareholders.

title: Whats On TV Wednesday
description: 1 P.M. (Starz) TERMINATOR 2: JUDGMENT DAY (1991) James Cameron directed this sequel in which two Terminators (one played by Arnold Schwarzenegger, above) have been sent back in time to battle over Sarah Connor (Linda Hamilton) and her son, John (Edward Furlong), who lead the human resistance against the robots. Mr. Cameron has made a swift, exciting special-effects epic that thoroughly justifies its vast expense and greatly improves upon the first films potent but rudimentary visual style, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. He has also broadened his initial idea to encompass better developed characters (after all, the first Terminator was barely verbal), a livelier wit and a more ambitious, if nuttier, message.

title: Nick Nixon: Photographing Slowly for 40 Years
description: For over 40 years Nick Nixon has photographed slowly, mining one vein of work deeply before moving on to his next project. Ninety-five percent of his photographs, he says, have been taken with a view camera and contact-printed from large negatives in the darkroom.

title: The Mayors Battle on Homelessness
description: The alarming abundance of people panhandling or bedding down in New York Citys streets and subways this summer has made life more complicated for Mayor Bill de Blasio. It fits neatly into a prebaked narrative about his election, which right-wing critics said foretold the collapse of New York. It has led to ugly responses by commentators and politicians and fed the sense that the mayor has a crisis on his hands.

title: An Alternative Approach to Campus Justice
description: As colleges and universities in the United States, Canada and elsewhere search for ways to handle campus misconduct, some have explored a practice called restorative justice, which focuses on repairing the harm done to the victim and the surrounding community. It has been used as an alternative or a complement to traditional disciplinary processes in cases of sexual harassment, racist behavior, alcohol violations and other offenses.

title: The Solution to Drug Prices
description: WERE paying too much for prescription drugs. The price for cancer drugs like Yervoy, Opdivo and Keytruda routinely exceeds $120,000 a year.

title: How Europes Other Half Lives
description: BUDAPEST  IT was mortifying to see refugees hurling themselves on the tracks at a Hungarian railway station  as they did last week when a train they thought was carrying them to Austria was stopped by the police in Hungary to take them to a detention camp. The migrants despair was because they didnt want to be stuck here  in the country where we Hungarians are destined to live our shabby little lives.

title: Walls, Borders, a Dome and Refugees
description: After Donald Trump proposed building a high wall all along the U.S.-Mexico border, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, not to be out-trumped, basically said, I see your wall and raise you one, stating that it was legitimate to consider building a wall along the 5,525-mile U.S.-Canada border as well.

title: Whose Neighborhood Is It?
description: On June 25, 1974, suburban residents of Detroit won their four-year battle to overturn court-ordered busing of black city students across county lines into their schools.

description: The completion of the Flight 93 National Memorial has taken 14 years. The brand new visitor center opens to the public on September 10 in Shanksville, Pa.

title: A Long Road to a Place of Peace for Flight 93 Families
description: SHANKSVILLE, Pa.  Gordon W. Felt stood perfectly still, his head bowed slightly, as he listened to the frightened voices of three long-dead victims of Flight 93, their final words captured on answering machines just before the plane crashed into a reclaimed strip mine on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: The Power of Third-Party Campaigns
Separatist
description: If you listen to Kynan Dutton, an Iraq war veteran living in rural North Dakota with his partner, Deborah Henderson, and five young children, he will tell you theyre a normal family who just want to live with their own kind  in this case, other white people.

title: Separatist
description: In this short documentary, a white separatist explains why he wanted to help transform a small North Dakota town into an all-white enclave.

title: All Choked Up
description: My grandma is lying on a rented hospital bed with oxygen nubs in her nostrils. We are at her home in California. Roses are blooming outside. The sun is shining. Shes on hospice. My parents, brothers, cousins, uncles and aunts are here. One cousin flew from as far as London. I just got in from New York.

title: 1926: Royal Birth Raises Prospect of Second Queen Elizabeth
description: LONDON  The prospect that in the ordinary course of nature  assuming the Prince of Wales remains a bachelor  a Queen Elizabeth may again sit on the English throne is held out by the birth of a daughter this morning to the Duchess of York, wife of King Georges second son. The duchesss first child and the kings first granddaughter was born at 2:40 a.m. at 17 Bruton Street, London, house of the Earl and Countess of Strathmore, the Duchess of Yorks parents. She became the third heir in the line of succession to the throne, ranking after the Prince of Wales and her father. She is expected to be christened Mary Victoria Elizabeth, respectively after Queen Mary, who will be the childs principal godmother; after Queen Victoria, whose name it has become the custom to keep in each royal generation, and after her mother, the Duchess of York. The last name will probably be that by which the child will be known, and thus a famous name in British history will be revived in the Royal family.  The New York Herald, European Edition, April 22, 1926

title: 1947: Princess Elizabeth Is Engaged
description: LONDON  The engagement of Princess Elizabeth, twenty-one-year-old heiress-presumptive to the throne of England, and Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten, twenty-six-year-old former Prince Philip of Greece, was announced to night [July 9] by her parents, King George VI and Queen Elizabeth. The young couple will be married in the autumn, probably in October, at Westminster Abbey, according to present plans. The formal announcement of the engagement was made in tonights Court Circular. It said: It is with the greatest of pleasure that the King and Queen announce the betrothal of their dearly beloved daughter, the Princess Elizabeth, to Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten. RN, son of the late Prince Andrew of Greece and Princess Andrew (Princess Alice of Battenberg), to which union the King has gladly given his consent.

title: 1947: Princess Elizabeth Weds Lieutenant Mountbatten
description: LONDON  A wedding pageant of precision, color and magnificence in the best traditions of English royal splendor unfolded today [Nov 20] before tens of thousands of people along the two-mile route from Buckingham Palace to Westminster Abbey.

title: 1952: King George VI Dies, Elizabeth Is Queen
description: LONDON  King George VI, a quiet, modest monarch, passed quietly away in his sleep early today [Feb. 6] at his country home in Sandringham, a few feet from where he was born 56 years ago. His elder daughter, Princess Elizabeth, 25, simultaneously inherited the throne. She was proclaimed Queen of Great Britain, Northern Ireland and the British Dominions Beyond the Seas by an Accession Council of 300 members who assembled at St. Jamess Palace, London, at 5 p.m. The new Queen will return here by plane tomorrow from Kenya, one of her dominions in East Africa, where she was spending a few days with her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, in the course of a tour to Ceylon, Australia and New Zealand. She will make final arrangements for the funeral.

title: Queen Elizabeth II, Britains Longest-Reigning Monarch
description: On Wednesday, Queen Elizabeth II becomes the longest-serving monarch in British history. The length of her reign surpasses that of her great-great-grandmother, Queen Victoria, who ruled for more than 63 years, from 1837 to 1901. Queen Elizabeth II ascended to the throne after the death of her father, George VI, on Feb. 6, 1952. Below, some excerpts from the archives, from her birth to her coronation:

title: News Qs | A Steady Flow Staggers Into Europe, Outpacing Pledges of Shelter
description: In A Steady Flow Staggers Into Europe, Outpacing Pledges of Shelter, Rick Lyman, Steven Erlanger and Aurelien Breeden write about how European leaders are grappling with the migrant crisis.

title: 1953: Queen Elizabeth Optimistic About Her Reign
description: LONDON  Queen Elizabeth II, in a world-wide broadcast tonight [June 2] urged her many millions of subjects to look upon her Coronation as cause for new optimism for the future. I have behind me not only the splendid traditions of the annals of more than a thousand years, she said, but the living strength of the Commonwealth empire; of societies old and new; of lands and races different in history and origin, but all by Gods will, united in spirit and in aim. Therefore I am sure that this, my Coronation, is not the symbol of a power and a splendor that are gone, but a declaration of hope for the future and for the years I may, by Gods grace and mercy, be given to reign and serve you as your Queen.

title: Living on City Island, the Bronx
description: Detached from New York Citys hustle and bustle, the island appeals to first-time buyers, artists, downsizing homeowners and boaters.

title: City Island, a Quainter Side of the Bronx
description: Faced early last year with a rent increase at their apartment in Washington Heights, Jessica Wolk-Stanley, 49, an illustrator, and her husband, Dmitry Kushnirsky, 45, an architect and avid sailor, shopped for homes in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. Leery of flood zones, they leaned toward places with heights or hill in the name.

title: Joseph Altuzarra and the Coat That Changed His Career
description: A scant half-dozen years ago, Joseph Altuzarra, 32, a 2005 Swarthmore graduate and former assistant at Marc Jacobs and Proenza Schouler, was anointed by the fashion world as a freshly minted talent, a young man to watch.

title: Whats Coming During Fashion Month
description: Its fashion month, that four-city marathon of clothes and celebrities that matters to everyone because it determines what we will wear and, at least partly, how we will spend our money come 2016.

title: Church, Rising at Trade Center Site, Will Glow Where Darkness Fell
description: What is most amazing about the World Trade Center, 14 years after the terrorist attack, is that it is steadily growing less amazing.

title: What Is Your Reaction to the Kentucky County Clerk Who Refuses to Issue Same-Sex Marriage Licenses?
description: Last week a Kentucky county clerk went to jail after she refused to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples. Her very public defiance of the Supreme Court turned her into a hero for some and a villain for others.

title: E.U. Nations Urged to Accept 160,000 Migrants
description: BRUSSELS  The European Unions top executive proposed a plan on Wednesday to distribute 160,000 migrants throughout the member nations, even while acknowledging that this measure alone was inadequate to the depth of the crisis.

title: Beauty Is a Wound and Man Tiger by Eka Kurniawan
description: In what is presumably late 1965, as Indonesia is racked by violence in the wake of a failed coup blamed on Communists, a gravedigger named Kamino hits upon a novel method of seduction: He allows himself to be possessed by the spirit of a recently murdered Communist so that the Communists daughter can speak with her father one last time. In gratitude, she cooks Kamino dinner. A week later, after Kamino has buried 1,232 Communists in one mass grave, she accepts his marriage proposal. By the time the newlyweds return from their honeymoon, Eka Kurniawans fictional Javanese city of Halimunda is filled with corpses sprawled out in the irrigation channels and on the outskirts of the city, in the foothills and on the riverbanks, in the middle of bridges and under bushes. Most of them had been killed as they tried to escape.

title: Date-Onomics, The Sex Myth and Modern Romance
description: Back when adultery and gay sex were widely criminalized in the United States, when masturbation was thought to make you crazy and fellatio was taboo, the Kinsey Institute famously revealed that Americans were secretly less faithful, more gay, more various in their sexual practices and more perverse than most wanted to think. Sixty years later, many of us have come to regard sex  preferably passionate, hot, transformative sex  as central to our lives. In the time of Tinder, our sexuality feels anything but secret. But romance is still mysterious  what does it feel like for everyone else?  and three new books try to explain modern mating.

title: Resort and Cruise News: Tennis With Connors; Trips in Alaska
description: Our morning travel news digest, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Why Runners Get Slower With Age (and How Strength Training May Help)
description: Young runners are different from you and me. They have more speed. And to achieve that swiftness, they use certain leg muscles quite differently than runners past age 50 do, according to a new study of runners strides at different ages. The study also intimates that many of us might be able to reinvigorate our flagging pace with the right type of strength training.

title: Morning Agenda: Yahoo Rethinks Alibaba Spinoff
description: YAHOO RETHINKS ALIBABA SPINOFF | Yahoo is reconsidering its plan to spin off its $23 billion stake in Alibaba after the United States tax authorities declined to rule in advance on whether the transaction would mean huge capital gains taxes for Yahoo and its shareholders, Vindu Goel reports in The New York Times.

title: The Daunting Din: Readers React to Noisy Restaurants
description: Jeff Gordiniers article on efforts to combat noise levels in New York restaurants inspired readers to post comments sharing their own frustration about the din and theories as to why owners would let their dining rooms get so loud. Selections from those comments are below; some have been edited for space.

title: Candidates Address the Growing Refugee Crisis
description: The migrant crisis in the Middle East and Europe shows no signs of abating, and if it worsens in the coming weeks, candidates running for president of the United States will continue to be asked how they would solve the problem.

title: Review: On Late Show Premiere, Stephen Colbert Tries to Bring Big Back to Late Night
description: Stephen Colbert was not given to effusions of humility when he played a blowhard pundit on his Comedy Central series. But he opened his first night as host of The Late Show with one. I am not replacing David Letterman, he insisted.

title: Today in Politics: Hillary Clinton to Weigh In on Iran Deal as Donald Trump and Ted Cruz Try to Crush It
description: Good Wednesday morning. The fate of the nuclear deal with Iran was high on the to-do list of lawmakers returning from vacation. But on Wednesday, the debate leaps to the front of the campaign trail as Hillary Rodham Clinton is set to speak to its merits, and Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas are holding a rally at the Capitol to tell the expected crowd of thousands what they think about the catastrophic deal.

title: Why We Should Fear University, Inc.
description: Here at Purdue University, where I recently completed my Ph.D. in English, we have a little garden on the far west side of our enormous campus, where students and their families and professors and nearby residents tend to tomatoes and sunflowers. Its one of my favorite places here. Overgrown and seemingly unmanaged, this western fringe of campus is perhaps the only place left at the university that is not meticulously landscaped and stage-managed for tour groups and the website. Theres nothing specific to Purdue in this aesthetic conformity. Over the past two decades, financial crises notwithstanding, the American university writ large has undergone a radical physical expansion and renovation, bringing more and more campuses into line with grand architectural visions. Thats precisely why I love the garden: Its one of the last little wild places left at Purdue. Naturally, its slated for demolition.

title: A Prescription for More Black Doctors
description: Norman Francis was just a few years into his tenure as president of Xavier University of Louisiana, a small Catholic institution in New Orleans, when a report that came across his desk alarmed him. It was an accounting of the nations medical students, and it found that the already tiny number of black students attending medical school was dropping.

title: Teaching Martin Luther King Jr. in the Age of Freddie Gray
description: In 1968, when my father was a teenage boy in Memphis, Martin Luther King Jr. went there to support the citys striking sanitation workers. He marched with King and thousands of other protesters, and in the violence that erupted afterward, the police shot another black boy, Larry Payne. They claimed he was a looter. King called Paynes mother to console her, but a planned visit never happened. King was murdered just a few days later.

title: At Arnhem Festival, Living Dolls Are on Display
description: On Sept. 26 and 27, more than a quarter-million people are expected to fill the streets of Arnhem, the Netherlands, to marvel at dozens of living dolls from at least 20 countries competing for the World Championship of Living Statues at the eighth World Living Statues Festival. Topping the list of contestants is John Eicke, 50, of Berlin, the only two-time winner, in 2010 and 2013. Mr. Eicke, a professional performer who goes by JOHNman, has displayed his multiple personas at arts festivals in nearly 30 countries and will return to Arnhem this year. Following are edited excerpts from an interview with Mr. Eicke.

He moved away in the 1970s for lack of prospects. Now there are shops, restaurants, boutique properties and gobs of tourists.

title: Queen Elizabeth II Becomes Britains Longest-Reigning Monarch
