title: Fashion Week, Reinvented
description: Imagine this: There you are, relaxing in your favorite ergonomic recliner, flipping channels on your tablet or TV, sipping green juice or espresso or chardonnay, when you come across a program featuring Maria Sharapova, Emma Stone, Charlize Theron and Kobe Bryant.

title: Robert Fairchild to Spin Briefly Back to City Ballet
description: If ballet seemed to go Broadway during the past year, with top dancers appearing on the Great White Way, a little bit of Broadway will be returning to the ballet this season.

title: At Performa and Crossing the Line, Barreling Through the Fourth Wall
description: This fall, two ambitious festivals, Crossing the Line and Performa, will try to take over New York: not only in theaters and gallery spaces but also on sidewalks. Havens for multidisciplinary performance and dance, each dispenses with convention in favor of adventurous programming that makes you think as much about your place in the world as about the art itself.

title: A Dance Season of Premieres Mixed With Masterworks
description: There are proven masterpieces to be seen this fall, but on paper what looks crucial is the wealth of new works on offer. Premieres are coming our way by Michelle Dorrance, Mark Morris, Justin Peck, Troy Schumacher, Paul Taylor, Twyla Tharp; and by many others too. Any good artist can have a fiasco; but the mere facts here whet the appetite.

title: How an Areas Union Membership Can Predict Childrens Advancement
description: It is well established that unions provide benefits to workers  that they raise wages for their members (and even for nonmembers). They can help reduce inequality.

title: Aakash Odedra and Jean Butler, Mixing Tradition and Innovation
description: I first encountered the dancer Aakash Odedra in 2013 at the Apollo Theater in Harlem, where he was spinning and fast-stepping to a remix of James Brown. This was a curious first sighting, considering that Mr. Odedra, who is British, is trained in the classical Indian forms of kathak and bharatanatyam. But he was up to the challenge of adapting those vocabularies to foreign grooves. The audience went wild, and his performance in the Brown tribute revue Get on the Good Foot won him a Bessie award.

title: The American Classical Orchestra and Juilliard415 Mine Telemanns Gold
description: Georg Philipp Telemann composed too many works for his own good, or posteritys. Factory products, the 19th-century music publisher and writer Hermann Mendel called them, achieved by dint of sedulous scribbling (as quoted in Richard Petzoldts Telemann biography).

title: Esa-Pekka Salonen Explores Messiaens Masterly Turangalla-Symphonie
description: The Finnish composer and conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen, the composer in residence at the New York Philharmonic this season, has described the moment when he first heard Messiaens Turangalla-Symphonie as an amazing shock, because of its completely new landscape. Mr. Salonen, who has been much discussed as a possible successor to Alan Gilbert as the Philharmonics music director, will conduct Messiaens glittering, otherworldly masterpiece on March 10-12 at Avery Fisher Hall as part of a weeklong exploration of the music of that visionary French composer, who died in 1992.

title: Mark Padmore Takes on Winterreise and More
description: New Yorkers have enjoyed a, well, flurry of performances of Schuberts Winterreise (Winter Journey) over the past couple of seasons. Among recent standout performers of this heart-scrapingly bleak song cycle about love lost and obsessed over during a winters travels are the baritones Gerald Finley, Christian Gerhaher and Matthias Goerne. In fact, ever since the iconic recordings by Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, this cycle has been so firmly associated with baritones that it is easy to forget that Schubert initially wrote it for the tenor voice. On Oct. 17 at Alice Tully Hall, the English tenor Mark Padmore will present what should be a memorable Winterreise at Lincoln Centers White Light Festival.

title: 1890: Flooding Recedes in Vienna
description: VIENNA Yesterday being a public holiday here, offices and shops remained closed in Vienna, and many thousands of people thronged the Kron Prinz Rudolf-bridge and other points of vantage to enjoy the sight of the Danube in its present grandeur. Since yesterday the Danube has been steadily falling, and Vienna may now be considered entirely out of danger. Today it is expected the over flow water will return into the river bed. The larger part of the Prater remains impassable for pedestrians. The Freudenau racecourse resembles a large lake, and it is feared has been much injured.  The New York Herald, European Edition, September 10, 1890

title: The Fantasy Might Be Believing Adrian Peterson Is Still a No. 1 Pick
description: The pro football season starts Thursday, which means fantasy football starts Thursday as well. For some fans, that is the more exciting news.

title: Helping Children Balance School and Fun
description: I love September. I still get that new-school-year thrill when I get a whiff of freshly sharpened pencils and crisp, unsullied notebooks. Unfortunately, September also stinks of a return to the same old struggles we left behind in a heap amid the sticky lunchboxes and ripped backpacks of last June.

title: At a Brooklyn Shop, Bras From A to M
description: There are simple T-shirt bras and lacy lingerie. Silky slips and nursing bras. Shapewear, strapless, corsets, bathing suits. The sizes run from the smallest smalls all the way up to a 46M. For items that are mostly meant to be hidden by clothing, underwear comes in a wide selection. But at Iris Lingerie in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, customers rarely paw through the racks of unmentionables. Instead, women put themselves in the capable hands of Iris Clarke.

title: Revivals That Illuminate the Mets Future
description: One of the most anticipated events of the new season at the Metropolitan Opera comes on the gala opening night, Sept. 21, with the premiere of Bartlett Shers production of Verdis Otello. The next three offerings during the first week, all revivals, at first glance seem much less newsy.

title: Down Syndrome and Abortion: Readers Share Their Stories
description: As legislators in Ohio consider banning abortion following a fetal diagnosis of Down syndrome, readers shared stories of abortion decisions and living with family members with the disorder.

title: Andris Nelsons Named Music Director of Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra
description: The career of Andris Nelsons, the dynamic young conductor who became music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra last season, continued its crescendo on Wednesday when he was named the next music director of the venerable Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra.

title: An Emotional First Day of School
description: School began for more than one million public school students in New York City, whether they liked it or not.

title: BAM Presents a Survey of 14 Ingrid Bergman Films
description: Forever luminous in our memories, Ingrid Bergman would have been 100 last month, and to celebrate, the Brooklyn Academy of Music has assembled a 14-film survey that runs through Sept. 29. Screenings begin on Sunday with the classic Casablanca (1942), which features her most famous role: the angelic Ilsa Lund, the thing that keeps Victor Laszlo going. On Saturday is the more complicated Notorious, the 1946 Hitchcock thriller in which she plays Alicia Huberman, the dissolute, self-destructive daughter of a Nazi spy. The role eerily anticipated the scandalous reputation that would attach to her in the early 1950s, after she left her husband and daughter for the Italian director Roberto Rossellini.

title: Works From African Kongo Art at the Metropolitan Museum
description: In this Kingdom of Kongo, they make fabrics with a nap like velvet, some of them worked in velvety satin, so beautiful that nothing finer is made in Italy, wrote the Portuguese explorer Duarte Pacheco Pereira, one of the first but certainly not the last European to wax ecstatic over the sumptuous artistic production of the political power that ruled over the vast territory that today includes part of the Republic of Congo, Angola and the Democratic Republic of Congo.

title: Hillary Clinton Backs Iran Nuclear Deal, With Caveats
description: WASHINGTON  With Donald J. Trump rallying at the Capitol Wednesday against President Obamas nuclear deal with Iran, Hillary Rodham Clinton embraced the agreement a short distance away. But she warned it would work only as part of a larger strategy toward Iran that contained Tehrans power in the region as sanctions are lifted.

title: The Singers of Mycale Blend Voices in Zorns Book of Angels
description: Mycale is  prepare yourself now for context  a four-woman vocal group brought together by John Zorn to perform original a cappella arrangements from Book of Angels, the second galaxy in his universe of succinct compositions collectively titled Masada, all of which use the so-called Jewish scales. (Among the many others who have recorded parts of Book of Angels: the guitarist Pat Metheny, the cellist Erik Friedlander, the guitarist Marc Ribot, the trio Medeski, Martin & Wood.) Mycale is Ayelet Rose Gottlieb, Sofia Rei, Sara Serpa and Malika Zarra  from Israeli, Argentine, Portuguese and Moroccan backgrounds  singing texts in Hebrew, French, Spanish, Portuguese and Arabic, from the Hebrew Bible, Rumi, Fernando Pessoa, Heraclitus and elsewhere. And the groups second record, Gomory: The Book of Angels, Vol. 25 (Tzadik), released in May, is astonishingly beautiful, a high point in the series: The singers individually rigorous tones and dispositions and arranging impulses surround the music and give it another dimension of originality; it sounds medieval and new at the same time.

title: Kim Davis Takes Break From Work,but Commotion Goes On
description: MOREHEAD, Ky.  Kim Davis, the Rowan County clerk who went to jail after refusing to issue marriage licenses, was not at work Wednesday and will not return until next week.

title: Cello and Percussion Performances in Queens and Manhattan
description: Friendship and travel are the twin sources of the Australian-born composer Kate Moores Stories for Ocean Shells, an hourlong collection of short pieces she wrote for the cellist Ashley Bathgate, a bright light on the new-music scene and a member of the Bang on a Can All-Stars. On Sunday afternoon at the Noguchi Museum in Queens, Ms. Bathgate will perform the entire suite, which she and Ms. Moore call a picture book that reflects Ms. Moores travels as well as the two womens deepening ties.

title: Agatha Christies Partners in Crime Places Detectives in the Cold War
description: There was the British invasion associated with the Beatles, and in recent years there has been another: A veritable army of British detectives and other crime fighters have crossed the ocean and ended up on American television. Among the latest are the Beresfords, a couple created by Agatha Christie and now seen on Acorn TV in Agatha Christies Partners in Crime.

title: 4 Moments That Didnt Make Stephen Colberts Late Show Premiere
description: Like someone who cant help but overindulge on too many Oreo cookies, Stephen Colbert had more material than he needed for his first episode as host of CBSs The Late Show on Tuesday. After a taping that ran about two hours, the show was cut down to about 70 minutes for air. Though some of that extra material has been released as bonus content on the web, heres some of what you didnt see on Mr. Colberts debut broadcast.

title: Clive Owens Broadway Debut in Pinters Old Times
description: The last time the Roundabout Theater produced Old Times, in 1984, its dramatist, Harold Pinter, came to rehearsal to offer help to its cast. As reported in The New York Times, Anthony Hopkins, who starred, asked him to explain the plays ending. Pinters response: I dont know. Just do it. Pinter has since died, but his masterly and enigmatic dramas, as spare as his advice to actors, endure, although New York is perhaps due for a revival of Old Times (an acclaimed English production in 2013 starred Rufus Sewell). The 1971 play is about a couple who are visited by an old friend of the wifes whose stories from the past startle and confuse, setting up a classic Pinter power struggle that manages to be both brutal and elusive at once. In this new production, the Oscar nominee Clive Owen makes his Broadway debut opposite Eve Best (who starred in the Broadway revival of Pinters The Homecoming) and Kelly Reilly (True Detective, the Donmar Warehouses After Miss Julie). Douglas Hodge directs. (Previews start on Sept. 17, American Airlines Theater, roundabouttheatre.org.)

title: Clinton Apologizes for Email Mistake
description: Hillary Clinton, the Democratic presidential nominee, said in two interviews that she was sorry for using two email addresses and a private server while she was secretary of state.

title: Friends at Work? Maybe, Maybe Not.
description: Readers shared their views on a recent Sunday Review essay that argued Americans need to socialize more in the office.

title: 1965: Pakistani Army Invades India
description: KARACHI  Pakistani troops drove into India east of Lahore tonight after pushing Indian forces across the border at Wagah, a Pakistani spokesman said. India neither affirmed nor denied the Pakistani announcement and said only that heavy fighting was in progress in most sectors. According to radio reports reaching Karachi, Pakistans first invasion into east Punjab followed a heavy counterattack against Indian tank troops at Wagah, which was the crossing point for Indias first invasion of Pakistan last Monday. The second invasion point was at Jassar, 60 miles from Lahore.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 10, 1965

title: Irans Supreme Leader Says Israel Wont Exist in 25 Years
description: TEHRAN  Irans supreme leader predicted Wednesday that Israel would not exist in 25 years, and ruled out any new negotiations with the Satan, the United States, beyond the recently completed nuclear accord.

title: The Future of Touch Beyond Apple Watch
description: Apple used haptic technology in its watch to deliver notifications by tapping on a users wrist. Now tech firms are finding more ways to, as one researcher said, let people feel things that arent actually there.

title: National Geographic and Fox Form a Commercial Media Company
description: Since 1888, the National Geographic Society has stood for science, discovery and storytelling. Its yellow-bordered magazine has served as the ultimate stage for award-winning photography, depicting the wonders of the world, and the group has supported pursuits as diverse as the underwater explorations of Jacques-Yves Cousteau and Jane Goodalls study of chimpanzees in Tanzania.

title: Texas Officials on Referee Hit
description: Officials with a San Antonio school district said on Wednesday that two football players said a referee directed racial slurs at them before they rammed into him during a high school game.

title: Clinton Defends Iran Nuclear Deal
description: The Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton backed the Iran deal in a speech at the Brookings Institution in Washington on Wednesday.

title: Freddie Gray Settlement Approved by Baltimore Officials
description: WASHINGTON  Baltimore officials voted Wednesday to approve a $6.4 million settlement for the family of Freddie Gray, the 25-year-old black man whose death from a spinal cord injury sustained in police custody set off the worst rioting the city has seen since 1968 and led to criminal charges against six police officers.

title: What Three Cool New York Shop Owners Are Wearing Now (And What Theyre Betting On This Fashion Week)
description: Here, three influential store owners, each with a distinctive point of view, on what they picked up for fall and the designers theyre keeping an eye on this season. (And the trends they are so over.)

title: Cloud Gate Troupe Takes Rice to Howard Gilman Opera House
description: When 24 dancers from the Cloud Gate Dance Theater of Taiwan step onto the stage in Lin Hwai-mins Rice, they are metaphorically crossing a field in a tribute to their islands essential agricultural crop.

title: Puerto Ricos Debt Plan
description: The five-year plan calls for restructuring about $47 billion of Puerto Ricos $72 billion in bond debt and carrying out economic overhauls under an independent financial control board.

title: High School Football Players Who Blindsided Referee Say He Made Racist Remarks
description: On a high school football field in Texas, one player made a beeline for a referee, slamming into him from behind and knocking him down.

title: Jeb Bushs Tax Plan Looks to Cut Loopholes for Wealthy
description: Former Gov. Jeb Bush is challenging some long-held tenets of conservative tax policy with a populist plan that targets valuable deductions that benefit the wealthy and the carried interest loophole that has enriched hedge fund managers for years.

title: In Mayoral Race, Nashville Politics Forgets Its Manners
description: NASHVILLE  Tonally, this citys politics and its most famous export, country music, could not be more different. While the music is full of punched-up emotion and raw tales of wrongdoing, the politics, in recent decades, has tended to be drama-averse, sober-minded and even a bit wonkish.

title: New York City Health Board Backs Warning on Menu Items With High Salt
description: The New York City Board of Health unanimously approved a measure on Wednesday that will require many chain restaurants to post a warning label on menu items that have a high sodium content.

title: The Detroit Graduates
description: Attention shifted away from Detroit after it emerged from bankruptcy. For five high school students, life has moved on, sometimes in unexpected ways, as the city struggles to get back on its feet.

title: The Illustrated Interview: Dave Eggers
description: In this series for T, notables from the worlds of fashion, art, design and entertainment sketch their responses to a brief questionnaire.

title: Queen Elizabeth Thanks Well-Wishers
description: Queen Elizabeth II spoke in Tweedbank, Scotland, on Wednesday, the day she became the longest-reigning monarch in Britains history.

title: Jennifer Lawrence Has No Appetite for Playing Fame Games
description: LOS ANGELES  I picture myself drowning.

title: What You Need to Know About iOS 9
description: Apple has made some small but marked improvements to its mobile operating system.

title: Test Driving Apples iOS 9
description: Apple introduced   new iPhones on Wednesday and will follow a week later by releasing iOS 9, its next mobile operating system. That may bring back some bad memories for consumers who felt chagrined by the last iOS rollout.

title: Fantasy Football Week 1: Rankings and Matchup Analysis
description: You have heard us say it before: N.F.L. Week 1 is the toughest fantasy football week to prepare for, for the simple reason that we are starting from scratch.

title: Antibiotic Use Tied to Diabetes Risk
description: Danish researchers have found an association between the use of antibiotics and the development of Type 2 diabetes.

title: Israel Bans 2 Muslim Groups That Protest at Jerusalem Holy Site
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Israel on Wednesday officially outlawed an organization of Muslim women who chase and shout at Jewish visitors to a contested holy site in Jerusalems Old City, along with a less-vocal affiliated group of men.

title: Hand to God Sets Broadway Closing Date
description: Alert the Transportation Security Administration: Tyrone, the diabolical sock puppet from Hand to God, is heading to London.

title: Reaction to Kim Daviss Release Floods Social Media
description: Reaction to the release of Kim Davis, the Kentucky county clerk who was jailed for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, has ranged from the political stage to debate over the place of personal religious beliefs in the workplace.

title: Uniform Design
description: With the military on their minds, designers are drafting a new kind of uniform.

title: A New Kind of Uniform
description: DESIGNERS HAVE always had a soft spot for the hard men who protect us during wartime. The word panache, after all, is borrowed from the French term for a plume on a helmet. This season, they seem taken with the romantic side of the historical soldier, with clothing that evokes sepia-toned photographs and the verse of Rupert Brooke. Inspired by military drabs with a dose of sober black, designers have created an aura more poetic than macho. Sarah Burton at Alexander McQueen celebrated a hero returned, his coat emblazoned with eight-point stars resembling the Grand Cross of the Order of the British Empire. Gucci accessorized a military-style jacket with a bag whose strap was reminiscent of the Sam Browne belt, named after the British officer who created it at the dawn of the Raj era. Craig Green reinterpreted the billowing straps of the daring parachutist.

title: Has The Times Dismissed Bernie Sanders?
description: Updated, 6 p.m., to include the link to a separate post with Carolyn Ryans response.

title: Passengers on Escaping Plane Fire
description: Passengers described evacuating a British Airways flight that caught fire on Tuesday before its planned takeoff at McCarren International Airport in Las Vegas.

title: The League Creators Jeff and Jackie Schaffer on Their Shows Final Season
description: Unlike most other TV shows, FXXs fantasy football-themed comedy The League has never needed a writers room. Its husband-and-wife creators, Jeff Schaffer and Jackie Marcus Schaffer, write the shows story lines, and a core cast of six improv all-stars provide its caustic, insult-flinging voice. Now theyre hanging up their cleats: The shows seventh season, which premieres on Wednesday night, is its final one.

title: 36 Hours in Portland
description: Portland, Oregons largest little city, is a bastion of creative living, excellent food, happy inebriation and devotion to the great outdoors.

title: Donald Trump Brings Theatrics to Iran Nuclear Deal Protest
description: Tea Party and other conservatives had hoped to make their gathering in Washington on Wednesday a clarion call to rally against the Iran nuclear deal, drawing on the star power of Donald J. Trump, the rhetoric of Senator Ted Cruz and a cast of 40 or so supporting characters speaking on a stage with the United States Capitol looming in the background.

title: Ford Looks to Carla Bruni-Sarkozy to Bolster Sales in France
description: Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, model, chanteuse and former French first lady, has given up show business to pursue her true passion: coaching a provincial soccer team.

title: 36 Hours in Portland, Ore.
description: There is no place in the country better known as a bastion of good living, leisure and happy inebriation than Oregons largest little city, the low-lying mini-metropolis of Portland. Bisected by a river and surrounded by peaks, Portland is nothing if not a very pretty and almost preternaturally pleasant town. But much of its appeal comes from being, for better or worse, one of our national capitals of cool. The citys sensibility  its stylized aesthetic, its thoroughly hyped food culture, its taste for irony  is celebrated, imitated and satirized. Portland is at its best, though, when you step back from its overwrought reputation and appreciate its appetite for simple pleasures: beer and bike riding, day trips to the Columbia River or Sauvie Islands farm stands, movies in vintage theaters and cocktails in ornate lounges.

title: Daniel N. Durant, Telling Stories With His Hands
description: Daniel N. Durant has never heard a sound. Now hes starring in a Broadway musical.

title: Jefferies May Be Canary in Wall Streets Shuttered Mine
description: As markets whipsawed last month, a dubious meme made the rounds on Wall Street. If big banks like Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase could put their own capital to work, investors would not have endured so much volatility, or so the thinking went. But thanks to new regulations in the Dodd-Frank Act, they had to sit idly by, unable to either profit much or lend a hand.

title: Inside Simone Rochas Mount Street Store
description: The designer opens her first brick-and-mortar location in London this month.

title: Simone Rocha on Her (Very Personal) First Store
description: Its been five years since Simone Rocha first showed at London Fashion Week, when she was just a promising Central Saint Martins graduate with a familiar last name. (Her father, John Rocha, had long been on the schedule with his eponymous label, run in partnership with her mother, Odette Gleeson.) But over the last 10 seasons, the younger Rocha has built a brand that has little to do with her family. Her textural, tough-romantic clothes have won her two British Fashion Awards, for Emerging Designer 2013 and New Establishment Designer 2014, and today her pieces are stocked by the likes of Dover Street Market, Colette, Bergdorf Goodman and 10 Corso Como. Finally, this fall, she has opened her first standalone store on Londons Mount Street, alongside Marc Jacobs, Roksanda and Cline.

title: Senior Sinn Fein Member Arrested in Northern Ireland Murder
description: DUBLIN  The fragile provincial government in Northern Ireland teetered on the brink on Wednesday evening after the arrest of a senior member of Sinn Fein, the Irish nationalist party that shares power with British unionists, in connection with a murder last month that the police have linked to Irish Republican Army operatives.

title: At Barnes & Noble, Chief Is New, but Earnings Woes Are Old
description: It was only Ronald Boires second day on the job as Barnes & Nobles new chief executive, and a rough initiation awaited him on Wednesday as the company posted disappointing results for its most recent quarter.

title: In Denmark, Migrants Aim for Sweden
description: Hundreds of people walked along a road north of Padborg, Denmark, toward Sweden on Wednesday.

title: Puerto Ricos Governor on Economic Plan
description: Gov. Alejandro Garca Padilla revealed a new economic plan for Puerto Rico on Wednesday, which includes major debt restructuring.

title: Iran Deal Debate Delayed as Talk of Secret Deals Divides G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  Confronted with a rank-and-file uprising, House Republican leaders on Wednesday abruptly shifted tactics in their battle against President Obamas nuclear deal with Iran, splitting off from their Senate colleagues and all but ensuring that no legislation opposing the accord will emerge from Congress this month.

title: Bard College Partners With Trisha Brown Dance Company
description: The Trisha Brown Dance Company is extending its reach to academia by partnering with Bard Colleges dance program for classes, workshops and performances.

title: Stephen Colberts Debut Tops Late-Night Ratings
description: Stephen Colbert won his first outing as CBSs new late-night host, as 6.6 million viewers tuned in late Tuesday night to watch The Late Show.

title: Text to Text | Lets Give Up on the Constitution and The Constitution of the United States
description: Sometimes the best way to appreciate the value of something is to take it away. Thats why Prof. Louis Michael Seidmans Op-Ed Lets Give Up on the Constitution can work as a catalyst for students to consider the relevance and significance of the Constitution today. What would happen if we stopped feeling obligated to the Constitution? And how should the words on this centuries-old parchment guide our current and future civic discourse?

title: Ted Cruz at Rally to Condemn Iran Pact
description: Mr. Cruz spoke at a rally against the nuclear agreement with Iran, saying that if it is approved the Obama administration will become the worlds leading financier of radical Islamic terrorism.

title: Billie Holiday, via Hologram, Returning to the Apollo
description: Billie Holiday often sang about being blue, but when she appears at the Apollo later this year shell be closer to translucent. The Apollo has partnered with Hologram USA to bring extended, permanent hologram technology to the theater. Ms. Holiday, who performed at the Apollo in the flesh nearly 30 times, will be the first, and is scheduled to debut around Thanksgiving.

title: Another Unexpected Stop
description: A train carrying a large group of migrants to Sweden, including the Majid family, came to an abrupt stop in Denmark, where the police asked everyone to disembark.

title: Paid For, by Rachel Moran
description: A few months after she began selling sex on the streets of Dublin at 15, Rachel Moran writes in her memoir, Paid For, a pack of teenage girls descended upon her on the sidewalk and beat her. As the girls retreated, Moran remembers, one of them turned and screamed back at me, Your body is your own and no one elses! That the lesson came with blows did not bother Moran, at least at the time of writing. On the contrary, she sees it as a misdirected expression of justified female fury at the sex trade. Prostitution is objectionable to females, she writes. I of all people know that.

title: Hillary Clinton Says U.S. Should Lead Effort to Help Syrian Migrants
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday urged the United States to lead the effort in assisting and resettling the millions of Syrian migrants who have fled to Europe and elsewhere to escape the civil war ravaging their country.

title: Apple Unveils iPhone 6S, and Breaks Own Taboos With Other Offerings
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As it nears a size and scope never before approached by a technology company, Apple is doing things its executives said it never would.

title: With Red Lipstick, Indian Acid Attack Victim Makes a Bold Statement
description: In her peppy and helpful online video tutorial, Reshma Bano Qureshi promises to teach her viewers how to get perfect red lips.

title: Test Your Knowledge of New York Fashion Week
description: How much do you really know about New York Fashion Week, the designers who show here and the front-row faces?

title: Start-Up Watch Geeks Take on Old Giants
description: For budding entrepreneurs, the watch industry would seem a strange place to start.

title: Dana Schutz: Fight in an Elevator
description: The painters new show opens tomorrow at Petzel Gallery.

title: Facts & Figures: Sarah Palins Glacier Claims
description: Apropos of President Obamas visit to Alaska, Sarah Palin cited the fact that some glaciers are growing in size as evidence against human-caused climate change. Obama was up here looking at, say, the glaciers and pointing out a glacier that was receding, she said on CNN over the weekend. Well, there are other glaciers, though, that are growing up here.

title: An Uninhibited New Show from an Art-World Provocateur
description: Ask Dana Schutz, as a reasonable person might, why she painted a man eating his own face  or a gyrating woman simultaneously cooking and urinating in her kitchen, or the autopsy of Michael Jackson, four years prior to his actual death  and her guileless reply often boils down to some variation on: I wanted to see if I could. Though she frames these assays as essentially formal challenges, skirmishes between painter and paint, Schutzs imagination has given rise to some of the most memorably skewed canvases of the past 15 years. That she so often succeeds reflects the sheer visual appeal of her clamorous palette, her bold gestures, and her knack for reflecting all-too-human foibles in absurdist scenarios.

title: Jeb Bush Tax Plan Makes Forays Into Populism
description: WASHINGTON  Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida challenged some long-held tenets of conservative tax policy on Wednesday by proposing to curtail valuable deductions that benefit businesses and the wealthy and eliminate a loophole that has benefited hedge fund and private equity managers for years.

title: Trump Condemns Iran Pact
description: Donald J. Trump told a crowd at a rally in Washington on Wednesday that he had never seen any transaction so incompetently negotiated as the Iran nuclear deal.

title: The Last Stretch to Sweden
description: A group of migrants, who were aiming to go to Sweden but were being detained by the police in Denmark, defiantly marched on.

title: App Smart | Panoramic Photos
description: Sometimes the viewfinder of your phone doesnt do justice to the vista in front of you. Thats when panorama apps come in handy.

title: Video Feature: Get the Broader View From a Smartphone Camera
description: Summer has waned. The children are back in school. Some of you may be looking back at the vistas in your summer holiday photos and already plotting the next getaway.

title: 4 Killed by Nepal Police in Clashes Over Draft Constitution
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  Four protesters were fatally shot by the Nepalese police on Wednesday amid clashes over Nepals draft constitution.

title: N.F.L. Thursday Matchup: Pittsburgh Steelers at New England Patriots
description: 8:30 p.m. Eastern, NBC

title: Migrant Tide Bringing Out Europes Best and Worst
description: BERLIN  Thousands of volunteers have heeded calls to help the stream of migrants arriving in Europe in recent days, cheering them at train stations in Austria and Germany and showering them with food, drinks and toys. But signs of tension have continued to appear this week, even in the most welcoming countries, reflecting fear, misunderstanding or racism as the Continent struggles to cope with an influx of tens of thousands of people.

title: Classical Playlist: Brahms, Vivaldi and Tallis
description: Brahms: The Complete Songs, Vol. 6Ian Bostridge, tenor; Graham Johnson, piano(Hyperion)In his complete lieder surveys for the Hyperion label, one of Graham Johnsons great talents has been matching songs to singer, building recital recordings that work on their own and also suit the demands of the whole. Ian Bostridges reflective, often pained way with words would not suit all of Brahmss songs, but, despite occasional strain, this is one of the tenors finest releases. Take the Opus 85 landscapes, the Heine settings Sommerabend and Mondenschein, which shimmer with detail, or the last of the Opus 32 Lieder und Gesnge, Wie bist du, meine Knigin  a master class of descriptive subtlety from singer and pianist alike. (David Allen)

title: Man Charged With Fraud Scheme Involving Forged Mets Officials Signatures
description: Federal prosecutors on Wednesday charged a New Jersey man with a fraud scheme that involved fake leases for office equipment and a case of identity theft using forged signatures of New York Mets officials.

title: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
description: Greece and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Bard Training Orchestra Announces First Season
description: Bard Colleges new training orchestra, called The Orchestra Now, announced Wednesday that it was welcoming its first 37 musicians this month and that it would perform concerts this season at Bard, Carnegie Hall, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and elsewhere.

title: September 9, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Greece, Hungary, Yemen and Samoa.

title: Report Details New Atrocities in Darfur by Sudanese Force

title: Review: In Exceptional, the Cheneys Make Obama the Villain

Nearly seven years after leaving office, Dick Cheney has produced a book that amounts to a stinging indictment of President Obama as an ineffectual, America-hating, military-destroying, soft-on-terrorism appeaser whose tenure has damaged the country.

Shortly after, Mr. Renfrow recalled being shoved into a wall by a corrections officer and warned to keep quiet about what he had seen.

description: LOS ANGELES  As Eli Broad prepares for the Sept. 20 opening of his self-named, self-financed $140 million art museum on Grand Avenue, he faces a branding challenge, among others.

At its media event in San Francisco on Wednesday, Apple added just a handful of features to its latest smartphones, the 6S and 6S Plus, including a pressure-sensitive screen, better cameras and a new color  pink, or Rose Gold, in Apples marketing argot.

description: After hearing for many weeks from readers about their disappointment with how The Times is covering the presidential candidacy of Bernie Sanders, I addressed those complaints in a post on Wednesday afternoon.

description: NEW ORLEANS  Commissioner Roger Goodell said Wednesday that he did not expect imminent changes to the N.F.L.s disciplinary process and that any revisions would be made as part of the next collective bargaining agreement.

description: After Stephen Colbert came twirling onto his new stage for the first episode of The Late Show on Tuesday, he thanked his adoring crowd, then looked straight up to the ceiling of the Ed Sullivan Theater.

description: The Perseus Books Group, a large independent publisher, is up for sale again.

title: Michael Derrick Hudson Posed as a Yi-Fen Chou: Did the Name Sell His Poem?
description: The list of poets who have pretended to be someone else to tweak the conventions of art and/or society is long and includes writers like Fernando Pessoa and Marian Evans (a.k.a. George Eliot). The list of poets who have pretended to be someone else so as to slightly increase their odds of being published in the literary journal Prairie Schooner is considerably shorter.

title: Family Files Lawsuit in Death of Inmate
description: A civil suit filed in federal court accuses officers at the Fishkill Correctional Facility in Beacon, N.Y., with brutally beating an inmate, Samuel Harrell. A medical examiner characterized Mr. Harrells death as a homicide.

description: In a portfolio curated by Leanne Shapton, seven women capture the mysterious, beloved, scrutinized subject still rare in the art world: men.

title: Israel Reopens Cairo Embassy 4 Years After Protesters Siege
description: CAIRO  Israel reopened an embassy in Cairo on Wednesday, four years to the day after the previous embassy was stormed by demonstrators during the aftermath of the popular uprising that ousted President Hosni Mubarak in 2011.

title: What Is Fashion Week?
description: Here is your no-nonsense guide to an occasionally high-nonsense event.

title: Review: Marco Cappelli, Banging on a Guitar
description: Its fairly common to see guitarists and other string players using their instruments as percussion, lightly tapping their fingers on the wooden frame to produce a particular sound. Its more unusual to see a guitarist hit the instrument with mallets, as Marco Cappelli did during his performance at the Stone on Tuesday evening.

title: At Toronto International Film Festival, a Very Early Peep at Demolition
description: TORONTO  When Demolition has its premiere on the opening night of this citys annual film festival on Thursday, it will have the look of a serious film making a beautifully timed entrance to the awards season.

title: The Bloomberg Terminal, a Wall Street Fixture, Faces Upstarts
description: For nearly three decades, the flickering orange-on-black screens of the Bloomberg terminal have been omnipresent on Wall Street trading floors and executive suite desks, maintaining a vital lifeline of data and communication.

title: 5 Models to Follow on Instagram
description: Fashion is the province of the natural-born provocateur, a concept not lost on a coterie of fashion models raising their profiles on Instagram.

title: Judge Rules House Can Sue Obama Administration on Health Care Spending
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge ruled Wednesday that the House had the right to sue the Obama administration over billions of dollars in health care spending, a decision that poses a new legal threat to the health care law and gave congressional Republicans a victory in their claims of executive overreach by the White House.

title: Debt Collectors to Pay $61 Million in Consumer Refunds and Amend Their Practices
description: Federal consumer regulators on Wednesday announced an enforcement action against two big debt-buying companies for using deceptive tactics to collect delinquent accounts.

title: What to Expect Today at Paris Fashion Week
description: Fashion week continues in Paris, where our editors share highlights from the shows.

title: Looking for Mens Wear Designers This New York Fashion Week? Come Back in January
description: There will be about 200 designers showing during New York Fashion Week, but some familiar faces will be missing, including Duckie Brown, Michael Bastian and Tim Coppens. Those men's wear designers, among many others, showed their collections in July, at the first New York Fashion Week: Men. (The next one is in January 2016.) Five designers who chose to participate in July reflect on that experience.

title: Hands-On Experience With Apples New Devices
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Just in time for the back-to-school and holiday shopping seasons, Apple on Wednesday announced a series of hardware upgrades for the iPhone, iPad and Apple TV.

title: Harold Koda on Passing the Torch at the Costume Institute
description: When Harold Koda, 65, retires in January, after 14 years heading the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, he will leave behind a legacy of ambitious and crowd-pleasing shows like Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty and the recent China: Through the Looking Glass, exhibitions that not only set attendance records but also reflected radical shifts in our understanding of the sociocultural, ethnographic and even anthropological dimensions of fashion and costume.

title: No Charges for Washington State Officers in Hispanic Mans Death
description: DENVER  Three officers involved in the February death of a Hispanic man in Pasco, Wash., will not face criminal charges, the Franklin County prosecutors office said Wednesday.

title: Jeb Bushs Tax Plan Is a Large Tax Cut for the Wealthiest
description: In recent weeks, Donald Trump has torn up the usual Republican script on taxes. He has called for tax cuts for the middle class while complaining of outrageous tax breaks for multimillionaires, especially hedge fund managers.

title: Cuomo Set to Back $15 Minimum Wage Across New York State
description: After devising a way to raise wages for fast-food workers, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is preparing to announce his support for a $15 minimum wage for all workers in New York State.

title: What Puerto Ricos New Plan Means
description: Puerto Rico issued a five-year plan on Wednesday to restructure about $47 billion of its $72 billion in bond debt and carry out an economic overhaul under an independent financial control board.

title: Clothing Retailer Totokaelo Has High Hopes for Manhattan
description: Totokaelo (TOH-toh-KYE-yo, a corruption of the Latin, meaning, more or less, the skys the limit), all 8,400 square feet of it, is preparing to open its doors on Crosby Street.

title: The Martian Brings a Nerd Thriller Into the Mainstream
description: Andy Weir started writing a book about an astronaut stranded on Mars. He hadnt had any success with publishers in the past, so he started posting chapters to his website. That was 2011.

title: Hooray for Hollywood! (No, Really.)
description: The system is broken. High-quality, mid-budget prestige movies are an endangered species. Television is better. Audiences are fleeing. Film is dying. Sequels are ruining everything. These are some of the familiar objections that surface whenever critics, media journalists and other entertainment pundits take stock of the big picture, an appraisal that often turns into agony over the (inevitably worsening) state of the art and industry. What everyone agrees on is that they dont make movies like they used to.

title: Matt Jacobson, Facebooks Gatekeeper for Hollywood
description: In 2005, Matt Jacobson was 44 and looking for a new job after leaving Quiksilver, the surf brand. A friend suggested that he meet with an unknown start-up based in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: New Night Life Spots to Drink After the New York Fashion Shows
description: Whether you spent the summer cliff-diving on the Amalfi Coast or sweltering in the city, September signifies the social seasons return.

title: Shopping Events and Sales Happening During New York Fashion Week
description: Even if you are not one of the 820 lucky souls who scored the tickets that Riccardo Tisci made available to the general public for Givenchys much-anticipated New York Fashion Week debut, you can still visit the luxury Givenchy temple he has opened on Madison Avenue. There youll find beautiful objets like a Nightingale top-handle bag in a multicolor carpet print ($2,395) thats sure to make you stand out from the street-style scrum. At 747 Madison Avenue.

title: Pennant Races Cant Match Williams Sisters on TV
description: Tuesday night was packed with three major events for New York-area sports fans: important pennant-race games involving the Mets and the Yankees, and the quarterfinal match between Venus and Serena Williams at the United States Open.

title: Report Renews Hope and Doubt on Missing Students in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  When the government told Cristina Bustamante that her son had been murdered and incinerated in an enormous pyre, that should have been it, the final chapter in the search for her child and the 42 other college students who vanished last September.

title: A Fashion Week Debut, With a Little Help From Lady Gaga
description: Growing up in Longview, Tex., in the 1990s, Brandon Maxwell used to go to the local beauty supply store and the Goodwill, buy cheap hair extensions and secondhand dresses with which to style his girlfriends, and then photograph them around town with disposable cameras from CVS.

title: The Intimate and Infinite Along the 100th Meridian
description: Combining aerial and large-format photography, Andrew Moore aimed to capture the vast landscape of the 100th meridian line, and the stories of families connected to the land.

title: Mexican TV Network Uses Trump to Hype Soccer Showdown With U.S.
description: Seeking to promote its broadcast of an important soccer match between the United States and Mexico next month, a Mexican television network has remixed Donald J. Trumps comments about the death of the American dream into a commercial mocking the chances of the United States team.

title: Why Did So Many Famous Couples Break Up This Summer?
description: Summer lovin, had me a blast. Or thats the idea, anyway.

title: Thabo Sefolosha, Atlanta Hawks Player, Spurns Lenient Plea Bargain
description: Thabo Sefolosha, the basketball player, was offered a lenient plea bargain on Wednesday to resolve criminal charges against him arising from a scuffle with the police in Manhattan: Do a day of community service, stay out of trouble for six months and the charges would be dismissed.

title: Justice Department Sets Sights on Wall Street Executives
description: WASHINGTON  Stung by years of criticism that it has coddled Wall Street criminals, the Justice Department issued new policies on Wednesday that prioritize the prosecution of individual employees  not just their companies  and put pressure on corporations to turn over evidence against their executives.

title: President Obama to Greet Pope Francis at Andrews Air Force Base
description: President Obama will take the rare step of heading to Andrews Air Force Base outside of Washington to personally greet Pope Francis when he arrives for a visit on Sept. 22, the White House said on Wednesday.

title: Lawyer for Ex-Dewey Executive Seeks to Sow Doubt on Evidence Against Him
description: A lawyer for Stephen DiCarmine, the former executive director of the once-prominent law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf, told a New York jury on Wednesday not to convict his client based solely on dozens of emails.

title: Andr Saraiva Adds Breakfast to His Portfolio
description: Andr Saraiva, the rakish graffiti artist and international club owner, has historically focused his ambitions at entertaining between dusk and dawn. For his next trick, hes taking aim at a new frontier: breakfast.

title: New Justice Dept. Guidelines
description: One of the most effective ways to combat corporate misconduct is by seeking accountability from the individuals who perpetuated the wrongdoing, wrote Sally Q. Yates, the deputy attorney general, in the memo on new guidelines.

title: United Airlines and the Port Authority
description: Reverberations from the traffic jam engineered two years ago by aides of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey have now hit United Airlines. Jeff Smisek, Uniteds chief executive, and two senior officials resigned this week in connection with the companys previously disclosed internal investigation related to the federal investigation associated with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, according to the official company statement.

title: Report Finds Most Nations Hinder Women
description: The United States is one of four countries around the world with no national laws requiring paid parental leave for new mothers.

title: Maine: Speedy Hiker Will Pay Fine After Champagne Celebration
description: Scott Jurek, the ultramarathon runner who set a speed record this summer for hiking the Appalachian Trail in 46 days, agreed Wednesday to pay a $500 fine for public drinking at the trails terminus on Mount Katahdin. In exchange, the state of Maine agreed to drop charges that he was littering when he spilled celebratory Champagne on the mountaintop and that he was traveling with an oversize group. Baxter State Park, the location of Katahdin, has said that so many hikers were breaking the rules, it might move the Appalachian Trail out of the park. That matter, which was not part of the case against Mr. Jurek, remains a question. Walter McKee, Mr. Jureks lawyer, said that while Baxter was hoping the charges might limit the number of hikers, as a result of the attention, there will probably be more people on the trail and in the park. R. Christopher Almy, who prosecuted the case, said the $500 fine  up from the normal $200  reflected the seriousness of the charge.

title: Queen Elizabeth II: Key Moments in Her Reign
description: Key moments highlighted during the reign of Queen Elizabeth II.

title: Seattle Teachers Go on First Systemwide Strike in 30 Years After Talks Collapse
description: SEATTLE  Elias Lawrences first day of kindergarten did not turn out as planned. With teachers walking the picket lines and classes across the city canceled, Elias, 5, instead got a day at a city community center near his home and a brief lesson in labor relations from his father, Noah Lawrence.

title: A Senseless Delay on the Iran Deal
description: The bruising battle over the Iran nuclear agreement should be over, now that 42 Democratic senators declared their support for the deal and made it clearer than ever that efforts to kill it will fail. But the Republican-led Congress seems determined to drag out the fight, even if it means neglecting other business, including legislation to fund the government.

title: In Making Everest, Filmmakers Embrace Towering Ambitions
description: To make it real, filmmakers contended with freezing temperatures, thin air and avalanches.

title: Toyota Fashions a Bolder Image for the Practical Prius
description: DETROIT  The Toyota Prius gas-electric hybrid did not need cutting-edge styling to become the best-selling alternative-fuel car in the world. If anything, its sensible design struck a chord with consumers more interested in fuel economy than fashion.

title: Saudi Diplomat in India Is Accused of Rape
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian police are investigating allegations that a Saudi diplomat imprisoned and repeatedly raped two Nepali maids who worked in his home. The Saudi Embassy has denied the allegations.

title: The Rail Executive United Airlines Tapped to Lift Its Fortunes
description: At first glance, Oscar Munoz might seem like an unlikely pick to run one of the worlds largest airlines.

title: Stanton R. Cook, a Chief of the Tribune Company, Dies at 90
description: Stanton R. Cook, who as chief executive of the Tribune Company in the 1970s and 80s transformed it from a privately held, conservative family enterprise into a publicly traded, more centrist media empire, died on Sept. 3 at his home in Kenilworth, Ill., near Chicago. He was 90.

title: Kerry Favors an American Commitment to Bringing in More Refugees
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State John Kerry told lawmakers in a closed-door session on Wednesday that he favored significantly increasing the number of refugees the United States is willing to accept, possibly to as many as 100,000 next year, according to congressional staff members and Obama administration officials.

title: James Blake, Retired Tennis Pro, Says Police Pushed Him Down; Inquiry Is Opened
description: The New York Police Department is investigating an episode in which James Blake, a retired top-10 professional tennis player, said he was pushed to the ground outside his hotel by a police officer on Wednesday and handcuffed by several officers who had mistaken him for a suspect in a fraudulent credit card operation.

title: Fires in West Have Residents Gasping on the Soot Left Behind
description: FRESNO, Calif.  The air in the San Joaquin Valley hangs thick with gray-brown dust, a result of the states largest fire, which has burned through more than 160 square miles in the nearby hills.

title: Others Left Standing Facea Tall Hurdle in Serena Williams
description: So who can still stop the first Grand Slam in 27 years?

title: Dynamic Voodoo
description: We have a first score on the Jeb! tax plan  in answer to Matt OBrien, I think we refer to this as the Bush! tax! cuts! Its $3.4 trillion in lost revenue. But most of this will be made up through higher growth, Bushs advisers, led by Glenn Hubbard, assure us.

title: Dennis Greene, a Singer With Sha Na Na, Dies at 66
description: Dennis Greene, a founding member of Sha Na Na, a band that became famous in the 1970s for its simultaneously nostalgic and comedic approach to the rock n roll of the 1950s, died on Saturday at a hospital near his home in Dayton, Ohio. He was 66.

title: Minneapolis Fighting Terror Recruitment
description: MINNEAPOLIS  This citys struggle with terrorism recruitment showed itself on two fronts Wednesday. In the morning, a Somali-American teenager admitted in court here that he had tried to flee the country and join the Islamic State. Hours later, federal prosecutors and some leaders among the regions large Somali population announced about $1 million in funding for programs meant to combat just that type of radicalization.

title: Two D.N.C. Officials Call for Adding More Debates
description: Two vice chairs of the Democratic National Committee are publicly calling on the party to increase the number of presidential debates, adding high-profile voices to efforts to change the process.

title: Breakthrough Performances of the Fall Season
description: The Final Girls

title: Rain Aids Simona Halep; Flavia Pennetta Wins Under Scorching Sun
description: The retractable roof on Arthur Ashe Stadium is not finished, despite the new steel structure rising above the court.

title: Onetime Chairwoman of NBCUniversal News Announces Her Exit
description: The former chairwoman of NBCUniversal News, Patricia Fili-Krushel, said Wednesday that she was leaving the company, probably in the coming months.

title: New York City Health Board Repeals Rule on Consent Forms for Circumcision Ritual
description: The New York City Board of Health voted on Wednesday to ease regulations on a controversial circumcision ritual practiced in the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community, fulfilling a priority of Mayor Bill de Blasio.

title: California Democrats Drop Plan for 50 Percent Oil Cut
description: LOS ANGELES  In a major setback for environmental advocates in California, Gov. Jerry Brown and Senate Democrats abandoned a 50 percent cut in petroleum use by 2030 that was a centerpiece of emissions legislation, blaming an intense campaign against the mandate by the oil industry.

title: Auto Safety Agency Sets Date for Update on Airbag Recall
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration will hold a public meeting on Oct. 22 to provide updates on the latest progress, or lack thereof, in the sweeping recall of defective Takata airbags. The airbags, linked to at least eight deaths and scores of injuries, contain faulty inflaters that can explode and spray metal into the cabin of a vehicle. Last week, the safety agency said the recall affected 23.4 million inflaters in 19.2 million vehicles. So far, only 4.4 million of those inflaters have been replaced. In a statement on Wednesday, the agencys administrator, Mark R. Rosekind, said the meeting would be an opportunity to provide the information weve gathered since launching the coordinated remedy proceeding in May.

title: Senate Republicans Balk at Iran Deal
description: As President Obama will, in all likelihood, obtain the votes needed to avoid a veto, Republican senators continued to frame the deal as dangerous and destabilizing.

title: Review: The Legend of Georgia McBride, From Elvis Impersonator to Drag Queen
description: A young Elvis impersonator barely eking out a living finds an unlikely path to prosperity in The Legend of Georgia McBride, a stitch-in-your-side funny, if improbable, new comedy by Matthew Lopez that opened on Wednesday at the Lucille Lortel Theater. The salvation of Casey, the plays beleaguered hero, portrayed with winning boyish (and girlish) charm by Dave Thomas Brown, turns out to be equipment already in his proverbial toolbox: sequins, makeup and a highly developed skill in lip-syncing.

title: BMI to Announce It Surpassed $1 Billion in Revenue
description: The music industry may be struggling to make money in the streaming age, but one part of the business has been growing consistently: payments to songwriters.

title: Blab
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  It will surprise absolutely no one who has been reading this blog for more than a month that I had an extremely slow start on this one. If I find myself glaring menacingly at the grid with very little filled in even after gaining a toehold, I automatically assume that the theme has a rebus element. Then I go about looking for places to squeeze letters into individual squares.

title: Gabrielle Burton, Feminist Novelist and Screenwriter, Dies at 76
description: Gabrielle Burton, a feminist novelist, memoirist and screenwriter who considered conventional marriage lopsided but identified with the pioneering Donner Party wife who perished protecting her husband, died on Sept. 3 at her home in Venice, Calif. She was 76.

title: New Jersey Man Pleads Guilty to Pledging to Join ISIS
description: A 21-year-old New Jersey man pleaded guilty in federal court on Wednesday to planning to travel abroad with other men from New York and New Jersey to join the Islamic State.

title: Putin and Pope May Hold Talks at United Nations
description: UNITED NATIONS  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia could have an audience with Pope Francis on the sidelines of the development summit meeting here this month  but only, the Vatican envoy to the United Nations said Wednesday, if Mr. Putin gets here in time.

title: Roger Federer and Stan Wawrinka Prey on Fatigue at U.S. Open
description: Richard Gasquet, ragged and panting, sweat cascading down his face, reached out and barely got his racket to the ball. It seemed to take every bit of energy he had just to do that.

title: Mets Latest Comeback Puts Rivals Far Behind
description: WASHINGTON  Nationals Manager Matt Williams emerged from the home dugout in the eighth inning Wednesday and headed to the mound for a routine pitching change, hanging his head as if to shield himself from a chorus of boos.

title: Giants Jason Pierre-Paul Isnt Ready for Opener, Coach Says
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Since the Fourth of July fireworks accident that resulted in the amputation of Jason Pierre-Pauls right index finger, nothing about the interaction between the Giants and Pierre-Paul, their best defensive player, has been orthodox. Shortly after the accident, he turned away team officials who arrived at his hospital in Florida. The Giants later withdrew a $60 million contract offer.

title: Lawmakers Against the Iran Nuclear Deal
description: Twenty-three Democratic lawmakers have said they will not support President Obamas nuclear deal with Iran, joining their Republican colleagues in the House and the Senate.

title: Shoddy Fielding Sabotages C. C. Sabathias Return to Yankees
description: It was like old times for C. C. Sabathia. Two strikes on a batter, a pivotal moment in the game, and the Yankee Stadium crowd throwing its support behind him.

title: Wider Division Lead May Ease Matt Harvey Dilemma
description: WASHINGTON  On Monday and Tuesday, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson was reduced to a fan, watching the team he had constructed make two scintillating comebacks to beat the Washington Nationals in two of its biggest games of the season. A lawyer and a former member of the Marine Corps, Alderson flashed a rare wide smile Wednesday afternoon before the Mets completed their sweep of the Nationals with a 5-3 win.

description: Looks from the VFiles collection label winners: David Ferreira, Namilia, Moses Gauntlett Cheng, Kozaburo and Feng Chen Wang.

description: vendor  \ven-dr\  noun

title: Irving Harper, Creator of the Marshmallow Sofa, Dies at 99
description: Irving Harper, who pioneered Pop Art furniture design with whimsical mid-20th-century modernist classics like the marshmallow sofa, the ball clock and the sunburst clock, died on Aug. 4 at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 99.

title: Whats On TV Thursday
description: 12:45 P.M. (Sundance) AMERICAN BEAUTY (1999) Lester Burnham (Kevin Spacey, above), a middle-age suburbanite, trades in his bourgeois trappings for a red Pontiac Firebird and a job at a fast-food restaurant after going wild for his teenage daughters cheerleader friend (Mena Suvari) and discovering that his wife (Annette Bening) has been unfaithful. As these characters struggle viciously  and hilariously  to escape the middle-class doldrums, the film also evinces a real and ever more stirring compassion, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times about Sam Mendess Oscar winner for best picture, director, actor (for Mr. Spacey), screenplay (Alan Ball) and cinematography (Conrad L. Hall). As it detects increasingly vital signs of life behind the absurd surfaces that Mr. Mendes presents so beautifully, the film takes on a gravity to match its evil zest. Theres a haunting power to Lesters last narrative note to the viewer: that if you dont share the films piercing vision of what really matters, someday you will.

title: Rachel Comey: Spring 2016 RTW
description: Looks from Ms. Comeys spring 2016 presentation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Corporations can only commit crimes through flesh-and-blood people. Its only fair that the people who are responsible for committing those crimes be held accountable.

title: The Intimate and Infinite Along the 100th Meridian
description: Andrew Moore is a veteran New Yorker accustomed to claustrophobic and overstimulated environments. Perhaps thats why a visit to North Dakota in 2005, and an encounter with the arid, expansive and mostly desolate lands of the 100th meridian, appealed to him as it had homesteaders in years past.

title: The Quieter Gun Death Toll
description: The grisly carnage from mass shootings regularly attracts the nations focus as a public safety issue, if only fleetingly. But the highest death toll from guns by far continues to be the far less noticed wave of suicides  nearly 20,000 a year  by Americans whose easy access to guns presents an irresistible temptation in a critical moment of despair.
