title: Compassion for Refugees Isnt Enough
description: Bravo to Pope Francis, Angela Merkel and so many ordinary Germans and Austrians who have welcomed refugees into their lands. Kudos to those American politicians acknowledging that we should accept more Syrian refugees  the U.S. has admitted only 1,500 since the war started four years ago, which is pathetic.

title: Hillary Is Hobbling, for Now
description: I must say that Im starting to feel bad for Hillary Clinton. There is a sense surrounding her candidacy of building doom and imminent disaster.

title: A Presidential Primary Cheat Sheet
description: The presidential campaign is getting serious, people. Just four months to the Iowa caucuses! Youre supposed to be concerned citizens, and your friends are going to expect you to update them regularly. If you cant, be prepared to take an active part in discussions about the Tom Brady divorce rumors.

title: A Smarter Way to Raise Paychecks
description: LOCAL and state minimum-wage increases are in style this season, with cities nationwide moving toward a $15-an-hour floor. But simply mandating that employers pay more is a clumsy and potentially counterproductive way to help the poor. Although some workers gain, others lose out on jobs altogether, while consumers  many poor themselves  face higher prices.

title: A Flawed Medical Malpractice System
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping a Suicide When the End Isn't Near
News Qs | The Hummingbirds Tongue: How It Works
description: In The Hummingbirds Tongue: How It Works, James Gorman reports on new research about how hummingbirds drink nectar.

title: The Target Neighborhood: Hamilton Heights
description: Many years ago, Janet Aschkenasys grandfather bought the five-story townhouse near Gramercy Park that housed his dental practice. He later moved his practice to the 1963 white brick co-op building diagonally across the street.

title: My Fathers Last Romance: Readers (and Arlene Herself) Respond
description: Last Sundays Modern Love column elicited a wide range of opinions on elderly love and Arlenes decision not to live with the authors father. Most notably, we heard from Arlene herself.

title: Europeans Seek to Use Force Against Smugglers at Sea
description: UNITED NATIONS  European countries are pushing for a United Nations Security Council resolution to allow their military forces to apprehend human-smuggling vessels in the international waters of the Mediterranean Sea, diplomats here said.

title: Notre Dame President Stands Firm Amid Shifts in College Athletics
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  Now is a good time to take a reflective walk with the president of the University of Notre Dame, through the woods behind his office in a golden-domed building, beside two lakes named after saints. A good time, and a serene setting, to ponder a sacred matter of profound moral implications: college athletics.

title: Review: Mike Kelley Uncorks Supermans Kandor City in a Bottle
description: During his last decade, Mike Kelley (1954-2012), one of the most influential artists of his generation, devoted an extraordinary amount of time and effort to a theme from Superman comics: the city of Kandor, capital of Supermans home planet, Krypton. Before Krypton was destroyed by a chain reaction in its radioactive core, the space archvillain Brainiac shrank Kandor and put it and its live inhabitants into a bottle. Years later, the grown-up Superman wrested the bottled city away from Brainiac. Unable to restore Kandor to its original size, he kept it in his Arctic Fortress of Solitude, along with all his other memorabilia.

title: Afghans See American General as Crucial to Countrys Defense
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Gen. John F. Campbell holds several titles: top NATO commander in Afghanistan, commander of the Resolute Support Mission coalition, commander of United States Forces-Afghanistan.

title: Homo Naledi, New Species in Human Lineage, Is Found in South African Cave
description: Acting on a tip from spelunkers two years ago, scientists in South Africa discovered what the cavers had only dimly glimpsed through a crack in a limestone wall deep in the Rising Star Cave: lots and lots of old bones.

title: What Does it Mean to Be a Real Man?
description: Do you think American men  and maybe men elsewhere in the world  are confused about what it means to be a man? A professor at Stony Brook University does, and he has founded a Center for the Study of Men and Masculinities to study the problem.

title: Minotaur in His Maze
description: No one, observing MacDonald Harris, would have taken him for a literary genius. He did not dress head to toe in black. He never posed for a photograph in a wrestling singlet, in Zen robes or atop a granite outcrop whose austere majesty was echoed by his windswept quiff. By September 1985, when I became his student and his friend, there was no hair at all to invite the winds attention. The luster of his pate gave his head the appearance of the polished ball end of some precision-engineered chrome socket, or an observatory dome. You might have supposed that the mind inside that dome was busy working up new techniques of heat dissipation in airplane engines, but not new plots, new characters. He wore button-down shirts, tucked into jeans that were belted and pressed. His preferred footwear was the kind of tan hybrid of sneaker and Oxford shoe favored by Elderhostelers. Sometimes, it is true, he would wear a floppy-brimmed bucket hat and a funny kind of jacket, vaguely suggestive of an interest in trout fishing or photo safaris. But  as with the high, lustrous cranial dome  if you saw him in his goofy hat and jacket, you would have been less likely to think, There goes a literary innovator gifted with an original and unfettered artistic imagination than There goes a chemical engineer who enjoys cultivating succulents.

title: Food and Tour News: Oysters in New York, Wine and Jambalaya in Maine
description: Our morning travel news digest, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Excess Weight at Age 50 Tied to Earlier Alzheimers Onset
description: Being obese at age 50 may be tied to an increased risk of developing Alzheimers disease at a younger age.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Morning Agenda: Justice Department Sets Sights on Wall Street Executives
description: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT SETS SIGHTS ON WALL STREET EXECUTIVES | After years of criticism that it has coddled Wall Street criminals, the Justice Department has prioritized the prosecution of individual employees and not just their companies, Matt Apuzzo and Ben Protess report in The New York Times.

title: New York Today: The City as Runway
description: Updated 10:52 a.m.

title: Floods Ravage Eastern Japan
description: The authorities issued rare weather warnings for five million people in Japan as rivers swelled after torrential rains, leaving scores stranded.

title: Migrants Meet Rain, Resistance and Confusion at Border Crossings
description: BUDAPEST  Rain, misery and more confusion marked the continuing trek of migrants and refugees from Syria and other Middle Eastern nations across Europe on Thursday as thousands endured a drenching downpour, growing opposition in some countries and potential obstacles at various borders.

title: Today  in Politics: Hunting for Clues in Joe Bidens Stroll Through Hillary Clintons Turf
description: Good Thursday morning. The debate over the Iran nuclear deal in Congress and among the candidates continues to pull focus onto the national stage. But a major character still waits in the wings as speculation will attach itself to his every move until he decides whether to stay out of view or to step into the campaign lights.

title: Japan Faces Severe Flooding After Heavy Rain in the East
description: TOKYO  Heavy rain from a tropical storm caused severe flooding in eastern Japan on Thursday, and television footage showed rescuers airlifting people who were stranded after river embankments collapsed.

title: Whos Responsible for the Refugees?
description: Policy paralysis over the refugee crisis is convulsing Europe: Of course we want to help, but if were too generous, more will come.

title: If You Build It, They Will Come ... Wont They?
description: When you think of a classic American college campus, you probably envision a set of pastoral images: a demure brick rowhouse crowned with a white steeple, a gargoyle perched on a limestone archway, a domed library on a sunlit grass quadrangle. Often far from cities or shielded from them by gates and walls, campuses exude a sense of refuge. Thomas Jefferson famously wanted the University of Virginia to resemble a kind of academical village.

title: Teaching Working Students
description: Students are generally passive when talking about the law, but Ellie, a sophomore at CUNYs John Jay College of Criminal Justice, leapt into the discussion of the constitutionality of capital punishment in my death-penalty course. When she eviscerated the Supreme Court ruling upholding Texas death penalty law, I knew I had met a special student. On the midterm, she earned the highest grade anyone had ever gotten on the exam. Later, I learned that she had scored 1,480 on her SAT. Ellie wanted to be an attorney; it seemed inevitable that she would end up at an Ivy League law school. She had a prodigious, nimble intellect and, as I saw it, a limitless future.

title: At Hawaii Resort, Yoga by Day, Party by Night
description: It may have been the most beautiful setting for a yoga class anyone ever imagined, the view out the plate glass window framing a dream-perfect slice of Oahus North Shore: elegantly arching palm trees, the fabled surf crashing against the rocky shoreline, a set of wispy clouds floating across an azure sky. The teacher of the class, the impossibly named Noelani Love, strummed a ukulele while the class sang a mantra, eyes closed, and she said we sounded like angels.

title: On Alaskas Ferries, Beloved Bars No Longer Make the Trip
description: For decades, the ferries of the Alaska Marine Highway System have been home to some of the most gloriously quirky bars in the 49th state. As the ferries, 11 of them now, make their runs along Alaskas south central coast, the Aleutian Islands and the Inside Passage of southeast Alaska and British Columbia, they collect all manner of passengers, from fishermen, oil workers, military personnel and adventure travelers to big fans of the ferries communal watering holes. The bars came with names like the Pitch & Roll aboard Motor Vessel Tustumena, and some had deliciously divey dcor, as on Motor Vessel Columbia: shiny lam wallpaper, gold Naugahyde booths and dimmer bulbs across the ceiling.

title: In N.F.L Opener, Tom Brady Gets Another Victory, This One on the Field
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Amid all the accusations, innuendo and speculation about Tom Brady and whether he was part of a supposed scheme to deflate footballs in last years A.F.C. championship game, few doubted his throwing skills.

title: The Return of the Sex Wars
description: Last summer, the Harvard law professor Janet Halley sat down at her dining-room table to look through a set of policies that her university created for handling complaints of sexual assault and harassment. Halley had taught this area for years, and she was interested to see what the university came up with. The new rules were released amid pressure from student-led groups of rape survivors and their advocates, who demanded that schools across the country do more on behalf of victims. Harvard was also responding to years of calls for change by the Obama administration. Just eight months earlier, Valerie Jarrett, a senior presidential adviser, called for a more victim-centered campus approach to dealing with the problem of sexual assault.

title: Donald Trump Finds Defenders and Detractors Among Conservatives
description: It could be the three marriages, but especially the one that ended after he was said to have started romancing his soon-to-be second wife during church.

title: A Department With Big Ambitions
description: Stanford University has lured an all-star lineup of economists to Palo Alto, Calif., in the last few years.

title: How Stanford Took On the Giants of Economics
description: The center of gravity for economic thought in the United States has long been found along the two miles in Cambridge, Mass., that run between Harvard University and M.I.T. But there is new competition for that title, and it is quite a bit farther west.

title: Baidu to Gain More Seats on Board of Chinese Travel Booking Site
description: Four years ago, the Chinese search giant Baidu bought a majority stake in one of Chinas biggest travel booking sites. Now it is gaining a bigger presence on the companys board.

title: First Draft Focus: Throwback Thursday  A Pre-Debate Dip
The Scale of the Migrant Crisis, From 160 to Millions
description: The latest E.U. proposal addresses just a fraction of a human crisis numbering in the millions.

title: Apple Plus Herms: Smartwatch Dream Team or Weird Mash-Up?
description: On Wednesday, Apple once again managed to overshadow the start of fashion month by announcing at an event in San Francisco that it was teaming up with Herms on a new version of the Apple Watch.

title: James Blakes Arrest Brings Swift Apologies From New York Officials
description: A New York Police Department officer was stripped of his gun and badge as Mayor Bill de Blasio and Police Commissioner William J. Bratton issued swift apologies on Thursday for the rough arrest of James Blake, the retired tennis star, after he was misidentified as a suspect in a fraudulent credit card ring.

title: Extra Ferries Ship Migrants to Athens
description: Overwhelmed by the influx of people, the authorities put in place extra vessels to ship them from the Greek island of Lesbos to the capital.

title: Updating: New York Fashion Week Day One
description: What you need to know on the first day of NYFW. See more coverage from Styles and T editors and reporters around the spring shows.

title: To the Dust Lady
description: Dear Diary:

title: Jeb Bushs Populist Tack on Taxes Finds Echoes in Unlikely Sources
description: WASHINGTON  What do Jeb Bush, Elizabeth Warren and Donald J. Trump have in common? They would like to raise taxes on the hedge fund guys.

title: The Popes Unforgiving Message of Forgiveness on Abortion
description: POPE FRANCIS announced this month that for a year, beginning in December, women who had terminated pregnancies could be granted forgiveness from Roman Catholic priests, instead of facing potential excommunication for their sins. It sounds like a step in the right direction: Mercy for women who have had abortions certainly seems preferable to condemnation.

title: Donald Trumps Uncomplimentary Comments About Carly Fiorina
description: Donald J. Trump is not letting political correctness get in the way of saying what he really thinks about Carly Fiorinas looks.

title: Driven | 2015 Ferrari California T
description: Ferrari sharpens its most affordable car, the California T, giving it more of the familys essence than in the previous model.

title: Video Review: The California Lives Up to the Ferrari Name
description: EVEN aristocratic families have a member who, while successful, doesnt hit the lofty heights the others reach. In Ferraris case, it would be the entry-level California. Consider it the college professor of the clan in a dynasty filled with brain surgeons, diplomats and chief executives. Successful in its own right? Sure. But surrounded by overachieving siblings and a legendary lineage including 250 GTOs and F40s, the spotlight eludes it.

title: Afghans Celebrate a National Hero, and Fighting Breaks Out
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The annual celebration of Afghanistans official national hero, Ahmed Shah Massoud, descended into violence and ethnic tensions again as his armed supporters began marauding through the streets here, officials said Thursday.

title: James Blake Calls for Police Apology
description: Mr. Blake, a retired top-10 tennis player, said on Wednesday that he wanted an apology from the New York Police Department after being wrongly accused of identity theft and slammed to the ground.

title: Daily Report: What Stood Out From Apples Product Event
description: Apples product event came and went as foretold by many.

title: Popcast: Jon Batiste and The Late Show With Stephen Colbert
description: Times music critics discuss Mr. Batistes role as bandleader on the show.

title: Guo Meimei, Chinese Web Celebrity, Gets 5-Year Sentence on Casino Charge
description: Read in Chinese |

title: Researchers Reveal New Human Species
description: Lee R. Berger, a professor of human evolution studies at the University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg, unveiled a previously unidentified species of the early human lineage  Homo naledi.

title: 1940: Churchill Visits East End
description: LONDON  With part of its East End blasted, blackened and leveled by fire and explosions and its West End pock-marked by bombs dropped indiscriminately, far from legitimate objectives, London survived today [Sept. 10] its third night of terror and prepared for another. Thousands of newcomers swelled the tide of the homeless from the working-class district behind St. Pauls Cathedral, its magnificent dome standing unscathed against a fiery background. Grim-faced firemen turned from their hoses to cheer when they suddenly found Prime Minister Winston Churchill standing beside them on the charred and sodden debris which littered a street near the cathedral in which those British heroes of another day are entombed.  New York Herald Tribune, September 11, 1940

title: Donald Trump and Ben Carson Gain in CNN Poll
description: The appeal of political outsiders continues to grow among Republican voters, as a new national poll shows Donald J. Trump and Ben Carson holding commanding leads over a field of mostly traditional politicians who are seeking the presidential nomination.

title: In Performance | Jennifer Hudson
description: Jennifer Hudson, with David Jackson on piano, sings Too Beautiful for Words from the Broadway revival of the musical The Color Purple. The show opens in December at the Jacobs Theater.

title: Chinese Citizen Held by ISIS Poses Test for Beijing
description: HONG KONG  In the advertisement he is known by a number, 05675, which appears above the pocket of his yellow jumpsuit. He stares somberly into the distance, his left eye swollen and disfigured. His price is not named, but his captors describe him as a limited-time offer.

title: Stephen Colberts First Late Show Almost Didnt Make It on Air
description: On Tuesday night, as Stephen Colbert and his team at The Late Show were editing an overstuffed debut, a crucial portion of the program very nearly missed making it to air for 11:35 p.m.  namely, the entire episode.

title: In Performance | Eloise Kropp
description: Eloise Kropp sings and tap dances in the number Star Tar, from the Broadway production of the musical Dames at Sea. The show opens on Oct. 22 at the Helen Hayes Theater.

description: The Brazilian singer Luciana Souza, accompanied by Lionel Loueke on guitar and Gregoire Maret on harmonica, sings At the Fair, from her latest album, Speaking in Tongues.

description: Craig Finn, a singer, songwriter and front man of the band the Hold Steady, sings Maggie Ive Been Searching for Our Son, from his new solo album, Faith in the Future.

description: So you think youve seen it all before  and recently, too.

description: A new musical called Hamilton opened on Broadway recently. Perhaps youve heard of it?

title: Bernie Sanders Has Small Lead in Iowa in Latest Poll
description: Raising the possibility that Hillary Rodham Clinton could lose both the first two nominating contests, Senator Bernie Sanders has taken a narrow lead in Iowa for the first time in a Democratic poll released Thursday.

title: Five Models to Watch This Fashion Week
description: T's cheat sheet to the faces on the spring/summer 2016 runways.

title: Super PAC Aiding Hillary Clinton Adds Communications Chief
description: The super PAC supporting Hillary Rodham Clinton is bringing on a full-time communications director as it enters a new phase in its efforts to try to define the Republican presidential primary field.

title: 1965: Fancy Presidential Footwear
description: WASHINGTON  Twelve-inch cowboy boots made of black alligator leather from Brazil! Six rows of gold silk stitching! And on the front of the boots, in red, white and blue, the presidential seal! President Johnson may be clumping around the White House in just such a pair of dazzling boots. He was presented with them by a Texas bootmaker. Quite recently a panty girdle resembling the Stars and Stripes was taken off the market after a protest by the Daughters of the American Revolution. The DAR has not yet been heard from on the boots, but is it proper for the presidential seal to appear on the presidential feet?  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 11, 1965

title: This Broadway Season, Diversity Is Front and Center
description: It has been a long journey from Tradition to Tradicin.

title: This Pooch Has a Tony: Annaleigh Ashford on Playing a Poodle in Sylvia
description: Annaleigh Ashford was walking through Central Park, keeping an eye out for dogs. It was a sunny early evening in August, and the park was bustling, but the busy city dogs didnt seem to realize there was a celebrity  a role model, even  among them. Ms. Ashford is about to play the title role in Sylvia, A. R. Gurneys play about a Manhattan love triangle (husband, wife and pet), which is finally making it to Broadway, beginning previews on Oct. 2 at the Cort Theater.

title: In Bed With Bruce Willis (on Broadway)
description: On a recent afternoon, Bruce Willis slipped into a two-bedroom suite on the 11th floor of the Trump International Hotel Central Park, at Columbus Circle. The room was decorated in taupes, grays and sedate purples, so tasteful it nearly came back around to tasteless. Mr. Willis looked pretty tasteful, too, in an off-white shirt, tan corduroy pants and gray sneakers. He had a handsome scruff of salt-and-pepper stubble and a bald head that shone like the dome of some well-tended mosque.

title: FIFA Official Proposes Reforms to Its Executive Committee
description: Domenico Scala, the independent chairman of FIFAs audit and compliance committee, on Thursday unveiled an aggressive eight-point overhaul plan that he had presented to the organizations powerful executive committee. The proposals, he said, offer top FIFA officials a chance to enact meaningful reforms for world soccers governing body as it navigates corruption investigations in the United States and Switzerland.

title: 2015 Fall Preview
description: The New York Times recently invited performers with new projects this fall to sing at a special concert before an audience at 54 Below. They got one shot to get it right.

title: Sams Spring Roll
description: Tour the flavors of the world through spring rolls on the Lower East Side.

title: Sams Spring Roll Brings Innovation to the Lower East Side
description: Once, the sign above this pinched storefront on Essex Street promised skullcaps and prayer shawls. Then came snapback hats and deadstock sneakers, and later eel buns and bubble tea.

title: Democrats Hand Victory to Obama on Iran Nuclear Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats delivered a major victory to President Obama when they blocked a Republican resolution to reject a six-nation nuclear accord with Iran on Thursday, ensuring the landmark deal will take effect without a veto showdown between Congress and the White House.

title: Verbatim: Bobby Jindal Questions Donald Trumps Christianity
description: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana in remarks prepared for a speech to the National Press Club.

title: In Key & Peele Finale, Two Performers Flaunt Their Range
description: No anger translator, no substitute teacher, no ornately named college football players, no Liam Neeson-loving valet parkers. Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele have developed a number of indelible characters over the five seasons of their sketch-comedy show Key & Peele, but almost none of them appeared in Wednesday nights series finale on Comedy Central.

title: Never Enough: Donald Trump and the Pursuit of Success, by Michael DAntonio
description: As pure entertainment, the race for the Republican presidential nomination has been a resounding success. Donald Trump, the star, has been by turns witty, provocative, outrageous  and always telegenic. He helped draw an estimated 24 million viewers to the first televised Republican debate, a record, and a ratings bonanza for Fox News, with which he nonetheless publicly feuded. Blithely flouting all conventions of presidential debate and decorum, Trump indulged in the name-calling, personal attacks and one-liners that have vaulted him to the top of the polls.

title: N.F.L. Oddsmakers Predicting Close Games in Week 1
description: When the N.F.L. season kicks off Thursday night, Patriots and Steelers fans will enthusiastically cheer for their teams. There will also be enthusiastic cheering from another set of viewers: those who bet on football. They will be celebrating the end of seven wager-free months.

title: Alessandra Ferri to Return as Juliet for One Performance
description: One of the great ballerinas of her generation, Alessandra Ferri, who retired from American Ballet Theater in 2007, will return to the Metropolitan Opera House stage for one performance next season with the company, in the role of Juliet in Kenneth MacMillans Romeo and Juliet. Her scheduled performance, on June 23, will be almost nine years to the day since she bade farewell to Ballet Theater, where she had been a principal dancer for 22 years.

title: Mitsuko Uchida Among Winners of Praeamium Imperiale Awards
description: The pianist Mitsuko Uchida and the ballerina Sylvie Guillem are among the winners of this years prestigious Praemium Imperiale international arts awards, the Japan Art Association, which presents the awards, announced Thursday.

title: Monclers Art for Love
description: Submissions by Solve Sundsbo, Alasdair McLellan and more.

title: The Pink and the Black
description: In these boom times for biographies written for children, the 20th-century fashion designers Elsa Schiaparelli and Coco Chanel make good subjects: Their lives were filled with drama and intrigue, not to mention stunning visuals. Both worked hard and succeeded against long odds, defying convention on the way to making a real impact on the world. Each honed her craft and rose to prominence in 1920s Paris, but they had little in common, background-wise or personality-wise: The down-to-earth yet flamboyant Schiaparelli came from a cultured, well-off Italian family, the theatrical but restrained Chanel from a dirt-poor French one. The two women developed a tense rivalry, capped off by their choices during World War II, when Schiaparelli did relief work for the French and trained as a Red Cross nurses aide, while Chanel became a Nazi agent. So its fitting that two new books intended to plant their life stories in the imaginations of a new generation, Hot Pink: The Life and Fashions of Elsa Schiaparelli and Coco and the Little Black Dress, take completely different approaches.

title: When Homework Stresses Parents as Well as Students
description: Educators and parents have long been concerned about students stressed by homework loads, but a small research study asked questions recently about homework and anxiety of a different group: parents. The results were unsurprising. While we may have already learned long division and let the Magna Carta fade into memory, parents report that their childrens homework causes family stress and tension  particularly when additional factors surrounding the homework come into play.

title: Police Officers Charged in Freddie Grays Death to Be Tried in Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE  Six police officers charged in the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who sustained a fatal spinal cord injury in police custody, will be tried in Baltimore, a circuit court judge ruled here Thursday, saying defense lawyers had not met their constitutional burden for moving the trials to another jurisdiction.

title: Welcome, Illustrator Allison Steen
description: The Motherlode blog welcomes our new artist-in-residence, the illustrator Allison Steen. Allison is a recent graduate of Pratt Institute and lives in Colorado with her two cats.

title: British Panel Urges Tate to Return Looted Constable Painting, Again
description: PARIS  For the second time in a year and a half, a British government panel is pressing the Tate Gallery in London to return an oil landscape by John Constable to the heirs of a Jewish aristocrat whose art works were looted by the Germans during World War II from his homes and bank vault in Hungary.

title: Presidential Race in Taiwan Reflects Womens Rise in Politics
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  The people of Taiwan appear poised to elect their first female president. Two of the three leading candidates in the January election, including the nominees of both major parties, are women.

title: Donald Trump Questions Ben Carsons Faith and Credentials
description: Is Donald J. Trump playing defense?

title: Back to School, Then and Now
description: Photographs of children on the first day of a new school year have a particular energy about them, with a mix of excitement and jitters  sometimes even a touch of dread  all swirling around in tiny bodies. Also, theyre so cute!

title: In Prague, Riding the Wave of a Cocktail Revolution
description: The drink looked like a whiskey sour, topped with a light cloud of foamy egg whites, much like the Boston sour variation of the classic cocktail. But the first sip was much lighter and fruitier than I had expected. Instead of whiskey, the bartender had used Zufanek Hruskovica, a type of pear brandy that had been aged in oak barrels, as well as house-made chocolate bitters. The taste was as acidic and sweet as the classic, but still noticeably different, making it both internationally recognizable and location-specific.

title: At Hawaii Resort, Downward Dog Is a Party Animal
description: At the Wanderlust festival at Oahus Turtle Bay Resort, wellness includes stretching, deep breathing and a nightly concert.

title: Janis Ian and Patricia Snyders Relationship Builds Upon Decades of Social Upheaval
description: Janis Ian, the singer and songwriter, has lived through many of the social upheavals of the last 50 years and has borne witness to many of them in song.

title: Exploring Whitby and the Roots of Dracula
description: Bram Stoker found inspiration for his famous Gothic villain in an unlikely place  a sunny seaside Yorkshire village.

title: New Seamus Heaney Translation to be Published Next Year
description: In the months before he died, the poet Seamus Heaney worked on a project that had occupied him since the 1980s: a translation of the sixth book of Virgils Aeneid, in which the hero Aeneas travels to the underworld to find his dead father.

title: Banksy and the Problem With Sarcastic Art
description: The day Banksy unveiled Dismaland  a sprawling exhibition of conceptual art that is itself a concept, with mock security guards and mouse-eared employees instructed to frown instead of smile  its ticketing website was so overwhelmed it crashed. Hours before the opening of the park, which is built on a disused resort in Weston-super-Mare, England, hundreds of people had lined up outside in the rain. Dismaland is a heartening display of public interest in conceptual art, even if the concept is What if Disneyland were as bad as real life?

title: Fat Dad: A Vegetarian Rosh Hashana
description: When I was 11 years old, my father spent six months at a Durham, N.C., fat farm, where he lived on the rice diet in order to shed an extreme amount of weight.

title: The Folly of N.F.L. Predictions
description: Super Bowl 50 will be played in five months. The game is so far in the future that The San Jose Mercury News has nothing better to do than speculate about whether Taylor Swift might sing at the halftime show. A long list of events needs to unfold at Levis Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif., before it hosts the big game on Feb. 7: like an entire N.F.L. season, for instance.

title: WeWork Caught in Labor Dispute
description: Adam Neumann, one of the founders of WeWork, tried to persuade protesters that his company had taken the moral high ground in a labor dispute that left about 100 jobless.

title: Change to Bank Rules Could Spur Political Fight in a Crisis
description: Global bank supervisors are tying themselves in knots over T.L.A.C. This ugly initialism  for total loss-absorbing capacity  is supposed to mean that regulators ensure creditors pay for cross-border bank busts. The emerging rules look likely to be watered down for banks like HSBC, to make sure they arent disadvantaged against their less sprawling rivals. But whats being proposed will make the final system even more prone to political standoffs.

title: At WeWork, an Idealistic Start-Up Clashes With Its Cleaners
description: Adam Neumann bounded through the downtown Manhattan headquarters of WeWork, beaming as he pointed out the amenities of the open floor plan.

title: You're All Artists Now
description: We asked readers to respond to a Sunday Review essay about adult creativity by drawing on the illustration that accompanied it. Here is a sample of their work.

title: Salt-Encrusted Tilefish
description: Chef Ignacio Mattos shares a recipe for the showstopping dish he prepared for each of Rachel Comeys tables last night.

title: A Recipe From Rachel Comeys Fashion Week Feast
description: Pair the fashion designer Rachel Comey with chef Ignacio Mattos of Estela for a dinner-party-slash-fashion show and youve got a recipe for one very chic unofficial start to New York Fashion Week, which begins today. Add in a musical performance by Justin Vivian Bond, choreographed models donning Comeys spring/summer 2015 collection, a sprawling arts venue near the Brooklyn waterfront, and its no wonder the event last night drew a crowd that included notable artists and performers, as well as fellow figures from the style and culinary worlds.

title: Justice Dept. Vow to Go After Bankers May Prove a Promise Hard to Keep
description: Banks dont break the law, bankers do.

title: New Data Gives Clearer Picture of Student Debt
description: An air of mystery has long surrounded student debt. We know the total number of borrowers and their combined debt  40 million people owe $1.2 trillion  but beyond these headline numbers, the data has been frustratingly thin. Who borrows? Who defaults? Why are so many borrowers in distress? The answers have been unclear, leaving analysts and policy makers to prescribe remedies without an accurate diagnosis of the disease.

title: White Bordeaux Demands Close Attention
description: The last 25 years in wine have been signified by the discovery or rediscovery of regions unknown, obscure or half-forgotten. Consumers, and critics for that matter, have often embraced wines from these regions. But they have occasionally rejected them, too, with no small measure of befuddlement.

title: Brian Williams to Start at MSNBC on Sept. 22
description: Brian Williams, the beleaguered former anchor of NBCs Nightly News, will start in his new position at the cable news network MSNBC on Sept. 22, an NBC News spokesman said on Thursday.

title: Family Protests White Poets Use of Chinese Pen Name
description: Controversy erupted in the poetry world earlier this week when it was discovered that a poem included in the annual Best American Poetry anthology was written by a white poet, Michael Derrick Hudson, who had submitted it to a journal under the Chinese pseudonym Yi-Fen Chou.

title: California Agency Says Former Uber Driver Was an Employee
description: A California agency ruled in August that a former Uber driver should have been considered an employee, according to recently unearthed documents.

title: When a Coat Is More Than a Coat
description: Everything is art, even clothing, given the right intention and context, says the fashion photographer Solve Sundsbo. The important question is, is it interesting as art or not? To put that philosophy to the test, Sundsbo and 30-plus other photographers were given a task: to reimagine Monclers Maya duvet jacket  in whichever way they pleased.

title: Your Next Lesson: Chinon
description: Are you ready for some red wine? I know I am. Next comes one of the most overlooked yet thought-provoking reds I know: Chinon from the Touraine region of the Loire Valley in France.

title: BCBG Spring/Summer 2016
description: Bucket hats, beachy hair and more scenes from the show.

title: Adviser on Chinese Reverse Mergers Is Charged in a Securities Fraud Case
description: Benjamin Wey has described himself as a leading Wall Street American financier who helped Chinese companies sell shares in the United States.

title: At Creatures of the Wind, Punk Goes Glam
description: It was all about the music at Creatures of the Winds spring/summer 2016 show  in the beauty references, at least. The makeup artist Aaron de Meys vivid, graphic eyes, inspired by Siouxsie Sioux, accompanied by the hairstylist Anthony Turners disheveled festival hair brought a modern punkishness to Shane Gabier and Christopher Peterss psychedelica-inflected collection.

title: Autopsy Cites Intentionally Removed Plug in Ruling Kayakers Death a Homicide
description: The medical examiners conclusion is clear: Vincent Viafore, who the police say was killed by his fiance during a kayaking trip on the Hudson River this past spring, was a victim of homicide caused by a kayak drain plug intentionally removed by other.

title: Whose Birthday Is It This Time?
Weatherman Triumphs in Welsh
description: Local high temperatures offered Liam Dutton of Britains Channel 4 News the opportunity to take on a tonguetwister.

title: On a New York Tour Bus, a New View of History
description: The Tour, on a $1.5 million tour bus with coliseum-style seats that all face one window, offers a new perspective on New York Citys past and present.

title: 9/11 White House Emails Capture History Through Modern Lens
description: In messages to one another and the outside world on Sept. 11, 2001, aides to Mr. Bush pivoted from business as usual to shock and confusion and the opening of a new era of war.

title: The Peril of Not Dying for Love
description: High school Friday nights for my sister and me meant romantic comedies, trading boy secrets in our basement and playing a game called, What Would You Do for Love?

title: Arrest of James Blake Highlights Policing Challenges for de Blasio
description: It was the kind of startling episode that Mayor Bill de Blasio sought to eliminate: a black man tackled to the ground and handcuffed by police officers for an offense, it turned out, he did not commit.

title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Looking for something fun to do?

title: Obama Increases Number of Syrian Refugees for U.S. Resettlement to 10,000
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, under increasing pressure to demonstrate that the United States is joining European nations in the effort to resettle Syrian refugees, has told his administration to take in at least 10,000 displaced Syrians over the next year.

title: N.F.L. Team Scoring Just 1 Point? Now Its Possible
description: A listing of N.F.L. scores usually includes a lot of familiar numbers: 21, 14, 35, 17.

title: The Joshua Tree Inn
description: Room eight at the motel, where the singer-songwriter Gram Parsons died in 1973, is still available to rent.

title: A Joshua Tree Motel Room, Haunted by the Ghost of a Country Legend
description: Through the curves of the Morongo Valley pass in San Bernardino County, Calif., and across a desert that shifts from a sandy void to a land dotted with Seussian plants, theres the Joshua Tree Inn. Its a normal motel on the side of a highway, albeit one washed in a buzzing ochre light that comes in by sundown. It is also haunted, some say, by the ghost of Gram Parsons.

title: Fashion Week Parties Warm Up
description: Emily Ratajkowski and Amanda Seyfried attend the Target party, and Rose McGowan and Lindsey Wixson dance to Erykah Badu at the Top of the Standard.

title: The New Double-Breasted Tailoring
description: The conservative cut shakes its stuffy image with a slimmer profile and awkwardly boyish proportions.

title: Collegiate Turn for Philharmonics Brass
description: Do not expect plumed caps. The outlook for high steps, flag-waving and chiropractor-defying back bends is unclear. But next month Alan Gilbert, the music director of the New York Philharmonic, will lead the orchestras brass section along with the mighty Michigan Marching Band at the homecoming football game against Northwestern.

title: An Apple Kind of Week
description: This week is all about Apple, the worlds richest tech company, which introduced new iPhones, an overhauled Apple TV and a jumbo-size iPad on Wednesday.

title: Fantasy Football Rankings 2015
description: These player rankings from the Sablich brothers are for standard and PPR scoring formats and will be updated throughout the season.

title: Creatures of the Wind: Spring 2016 RTW
description: The latest designs from Shane Gabier and Christopher Peters.

title: G.E. to Seek Sale of Its Asset Management Arm
description: General Electric has already been moving to shed its huge lending arm. Now the industrial conglomerate is potentially becoming even smaller.

title: Northern Ireland Faces Crisis as Unionist First Minister Resigns
description: DUBLIN  The fractious power-sharing provincial government in Northern Ireland came perilously close to collapse on Thursday as Peter Robinson, leader of the majority party, followed through on his threat to resign as first minister. It was the latest chapter in a political crisis prompted by police claims that the Irish Republican Army is still active a decade after it said it had disbanded.

title: India Seeks Saudi Cooperation to Investigate Rape Allegations Against Envoy
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian government summoned the Saudi ambassador on Thursday to convey a police request for his embassys cooperation in an investigation of allegations that two Nepali women were repeatedly raped and confined by a Saudi diplomat in the city of Gurgaon, a suburb of Delhi.

title: Rain Postpones U.S. Open Womens Semifinals
description: With the forecast calling for persistent rain, United States Open organizers postponed Thursday evenings womens singles semifinals until Friday morning, with play scheduled to begin at 11 a.m.

title: Teaching Mockingbird, Watchman and Harper Lee With The New York Times
description: Updated | Feb., 2016

title: Jeb Bush Boasts of Florida House Speakers Backing Him  Except for Marco Rubio
description: Jeb Bush has a message for Marco Rubio: Your former colleagues like me better.

title: A Pregnancy Souvenir: Cells That Are Not Your Own
description: Recently, a team of pathologists at Leiden University Medical Center in the Netherlands carried out an experiment that might seem doomed to failure.

title: Breaking Good News Can Be as Hard as Breaking Bad
description: I was standing at a counter on the medical ward, having my afternoon coffee, when one of the residents threw her hands up in the air.

title: Brother Vellies: Spring 2016 RTW
description: The latest from Aurora Jamess sustainable shoe label.

title: The Surf Is Always Up at This NoLIta Boutique
description: The arrival of cooler weather doesnt mean that summer has to end. Warm, a boutique in NoLIta that caters to men and women, has a beachy feel all year. An alcove near the entrance is where the shops owners, the husband-and-wife team Rob Magnotta and Winnie Beattie, stock their mens wear from obscure Japanese and French labels, not to mention their mens wares, like candles in tin cups and knives handmade from reclaimed disk plows. While the couple redesigns Warms interior for each season, certain staples, like flip-flops and swim trunks, are available year-round. Stepping into the store, you feel as if youve been transported from New York City to the Venice section of Los Angeles. Here, Mr. Magnotta talks more about Warm.

title: Answers to Questions About Apples New Products
description: We asked readers to send us questions about Apples new products on Wednesday when the company unveiled updated iPhones, a bigger iPad, an upgraded Apple TV and accessories. Many readers had queries about the new devices and how they work. Brian X. Chen and J.D. Biersdorfer answered the most frequently asked ones.

title: Match the Artists with Their Childhood Works: Round Two
description: In the second installment of a series for T, artists pair a piece of their past with the present.

title: Fashion Week Parties Warm Up
description: In a prelude to New York Fashion Week, Target hosted a party Wednesday that paid homage to vintage Vogue covers as well as high and low fashion. Guests included Emily Ratajkowski, dressed in Balmain and a Target necklace, who said she was not quite a fashion week veteran. Im kind of like a sophomore or junior, she said.

title: Police Release Sketch of Suspect in Shooting of Cuomo Administration Lawyer
description: New York police officials have released a sketch of a man who they say is being sought for questioning in connection with the shooting of a Cuomo administration lawyer in Brooklyn early on Monday.

title: As Head-Up Displays Become Common, Distraction Becomes an Issue
description: When Manish Undavia took delivery of the 2016 Audi A7 sedan  list price, about $71,000  it came with technology rarely found in automobiles, even five years ago: collision avoidance systems, sensors to keep the car from drifting and, perhaps most baffling to Mr. Undavia, a head-up display.

title: No Surf, but Maybe Dunes in NASAs Latest Pluto Photos
description: Dunes on Pluto?

title: On Set | They Made New York
description: As 28 legends of the downtown scene gather for a special portrait, Chuck Close remembers SoHo in the late 70s and early 80s.

title: Bernie Sanders Has a Fan in the James Bond Actor Daniel Craig
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has been busy rounding up Democratic endorsements, but her chief rival, Senator Bernie Sanders, can now boast a powerful supporter of his own: James Bond.

title: Why Tennis Transcends Nationalism
description: With the towering exception of Serena Williams, who is on the cusp of completing a calendar grand slam and tying Steffi Grafs mark of 22 major singles titles, these are pretty lean times for American tennis. Williams is one of just two Americans in the womens Top 20. John Isner is the only American in the mens Top 20, and it has been 12 years since an American man won the U.S. Open.

title: Staying Signed Into Gmail
description: Q. I keep checking the box to stay signed into my Gmail account when I log into the Firefox browser on my Mac, but when I quit the program, the browser never retains the information and I have to keep logging in and typing in the security code that gets texted to my phone. How can I get Firefox to remember me?

title: Next Steps in Putting Iran Nuclear Deal Into Effect
description: WASHINGTON  With Senate Democrats blocking passage of a resolution disapproving of the Iran nuclear deal, the attention will shift from the halls of Congress to the nations and international agencies that must put the accord into effect. Heres what happens next.

title: N.F.L. Week 1 Schedule and Picks
description: Seahawks at Rams

title: They Made New York
description: On July 14, 2015, T magazine assembled some of the artists, writers, performers, musicians and intellectuals who defined New Yorks inimitable and electrifying cultural scene of the late 1970s and early 80s. There were longtime friends (and some rivals) in the group, but overall, the mood was one of celebration. And why not? Every generation thinks its uniquely special, but this generation really is: These are the people who came to, and stayed in, New York when it was at its worst, and in so doing, created what was arguably the most important multidisciplinary artistic movement that the city has ever seen.

title: Why Cant We Stop Talking About New York in the Late 1970s?
description: The late 1970s were some of the darkest, bleakest years in New Yorks history. So why cant we stop talking about them?

title: Longmire, Revived on Netflix, Continues Its Embrace of Western Traditions
description: Longmire is the third major show Netflix has picked up following its cancellation on television, after Arrested Development and The Killing. At first glance, it might seem like an odd choice: a popular but old-fashioned crime procedural that was dropped by A&E after three seasons because its audience was north of the 18-to-49 demographic.

title: Review: Louise Lecavalier Is a Typhoon of Physicality in So Blue
description: In the first half of So Blue, Louise Lecavalier is like a one-woman typhoon, twisting and snapping her slender, androgynous body while contorting wildly to Mercan Dedes lurching, pulsating beat. Ushering in the fall season at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, this Canadian dancer  best known as a leading member of douard Locks La La La Human Steps (from 1981 to 1999)  comes out, arms and legs swinging, in loose track pants and a skin-hugging top. Often during this moody, 60-minute work, it seems that Ms. Lecavalier is engaged in battle, but with what is hard to say.

title: A New Concept Store in SoHo Boasts Basquiat  and Foosball
description: Perched on a second-floor loft on Wooster Street, an ambitious new concept jewelry store brings high-end pieces  the kind you find around 50th Street, where Madison and Park Avenue giants like Tiffanys reign  to SoHo. And its buying into the downtown, stay-awhile vibes of its neighboring shops. A custom-made Douglas Little light fixture hangs above a long dining table, not far from a shearling daybed, a dining room table, a custom foosball table and a kitchen. But the walls are lined with gold, silver and diamonds. Its unforced luxury, says Rob Ronen, a co-owner, about the homey loft. I want people to be able to come in, and, you know, enjoy a cup of coffee or a glass of Champagne, not necessarily just to buy something. Just to hang out. But if they are in the market, theres no shortage of items to choose from: In addition to high-end jewelry and watches (Ronen, alongside the stores other co-owner, Michael Herman, are authorized dealers for Audemars Piguet and Richard Mille), there are vintage watches, bought at auction houses like Christies and Sothebys; custom-made furniture by designers such as Prouv or Charlotte Perriand; and contemporary art, including works by Jean-Michel Basquiat and Andy Warhol.

title: The Downtown Decade: NYC 1975  1985
description: A new exhibition celebrates the New York undergrounds most interesting 10 years.

title: Review: A Brilliant Young Mind Facing Infinite Obstacles
description: A Brilliant Young Mind refuses to soft-pedal the infuriating arrogance and coldness of its protagonist, Nathan Ellis (Asa Butterfield), a British math prodigy with autism. More than most films that address that condition, this one shows the amount of patience, understanding and commitment required from caring parents and friends who deal with someone who, however gifted, may appear selfish and unfeeling.

title: A Time Capsule From Downtown New Yorks Most Interesting Decade
description: As Edmund White notes in Ts Fall Mens issue, our current culture is fascinated by the late 70s and early 80s in New York, a period when the city was veering toward financial ruin and downtown looked like a war zone. The was a reason there was a bar called Downtown Beirut, says the curator Lauren Miller Walsh. But downtown New York was where artists, actors, musicians and playwrights could afford to live and work, forming a vibrant artistic community.

title: Review: Twin Terrors Haunt Goodnight Mommy
description: Like many foreign movies that venture outside their home countries, Goodnight Mommy must live with an English title far inferior to its Austrian original, which literally translates as I see, I see. Eyes  and what we think they see  are everything in this carefully controlled creep-out, gazing into mirrors and peering through shutters and tightly wrapped gauze. When its over, even those who have guessed its final twist (because we have seen it before) will immediately want to watch again, if only to check the logic of its shifting points of view.

title: Bratton on Arrest of James Blake
description: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton said he wanted to extend a personal apology to James Blake, a retired tennis player, after his mistaken arrest on Wednesday.

title: Review: Annauds Wolf Totem, Set in Inner Mongolia in the 1960s
description: In Wolf Totem, the French director Jean-Jacques Annaud, no stranger to animals (The Bear) or turbulent Chinese history (Seven Years in Tibet), adapts a novel that grew into a controversial phenomenon in China. The book, written by a Beijing professor, Lu Jiamin, under the pseudonym Jiang Rong, was second in circulation only to Maos little red book, according to a 2008 review in The New York Times.

title: Australia Pulls Out of Soccer Friendlies With U.S. Womens Team
description: Australia on Thursday pulled out of two exhibition matches that were to be part of the United States womens national teams World Cup victory tour, but U.S. Soccer said the games in Detroit and Birmingham, Ala., would go ahead as scheduled with Haiti as a replacement opponent.

title: Avon Is Said to Be in Talks About Selling a Stake
description: Avon Products is in talks with investment firms about selling a stake in itself, potentially bringing in a partner to help the cosmetics maker turn itself around, a person with direct knowledge of the matter said on Thursday.

title: Review: Listening, a World Where Your Thoughts Are Not Your Own
description: Its been a while since there has been as loopy a techno-paranoia fable as Khalil Sullinss Listening. This quasi-philosophical treatise on mind control and hard-wired telepathy begins as a fitfully intriguing character study before flying off the rails as a nightmarish vision of government encroachment on free thought.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, Sept. 11 to 18, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: White House Wants to Admit More Refugees
description: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, said that President Obama wants the United States to accept at least 10,000 Syrian refugees in the next fiscal year.

title: Fiat Chrysler Recalls Nearly 1.7 Million Ram Pickups
description: Fiat Chrysler is recalling almost 1.7 million Ram pickup trucks over airbag or steering problems, the automaker said on Thursday. Just two months ago, Fiat Chrysler was assessed $105 million in civil penalties to settle regulators accusations that it jeopardized public safety by failing to comply with federal laws in 23 other recalls.

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
description: Japan and More  Pictures of the Day

title: September 10, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Japan, Greece, Germany and Afghanistan.

title: Biden Discusses Minimum Wage in New York
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. applauded Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday for approving plans to raise the minimum wage for fast-food workers to $15 an hour.

title: A Plan to Save Refugees and Europes Open Borders
description: Jean-Claude Juncker, the president of the European Commission and the highest official of the European Union, has laid out a plan to  distribute 160,000 refugees among E.U. members by mandatory quotas. It is a plan Europe simply must adopt if it is to get a handle on the crisis and remain true to its history and values.

title: Bill de Blasio Opposes a Joe Biden Presidential Bid
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York has held out on endorsing his former boss, Hillary Rodham Clinton, in the presidential race, saying he needs to hear more about her vision for the country.

title: A Tiki Bar in Queens With an Off-the-Menu Daiquiri
description: At first glance, End of the Century is very much within the Queens Neighborhood Watering Hole genotype. There are exposed brick walls, a red-felt pool table,and a signed photo of the former Mets captain Keith Hernandez with Rodney Dangerfield.

title: Review: The Moving Creatures, Three Tales of Family Ordeals
description: The Moving Creatures, written and directed by Caetano Gotardo, is a small-bore examination of three Brazilian families beset by wrenching ordeals.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, Sept. 11 to 18, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Sprawling Art Shows in Brooklyn Bridge Park and on Governors Island
description: The work of more than 100 artists will grace two of the citys waterfront sites this weekend, giving New Yorkers the opportunity to become better photographers, take home pieces and meet their creators.

title: U.S. Makes Final an Array of Rules on Food Safety
description: Far-reaching food industry rules aimed at reducing food-borne illness in the United States have become final, the federal government announced on Thursday, nearly five years after Congress passed a law requiring an overhaul of the nations food safety system.

title: Palestinians Get Approval to Fly Flag at United Nations
description: UNITED NATIONS  Palestinians overwhelmingly won the right on Thursday to fly their national flag in front of United Nations headquarters, a symbolic step opposed by Israel and the United States.

title: At Venice Festival, the Wisdom of Lunatics, the Wildness of Age
description: VENICE  There is a character in Sangue del Mio Sangue  the Italian director Marco Bellocchios strange and wonderful new film  known as Il Pazzo, which translates as the Madman. Hes an unshaven, excitable fellow who wears a mismatched plaid suit, guzzles the aperitif Aperol and spouts barely comprehensible conspiracy theories. If you believe a possibly tongue-in-cheek interpretation Mr. Bellocchio offered at a news conference on Tuesday, he may be the only sane person in the movie. The lunatic-as-truth-teller is a venerable literary conceit (found in King Lear and, more locally, in the harlequins and zanni of commedia dellarte) and also a notion that has a particular relevance to this festival.

title: Nick Jonas, at Terminal 5, Sings His Hits and Covers, Too
description: Nick Jonas came onstage Wednesday night at Terminal 5 in a conspiratorial crouch, not to look smaller, as if he wanted to hide himself, but to move more slowly, emphasizing the creeping movements of his muscles, as if he were about to pounce.

title: A Dual Review of Whats New, Starring Salman Rushdie and Bear Grylls
description: Bear Grylls and Salman Rushdie take shelter in an inflatable tent while considering doorstep drugs and a rodent romance.

title: Donald Trump Denies Attacking Carly Fiorinas Looks
description: Donald J. Trump said Thursday he was not referring to Carly Fiorinas looks when he was quoted as saying, Look at that face and, Would anyone vote for that?

title: Review: Paul Taylor: Creative Domain Shows a Choreographer at Work
description: Paint doesnt talk back, Paul Taylor muses in Kate Geiss absorbing new documentary, Paul Taylor: Creative Domain. But dancers do, and choreographers need dancers. Mr. Taylor seems to have figured out how to make this work: His dancers, as seen here, dont talk back much, either. Theyre too busy working and trying to please him, to give him something more than he asks for.

title: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Sept. 11 to 18, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Scenes From New York Fashion Week: Day 1
description: Photos of off-the-runway scenes at fashion week.

title: Review: Negroland, by Margo Jefferson, on Growing Up Black and Privileged
description: Margo Jeffersons memoir, Negroland, possesses a refrain, a series of sentences that are repeated, as if out of a Duke Ellington composition, so the author can hang onto them and so can we.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Clinton Rips Trump After Fiorina Insult
description: The Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton criticized Donald Trumps remarks on women on Thursday after he insulted the looks of his Republican rival, Carly Fiorina.

title: Inside Christian Marclays World of Words
description: Entering Christian Marclays newest work, Surround Sounds, is like walking into a particularly loud comic book. Inside a large, darkened room, cut-out sound effects whizz by on all four walls. Though the room is silent, words like SHEEEE and TIC crawl across the space. BAM! flashes aggressively. I hope, Marclay told this T reporter, that you dont have epilepsy.

title: Review: The Visit Is Hansel and Gretel With Less Candy and More Camcorders
description: In The Visit, an amusingly grim fairy tale, floorboards creak, doors squeak and lights lower and sometimes shriek to black. The story, a Hansel and Gretel redo for Generation Selfie, has the virtue of simplicity and familiarity: A young brother and sister travel into the deep, dark woods, but where they once innocently held hands, theyre now holding camcorders to record an adventure quickened by anxious laughs, yelps and screams and one shivery long knife. These children dont need someone else to immortalize their once-upon-a-time; they just point and shoot.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, Sept. 11 to 18, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Review: In Meet the Patels, a Son Submits to a Marriage Quest
description: Meet the Patels is a tidy, easygoing documentary in which peripheral players prove more intriguing than its central focus. That would be Ravi Patel, a successful actor (Transformers; the coming TV series Grandfathered) in Los Angeles who has separated from his redheaded girlfriend, Audrey, lacking the nerve to tell his Indian-born parents about their relationship.

title: To Glimpse Pope Francis, Ticket or Patience Is Required
description: When he visits the United States this month for the first time, Pope Francis will meet with the mighty (world leaders, members of Congress, archbishops) and the meek (homeless people, schoolchildren, day laborers).

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Sept. 11-17
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for Sept. 11-17
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Creatures of the Wind Spring/Summer 2016
description: Shane Gabier and Christopher Peters showed a hodgepodge of patterns and textures.

title: Classical Music Listings for Sept. 11-17
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Come to American Beech for the Sea and Sun, Stay for the Chicken
description: American Beech Restaurant, Bar & Suites has taken over the 19th-century horse stable in Greenports Stirling Square that previously housed Main Restaurant and Oyster Bar and, a few years before that, North Fork Oyster Company. The new establishment is light, airy and appealing. The old rustic look, along with the oyster shucker at the front of the restaurant, is history. Now it has a sparkling white bar, dove-gray walls and a floor painted in wide strips of gray and white.

title: A Venezuelan in Silicon Valley Finds a Niche in Finance
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Jonathan Gheller went from selling tequeos, a Venezuelan fried, cheese-filled appetizer, in Caracas to building a company that he sold to Facebook. Now, working at its placid Menlo Park, Calif., headquarters, he credits mostly one person for his change in fortune.

title: Comedy Listings for Sept. 11-17
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Hillary Clinton Takes Aim at Donald Trump for Insulting Women
description: Donald Trumps Uncomplimentary Comments About Carly Fiorina

title: As a Boom Fades, Brazilians Wonder How It All Went Wrong
description: BRASLIA  The president of Brazil should have been ecstatic. She had just won re-election after an intense campaign in which she fiercely defended her role in making Brazil, for a few fleeting years, a rising star on the global stage.

title: Review: In Home From Home, a Blacksmiths Son Dreams of a Different World
description: Jacob, the blacksmiths son in the German historical epic Home From Home, is the rare reader in his poor village, and a formidable anthropologist. The same tag could be given to Edgar Reitz, the director of this thick slice of life in 1843 Germany and its landmark predecessor, the 50-plus-hour Heimat film series.

title: New Leader for Atlanta Symphony
description: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, which has been led by an interim president since its last one resigned last year in the midst of a two-month lockout during a heated labor dispute, announced Thursday that it had selected a new leader: Jennifer Barlament, currently the general manager of the Cleveland Orchestra.

title: Movie Listing for Sept. 11-17
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Review: Field Notes Uses Visual Art to Explore Caribbean Heritage
description: FIELD NOTES

title: As Lobsters Dwindle in Long Island Sound, Oysters Thrive
description: To see some of Connecticuts most industrious food producers, you will need to move beyond its many orchards and cornfields and head past the shore. Beneath the briny waters along the rocky coast and sandy shoals of Long Island Sound, you will find a thriving oyster industry.

title: Restaurant Review: Fogama in Rye Helps Customer Work Up to Sushi
description: Fried calamari is available just about anywhere in Westchester County, from high-end seafood restaurants to Italian neighborhood joints. But the version at Fogama, a nearly two-year-old neo-Japanese spot in Rye, still has the power to surprise.

title: Dance Listings for Sept. 11-17
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Sept. 11-17
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Searching for the Best Bar Burgers in New Jersey
description: Finding a simple cheeseburger is difficult these days. Gastropubs, for example, take enormous pride in offering fancy burgers with novel-like back stories.

title: Spare Times for Sept. 11-17
description: Museums and Sites

title: Review: Breathe, the Story of a Scary Teenage Romance
description: The scary, spellbinding performance of Lou De Lage in Breathe, the story of a high school friendship that goes bad, is so gripping that Ms. De Lages dangerous mixture of sensuality and bravado brings to mind Angelina Jolie in Girl, Interrupted and Jeanne Moreaus Catherine in Jules and Jim. She is the kind of seductive daredevil who challenges admirers to follow her into the fire, no matter what the consequences.

title: Tome: Spring 2016 RTW
description: Looks from Ryan Lobo and Ramon Martins spring 2016 collection.

title: Spare Times for Children for Sept. 11-17
description: Out of the Past: Celebrating 40 Years of the Mettawee Journey

title: Review: The Three Sopranos, at the Resonant Bodies Festival
description: For new-music lovers, Wednesday evenings performance at Merkin Concert Hall outdid any of those old Pavarotti, Domingo and Carreras three-tenor spectacles. Presented by the indispensable Resonant Bodies Festival, here were the Three Experimental Sopranos, given the freedom to program their own 45-minute sets.

title: Review: A Kingston Painter, Chronicler of the Hudson River School
description: Jervis McEntees legacy moment arrives at last, if 125 years after his death. Two exhibitions celebrate this influential and prolific 19th-century painter, best known until now for his personal journals, a treasure trove for scholars studying the early days of what is considered the United States first native art movement, the Hudson River School.

title: Review: The Beauty Inside Features 123 Actors for One Leading Man
description: Who plays the leading man in this quirky romance?

title: Review: In Sleeping With Other People, Star-Crossed Sex Addicts Make a Pact
description: Gee, its tough for straight women and men to lock lips and fates together on screen. One obvious problem is that virginity, marriage and children are no longer necessarily compulsory, which has complicated the happily-ever-after thing. The writer and director Leslye Headland gets this, but she apparently enjoys a challenge, so she has worked hard to complicate her romantic comedy Sleeping With Other People, about a man and a woman who do everything to stay apart even though they and everyone else know they were, sort of, made for each other.

title: Remembering Rowan & Martins Laugh-In
description: 47 YEARS AGO

title: Meet the Orleys of Orley
description: After impressing critics and industry people, its time to start selling clothes.

title: A Poet Shaped by a Bleak Childhood in Ireland
description: Connie Roberts endured a harsh childhood in Ireland, including an abusive father and a dozen years in a bleak Irish orphanage. Now, in a near-miraculous transformation, she is an adjunct assistant professor at Hofstra University in Hempstead, the mother of an 11-year-old son, and the author of Little Witness, a book of poetry published this year by Arlen House, a literary press in Dublin.

title: In Ridgefield, a Movie Theater With a Lofty Mission
description: When Debbie Kadagian and her parents, Dale and Joan Learn, headed out for a Friday matinee of Ricki and the Flash recently, they did so with a simple goal.

title: Jobless Claims
description: Jobless claims dropped by 6,000 in the week ended Sept. 5.

title: Orley, a Tastemakers Gem, Looks to Turn Praise Into Sales
description: The Orleys of Orley, a fledgling fashion label, tend to call one another by their full names. That is a bad habit that we all have, Matthew said. Even among themselves, they are Matthew Orley, 29, the oldest sibling; his brother Alex Orley, 27, who spearheads design; and Matthews wife, Samantha Orley, 30 (nee Florence).

title: Review: The People Before the Park, a Family Clash Rich in New York History
description: Once the exposition has been delivered and the plot is established and the characters are sketched out, a fairly good play emerges in The People Before the Park. Still, it takes some time to get there.

title: Review: 90 Minutes in Heaven, Then a Long Road Back
description: Caveat emptor: 90 Minutes in Heaven does not in fact depict a full hour and a half of the afterlife, as the travel-guide-like title might suggest. Rather, Michael Polishs cinematic homily dwells on the physical and spiritual recovery of a Texas pastor, Don Piper (Hayden Christensen), after he is declared dead in a car crash. Its based on Mr. Pipers best-selling book.

title: A Mash Note to New York at Photoville
description: New York Times photographers will be highlighted in projections at the Photoville festival. Also featured will be work by Eli Reed, Ernesto Bazan, Tanya Habjouqa, Joni Sternbach and others published on Lens.

title: Movie Review: The Visit
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The Visit.

title: Cooking With Friends (Without a Fight)
description: Have questions about recipes, cooking and food? I aim to answer them. Ask me anything: foodeditor@nytimes.com.

title: Works from Picasso Sculpture at MoMA
description: Selections from the exhibition, which fills 11 galleries on the fourth floor of the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Review: Picasso, Completely Himself in 3 Dimensions
description: Many exhibitions are good, some are great and a very few are tantamount to works of art in their own right  for their clarity, lyricism and accumulative wisdom.

title: Theater Listings for Sept. 11-17
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: A Paris Apartment for the Herms Mens Wear Designer
description: Vronique Nichanian

title: Movie Review: Sleeping With Other People
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Sleeping with Other People.

title: Fighters in Yemen Agree to Talks With U.N. Mediator
description: UNITED NATIONS  The warring parties in Yemen have agreed to hold direct talks mediated by the United Nations envoy next week, the United Nations announced Thursday.

title: British Airways Jet That Aborted Takeoff Had Multiple Engine Breaches
description: Federal accident investigators said on Thursday that they found multiple breaches in the engine of a British Airways aircraft that was forced to abort its takeoff on Tuesday at the Las Vegas McCarran International Airport, suggesting the airplane had suffered an uncontained engine failure.

title: Movie Review: Time Out of Mind
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Time Out of Mind.

title: Review: Laugh It Up, Stare It Down, on Love and Marriage
description: If an existentialist philosopher ever attempted a light romantic comedy, it might sound a little like Laugh It Up, Stare It Down, Alan Hruskas quaintly absurdist play at the Cherry Lane Theater. An amiable, if surface-skimming approach to love, marriage and all that sort of thing, it follows Joe (Jayce Bartok) and Cleo (Katya Campbell) from first date to probable death after a storm surge threatens to obliterate Rhode Island.

title: Review: Charles Swedlunds Buy Photographs Highlights His 1970s Work
description: Charles Swedlunds exhibition of playful images from the early 1970s offers an amusing trip back to a time when conceptually minded photographers were looking for ways beyond the Modernist, black-and-white print. Now 80 and having his first solo exhibition in a New York gallery, Mr. Swedlund is a Chicago native who taught for many years at Southern Illinois University until his retirement in 2000.

title: Review: Everything, Everyday Explores Affinities at Studio Museum in Harlem
description: Everything, Everyday, the title of this years artist-in-residence show at the Studio Museum in Harlem, catches the assemblage character of much of what three artists made during their stay. Eric Mack has worked out a deft combination of painting and sculpture using swatches of fabric, distressed clothing, rope, clamps, pegboards, packing blankets and paint. The result is a threatening-to-fall-apart choreography of heavy and light. In one piece, Alldayz, a big paint-spangled industrial blanket looks pretty enough to curl up in. In another, Metal (jacket), a quilted cold-weather coat, has been pierced with holes like wounds.

title: A Ralph Lauren Workout Shirt, Punky Vans Sneakers And Other Items for the Fall Shopping List
description: An eclectic collection of fall must-haves.

title: Review: Eduardo Paolozzis Sculpture and Prints Visit Brooklyn
description: The gap between art and life might best be summed up as the difference between public sculpture and playground equipment. Despite the seemingly obvious disparities between those objects, the Internet brims with stories of people  primarily children, but adults, too  who have climbed a sculpture and become stuck in it. In the best Pop Art tradition  that is, blurring the boundary between art and life  the three Eduardo Paolozzi sculptures here actually did time as playground equipment.

title: Joe Bidens Trip to New York Smacks of Campaign Visit
description: As he contemplates whether to run for president, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is continuing his day job. And along the way, he is offering a peek into the kinds of issues that might animate a White House campaign, many of which have been at the center of his political identity for decades.

title: Ellen Pao Ends Legal Battle, Citing Personal Resources
description: Ellen Pao, a tech industry executive who brought an unsuccessful discrimination lawsuit against her former employer, the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, said on Thursday that she would not pursue an appeal.

title: Review: Jeanine Durnings To Being, a Dance Premiere in Queens
description: How will they get themselves out of this? I kept wondering that during Jeanine Durnings To Being, which had its premiere on Wednesday at the Chocolate Factory in Queens, and not because I wanted it to end. This marathon of a dance enmeshes the dancers so wholly in doing, doing, doing that you cant imagine them being done. Its like watching people live, right in the thick of passing time.

title: The Architect Poy Gum Lee Finally Has a Retrospective
description: A few months after his descendants retrieved his archive from storage, the Chinese-American architect Poy Gum Lee is receiving his first retrospective. They have lent stacks of drawings and documents, which had lain largely unknown since his death in 1968, to the Museum of Chinese in America for Chinese Style: Rediscovering the Architecture of Poy Gum Lee, 1923-1968, opening on Sept. 24.

title: Review: A Garden Idyll for Noguchis Stones and Steel
description: Its a great and rare occurrence to see art installed in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Some might argue that this is where you go to look at nature rather than art  although tags and labels on the plants remind you that humans made this garden and bred plenty of the species in it. The Japanese-American artist Isamu Noguchi (1904-1988) is an excellent choice for a show here, since he himself created parks, playgrounds and gardens around the world, drawing heavily from a Japanese art tradition that considered aesthetics in relation to nature.

title: A Fish Caught by Hemingway Is Being Restored
