description: A chipped and scuffed blue marlin hangs in a gallery at the L. C. Bates Museum in Hinckley, Me., above preserved sea creatures arranged in wooden display cases. The marlins skin, wrapped around a wooden core, came from a 12-foot-long fish that Ernest Hemingway caught off the Bahamas in the 1930s. This fall visitors to the museum will be able to watch Ronald Harvey of Tuckerbrook Conservation in Lincolnville, Me., repair the deteriorated marlin, which he will access by maneuvering along a platform.

title: Rudolf Hulka Photos Show Europe and North Africa in the 1920s
description: Five years ago, librarians in Prague started sorting through about 4,400 images that the Czech photographer Rudolf Hulka took in Europe and North Africa, mostly in the 1920s. Two-dozen prints from his negatives, found in storage at the National Library of the Czech Republic, go on view Wednesday in the Harriman Institute Atrium at Columbia University.

title: Tom Wesselmann Nudes, and the Collection of the Baron of Botox
description: WESSELMANNS NUDES UNCOVERED AT SHOW

title: Series of Highway Shootings Unnerves Phoenix
description: A series of shootings over nearly two weeks along highways in the Phoenix area, most involving the same stretch of Interstate 10, has alarmed residents and confounded the police.

title: Prosecutor in Dewey Case Appeals to Common Sense
description: For more than two days, lawyers for three former Dewey & LeBoeuf executives on trial for cooking the law firms books picked holes in the prosecutions case by pointing out the unreliability of email evidence and the paucity of accounting experts called to testify during the lengthy trial.

title: The Dubious Case of Dewey & LeBoeuf
description: The names Enron and WorldCom are synonymous with accounting fraud and an era in which top executives turned to desperate measures to inflate company earnings, mislead investors, prop up share prices and supercharge their already exorbitant compensation.

title: Cuomo Pivots Again as He Seeks a $15 Minimum Wage
description: With Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at his side, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York presented himself as a champion of the working class on Thursday, pledging to campaign for a statewide minimum wage of $15 an hour.

title: Mamma Mia! Is Closing, and Super Troupers Give Thanks for the Music
description: Sorry, Chiquitita, but after 14 years, the Abba musical is closing on Broadway.

title: For California, El Nios Dark Clouds Could Mean Rain but Also Trouble
description: LOS ANGELES  A soaking El Nio weather system is in the forecast, promising to pummel California with torrents of rain by the end of the year. That would seem like Champagne-popping news as this state suffers through its worst drought in a millennium.

title: Partisan Tussle Keeps Top U.S. Aid Job Vacant
description: WASHINGTON  As the international community confronts a refugee crisis, the nominee to head the American agency responsible for overseas humanitarian issues is stalled in the Senate, leaving the Obama administration with a critical vacancy as it grapples with how to assist those displaced by conflict in the Middle East and Africa.

title: House Hearing on Insurers Mergers Exposes Health Care Industry Divide
description: WASHINGTON  Doctors, hospitals and health insurance companies clashed Thursday over the merits of mergers planned by four of the five biggest insurers in the United States.

title: Inquirys Trail: From George Washington Bridge to Uniteds Executive Offices
description: It was a traffic jam that, in the end, rerouted the career of the chief executive of the worlds fourth-largest airline, and how one led to the other is a tale of power, politics and New Jersey wheeling-dealing.

title: Evans Bank Settles New York Redlining Lawsuit
description: Redlining, the practice of denying mortgages to predominantly African-American neighborhoods, was supposed to be a relic of a long-gone era. But a settlement on Thursday between the New York attorney general and a small bank near Buffalo suggests that the practice persists.

title: Review: Summation Dances At the Hour Elevates the View From Below
description: At the start of At the Hour, the hour appears to be early. Light is slowly dawning. Birds are beginning to chirp. A woman in a loose shift might be doing her morning exercises, bending and twisting with her feet in ballet positions, and if you watch her closely enough, you may soon be surprised to realize that she is not alone. Others have appeared  some on the balconies that run along two sides of the stage area, some directly above your own head.

title: Duke Energy to Pay Fine Over Power Plant Violations
description: Duke Energy, the nations largest electric utility, agreedon Thursdayto pay nearly $5.4 million to settle a 15-year legal battle with federal regulators over whether its power plants skirted Clean Air Act regulations in the 1990s.

title: Four Years After a Fire, a Congregation Returns to Its Synagogue
description: Four years ago, Rabbi Haskel Lookstein gazed with fear and sorrow at the smoke billowing from the roof of the synagogue in Manhattan he had presided over for more than three decades. But instead of lamenting what had been lost in the fire, he recalled, he found himself wondering what the building that would replace the structure would look like.

title: CNN Sets Lineup for Republican Presidential Debate
description: CNN released on Thursday night the lineup for its Republican presidential debate next week, showing Donald J. Trump once again squarely in the middle of the stage, the spot reserved for the top performer in the polls, with the retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson to his right and Jeb Bush to his left.

title: In Second Republican Debate, Donald Trumps Rivals Seek Points, Not Knockout
description: The Republican presidential candidates, increasingly certain that their televised debates can have make-or-break consequences for their campaigns, are preparing aggressive new tactics for their next face-off on Wednesday, hoping to draw voters away from the surprisingly durable Donald J. Trump as the 2016 race enters a more combative phase.

title: Stan Wawrinka Rises, Challenging Roger Federers Swiss Supremacy
description: Famously smooth with a tennis ball in play, Roger Federer likes the rest of his professional life to move along smoothly as well: minimal controversy, minimal complications.

title: New York City Prosecutor Using Millions Taken From Banks for Rape-Kit Testing
description: The Manhattan district attorney is sending $38 million taken in civil forfeiture from international banks in New York to cities and counties across the country to pay for testing 56,000 rape kits that have been collecting dust in police storage rooms for years.

title: Joe Biden, in Colbert Interview, Expresses Doubts About Bid for President
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., in an emotional, wide-ranging interview on Stephen Colberts Late Show on Thursday, expressed doubt about the likelihood that he would run for president, saying that Id be lying if I said that I knew I was there.

title: Netanyahu Makes Quick Pivot From Loss on Iran Deal
description: JERUSALEM  In the week since it became clear that Congress would not block the Iranian nuclear deal he loathes, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has largely toned down his rhetoric on the issue and pivoted to others.

title: Merv Adelson, Las Vegas Developer-Turned-Daring TV Producer, Dies at 85
description: Merv Adelson, a real estate and resort developer who pivoted to become one of televisions most successful producers in a roller-coaster life involving the mob, the Teamsters pension fund, a marriage to Barbara Walters and a huge fortune made and lost, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 85.

title: Influential Pro-Israel Group Suffers Stinging Political Defeat
description: WASHINGTON  Officials at the American Israel Public Affairs Committee knew the odds were against them in the fight to block President Obamas nuclear deal with Iran from surviving a congressional vote. But the influential pro-Israel group threw itself into a nearly $30 million advertising and lobbying effort to kill the accord anyway.

title: Dan Tepfer Plays Dizzys Club Coca-Cola With Seasoned Elders in Tow
description: After putting the finishing touch on a delicate, rapturous ballad at Dizzys Club Coca-Cola on Wednesday night, the pianist Dan Tepfer reflected on his present circumstance. He was leading a trio with musicians more than 40 years his senior: the drummer Billy Hart, 74, and the bassist Gary Peacock, 80. Working in such company, Im constantly reminded of the amazing people theyve played with over the years, Mr. Tepfer said.

title: Blue Jays Swift Rise in the A.L. East Was Built on Patience and Prospects
description: Alex Anthopoulos had been general manager of the Toronto Blue Jays for two seasons when he welcomed a reporter to his office in Dunedin, Fla., in the spring of 2012. The topic was Brandon Morrow, an inconsistent pitcher with alluring potential who had just signed a modest three-year contract. The premise of the story was that the Blue Jays were wise to gamble on such players as a way to compete in the rugged American League East.

title: A Stolen Car Found, With the Help of Cold War Technology
description: A police car headed the wrong way down Smith Street in Brooklyn, three young officers inside, one of them thumbing through a smartphone and calling out directions.

title: New York Police Focus on Fraud Involving Credit Cards
description: The undercover investigators arranged to meet at a hotel near Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan around the lunchtime rush on Wednesday. They were looking for men they believed had used stolen credit card information to go on a shopping spree, spending about $18,000 on 16 transactions  mostly on luxury designer shoes.

title: Review: Richard Maxwells Isolde Returns With Starry Eyes
description: Isolde, which played at the Abrons Arts Center in April 2014, reopened last night at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center, Fort Greene, Brooklyn; 866-811-4111, tfana.org. Here are excerpts from Ben Brantleys review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 14; the full text is here.

title: Review: Empire Travel Agency Guides Adventurers on a New York Odyssey
description: Is the 4 train a place of mystery and danger? It feels that way when you are slinking around a subway car, whispering code words in an anxious attempt to locate a shadowy Manitoban. When you have fled kidnappers, buskers and more than one sinister cabal, there is much more to stand clear of than just the closing doors.

title: Review: Desire, Six Plays That Second-Guess Tennessee Williams
description: Desire makes for a generic if apt title for a collection of short plays adapted from stories by Tennessee Williams, the playwright who has anatomized that emotion  its pleasures, tortures, dangers  more thoroughly and with more lyric eloquence than any other. This production from the Acting Company, which opened on Thursday at the 59E59 Theaters, directed by Michael Wilson, features works from six notable playwrights, based on tales mostly written by Williams in the 1940s.

title: Tremble With Indignation
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Crossword puzzle constructors are a competitive lot. Youve got your faction who are constantly trying to construct a puzzle with the fewest number of words in it. Youve got your faction of constructors who try to outstack each other in terms of having long entries piled on top of each other. And then there is the faction of constructors who try to get lively and unusual entries into their puzzles before anyone else does.

title: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Scott Walker Over Unions at Event in Wisconsin
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has picked up a string of early support from labor unions in recent weeks and on Thursday took her pro-union message to Gov. Scott Walkers backyard.

title: 3 Men Laundered Over $5 Billion for Drug Cartels, U.S. Says
description: A group of Colombians used the Chinese counterfeit market to launder more than $5 billion for drug traffickers in the United States, Europe and Asia, federal prosecutors said Thursday.

title: Candida Royalle, 64, Dies; Filmed Erotica for Women
description: Candida Royalle, a former star of pornographic movies who became a self-styled feminist filmmaker spurning what she called a misogynistic wham, bam, thank you, maam genre to create erotica that would appeal to women, died on Monday at her home in Mattituck, N.Y., on Long Island. She was 64.

title: Dickie Moore, Child Actor Known for a Screen Kiss, Dies at 89
description: Dick Moore, a public relations executive who was known as Dickie when he was a Hollywood child star, playing the movies first talking Oliver Twist and later giving Shirley Temple what was widely publicized as her first on-screen kiss, died on Monday in Connecticut. He was 89.

title: Eli Manning Said to Be Near Deal With Giants
description: Entering the final year of his contract, Eli Manning on Monday did not rule out continuing the negotiations for a new deal during the regular season. But Mannings expression seemed to say otherwise, and he meaningfully added, Im not a fan of contract negotiations during the season.

title: Adam Selman: Spring 2016 RTW
description: The latest collection from Mr. Selman, a designer who has worked on many of Rihannas tour costumes.

title: Yeshiva University President to Step Down in 2018
description: Yeshiva University said on Thursday that its president would leave his post at the end of his current term in 2018, the same day that it announced a deal involving ownership of its prestigious but money-losing medical school.

title: Girardi Sees Yanks Rainout as a Help and a Hindrance
description: If the Yankees had been harboring a great deal of anticipation about their most significant series in three years  a four-game visit from the Toronto Blue Jays with first place at stake  then whats waiting another 24 hours?

title: Corrections: September 10, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: The Things They Left Behind
description: Artifacts that remain in a hangar at Kennedy International Airport paint a poignant picture of everyday life at the World Trade Center before Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Hillary Clintons Support Erodes in National Poll
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons national lead over her rivals for the Democratic nomination has shrunk, and she is in a statistical tie with leading Republicans in head-to-head surveys, a new CNN/ORC poll released Thursday evening showed.

title: Yoenis Cespedes Launches an Unlikely M.V.P. Candidacy
description: It is hard to say if the deadline trade that sent Yoenis Cespedes from the Detroit Tigers to the Mets has been better for the player or the team. The Mets have built a commanding division lead while perched atop Cespedess broad shoulders, and Cespedes, an outfielder from Cuba, has opened the door for a contract extension well into nine figures.

title: Virginia Sheriff Releases Video of Effort to Subdue Inmate Who Died
description: The sheriffs office in Fairfax County, Va., released a graphic video on Thursday showing the struggle between officers and a mentally ill woman that preceded her death, and said it was conducting an internal affairs investigation into the episode, in which the officers used a stun gun four times on the woman.

title: Sleeping With Other People (With Movie Trailer): Leslye Headland Narrates a Scene
description: Two people with issues around sex become buddies in Leslye Headlands romantic comedy Sleeping With Other People. This scene features Alison Brie as Lanie, a woman sexually obsessed with Matthew (Adam Scott). They have been having an affair and she spots him running in a park.

title: Anatomy | Sleeping With Other People
description: The writer and director Leslye Headland narrates a sequence from her film.

title: Venezuelan Opposition Leader Leopoldo Lpez Sentenced to Prison Over Protest
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  A judgeon Thursdayfound the Venezuelan opposition politician Leopoldo Lpez guilty of inciting violence and other charges stemming from his leading role in a large antigovernment protest, according to government television reports.

title: Longer Lunch Periods Mean Fuller Students
description: In schools with short lunch periods, children eat less and discard more than in schools where they are allowed more time to eat, a new study has found.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | witless
description: witless  \wit-ls\  adjective

title: Prison for Man Who Slashed U.S. Ambassador in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A South Korean man who attacked the American ambassador to Seoul with a kitchen knife this year was sentenced on Friday to 12 years in prisonfor attempted murder.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 8 P.M. (Starz) INTO THE WOODS (2014) After being cursed by a witch (Meryl Streep, above, in an Oscar-nominated performance), a baker (James Corden) and his wife (Emily Blunt) find their fates bound to Cinderella (Anna Kendrick), Little Red Riding Hood (Lilla Crawford), Rapunzel (MacKenzie Mauzy) and other fairy tale characters in this Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine musical, directed for the screen by Rob Marshall. This splendid Disney adaptation infuses new vitality into the tired marketing concept of entertainment for children of all ages, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. That usually translates to mean only children and their doting parents. But with Into the Woods, you grow up with the characters, young and old, in a lifelong process of self-discovery.

title: Corrections: September 11, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I was standing there doing nothing  not running, not resisting, in fact smiling.

title: Mets and Bartolo Colon Wait Out a Rain Delay and Swamp the Braves
description: ATLANTA  Around the time the Mets game against the Braves was supposed to begin on Thursday night, thunder clapped from above, and a heavy rain fell. After a while, the outfield looked like a swamp. Water poured down the Mets dugout steps like a fountain, creating a small moat that kept the players from peeking outside.

title: Bon Jovi Adds Taiwan Show After China Cancellations
description: Bon Jovi has been frozen out of China, apparently because of the bands homage to the Dalai Lama, but its lead singer, Jon Bon Jovi, will still have a few chances to try out the Mandarin-language song hes been practicing.

title: Singapore Voters Give Ruling Party a Resounding Victory
description: JAKARTA  Voters in Singapore delivered a resounding mandate on Friday to the governing party, which had been working to overcome its worst showing ever in an election four years ago.

title: A Mash Note to New York at Photoville
description: Newspaper photographers are somewhat captive to the city where their employers originally set up printing presses. Sure, New York Times staff photographers travel occasionally, and a few of us are stationed overseas or in Washington, but most of us work in New York.

title: The Catholic Church and Marriage Annulments
description: To the Editor:

title: Hungary Today, and in 1956
description: To the Editor:

title: United Arab Emirates Aid to Syrians
description: To the Editor:

title: Homeless in New York: Ways to Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Japans Economy, Crippled by Caution
description: TOKYO  Visitors to Japan are often surprised by how prosperous it seems. It doesnt look like a deeply depressed economy. And thats because it isnt.

title: Will We Always Remember 9/11?
description: Soon after the horrific destruction of the World Trade Center towers 14 years ago, bumper stickers abounded in parallel with the nations grief. Never Forget, one proclaimed with great resolve. We Will Always Remember, promised another.

title: Abortion, a Personal Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: The Russia I Miss
description: St. Petersburg, Russia  People who came of age after the end of the Cold War may not realize how powerfully Russia influenced Western culture for 150 years. For more than a century, intellectuals, writers, artists and activists were partly defined by the stances they took toward certain things Russian: Did they see the world like Tolstoy or like Dostoyevsky? Were they inspired by Lenin and/or Trotsky? Were they alarmed by Sputnik, awed by Solzhenitsyn or cheering on Yeltsin or Gorbachev?

title: The House Stretches Legal Logic on Health Reform
description: Once again congressional Republicans are trying to manipulate the courts into overturning health care reforms that they have been unable to block in the normal political process.

title: How to Cheat on Taxes in China
description: Beijing  WHEN the accountant at one of the companies I work for as a teacher asked me to evade taxes, she posed it as a challenge.

title: For Students With a Mission, a Little Capital Goes a Long Way
description: Rose Wang wants you to eat bugs. Two billion people in the world already do. Her new company, Six Foods  so named because six legs is better than four sells Chirps: snack chips made from cricket flour. Insects are an environmentally sustainable source of complete protein: Producing a pound of beef uses 2,000 times the water and creates 100 times the greenhouse gas emissions of producing a pound of cricket meat, and crickets are higher in protein and lower in fat.

title: Fosun to Raise $1.5 Billion to Finance Acquisitions
description: HONG KONG  Fosun International, the Chinese conglomerate, said on Friday that it planned to raise up to 11.7 billion Hong Kong dollars, or $1.5 billion, by issuing rights shares to pay for deals in the banking and insurance industry.

title: News Qs | Homo Naledi, New Human Species, Is Found in South African Cave
description: In Homo Naledi, New Human Species, Is Found in South African Cave, John Noble Wilford reports on a previously unidentified species of the early human lineage.

title: Quota Proposal Fails to Gain Traction as Germany Prepares for More Arrivals
description: BERLIN  Germany on Friday failed to persuade Hungary and three other Central European partners to accept joint European Union action and a quota to distribute migrants from the Middle East.

title: Telenor and TeliaSonera Call Off Merger of Danish Operations
description: LONDON  The Nordic telecommunications companies Telenor and TeliaSonera said on Friday that they had called off plans to merge their Danish businesses after they were unable to win approval from Europes antitrust authorities.

title: Document Submitted to Hong Kong Police Department
description: A copy of a document purports to show deposits that the Malaysian prime minister, Najib Razak, directed into Swiss bank account.

title: An Affordable Country House Sampler for New Yorkers
description: Disappointed by what their budget will buy in the city, some New York City renters are heading to second-home markets, from the Catskill Mountains to the Jersey Shore, to live the American dream, if only on the weekends. Heres a look at what $350,000 or less will buy in second-home markets within a three-hour drive of New York City.

title: Buying a Second Home First
description: Some New York City renters are skipping the typical first rung on the urban homeownership ladder: Instead of investing in an apartment, they are buying a country house. Disappointed by what their budget will buy in the city, they are still living the American dream of having a place of their own, if only on the weekends, in the Catskills, at the Jersey Shore or in Connecticut.

title: Sanctions Debate Emerges From Shadow of Iran Nuclear Accord
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, in advance of his victory in Congress on Thursday on the Iran nuclear deal, focused on centrifuge numbers, uranium stockpiles and the breakout time to build a bomb. But now, as the agreement is carried out, he will face a new battle over how stringently to impose economic sanctions on Iran.

title: When in Rome, Learn to Cook Italian
In the Studio | Thom Browne
description: Thom Browne talks with Vanessa Friedman about the virtues of minimalism, the color gray and having his staff members dress as if hes their father.

title: In the Studio: Thom Browne
description: In the first episode of Season 3 of our video series that goes inside the private offices and behind the scenes of the working lives of designers, Thom Browne reveals that the extreme aesthetic discipline apparent in his collections extends to his environment, too.

title: For Jets Todd Bowles, a Lifetime of Calmly Facing Challenges
description: The day Todd Bowles was almost attacked while coming home from football practice, he was 8, maybe 9.

title: What Do You Wish You Could See, Hear, Read or Experience for the First Time All Over Again?
description: What cultural experience  a concert, a movie, a book, a visit to a museum or restaurant, a play or anything else  has been so meaningful to you that you wish you could experience it for the first time all over again?

title: On the Iran Deal
description: Senate Democrats blocked a Republican resolution to reject the nuclear accord.

title: Turkeys Military Rulers
description: GOTHENBURG, Sweden  Many commentators have interpreted the decision of Turkeys president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, to restart the war against the Kurdistan Workers Party, or P.K.K., as designed to undo the results of the June 7 general election. The ruling Justice and Development Party, also known as the A.K.P., was deprived of its majority in Parliament when the pro-Kurdish Peoples Democratic Party, or H.D.P., surged at the polls.

title: Tour News: Rugby in England, Fall Photography in Maine
description: Our morning travel news digest, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Ask Well: Choosing the Right Grain for Your Morning
description: Question:

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: New York Today: A Day to Remember
description: Updated at 9:17 a.m.

title: Morning Agenda: Avon in Talks to Sell a Stake
description: AVON IN TALKS TO SELL A STAKE | Avon Products is discussing selling a stake in itself and bringing in a partner to help turn the company around, Michael J. de la Merced reports in DealBook. The cosmetics maker considered bringing in a private equity firm for what is known on Wall Street as a private investment in public equity, or PIPE,  essentially a negotiated stake sale by a publicly traded company. It has also explored other options. Bids are expected within the next few weeks.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Sept. 11
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include an image of the first day of school, the West Indian American Parade in Brooklyn and homelessness in the city.

title: Japan Flooding Kills 3 and Leads to Release of Tainted Water
description: TOKYO  At least three people were killed in extensive flooding this week in eastern Japan, the authorities said on Friday, with the deluge prompting the release of an unknown amount of contaminated water from a shuttered nuclear power plant. An additional 23 people were still missing, according to the public broadcaster NHK.

title: Anne of Green Gables Was a Terrible Mother
description: She is a terrible mother.

title: Nuclear Deal Clears Hurdle, but Iranian Reaction Is Muted
description: TEHRAN  Iranians waiting a long time for their country to shed its role as perpetual global outsider greeted the news that a landmark nuclear accord had cleared a crucial hurdle in Washington with a temperate response on Friday.

title: Today in Politics: Sept. 11 Anniversary Offers a Pause Amid the Clamor
description: Good morning on Friday, Sept. 11, 2015, 14 years later. CNN has released its lineup for the Republican debate next week: Carly Fiorina will be promoted to the prime-time event, and the soft-spoken Ben Carson will share center stage with Donald J. Trump, offering a split-screen study in contrasts of the current Republican front-runners. But that is for next week. On Friday, there will be a relative break from the typical campaign noise as candidates and public officials attend memorials and read the names of the dead.

title: M.T.A. Chief Presses New York City for Funding After G Train Derails
description: After a subway train derailed in Brooklyn, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Friday issued a scathing statement that sought to call attention to New York Citys reluctance to pay more toward the agencys capital infrastructure plan.

title: Teaching Slavery to Reluctant Listeners
description: One thing is certain as I prepare to teach another course on U.S. history. Invariably, at least one student evaluation will complain that Professor Baptist only talks about slavery. Its an annual reminder that while Ive been trying to teach the history of slavery for two decades in American classrooms, America has tried to evade thinking about that history for far longer. Twenty-four decades have passed since the Continental Congress deleted Thomas Jeffersons criticisms of slavery from his first draft of the Declaration of Independence, and college students today arrive knowing little about the way Americas history of slavery has shaped their lives. Avoidance of the topic is deeply ingrained.

title: The First Day of College
description: It is a late-summer rite: A convoy of shambling family vehicles descends on clean-scrubbed, iron-gated villages whose sole recent inhabitants, it would seem, have been lawn mowers and paintbrushes. The cars have license plates from distant places, clattering bike racks and the occasional cumbersome item (lacrosse stick? longboard?) secured to the roof with straps. Their interior contents are more disorderly still: typically a pair of adults well past the age of footloose road trips and a veteran teenager on the slippery cusp of a new world. The previous few years of test-taking, application-filing and hand-wringing have been aimed at learning the name and address of the site where this rift would occur. In short order the travelers will part ways; its a long-awaited, inescapable and horrible fact  and if all goes well, it will be more or less permanent. But fortunately, with so many families going through this drama at once, the ensuing chaos has a way of tempering emotions  at least initially.

title: Teaching a Different Shakespeare From the One I Love
description: My first encounter with Shakespeare  As You Like It, in Miss Gillespies eighth-grade English class  left me cold. I still remember the words I pray thee, Rosalind, sweet my coz, be merry, which I must have been compelled to recite out loud, with a shudder. But not long afterward, I fell in love with him, not through the charm of performance but through the hallucinatory power of his language.

title: The 8.30.15 Issue
description: RE: SERENA WILLIAMS

title: Uber Would Like to Buy Your Robotics Department
description: In the center of the lab, CHIMP stretched out one huge arm, then gracefully unfurled its three metal fingers, as if about to beckon someone. On its head, two rapidly rotating laser scanners enabled it to monitor its surroundings, but the engineers standing nearby were wary nonetheless. If the robot  a five-foot-tall, crimson-colored humanoid machine designed to emulate the complex movements of the human body  moved suddenly and hit one of them accidentally in the chest, it could easily break some ribs. The contraption weighs 407 pounds and is powerful enough to bench-press 150 pounds.

title: Buzzing About Jim Harbaugh While Cutting Hair in Ann Arbor
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  It could have been any of the thousands of afternoons at Coach and Four Barber Shop over the past 43 years  ever since Jerry Erickson bought this State Street storefront halfway between downtown and what is now the University of Michigan football complex known as Schembechler Hall.

title: Film Club | Rent-a-Foreigner in China
description: In this short documentary, housing developers in China hire ordinary foreigners to pose as celebrities, boosting flagging property sales.

title: Empathy and Angst in a German City Transformed by Refugees
description: ERFURT, Germany  The mood in the school gymnasium was turning. City officials had invited people from the nearby tower blocks, to explain that a group of migrants, mostly Syrians, had been housed in the neighborhood the night before.

title: For Many Chinese, Scant Time for Holidays
description: Read in Chinese |

title: Q. and A.: Tony Saich on What Chinese Want From Their Leaders
description: Read in Chinese |

title: The Towering Lights of 9/11
description: The Tribute in Lights twin beams first pierced the sky over Lower Manhattan, six months after the attack.

title: Tribute in Light Captures Grief and Joy of 9/11 Anniversary
description: What are we to feel?

title: Bioluminescence in Battery Park
description: Dear Diary:

title: Simpler, Less Expensive 401(k) Options Emerge for Small Businesses
description: The way Jon Stein sees it, receiving financial advice for retirement should be a fundamental right.

title: Charlatans, Cranks, and Apparatchiks
description: The Jeb! tax plan confirms, if anyone had doubts, that the takeover of the Republican Party by charlatans and cranks is complete. This is what the supposedly thoughtful, wonkish candidate of the establishment can come up with? And notice that the ludicrous claim that most of the revenue effects of huge tax cuts would be offset by higher growth comes from economists who, like Jeb!, are very much establishment figures  but who evidently find that the partisan requirement that they support voodoo outweighs any fear of damage to their professional reputations.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Erica Jong
description: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from Erica Jong, the writer and feminist icon whose 11th novel, Fear of Dying, is out this week.

title: Health Savings Accounts Growing, Especially Among the Better Paid
description: THE number of people with health savings accounts has ballooned, but higher-income families are much more likely to fund the accounts, a new analysis found.

title: Indian Court Convicts 12 in 2006 Bombings of Mumbai Trains
description: NEW DELHI  After a trial lasting more than seven years, aspecial antiterror court in Mumbai convicted 12 men on Friday in connection with near-simultaneous bombings in 2006 on seven commuter trains in the city, an attack that killed more than 180 people and left 800 wounded, a prosecutor said.

title: Architects Dream Home Roils Rowayton, Conn.
description: Last month marked two years since Bruce Beinfield, a 63-year-old architect, bought the property on which he hoped to build a house he had designed for himself. The 0.64-acre tract, in Rowayton, Conn., a coastal section of Norwalk, consisted of a long strip of land, just 50 feet across at its widest point, that extended away from the shore into the middle of a serene tidal estuary called Farm Creek. A modest single-story cottage sat at the tip, a rustic throwback to 1949.

title: Hobo Chic From the Bindle Bros. of Brooklyn
description: The Bindle Brothers, Josiah and Dusty, have a name that sounds like one of those banjo-plucking decidedly old-timey musical groups. With their suspenders, floppy caps and cotton work clothes, you may imagine them playing a foot-stomping rendition of Big Rock Candy Mountain.

title: Pittsburgh Steelers Headsets Malfunction Against New England Patriots
description: The N.F.L. season is only one game old, and already a league eager to move past controversies has its first one. Once again it involves the New England Patriots and strange doings at their stadium.

title: Poland Versus Greece
description: Yannis Ioannides and Christopher Pissarides, in a new Brookings Paper, talk about the ways lack of structural reform hurts Greek productivity and competitiveness. I have no reason to doubt that there are big things that should change, and that Greece would be much better off if it could somehow break the political barriers to making these changes.

title: Adam Selman Spring/Summer 2016
description: Scenes from the show.

title: The Daily Do: Adam Selman
description: At last nights Adam Selman show, the hair maestro Jimmy Paul added to the youthful, 90s vibe of the collection  watercolor florals, oversized Hawaiian shirts, custom Converse sneakers  with two joined ponytails, each fastened with a simple swatch of fabric that matched the models clothes. (It is, after all, that back-to-school time of year.)

title: 1940: Royalty Visits Ruined Homes
description: LONDON  King George VI and Queen Elizabeth took refuge in an air-raid shelter below a police station in a devastated district of South London today [Sept. 11] when Nazi bombers broke through the citys defenses on another expedition of destruction. The King and Queen had been visiting some of the areas where homes of working people had been blasted by heavy-caliber bombs. The sovereigns went where danger was gravest and suffering most intense. They talked with Air-Raid Precaution workers, demolition squads working on the debris of the latest raid and homeless people trying to salvage their belongings. Wherever they went, they were cheered by their people as their car, preceded only by a police guide car, made its way through shattered streets. The way the people felt about it was summed up by one woman who said to the King and Queen, Hitler has to have a bodyguard wherever he goes, but you come down here just like this. God bless you and keep you safe.  New York Herald Tribune, September 12, 1940

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Rio de Janeiro

title: Migrants Receive Aid in Brussels Camp
description: A camp beneath skyscrapers in the Belgian capital is run almost entirely by volunteers. Residents have donated tents, food, toys and even electricity.

title: Readers Turn: Return of Robo Restaurant
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Donald Trump Leads in Iowa in New Quinnipiac Poll
description: Republican presidential candidates spent much of the summer canvassing Iowa to court the states caucus-goers and, so far, Donald J. Trump and Ben Carson seem to have made the best impressions.

title: Migrants Scramble for Food in Hungary
description: Hungarian police officers were filmed throwing packs of sandwiches to migrants at a reception center in Roszke. The authorities told Reuters they had started an emergency inquiry into the matter.

title: Tome Spring/Summer 2016
description: Ryan Lobo and Ramon Martin riffed on the nautical, presenting fish bone earrings and gowns with mesh sleeves.

title: Cloud Gate Dance Theater: A Roving, Bounding Symbol of Taiwan
description: NEW TAIPEI CITY, Taiwan  Most people in Taiwan are probably aware of the islands pre-eminent performance group, Cloud Gate Dance Theater, even if they have no interest in modern dance.

title: Baltimores Mayor, Stephanie Rawlings-Blake, Wont Seek Re-election
description: BALTIMORE  Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake, who has come under withering criticism since riots tore through this city in April, announced Friday that she would not seek re-election next year, saying she wanted to focus on the citys future, and not my own as Baltimore prepared for the racially charged trials of six police officers in the death of a 25-year-old black man, Freddie Gray.

title: White House Holds Moment of Silence
description: The president and first lady held a tribute at the White House on Friday, honoring the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks of 14 years ago.

title: Inside the List
description: The Plague: Is there any way, at this point, to separate Jonathan Franzens work from his polarizing public image? Most readers will recall that Franzens fame problem began in 2001, when he openly squirmed after Oprah Winfrey picked his novel The Corrections for her book club, then escalated through no real fault of his own when media outlets (including The Times) hailed his 2010 follow-up, Freedom, as a masterpiece. Both were best sellers, but they also fostered an enthusiastic backlash among people who objected less to Franzens writing than to Franzen himself, as an emblem of literary ambition and elitism. (Laura Miller put her finger on this in a recent essay for The New Yorkers website: Franzens persona, she wrote, has its own audience, one that seems to derive great pleasure from hating it. Although his fiction is the occasion of his fame, it is now no longer necessary to have read any of it to have an opinion about Franzen.)

title: From 'No, Thanks!' to Separate Bedrooms, Comments on Remarrying the Ex
description: Readers shared personal stories of rekindling romance with their exes and expressed concern as to whether people really change.

title: Alaska: Aided by Governor, Medicaid Coverage Grows
description: Alaska expanded federal Medicaid coverage after the states highest court on Monday refused an appeal by the State Legislature to halt Gov. Bill Walkers expansion order. Mr. Walker, an independent, said that the expansion could save the state about $100 million and bring 20,000 or more residents into health care coverage, and that he did not need legislative approval. The Republican-controlled Legislature, in filing a lawsuit and seeking a temporary restraining order, said Mr. Walker had violated the State Constitutions separation of powers provisions. The expansion will, among other changes, increase federal reimbursement to 100 percent from 50 percent for medically necessary travel for Medicaid-eligible Alaska Natives and American Indians receiving care in Indian Health Service facilities, which is a major medical expense and care concern in rural Alaska. The Alaska Supreme Court upheld a lower court decision, issued last week, not to halt the plan while the Legislatures lawsuit proceeds.

title: When Family Members Run Foundations, Scrutiny Never Ends
description: JAY RUDERMAN went to work in his familys foundation after careers as a lawyer, political lobbyist and captain in the Israel Defense Force. He hadnt imagined that he would become a professional philanthropist, charged with giving away $8 million to $10 million a year. But he found that he liked the role immensely.

title: Megan BarryBecomes First Female Mayor of Nashville in Runoff
description: NASHVILLE  Megan Barry, a liberal member of the consolidated city-county council here, was elected mayorThursday, besting a more conservative opponent in a contest in which bouts of mudslinging threatened to overshadow pressing issues of growth and development in the booming city.

title: A Lull After Apples Event
description: After the Apple product event on Wednesday, tech news slowed down.

title: Arizona Official on Freeway Shootings
description: Tim Case, a spokesman for the Arizona Department of Public Safety, discussed the latest in a long string of shootings that have happened on highways in the Phoenix area since Aug. 29.

title: The Daily Shoe: Brother Vellies
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Lower Blood Pressure Guidelines Could Be Lifesaving, Federal Study Says
description: Declaring they had potentially lifesaving information, federal health officials said on Friday that they were ending a major study more than a year early because it has already conclusively answered a question cardiologists have puzzled over for decades: How low should blood pressure go?

title: London Theater Journal: Nowhere Man
description: LONDON  Theres not a lonelier sight in town at the moment than that of the naked man in a naked room on a stage at the Young Vic Theater. The name of this chillingly solitary soul is Willem. And he has just returned to New York from spending time with his family in Amsterdam, an experience that leaves him more than ever with the sense that he belongs nowhere and to no one.

title: Matt Damon Is Taking Your Questions in Toronto
description: The Martian, directed by Ridley Scott and based on the novel by Andy Weir, features Matt Damon as an astronaut stranded on Mars and struggling for survival. While the actor has tackled many leading roles over the years, few have included this much solo screen time.

title: Donations for Refugees Surging, American Charities Report
description: Leading aid organizations in the United States are reporting a surge in charitable donations for helping refugees in the week since a photograph of a drowned Syrian toddler on a Turkish beach rocketed around social media worldwide.

title: Ai Weiwei, in London for Exhibition, Softens Tone Toward Beijing
description: LONDON  The dissident artist Ai Weiwei, in London to attend an overseas exhibit for the first time in five years after his travel ban in China was recently lifted, abandoned his usual combative style toward the authorities on Friday in favor of a conciliatory tone.

title: Ending Marketing Agreements Between Lenders and Brokerages
description: Marketing agreements between mortgage lenders and real estate brokerages have been commonplace for years. But federal regulators are cracking down on some of these arrangements as violations of anti-kickback laws, and two major lenders have taken steps to end the practice.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Oysters, Antibiotics and Older Runners
description: Take the Quiz

title: The Fashion News to Know Today
description: For a good time, call Herms

title: A Quiet End for the U.S. Opens Beloved Grandstand
description: The Grandstands grand finale could not have been more fitting.

title: Safety Suffers as Stock Options Propel Executive Pay Packages
description: Outsize executive pay packages have frequently been a flash point for stock market investors. Lavish executive compensation at publicly traded companies should be a significant concern for consumers, too.

title: Subway Station to Open This Weekend, Bringing 7 Line to Far West Side
description: In his final weeks as mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg took a ceremonial ride to a new subway station on the Far West Side of Manhattan. For people who live and work in the neighborhood, the wait has been longer.

title: Colin Myler, Top Editor, Is Leaving Daily News
description: Colin Myler, the editor in chief of The New York Daily News, is stepping down after less than four years on the job, according to a memo sent to staff members on Friday.

title: Matthew Leveys Charter School Quest
description: Late last month, on a warm, luminous morning, Matthew Levey, a 48-year-old former McKinsey consultant, stood on Willoughby Street in Downtown Brooklyn and shook hands with his new charges: 65 kindergartners, a sea of neon sneakers, starched dresses and cotton golf shirts. It was the first day  ever  for the International Charter School of New York. And Mr. Levey, who had spent the last 36 months planning, developing and hiring for his new elementary school, was in high spirits. The kindergartners would be joined a few days later by 70 first graders. Ultimately, plans call for the school to run through fifth grade, educating students in topics that Mr. Levey cares about: how Francis Bacon developed the scientific method, why Aristotle matters and what led to the decline of the Roman Empire.

title: Paperback Row
description: SOME LUCK, by Jane Smiley. (Anchor, $15.95.) Smiley returns to the familiar terrain of Iowa in this novel, the first in a trilogy. Its multigenerational story of a Midwestern farming family unfolds against the backdrop of American cultural and economic upheaval, spanning the time from before the Depression through the years after World War II.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE GIRL IN THE SPIDERS WEB, by David Lagercrantz. Translated by George Goulding. (Knopf, $27.95.) This posthumous sequel to Stieg Larssons Millennium series brings the beloved antihero Lisbeth Salander back to life, almost.

title: 1965: Astronauts to Tour Africa
description: WASHINGTON  Gemini-5 astronauts L. Gordon Cooper and Charles Conrad will leave Wednesday [Sept. 15] on a six-nation, 12-day tour through the Near East and Africa, the White House announced yesterday. The trip will mark the first time that any nation of the developing world will have the chance to see in person Americans who have traveled in space. Before the astronauts leave the United States, they will come to Washington on Tuesday for a day of honors which will be highlighted by a meeting with President Johnson. Their tour will take them to Greece, Turkey, Ethiopia, the Malagasy Republic, Kenya and Nigeria. Accompanying them will be their wives; Lt. Col. Coopers teen-age daughters; Dr. Charles Berry, who is chief of medical programs at the Manned Space Flight Center in Houston, and Maj. Hugh Robinson, a Negro who serves as one of the White House military aides.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 12, 1965

title: Turning to Religion in Prison, Brazilian Ends Up on Other Side of the Bars
description: SAP, Brazil  Stories of fervent religious conversions are frequent in Brazilian prisons, where desperation, abuse and visiting teams of evangelical Christians abound.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Fates and Furies
description: This week, Lauren Groff talks about her new novel, Fates and Furies; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Scott Shane discusses Objective Troy; feedback from listeners; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Fates and Furies
description: This week, Lauren Groff and Scott Shane.

title: Stuff We Liked: Science Quizzes and Long Subway Rides
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: SoHo Townhouse at $16.3 Million
description: An impeccably refurbished Federal-style SoHo townhouse at 27 Vandam Street, built in 1823 as part of a quaint row of four brick dwellings and later home to the choreographer Paul Taylor, is poised to enter the market at $16.3 million. The 20-foot-wide-by-100-foot-deep property is on a leafy block between Avenue of the Americas and Varick Street in the Charlton-King-Vandam Historic District.

title: Review: PBSs Walt Disney Explores a Complex Legacy
description: Before his name became synonymous with a staid, whitewashed version of Americana, Walt Disney was considered a boundary pusher, expanding the possibilities and ambitions of his art form. Making your way through the two-part treatment of him on PBSs American Experience on Monday and Tuesday nights, you may find yourself wishing that some boundary pushing had gone into the program.

title: Exclusive | 27 Vandam Street
description: A luxuriously appointed 1823 Federal-style townhouse is about to enter the market at $16.3 million.

title: Does Donald Trump Really Need Ideas?
description: Jeb Bush told CNNs Jake Tapper on Thursday that Donald Trump cant insult his way to the presidency or even the Republican Partys 2016 nomination. I certainly hope he is right.

title: Black Man in a White Coat, by Damon Tweedy
description: On average, black women can expect to live three years less than white women; the difference between black and white men is nearly five years. These and other racial disparities led Damon Tweedy to announce in his memoir, Black Man in a White Coat, what many of us already knew: Being black can be bad for your health. This is an inescapable fact, especially when you consider the following people and circumstances surrounding their deaths: Kathryn Johnston, Tarika Wilson, Trayvon Martin, Eric Garner, Michael Brown, Tamir Rice, Walter Scott and Freddie Gray. It seems strange that none of them are mentioned in this book.

title: CG by Chris Gelinas: Spring 2016 RTW
description: The labels spring 2016 show.

title: The Marvels, by Brian Selznick
description: Whats fiction made of? Do true stories matter more than invented ones? These are heady questions for any book to tackle, especially one aimed at young readers. But Brian Selznicks The Marvels takes them on and, like the best childrens literature, doesnt shy away from complex answers. The book revels in complication, echoes and mirrorings, and peeling back its layers makes for a rich and surprising reading experience.

title: Bookshelf: Letting Go
description: New picture books include Boats for Papa and Bug in a Vacuum.

title: First Draft Focus:  Remembering  9/11 at the White House
Greenwich Village Townhouse Sold for $22.3 Million
description: A vintage four-story Greenwich Village townhouse with a separate studio in the rear has quietly sold for $22,300,000  the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records  amid speculation that the new owner might be from the upper echelons of Facebooks past or current corporate offices, even the chief executive and co-founder, Mark Zuckerberg.

title: Beyond the Pond, The Tea Party in the Woods and The Little Gardener
description: On my walk to the studio each morning, I pass a busy playground. Recently I overheard one mother telling another: Thank God! I found him! He was hiding. She held the sheepish child firmly by the wrist. I have felt the intense panic of temporarily losing a child, but nonetheless I shot the kid a sympathetic glance. Its hard to be an explorer these days. Summer camps and preschools tout exploration as part of their agenda, as long as you wear a brightly colored uniform T-shirt, never stray out of sight and explore only things that have already been thoroughly explored.

title: George, by Alex Gino
description: Prepare yourself, Alex Gino: Youll be receiving lots of feedback when readers discover your timely, touching novel.

title: The Boys Who Challenged Hitler and Somewhere There Is Still a Sun
description: Heroism is not in fashion right now. We prefer our heroes smudged and compromised; its more comforting, less demanding. Yet two new nonfiction portraits of young people during World War II remind us that bravery, defiance and generosity of spirit are possible even in the direst circumstances.

title: Justice Dept. Shift on White-Collar Crime Is Long Overdue
description: It took only 16 years, but the Justice Departments horribly misguided Holder Doctrine has finally been relegated to the dustbin of history where it belongs.

title: At Toronto Restaurant, Unfussy, but Fish Aplenty
description: This restaurant does one thing exceedingly well: seafood, both finned and shellfish. That may sound like damning with faint praise, but its what John Bil envisioned when he opened his fish counter and sit-down restaurant in the scruffy Toronto neighborhood called the Junction in January.

title: A Borscht for Vegetarians Thats Light and Comforting
description: Nose around for borscht recipes, and youll find that most classic hot borschts call for beef stock or a beef or veal shank to simmer along with the vegetables.

title: Appleblossom the Possum and Firefly Hollow
description: Appleblossom is the smallest of Mama Possums babies. She may be little, but by the time shes just a few months old she must be prepared to face, on her own, the great big world and the many dangers it holds for possums. Appleblossom is timid, but shes also curious  and skeptical of Mamas warnings, which is how she becomes interested in a small monster (a human girl) and falls down a chimney into the monsters house. This is just the beginning of the wild and wholly engaging adventure on which Appleblossom unwittingly sends two of her brothers. It takes them from the safety of their neighborhood all the way to big-city night life. More important, it shines a spotlight on Mamas teachings about the solitariness of possums.

title: Friday Night Music: Bob Fosse on Fiscal Policy
description: I know, not night yet in New York, but Im still traveling  and still making the case for more spending, which Bob Fosse got:

title: In California, Olive Oil Tourism Is on the Rise
description: Olive oil tourism in California is growing. The state produces 99 percent of the extra-virgin olive oil in the United States and 4 percent globally, according to the California Olive Oil Council, a trade association. Many artisan labels are within a few hours drive of San Francisco and have recently opened their estates to the public.

title: Erica Jongs Fear of Dying
description: In Erica Jongs Fear of Flying, published 42 years ago, Isadora Wing invented the notion of zipless sex, that is to say, no-strings sex with a near stranger. Thus Jong presented millions of women readers with the possibility of  the great joys of  agency in place of soporific and joyless passivity in life and, of course, sex. Isadora nudges her way onto the sidelines of Jongs latest novel, not coincidentally titled Fear of Dying. On display is the authors characteristic mix of salty language and broad humor, warmth and truth-telling.

title: Joe Menos Marvel and a Wonder
description: Do you ever have a thought you keep to yourself? Jim asks his grandson, Quentin, as the boy explains that he can talk to animals and some trees, and is able to hear things most other mortals cannot.

title: Can I Go Now? by Brian Kellow
description: Even the brightest star is occasionally eclipsed by a moon. Sue Mengers was a moon. Photographs from the 1970s show her looming, lipsticked and luminously coifed, at the elbows of the A-list movie actors she represented (considering television and theater somewhat lesser forms, for losers): Faye Dunaway or Ryan ONeal or her especial favorite, Barbra Streisand. For a time beaming brighter even than Swifty Lazar, with his bald head, black-rimmed glasses and parties at Spago, Mengers inspired characters in The Last of Sheila, the shadowy cult movie with a screenplay by Anthony Perkins and Stephen Sondheim; and very likely also in the novels Myra Breckinridge, by her pal Gore Vidal, and The Love Machine, by Jacqueline Susann.

title: The Long Emancipation, by Ira Berlin
description: Ira Berlin ranks as one of the greatest living historians of slavery in the United States, in no small part because of his commitment to readers beyond academia. For almost four decades, he has been the moving force behind the Freedmen and Southern Society Project, based at the University of Maryland. He and his colleagues at the project have combed through millions of documents generated by emancipation and Reconstruction. They have found amazing characters, like the newly commissioned, recently liberated black soldiers who sent letters to their former masters, demanding that these white Southerners hand over still-enslaved family members.

title: Debut Novels
description: THE MOUNTAIN CAN WAITBy Sarah Leipciger311 pp. Little, Brown, $26.

title: No Slouch
description: At 80, Joan Didion has never been cooler, which in her case is really saying something. Earlier this year, she was featured in an ad for the luxury fashion brand Cline. The Los Angeles bookstore Book Soup recently floated the idea of putting her image on the $10 bill.

title: The Making of Home, by Judith Flanders
description: Theres no place like home, as Dorothy told Toto somewhere between Oz and Kansas. Home is where the heart is, and thats where the trouble starts. Home is what we think we know best already, wherever and however we live. Its the most intimate of subjects, involving privacy, comfort, childhood memories, somewhere clean and protected from the street and modern times, a womans own place. (Or so men insisted, thoughtfully providing labor-saving devices that made housework even more difficult for middle-class women who took on work once done by servants or other women in other houses.)

title: A Nation of Nations, by Tom Gjelten
description: Over the past half-century, immigration to the United States has radically transformed. In his prologue to A Nation of Nations, the NPR correspondent Tom Gjelten describes how his 19th-century Norwegian ancestors arrived in America and homesteaded their way across the upper Midwest, striking out into the wilderness. For the first 200 years of the countrys history, most of the foreigners who settled here voluntarily were European and white. In 1965, however, legislators rewrote our restrictive immigration laws, and over the past 50 years, the foreign-born population has become far more diverse, with new immigrants hailing from South America, Asia and Africa.

title: The Last Love Song, a Biography of Joan Didion
description: In a spiky little essay on the painter Georgia OKeeffe, Joan Didion writes coded instructions for would-be biographers. Where I was born and where and how I have lived is unimportant, she quotes OKeeffe. It is what I have done with where I have been that should be of interest. In other words, study the particulars of the paintings, not the particulars of the life. In the next sentence, however, Didion tells the story of her 7-year-old daughter, who, on seeing one of OKeeffes sublime Sky Above Clouds paintings in the Art Institute of Chicago, runs toward it and whispers: Who drew it? ... I need to talk to her. The longing to corroborate ones own feelings with the facts of an artists life  the assumption that the glory she saw in the work reflected a glory in its maker  is a primal one, Didion suggests. But there is a paradox inherent in the encounter with art: Even as it may touch us acutely, it is essentially mysterious. It carries only a trace of its maker, and this is style. Style is character, Didion declares, throwing down the gauntlet: Find me if you can.

title: The Story of My Teeth, by Valeria Luiselli
description: On its not-so-placid surface, Valeria Luisellis second novel is the tale of a guy named Gustavo (Highway) Snchez Snchez, who auctions off his old teeth, claiming they are from the mouths of Plato, Montaigne, Virginia Woolf and Borges, among others. Then he takes his profits and buys a set of teeth that supposedly belonged to Marilyn Monroe, implanting them in his own mouth. After that, things go well for a while until Highways son, Siddhartha, knocks him out and steals Monroes teeth, leaving his dad chopperless. Eventually Highway runs into a man named Voragine (an abyss?) who helps him, and who later appears to be the person telling this story. Along the way, the names of Proust, Unamuno, Foucault, Walser, Cortzar and Raymond Roussel burst out of random paragraphs like startled grouse.

title: The President and the Apprentice: Eisenhower and Nixon, 1952-1961
description: Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., someone who unquestionably understood charisma, considered Vice President Richard Nixon one of the most magnetic personalities he had ever encountered. When you are close to Nixon, King observed in 1958, he almost disarms you with his apparent sincerity. But King also worried that there might be a hidden duality to Nixon, or worse, a facade. If the vice president was actually insincere, King warned, he could be the most dangerous man in America.

title: On 9/11 Anniversary, a Small and Somber Ritual in Lower Manhattan
description: At 8:48 a.m., 14 years and two minutes after a plane crashed into the north tower of the World Trade Center, the recitation of the names began.

title: Marc Jacobs Hosted a Heck of a Party Last Night
description: Despite the host Marc Jacobss encouragements, not one guest rode astride a white horse to the book party for Gloss: The Work of Chris von Wangenheim last night at the resurrected Tunnel nightclub in Chelsea. A galloping equine sculpture instead overlooked the bar, where lemon- and orange-flavored Marctails were served to a thirsty throng of black-and-sequined clotheshorses.

title: What I Learned in the Locker Room
description: BOSTON  TOWARD the end of my sophomore year in college, I secured a summer internship with the sports department of my hometown newspaper, which was located just south of San Francisco.

title: For New Yorks Pools, Its Not the Heat, Its the Politics
description: On the day after Labor Day, as so many people uploaded moody pictures of empty meadows and forlorn marine birds, indulging the ritual mourning of summers end that social media has amplified, the temperature in Central Park reached 97 degrees. This surpassed a record for the day (set in 1919 when it was 4 degrees cooler), making Sept. 8, 2015, the hottest September day in New York City in 32 years. Among the masses already returned from Nantucket or Vermont or Beach 108th Street, complaint and distress proceeded accordingly.

title: Winning Her Back, Using a Little Political Clout
description: A former United States senator helps re-form a union after a regrettable split.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Sothebys S.E.C. Records Confirm Taubman Sale Guarantee
description: Sothebys has confirmed in records with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has guaranteed roughly the full $500 million it expects to take in from its sale of the art collection of A. Alfred Taubman, its former chairman who died in April.

title: A New York Hotel Inspires a Scarf Design for Rodarte
description: Collaborations between prolific fashion designers and luxury hotels arent a novel concept, but the latest such partnership, debuting in time for New York Fashion Week, has a more personal touch.

title: House Rejects Iran Nuclear Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Following the playbook of their crusade against the Affordable Care Act, congressional Republicans on Friday showed no sign of letting up in their effort to pressure the White House over the Iran nuclear accord, even after the Senate effectively settled the matter and blocked a Republican resolution aimed at stopping the deal.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are co-ops in Chelsea and Clinton, and a condo in the Columbia Street Waterfront District, Brooklyn.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Wes Gordon: Spring 2016 RTW
description: Mr. Gordons spring 2016 collection.

title: Remembering the 9/11 Attacks, One More Time
description: Fourteen years later, the memory remains, but the ceremony is muted.

title: Argentine Ants Carry Virus Deadly to Honeybees
description: The Argentine ant, already known as one of the worlds most widespread and damaging pests, may be infecting honeybees with a deadly virus, a new study finds.

title: Biden Talks to Colbert About His Son
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said he was overwhelmed at times by his sons death and unsure he could fully commit to being president, in an interview on The Late Show With Stephen Colbert.

title: Sussman Brothers Expand in Bergn
description: The chefs and brothers Max and Eli Sussman this week opened Ed & Bevs Detroit-Style Coney Island, a stand in Bergn, the beer hall in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, where they already run a shawarma stand called Samesa. In Detroit, where the two men grew up, a coney island is a Michigan spin on a Greek diner; coney islands are ubiquitous in and around that city.

title: Reactions to Mumbai Bombing Convictions
description: Lawyers and a victim reacted after a court in India convicted 12 of the 13 men accused of bombing commuter trains in Mumbai in 2006.

title: House Tour | James Ivory
description: The Merchant Ivory directors 19th-century mansion in New Yorks Hudson Valley is filled with memories and ephemera from over 50 years of filmmaking with his late partner Ismail Merchant.

title: James Ivorys White Castle
description: After four decades spent patiently restoring his early 19th-century mansion, the director James Ivory finally has a home befitting his extraordinary life.

title: At Jason Wu, Dont Let the Red Lips Fool You
description: I think beautys becoming less about piling on, and more about whats underneath, said the makeup artist Yadim about his minimalist-inspired beauty look for Jason Wus spring/summer 2016 collection. Dont let the red lips fool you. Beyond that one standout feature, faces were clean  literally. We didnt use any foundation, just a tiny bit of concealer where they needed it, he went on. Same goes for blush (none) and mascara (transparent), which played to Wus particular kind of polished girl this season. Moments before curtain call, Yadim applied a ruby red powder pigment over a layer of Maybellines Vivid Matte Liquid in Rebel Red, for a deep, velvety appearance and texture  and a timeless, low-maintenance look for any season.

title: As the Nation Watches, Joe Biden Struggles With Whether to Run for President
description: WASHINGTON  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. looks like a man running for president, but he does not sound like it.

title: The Stylish Streets of New York Fashion Week
description: As models and guests rushed between fashion shows, photographer Craig Arend captured some looks of the day.

title: Its My Nervous System Thats Lazy
description: The human nervous system ensures that the body reserves its energy and expends as few calories as possible with every movement. Now, a new study reports that the nervous system performs this optimization in real time.

title: A Week of Insults as Candidates Turn Nasty and Personal
description: When Republican presidential candidates gather in California for their second debate next week, it could be a little awkward. The ability to deliver a well-crafted political insult is a necessary skill when it comes to running for office, but this week the zingers have rapidly zagged from the political to the personal to the nasty.

title: After Death of Family of Five in Minnesota, a Search for Answers
description: Five members of a family who were found dead in their home in a Minneapolis suburb died of gunshot wounds in an apparent murder-suicide, the police said Friday.

title: As Hungarian Camerawoman Apologizes, Video of Food Tossed at Penned Migrants Stirs Fresh Outrage
description: Hungarian officials opened a police investigation on Friday into conditions at a migrant camp near the countrys border with Serbia, as video circulated on social networks showing officers throwing food to detainees held in pens.

title: Scores Killed in Mecca as Crane Crashes Into Grand Mosque
description: IZMIR, Turkey  A large construction crane toppled over and crashed into the Grand Mosque in the holy city of Mecca on Friday, killing at least 107 people and raising fears about the safety of the site before the yearly hajj pilgrimage that is expected to bring in millions of visitors to Saudi Arabia this month.

title: Jeremy Corbyn, Unlikely Front-Runner for Labour Leader, Poised to Win Party Vote
description: LONDON  He wants to scrap Britains nuclear missiles, nationalize key industries and print money to bolster the economy. He is a critic of NATO and seems less than enthusiastic about the European Union.

title: James Ivorys Home Befits His Extraordinary Life
description: The directors early 19th-century mansion on the Hudson is where, for 40 years, he and his longtime friends and collaborators gathered to feast, drink, argue and make movie magic. At 87, hes still creating beauty.

title: Review: Johnny Cash: An American Rebel, Even if You Already Know the Story
description: Johnny Cash: An American Rebel, a documentary debuting on CMT on Saturday, the 12th anniversary of Cashs death, includes a fair amount of image-burnishing and hagiography. This is expected, given that it was made in association with the John R. Cash Revocable Trust and counts Cashs son, John Carter Cash, among its executive producers.

title: Motion Picture Academy Settles Dispute Over Planned Museum
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and its planned movie museum cleared a hurdle as the academy reached a settlement with a neighborhood group that had been expected to challenge the project in court.

title: Donald Trump Says He Has Bought NBCs Miss Universe Stake
description: Donald J. Trump said on Friday that he had bought  NBCs stake in the Miss Universe Organization, the group that produces the beauty pageant, which the network refused to broadcast this summer.

title: Study Predicts Antarctica Ice Melt if All Fossil Fuels Are Burned
description: Burning all the worlds deposits of coal, oil and natural gas would raise the temperature enough to melt the entire ice sheet covering Antarctica, driving the level of the sea up by more than 160 feet, scientists reported Friday.

title: Justice Department Releases Letters to Congress
description: In response to a Freedom of Information Act request by the New York Times, the Department of Justice has released three batches of letters it sent to lawmakers on congressional oversight committees between 2011 and 2013. The letters cover a wide variety of topics, including enforcement of civil rights laws, leak investigations, antitrust matters, spending on conferences, and criminal prosecutions.

title: Hillary Clintons Long Road to Sorry Over Email Use
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton did not want to apologize.

title: Cuba to Release 3,522 Prisoners Before Pope Francis Visit
description: MEXICO CITY  The Cuban government announced Friday that it would release 3,522 prisoners from its jails before the popes visit this month, a gesture the nation also took before the last papal visit, in 2011.

title: On Set | Michael Fassbender
description: Bruce Weber photographs the actor Michael Fassbender in Montauk, N.Y. for T magazines fall mens issue cover.

title: Kathleen Chalfant to Portray Rose Kennedy in New Play
description: Kathleen Chalfant will play Rose Kennedy in Rose, a one-woman show about the political matriarch written by the longtime Kennedy watcher Laurence Leamer that will have its world premiere at the Clurman Theater at Theater Row in Manhattan this fall.

title: How Jeffrey Immelt Is Staking His Legacy on Alstom
description: It has taken 14 years, but Jeffrey R. Immelt has finally been emancipated  by the French.

title: Death, Sex and Money: This Senator Saved My Love Life
description: Anna Sale explains how she wound up in the kitchen of Alan and Ann Simpson, getting advice on maturity, commitment, and of course, sex.

title: Jason Wu: Spring 2016 RTW
description: Looks from Mr. Wus spring 2016 show.

title: Yale Grapples With Ties to Slavery in Debate Over a Colleges Name
description: NEW HAVEN  When Maya Jenkins was accepted to Yale, her family erupted in joy. Still, her mother confessed a concern: that her daughter might be assigned to Calhoun College, one of the 12 residential colleges at the heart of the universitys undergraduate life. It is named for John C. Calhoun, a Yale valedictorian-turned-politician from South Carolina and one of the 19th centurys foremost white supremacists, who promoted slavery as a positive good.

title: The Case of the Missing Jewels
description: Daniel Ternas photographs of empty diamond district storefronts.

title: Michael Fassbender, Nobodys Fool
description: I HAD ALREADY been turned down by two drama schools, Michael Fassbender was explaining over breakfast in one of those New York hotel restaurants where beautiful people add wheatgrass to their smoothies. That rejection at 19 led him to London to try his luck auditioning for the Drama Centre there. He had prepared an Iago monologue, had gone over it hundreds of times, but he was still nervous. He had been replaying the words of a director from one of the other drama schools, who had told him that he could recognize an actor from the way he enters a room. I still hate that, said Fassbender. Before the audition, he was trying to get the directors words out of his mind. I went to the urinal, and as I was pissing, I saw that someone had written Hi, Cookie! on the wall. Those words were staring at me, as I stood there. I had just finished playing the Cook in a production of Mother Courage, and I had done it with a Scottish accent. Cook; cookie. Ill do the Iago monologue in a Scottish accent, I decided, even though that wasnt how I had prepared it. After the audition, Fassbender was asked why hed chosen that accent, to which he answered something about it being a way to bring mischief into the piece, which seemed true enough. Its funny. I havent thought about that for years and years. Im not saying what I saw was a sign or anything. But maybe I did sort of take it that way, and that helped me.

title: Anna Sale and Arthur Middleton: A Political Favor Wins Her Back
description: The season was to be the Summer of Anna. So proclaimed Anna Sale, a New York City-based radio reporter, in 2011. One of the rules of the Summer of Anna was if something seemed intriguing, I would just say, Yes,  Ms. Sale said.

title: When the Jewels Are Unseen in the Diamond District, but Beauty Remains
description: A gold necklace can be a pretty thing. But a missing gold necklace is something more interesting. It is a story.

title: Donald Trumps Immigration Plan Is Laughable. But . . .
description: Maybe you thought Donald Trump was speaking rhetorically, or joking, when he promised, as president, to expel all 11 million unauthorized immigrants from the United States. He has just put a time frame on his proposal: The deportations would take 18 months to two years, he said in a Thursday conference call with supporters in Alabama.

title: A Go-Ahead on the Iran Nuclear Deal: Cheers and Fears
description: To the Editor:Re Democrats Hand Victory to Obama on Pact With Iran (front page, Sept. 11):

title: NCR Is Said to Resume Attempt to Sell Itself
description: The NCR Corporations efforts to sell itself may not be done after all.

title: New Study: Burn it All (Fossil Fuel), Lose it All (Antarctic Ice and Todays Coasts)
description: A new analysis of Antarcticas vast ice sheet in a world heated by unabated greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuel burning comes to a stark, if unsurprising, conclusion: Burn it all, lose it all.

title: Step Aside, Turkey. Finding the Next Great Vegetarian Main Course for Thanksgiving
description: Every fall, Well celebrates Thanksgiving by focusing on the best part of the meal  the vegetarian side dishes.

title: Roberta Vinci Ends Serena Williamss Grand Slam Bid at U.S. Open
description: The Grand Slam seemed there for the taking. The Grand Slam will have to wait.

title: T City Guides: New York
description: Five leaders in creative fields share their favorite places to eat, drink, shop and play.

title: The Other Side of the Counter
description: Tumbleweed Tuesday is what Hamptons locals call the day after Labor Day. Its always refreshing. The summer people have disappeared. Parking spaces reappear. Stress levels dip.

title: Pope Wants Poor Helped in Climate Debate
description: Pope Francis, meeting with the foundation for Sustainable Development at the Vatican, called for inclusion of the worlds poor in the climate discussion.

title: Pynchon Intrigue Abounds Over Cow Country
