description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Liesl Schillinger discuss the pleasures of reading forbidden books.

title: Demise of Scott Walkers 2016 Bid Shows Limits of Super PACs
description: In the age of super PACs, a presidential campaign can die of thirst on the shores of the Great Lakes.

title: TechFix | iPhone 6s Buyers Guide
description: In many respects the iPhone 6s bears a strong resemblance to its predecessor. But a few new features warrant a look if its time to upgrade.

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help
description: Here are the latest examples from the file of sound-alike mix-ups. Weve seen them all before  make sure theyre on your better-check-twice list.

title: Testing iPhone 6ss 3D Touch and Live Photos Features
description: NOW that smartphones can do more than a million different things with apps, you have to wonder whether it matters when Apple adds two main new features to its latest iPhones.

title: IPhone 6ss Hands-Free Siri Is an Omen of the Future
description: The headline feature in Apples latest smartphones, the iPhone 6s and 6s Plus, is something called 3D Touch, which lets you activate shortcuts on the phone by pressing a bit harder on the screen. For now, though, I found a less novel, but far handier feature in the new iPhone  one that has long been the butt of jokes but is now becoming a necessary part of modern computing.

title: The N.F.L. Extra Point Has Changed, but Deuces Still Arent Wild
description: The N.F.L.s new try rule  try is the correct term, not point-after attempt, which applies only to kicks  is having the desired effect of making after-touchdown placement attempts no longer automatic. In the 2014 season, there were eight missed extra-point kicks. Already this season, with extra-point attempts snapped from the 15-yard line instead of the 2, there have been nine.

title: A Butchers Extraordinary Past
description: Dear Diary:

title: Fashion East: The Force Behind the Industrys Rising Stars
description: LONDON  With so many big name brands vying for their moment in the spotlight during London Fashion Week, it is easy to forget that there are even more designers waiting in the wings, desperate for a chance to shine.

title: Lloyd Blankfein, Goldman Sachs C.E.O., Has Lymphoma
description: It seemed to be no big deal when Gary D. Cohn, the president of Goldman Sachs, spoke at a panel event Monday night.

title: A $1,000 Day in London for $100
description: Are you Mr. Kugel? asked the uniformed doorman in a town shell top hat as I approached the St. James's Hotel and Club, a scones throw from Buckingham Palace. I was there to meet Madeleine Calon, head concierge and the only female board member of the Society of the Golden Keys of Great Britain and the Commonwealth, a prestigious concierge organization.

title: Anya Hindmarch: Spring 2016 RTW
description: Ms. Hindmarchs latest collection.

title: Rate Rage in 1932
description: Both Rob Johnson and Peter Temin direct me to a paper by Gerald Epstein and Thomas Ferguson on the Feds strange, destructive turn away from expansionary policy in 1932. They look carefully at the archival evidence, and find that a key factor was the complaints of commercial banks that low interest rates on government securities were squeezing their profits. That is, the turn to tight money in the face of deflation and a collapsing real economy was driven by the same narrow banker interests I have suggested explain current demands for higher rates despite low inflation.

title: Daily Report: A New iPhone for the Slow Upgrade Crowd
description: Despite many reports to the contrary, not everyone rushes out to get a new iPhone every time Apple has an upgrade.

title: The Worlds Most Expensive Pop-Up Shop
description: Four of Europes top antiquities dealers bring their treasures to America, hoping to seduce a generation of collectors raised on contemporary art.

title: U.S. Trying to Protect Sage Grouse Without Listing It as an Endangered Species
description: HOUSTON  The Obama administration announced on Tuesday that the greater sage grouse, a flamboyant bird that roams across 11 Western states, does not warrant a listing as an endangered species, an action that could have damaged oil and natural gas interests and the economies of many local communities.

title: Religions Are What People Make Them
description: The current crop of Republican presidential candidates is accomplishing something I would have considered impossible: making George W. Bush look like a statesman. Say what you like about his actions after 9/11  and I did not like, at all  at least he made a point of not feeding anti-Muslim hysteria. But that was then.

title: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins and Dominique Morisseau Win Steinberg Playwright Awards
description: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins and Dominique Morisseau will be named the recipients of this years Steinberg Playwright Awards, which honor promising dramatists with $50,000 grants.

title: Hillary Clinton to Present Health Care Plan
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton will present on Tuesday a multipart plan to decrease the cost of prescription medication, as part of a series of campaign events this week devoted to health care policy and how she plans to build on the progress made under the Affordable Care Act.

title: Muse dOrsay Reopens After Strike
description: PARIS  The Muse dOrsay reopened here on Thursday after a two-day strike shut the museum down, delaying the opening ofahighly anticipated show on the artistic representation of prostitution.

title: At Giles, Sweaty Strands Made Chic
description: Queen Elizabeth I was the regal template for the irregular braids backstage at the Giles spring/summer 2016 runway: The Toni&Guy team recreated the slightly shiny (ahem, sweaty) hair revealed once all those grand Tudor ladies took off their towering wigs. Even though theyre braids, we didnt want it to get too pretty, said the hairstylist Indira Schauwecker, emphasizing the thinned-out quality of this anti-volume look. Its a lived-in and wet look with a masculine edge. The idea is that these braids have been destroyed by the wigs.

title: 1940: Nazis Torpedo Refugee Liner
description: LONDON  In one of the most tragic sea disasters of the war, 293 persons, including eighty-three children evacuated from England to escape Nazi bombs, lost their lives when a liner bound for Canada was torpedoed by a German submarine last Tuesday night 600 miles at sea, it was officially announced tonight [Sept. 22]. Only 113 persons out of a total complement of 406 aboard the vessel  which sailed Friday, the 13th  were rescued by British warships and landed last Friday at a northern British port.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 23, 1940

title: Volkswagen: We Have Totally Screwed Up
description: Michael Horn, the president and chief executive of Volkswagen Group of America, spoke in September after the company admitted to cheating emissions tests in the United States.

title: Colts Off to 0-2 Start Thanks to Andrew Lucks Interceptions
description: Going into the season, most people had Andrew Luck of the Indianapolis Colts at the top of the pile among quarterbacks.

title: Giles Deacon Shares the Finer Details of His Showstopping Collection
description: The designer captions images from his dramatic and romantic spring/summer 2016 show.

title: From Alaska to Iceland, Breaking Barriers to Arctic Travel
description: Growing up in New Hampshire, Sarah Aciego, 38, wanted to escape the cold, so she began her career as a scientist studying volcanoes. But when a research project sent her to Antarctica, she fell in love with a whole different cold, a whole different kind of ice and switched tracks completely.

title: Blake Speaks After de Blasio Meeting
description: The retired tennis star James Blake spoke on Monday after meeting with Mayor Bill de Blasio and Police Commissioner William J. Bratton, saying it was a very productive meeting.

title: Health Insurers Seeking Mergers Play Down Antitrust Concerns
description: WASHINGTON  The chief executives of two of the nations largest health insurance companies told skeptical senators on Tuesday that consumers would benefit if the federal government approved their plans to acquire two other big insurers.

title: Catholics in White House Often Help Obama Build Support for Thorny Policy
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obamas decision to require religious organizations to provide insurance with free birth control encountered the fierce resistance of the nations Roman Catholic bishops, the presidents top aides  including Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services  set out to find a compromise.

title: Donald Trumps Old Queens NeighborhoodContrasts With the Diverse Area Around It
description: On a recent afternoon, Sabrina Dabakarov stood under the colonnaded portico of her familys brick home on Midland Parkway in Queens and gestured at a neighborhood lined with oak trees and stately houses that for a century has played home to doctors, politicians and political bosses on 500 acres of hilly, meandering streets.

title: Victory for the Chief and the Board at Bank of America Over a Dual Role
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  When the votes were in and his victory assured, Brian T. Moynihan of Bank of America hustled quickly off the stage, his face showing no hint of celebration.

title: Report Stresses Importance of Agreement to Avoid Cyber Conflict
description: As China president Xi Jinping begins a trip to the United States that could include the first arms control accord for cyberspace between the United States and China, a new RAND report that rates the cyber warfare capabilities of the worlds two largest economies shows how important such an agreement could be.

title: 1890: The War on Slavery
description: PARIS  The meeting of the anti-slavery congress in this city, convoked by Cardinal Lavigerie, will give a new impulse to the crusade against the African slave trade. The Powers that have divided Africa between them are now responsible. Now that the countries from which the slaves are brought are English, French, German, Belgian, Italian and Portuguese territories the European Governments are compelled to exercise a more active and extensive hostility to the trade. Fully 80,000 slaves are annually exported from Africa and as it is estimated that four-fifths of those brought down to the coast perish on the way, at least 400,000 negroes are annually torn from their homes.  The New York Herald, European Edition, September 23, 1890

title: Funding Dispute Over F.B.I. Headquarters Delays Next Step
description: WASHINGTON  The fate of the proposed new F.B.I. headquarters, to be built near the nations capital in return for its current building on Pennsylvania Avenue, is embroiled in a behind-the-scenes funding dispute involving the bureau, the General Services Administration and the federal Office of Management and Budget.

title: 2 Are Killed in West Bank as Jewish and Muslim Holidays Approach
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Israeli soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian woman early Tuesday at a checkpoint in Hebron in the West Bank. The Israeli military said the woman had pulled out a knife, but a European advocate for Palestinian rights, who said he had witnessed the episode, said the woman appeared to be only trying to open her purse for inspection.

title: Chinese Official on Accused U.S. Spy
description: Hong Lei, a spokesman for the Chinese foreign ministry, said on Tuesday that Sandy Phan-Gillis, an American held in China on suspicion of espionage, is cooperating with an investigation.

title: Health Insurance Deductibles Outpacing Wage Increases, Study Finds
description: It may not seem like much  just an extra hundred dollars or so a year.

title: Kosovo Prime Minister Pelted by Eggs
description: While making a speech to parliament in favor of a deal with Serbia, Prime Minister Isa Mustafa was met with a rain of eggs thrown by opposition members.

title: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch This Week
description: Two games a week is going to be the norm for all the big clubs now, with domestic cups rearing their heads to join league and European matches on the cluttered calendar. Heres what you should watch this week:

title: First Draft Focus: On the Edge of Their Seats for the Pope
Tate Modern Announces Opening Date for New Extension
description: LONDON  It was the best year ever. So declared Tate officials at a news conference on Tuesday, held to release the organizations annual report for 2014-15, and to announce the opening date of the long-awaited major extension to the Tate Modern. It will be June 17, 2016.

title: Pajama-Party Glam at Ashley Williams
description: For spring/summer 2016, the designer dreamed up graphic tanks, silk separates and slouchy caps.

title: Which States Restrict Abortion After a Certain Point in Pregnancy
description: Forty-three states have enacted laws banning abortion at different stages of pregnancy.

title: Senate Republicans Take Steps to Avert a Government Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republican leaders on Tuesday took the first steps to avert a government shutdown by scheduling a vote on a temporary spending measure that would keep agencies functioning through Dec. 11.

title: Pope Francis Arrival in the U.S. Is a Low-Key Prelude to Pageantry
description: WASHINGTON  Pope Francis landed to a red-carpet welcome on Tuesday as he opened his first visit to the United States determined to press the worlds last superpower to do more to care for the planet and its most marginalized inhabitants.

title: How to See Pope Francis During His U.S. Visit
description: Tens of thousands will flock to see Pope Francis this week during his three-city tour of the United States. If youre not one of the comparatively few who have received tickets to the Masses, speeches or parades, have faith. There are still a few places where you can catch a glimpse of the pontiff  or get into the weeks spirit  in Washington, D.C., New York City and Philadelphia.

title: WTA Chief Stacey Allaster Decides to Leave Hectic Job Behind
description: Stacey Allasters tennis counterpart Brad Drewett died in 2013 of Lou Gehrigs disease at age 54. Her brother-in-law Greg Milkovich died of brain cancer in March at age 49.

title: Jeb Bush Plans to Alter Federal Regulations to Invigorate Economy
description: Jeb Bush outlined a series of proposed changes to federal regulations on Tuesday, arguing that the Obama administration has stifled economic growth and pledging to freeze the publication of new rules until they are approved by an agency head that Mr. Bush nominates.

title: De Blasio Says James Blake Has Handled Mistaken Arrest With Selflessness
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who the retired tennis star James Blake said had been cooperative and sympathetic to his calls for police reform during their meeting on Monday, returned the compliment on Tuesday, praising Mr. Blake for looking to spur change in the aftermath of his mistaken arrest.

title: Exit Walker
description: About four hours passed yesterday between my hitting publish on a post suggesting that Scott Walkers donors and supporters shouldnt bail on himjust yetand Walker surprising many of those same donors and supporters, as well as the political press, by deciding to drop out of the presidential race entirely. I was obviously among the surprised, and the sheer speed of Walkers exit makes me think that all the savvy post-mortems might end up missing a key truth: Running for president is hard, unpleasant work, Walker had fought three intense campaigns in just four years, and its possible that he simply burned out on running for office sometime in the last two months.

title: The Understated Elegance of the Airline Scarf
description: In an airport, there is not much to do but wait, and watch. Our fellow passengers tend to dress as if planning to attend a pajama party at 35,000 feet, of course, while the professionals dress professionally. Amid the terminal boredom, we find ourselves comforted by a pilots winged badge, oddly transfixed by a gate agents epaulets and charmed by what may be the last remaining glamorous thing about flying commercial, which is the scarf worn by the woman pleading for laggards to fold up their tray tables. While not all female flight attendants wear scarves, the attitude exemplified by Air Canadas uniform guide  Wear your scarf at all times!  is common enough to keep the item tightly knotted to the iconography of the job. In a travelers wishful moments, the panache of the scarf can perk up a slog of a trip with the hint of a colorful jaunt.

title: David Petraeus Urges Stronger U.S. Military Effort in Syria
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations Syria policy came under sharp criticism Tuesday from one of its own former top military commanders and C.I.A. directors David H. Petraeus  even as the White House is weighing new options for fighting the Islamic State in Syria.

title: Gabriel Kreuther
description: European technique with a purpose at the chefs new restaurant near Bryant Park.

title: Restaurant Review: Gabriel Kreuther in Midtown
description: When the chef Gabriel Kreuther left the Modern in 2014, he seems to have packed up virtually everything except Picassos goat in the sculpture garden. He named the place he opened in June, across 42nd Street from Bryant Park, after himself, but it could just as easily be called the Modern in Exile.

title: A Thomas Hart Benton Mural, Repurposed as a Writing Desk
description: COLUMBIA, Mo.  A community newspaper photographers picture of a Republican official using a Thomas Hart Benton mural as a writing backdrop went viral on Monday.

title: Harumi Klossowska de Rola
description: A look at some of the things that inform the jewelry designers work.

title: Spell-Checking Your Tweet
Glenn Close to Play Norma Desmond Again in a Sunset Boulevard in London
description: LONDON  Glenn Close, who portrayed Norma Desmond, the fictional faded film star, in Andrew Lloyd Webbers musical adaptation of Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles and Broadway more than 20 years ago, will reprise the role for a semi-staged production at the London Coliseum in April.

title: 30 New Fall TV Shows in 3 Minutes
description: Its fall premiere season, and theres more TV than ever. Heres a quick survey of whats new out there.

title: The Fabulous World of Harumi Klossowska de Rola
description: Balthuss jewelry-designing daughter reflects on her ethereal life in a historic Swiss chalet  and on memories of a singular childhood.

title: Pope Francis Celebrates Mass in Santiago
description: Pope Francis celebrates Mass at the basilica in Santiago, Cuba, urging followers to build bridges and plant seeds of reconciliation.

title: 6 Bold Graphic Patterns for Fall
description: Prints not dead: Abstract and animal motifs find ample space to repeat.

title: Inside a Jordanian Refugee Camp: Reporters Notebook
description: ZAATARI REFUGEE CAMP, Jordan  When I first visited Zaatari a few months after it opened in 2012, I wrote about the emerging marketplace: a couple dozen kiosks where people hawk used clothes, snacks, SIM cards and perfume. It was one of several signs of Syrians settling in, I said then; of realizing that they would likely live in this camp for months, not days or weeks.

title: As London Fashion Week Ends, a Burberry Concert and Anya Hindmarchs Fun House
description: LONDON  To paraphrase the Edwardian satirist H.H. Munro (better known as Saki, in one of English literatures early feats of branding): They were good fashion shows, as fashion shows go, and as fashion shows go, they went.

title: Volkswagen Debacle on Financial Par With BP Oil Spill
description: Volkswagens cheating on clean air rules in the United States has driven investors into a deep funk.

title: T.S.A. Defends Treatment of Transgender Air Traveler
description: The Transportation Security Administration defended its officers treatment of a transgender woman on Tuesday, a day after she says she was harassed and held for 40 minutes while passing through security in Orlando, Fla., causing her to miss a flight.

title: Culture Project Cancels Play Directed by Cynthia Nixon
description: Citing serious financial trouble, the Culture Project on Tuesday abruptly canceled the premiere of a new play, backed by Rosie ODonnell and directed by Cynthia Nixon, that was to have begun performances on Thursday.

title: Buffy Sainte-Marie Wins Canadas Polaris Prize
description: The veteran folk singer Buffy Sainte-Marie was awarded the 2015 Polaris Prize for Canadian album of the year at a ceremony in Toronto on Monday night. Ms. Sainte-Marie was honored for Power in the Blood, which was released in May, and will receive a prize of 50,000 Canadian dollars.

title: Ben Carson Cant Change Subject After Contentious Muslim Remark
description: Ben Carson, the retired neurosurgeon who is running for president, has seen his campaigns first firestorm after remarks over the weekend in which he said that a Muslim should not be president of the United States.

title: Ta-Nehisi Coates to Write Black Panther Comic for Marvel
description: Ta-Nehisi Coates can be identified in many ways: as a national correspondent for The Atlantic, as an author and, as of this month, as a nominee for the National Book Awards nonfiction prize. But Mr. Coates also has a not-so-secret identity, as evidenced by some of his Atlantic blog posts and his Twitter feed: Marvel Comics superfan.

title: Ben Carson Attacks P.C. Culture
description: In remarks on Tuesday, the Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson defended saying over the weekend that Muslims should not be president.

title: Cardinals Are a Different Team When Carson Palmer Is Healthy
description: Over the final 10 weeks of the 2013 season, the Arizona Cardinals posted the second best record in the N.F.L. at 7-2. Then, over the first 11 weeks of the 2014 season, the Cardinals sat atop the N.F.L. standings with an 8-1 record. But quarterback injuries doomed the team, and Arizona lost its final three games of the season playing with a third-string quarterback, Ryan Lindley.

title: Panda Express Takes a Second Run at New York
description: ROSEMEAD, Calif.  You tend to hear two prevailing views of Panda Express, a buffet-style chain that spoons up populist Chinese-American dishes at more than 1,800 locations around the world  and that plans on planting flags in New York City this year.

title: An Emphasis on Lace and Organza at MarquesAlmeida
description: The designers decided to play up textures in their spring/summer 2016 collection at London Fashion Week.

title: Threes a Trend: All-Over Cutouts
description: Weve already discovered that spring/summer 2016 may well be the Season of the Shoulder. But shoulders arent the only body part that have been exposed on runways over the last few weeks  weve seen cutouts all over garments, particularly black ones, in New York and London. At Proenza Schouler, flamenco-inspired dresses included tidy cutouts at the waist (and shoulders, too). Across the pond, Anthony Vaccarello, the connoisseur of sporty-yet-sexy silhouettes, sent down a black tank with cutout detailing atop oversize, billowy black pants for Versus Versace. And a cutout form-fitting dress (in, you guessed it, black) showed up at Christopher Kane, whose collection was inspired by John Chamberlains car crash sculptures.

title: San Francisco Opera Picks Matthew Shilvock, an Insider, to Be Its Leader
description: The San Francisco Opera mounted a 10-month international search to find a general director to succeed David Gockley when he steps down after this season. But in the end it decided that the best candidate was closer to home: On Tuesday the company announced that it would promote Matthew Shilvock, its associate general director, to the top job in August.

title: Lord of the Dance Creator Michael Flatley Announces His Farewell
description: Michael Flatleys starring role in Lord of the Dance: Dangerous Games will mark more than one milestone for the 57-year-old who founded two major Irish dance franchises. It will be his Broadway debut  and his farewell.

title: ConAgra Reports $1.2 Billion Quarterly Loss as Overhaul Continues
description: ConAgra Foods, which owns brands like Marie Callenders, Reddi-wip and Chef Boyardee, reported a steep loss in its first quarter on Tuesday after knocking down the value of its beleaguered private label business.

title: Volkswagen C.E.O. Apologizes for Fraud
description: Martin Winterkorn, the chief executive of Volkswagen, apologizes for the companys diesel emissions deception but calls it the mistakes of a few people.

title: Sadness vs. Euphoria: Fans Script Endings to Mets Season
description: Mets Win, and the World Is a Better Place

title: Anguished 911 Call of Man Who Said He Had Tried to Drown His Children
description: The crime started in a dark North Carolina neighborhood and ended when two children were pulled alive from a nearby lake by an off-duty deputy, and the police said their father had tried to kill them.

title: One Direction Announces November Album, Setting Up Battle With Bieber
description: Two of the biggest teen-pop acts in recent memory have picked the same day to grow up.

title: Black Barn Takes Its Inspiration From the Farm
description: Black Barn Whitewashed barn board walls, steel paneling and an elaborate overhead maze of raw crisscrossed beams give new personality to the space that was the restaurant SD26. Can you believe it? asked the chef and owner John Doherty, pointing out the dramatic ceiling. The design, by Mark Zeff, who is also a partner, includes tables for larger parties in roomy alcoves and a chefs table stationed to one side of the bright open kitchen. The resolutely farm-to-table menu executed by the chef, Matteo Bergamini, who was at SD26, only hints at Italy with an array of charcuterie, a black fig pizza, and porchetta with broccoli rabe. Mushroom toast, lobster salad and grilled corn salad are on the savory side of the menu. Sweets include an apple pudding with buckwheat croutons. Theres a long list of sparkling wines and Champagnes, some served at the compact oyster bar near the entrance: 19 East 26th Street, 212-265-5959, blackbarnrestaurant.com.

title: Newfest Lineup Includes  Peter Greenaway and Todd Haynes Films
description: Films from seasoned directors join the work of newcomers in the lineup for Newfest, New Yorks lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender film festival. Organizers announced Monday that the festival would open Oct. 22 with Eisenstein in Guanajuato, from Peter Greenaway, about the Russian director Sergei Eisensteins pivotal months in Mexico in the 1930s. The film received a warm reception when it played in Berlin earlier this year.

title: Palestinian Woman Is First to Oversee Muslim Wedding Vows
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Tahrir Hammad thinks women, including herself, are too emotional to serve as judges, and accepts without question an Islamic legal dictate that sees two women as equivalent to one male witness for official ceremonies.

title: Bernie Sanders Joins Rally of Striking Federal Workers to Call for Wage Increase
description: Senator Bernie Sanders, the Democratic presidential candidate, is using the popes visit to Washington to amplify his call for a wage increase for federal workers.

title: Video Review: The Ford Edge Adds a Touch of Luxury
description: ONE glance at your neighbors Chevrolet Suburban will confirm that Americans prefer roomier vehicles, so the dwindling number of midsize crossovers is puzzling. Honda Crosstour and Toyota Venza have been discontinued for lack of interest. That leaves the second-generation Ford Edge to do battle with the Sorento, Santa Fe, Murano and perhaps the raised wagon that is Outback.

title: Driven | 2015 Ford Edge
description: The number of midsize crossover choices may be shrinking, but Ford has produced a new Edge and given it a premium feel and a sharp design.

title: Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, Deposed President, Returns to Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi of Yemen flew back to his war-ravaged country on Tuesday for the first time since he was forced into exile six months ago, according to a senior Yemeni security official and a statement by his exiled government.

title: Los Angeles Puts $100 Million Into Helping Homeless
description: LOS ANGELES  Flooded with homeless encampments from its freeway underpasses to the chic sidewalks of Venice Beach, municipal officials here declared a public emergency on Tuesday, making Los Angeles the first city in the nation to take such a drastic step in response to its mounting problem with street dwellers.

title: Donald Trump Threatens to Sue Club for Growth Over Ad Campaign
description: Donald J. Trump is hitting back at the Club for Growth, threatening to sue the conservative organization unless it stops running advertisements asserting that he wants to raise taxes.

title: Should You Watch CBSs Limitless?
description: SERIES: Limitless, which premieres Tuesday on CBS, is based on the 2011 movie of the same title. Bradley Cooper, the star of the film, is an executive producer, is in the first episode and might appear on the show occassionally.

title: Threes a Trend: Asymmetrical Harnesses
description: Weve seen plenty of unexpected skin in London this week, by way of creative cutouts. Another sexy trend that popped up this week: inventive, asymmetrical new plays on the harness. First, Simone Rocha sent innocent, girlie dresses down the runway bound with fabric or plastic harnesses. At Joseph, creative director Louise Trotter added a provocative touch  a double fabric harness, arcing over one shoulder and across the waist  to a simple ensemble comprised of a white top and black trousers. And true to form, Phoebe English delivered another collection filled with textures and layers, including a choppy cream skirt with suspenders that bound the arms.

title: Is Bridge a Sport? The High Court Will Decide
description: Bridge, the trick-taking card game, has complex rules, prestigious international tournaments and a century of history.

title: Petraeus Warns of Danger in Syria
description: Retired Gen. David H. Petraeus told the Senate Armed Services Committee that the effort to thwart the Islamic State and bring peace to Syria has been inadequate and lacked resources.

title: French Law That Banned UberPop Service Survives Legal Challenge
description: The Constitutional Council in France upheld on Tuesday a law that banned Ubers low-cost ride-hailing service, a much-awaited decision that underscores how national courts are enforcing limits on the companys expansion into new markets.

title: In Detroit, a 100-Foot Graphic Mural That Distills the Urban Experience
description: When Elysia Borowy-Reeder, the executive director of the Museum of Contemporary Art Detroit (MOCAD), first glimpsed the graphic geometric shapes and the vivid hues in the New York artist Andrew Kuos work, she immediately thought it would be perfect for MOCADs Woodward Avenue facade, a space previously covered with murals by the San Francisco artist Barry McGee and by Detroits Seventh Letter Crew.

title: Why Some Policy Experts Question Clintons Plan to Contain Drug Costs
description: When critics complain about the high cost of a prescription drug, drug makers tend to have two main defenses. One is that developing drugs is an expensive, risky endeavor, and so companies need high prices to cover the cost of medical research. The second is that their products bring value by improving health and wellness, and the companies should be rewarded for those public benefits.

title: 5 Easy Meals for the Distracted Cook
description: How many dishes can you cook on autopilot?

title: Why Everything Is Bad for You
description: When I was growing up in the same New Jersey suburbs so expertly described in Todd Solondz movies and Tom Perrotta novels, the usual lunch for me was a sandwich consisting of Wonder Bread spread thick with Land O Lakes butter, a wad of Oscar Mayer bologna and a slice of American cheese.

title: A Glittering After-Party Look at Ashish
description: For spring/summer 2016, the label featured shiny, upbeat garments worn by models with confetti in their hair.

title: Donald Trumps Letter to Club for Growth
description: Alan Garten, Mr. Trump's lawyer, sent a letter to Club for Growth's president, David McIntosh, accusing it of trying to damage Mr. Trumps reputation by lying about his policies.

title: A Religious Museum Expands in Amsterdam
description: The restored and expanded Our Lord in the Attic Museum (Museum Ons Lieve Heer op Solder) in Amsterdam makes its debut on Sept. 23, when visitors will enter the museum through a new entrance building connected by underground passage to the 17th-century house. The six-year, $12 million project adds a museum shop and cafe as well as more exhibit space to cover themes such as religious freedom historically through modern times. In its new layout, the museum also focuses on the stories of the various people who lived in the house.

title: The Risk of a Billion-Dollar Valuation in Silicon Valley
description: Deep inside a Silicon Valley unicorn lurks a time bomb.

title: Siri, Apple Music and Other iPhone Questions
description: We asked readers to send us questions about Apples newest smartphones, the iPhone 6s and 6s Plus, which go on sale on Friday. Brian X. Chen and Farhad Manjoo answer the queries.

title: Why the Pope Should Scare Climate-Change Deniers
description: Perhaps unsurprisingly, conservatives are scrambling to condemn Pope Franciss views on climate change in advance of his speech to Congress on Thursday.

title: The Martian Gets a Sneak Preview at the New York Film Festival
description: Days after being screened for the International Space Station, the Ridley Scott-Matt Damon nerd thriller The Martian will be shown on the planet of New York.

title: Education Gap Between Rich and Poor Is Growing Wider
description: The wounds of segregation were still raw in the 1970s. With only rare exceptions, African-American children had nowhere near the same educational opportunities as whites.

title: Pope Francis, Welcome to America
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Lewandowski Scores Five Goals in Nine Minutes for Bayern Munich
description: The goals came so quickly from Robert Lewandowski that it was hard to keep track of them.

title: India Retracts Proposal on Encryption for Social Media Data After Outcry
description: NEW DELHI  Responding to a chorus of criticism, Indian officials on Tuesday hastily withdrew a draft policy on encryption that would have required users of social media and messaging applications to save plain-text versions of their messages for 90 days so that they could be shared with the police.

title: Samu-Jussi Koski in Greece
description: The designers photographs from Athens, Serifos and the North Aegean Islands.

title: A Finnish Designer Finds Inspiration  Truly  in the Greek Islands
description: Samu-Jussi Koski, the founder and head designer of the Helsinki-based fashion brand Samuji and its housewares line, Samuji Koti, cites nature as a huge inspiration. Hearing him describe the Greek landscape, its clear that phrase isnt just a Q&A cop-out  he finds real motivation in, as he puts it, the colors of the plants, the hills, the strange flowers, the ever-changing tone of the sky. On the island Serifos, which he and his husband have visited each summer for the last decade or so, Koski likes to climb to the top of the highest hill at the edge of Chora, reaching a small church at either sunrise or sunset. The sky that drops to the calm Mediterranean Sea at those times is something so beautiful, he says. One cannot find those colors anywhere else.

title: Should You Watch ABCs The Muppets?
description: SERIES: The Muppets, the latest gig for Jim Hensons menagerie, premieres Tuesday on ABC. It was created by Bill Prady, an executive producer of The Big Bang Theory.

title: Pope Arrives in the U.S.
description: Pope Francis arrived on Tuesday at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland for his first visit to the United States.

title: In Interview, Donald Trump Denies Report of Fathers Arrest in 1927
description: For a story about Donald J. Trumps childhood home of Jamaica Estates, Queens, I talked to the presidential candidate about the role his father, Fred C. Trump, played in developing the neighborhood. I also asked him about a 1927 report in The New York Times, unearthed by the website Boing Boing, that listed Fred Trump as being among a group of people arrested, and then discharged, by the police in response to a Ku Klux Klan rally that had turned violent in Queens. The question, essentially, was, Did you ever hear of this?

title: Should You Watch Foxs Scream Queens?
description: SERIES: Scream Queens, which premieres Tuesday on Fox is the latest from Ryan Murphy, Brad Falchuk and Ian Brennan, the creators of Glee.

title: Saudi Held at Guantnamo Is Repatriated, Reducing Number of Detainees to 114
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon announced on Tuesday that it had repatriated a Guantnamo Bay detainee who intelligence analysts had concluded was probably once a bodyguard for Osama bin Laden. The United States held the man as a wartime prisoner for more than 13 years, government files show.

title: The Top 10 Moments From London Fashion Week
I.R.S. Ruling Makes After-Tax Contributions More Attractive
description: Making pretax contributions to your 401(k) retirement plan is a no-brainer. But recent changes in federal tax rules may make it more attractive for serious savers to increase after-tax contributions, as well.

title: Weeknight Recipes and Cooking Strategies
description: Cooking is a joy, a balm for mind and spirit. At its best it is a kind of magic, the transformation of groceries into art. But midweek cooking? Midweek cooking is a drag.

title: Kardashian Sisters Off to Big Start With Their Own Web Channels
description: LOS ANGELES  And you thought the Kardashian-Jenner sisters had peaked.

title: Harvards Endowment Earns 5.8%, but Lags Some of Its Peers
description: The Harvard University Management Company, which oversees an endowment of $37.6 billion, the academic worlds largest, generated a 5.8 percent return for its most recent fiscal year, significantly lower than several of its rivals.

title: Ryan Los Spring Romance
description: For his spring/summer 2016 collection, the designer used ruffles in a variety of pinks  and introduced prints.

title: Why Scott Walkers Campaign Failed
description: When a political campaign teeters on the edge of failure, the candidate and the campaign staff start to look for explanations. They blame the staff. They blame the press. They blame the weather. They blame everyone except the candidate.

title: U.S. Targets Four States in Effort to Enroll the Uninsured
description: WASHINGTON  With the third open enrollment season under the Affordable Care Act beginning in about six weeks, Obama administration officials said Tuesday that they would focus efforts to expand health coverage to the uninsured in Dallas, Houston, northern New Jersey, Chicago and Miami.

title: Review: In Foxs Rosewood, a Cocky Crime Pathologist in Sultry Miami
description: Miami occupies a special place among TV locations. Dexter, Miami Vice, Nip/Tuck, CSI: Miami, Magic City, HBOs new Ballers: show after show is built on the idea that this citys sun-drenched, hard-bodied exterior must hide corruption. No place, the implication is, can be that beautiful without being sick underneath.

title: Hillary Clinton Says She Opposes Keystone Pipeline
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said on Tuesday that she opposed building the Keystone XL oil pipeline, revealing her position on an issue that divides two Democratic constituencies, organized labor and environmentalists, and that she has long declined to address.

title: Believing in Magic
description: A magician and his assistant, who travel the world performing, decide to tie the knot.

title: A Conversation With Hamid R. Moghadam
description: Mr. Moghadam, 59, is the chairman and chief executive of Prologis, a publicly traded real estate investment trust, or REIT, based in San Francisco, that develops and owns about 700 million square feet of industrial property worldwide, including many sites in New Jersey.

title: Xi Jinping Pledges to Work With U.S. to Stop Cybercrimes
description: SEATTLE  President Xi Jinping pledged in a speech here on Tuesday night to work with the United States on fighting cybercrime, saying that the Chinese government was a staunch defender of cybersecurity.

title: Empire Returns for Its Second Season, Still Juicy With Melodrama
description: Empire returns for its second season on Fox with a show of power. Several, actually.

title: Tony Awards May Leave Radio City for Beacon Theater
description: It looks as if the Tonys are hitting the road again.

title: Making Times Squares Pedestrian Plazas Work
description: So the pedestrian plazas in Times Square arent going away. Last months tabloid flap over topless women and costumed panhandlers prompted William J. Bratton, the citys police commissioner, to say hed like to rip the plazas up. The mayor, Bill de Blasio, didnt disagree, calling for a task force to study ways to improve the square.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Review: Baby Doll, a Child-Woman at the Center of a Moral Sinkhole
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Everyone onstage looks a little clammy at times in the enjoyable if slightly tame new stage adaptation of Baby Doll at the McCarter Theater Center here. The once-grand but now visibly crumbling mansion in which much of the action takes place looks as if it would give scant protection from the fierce Mississippi Delta sun. But the tensions that inflame its inhabitants are the primary cause of any excessive perspiration.

title: Joshua Jay and Anna Kloots: A Magician Marries His Assistant
description: The groom? The magician Joshua Jay. The bride? Anna Kloots, his magicians assistant. When Mr. Jay, 33, appears in a straitjacket, Ms. Kloots, 26, pulls in people from the audience to check the integrity of his bonds and his blindfold.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: What Scott Walker Could Have Learned From George W. Bush
description: The Internet is not wanting for explanations of the flameout of Gov. Scott Walkers short and surprisingly anemic presidential campaign. Walker couldnt lock down the Republican Partys conservative base. His average-Joe persona was no match for the scene-stealing Donald Trump. He didnt understand foreign policy. He didnt understand domestic policy. He flip-flopped. He was too timid in the first debate. He was too gimmicky in the second debate. Above all, the Wisconsin governors downfall illustrates yet again how difficult and unforgiving the business of presidential campaigning is, even for a career politician like Walker.

title: New York City Police Officer Pleads Guilty to Attempted Murder in Drunken Shooting
description: A New York City police officer pleaded guilty to attempted murder on Tuesday for firing a barrage of bullets at a car in Westchester County last year, an unprompted, drunken attack that seriously injured a 47-year-old passenger.

title: Teaming Up, Together (Drake and Future) or Apart (Ryan Adams and Taylor Swift)
description: The idea of a partnership of equals is, at best, fallacy, and at worst, fantasy. Never is that more clear than when one-half of the team-up is Drake or Taylor Swift, the anchors of contemporary pop music.

title: Pizza Rat Prompts a Collective Ew and Debate on Cleaning New York Subway
description: Even in a subway system often cluttered with trash, it stood out: a whole slice of pizza left carelessly on the floor.

title: Giants Cut Receiver Preston Parker; Victor Cruz Runs in Practice
description: Preston Parker, the wide receiver who dropped several passes in the Giants first two games, was released by the team Tuesday. Just a few hours later, Victor Cruz, who has not played since early last season because of two leg injuries, was running in practice for the first time since mid-August.

title: Quirky, an Invention Start-Up, Files for Bankruptcy
description: Quirky, an ambitious crowdsourced invention start-up, which raised $185 million from investors that included General Electric and leading venture capital firms, filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Salt and Pepper Roast Chicken
description: Melissa Clark makes a simple roast chicken.

title: Review: Pondling Looks Deep Into the Heart of a Disturbed Child
description: The rhyme about sugar and spice and everything nice has always been absurd. Anyone whos ever been a little girl can tell you that much. But Madeleine, the faintly disheveled menace at the center of Genevieve Hulme-Beamans poignant and engrossing solo play, Pondling, is in particularly misleading disguise as a darling moppet.

title: Review: In Deep South, Paul Theroux Takes an Eye-Opening Road Trip
description: Paul Theroux is in a suspiciously good mood in Deep South, his 10th travel book. You begin to wonder if, in his relative old age  Mr. Theroux is 74  this inimitably caustic novelist and nonfiction writer is mellowing.

title: As Frustrations Build in Libya, So Do Calls for Help
description: TUNIS  For more than a year, Libyans have been watching their politicians shuttle between foreign capitals on rounds of peace talks, workshops and conferences in search of a solution to the worsening chaos at home. At one recent event in the Tunisian capital, frustrations at the slow progress were evident in the heartfelt questions and statements from the Libyan refugees in the audience.

title: Scott Walkers Dismal Finish Is a Fitting Result, Old Foes Say
description: MILWAUKEE  For the last 25 years, Representative Gwen Moore has sought to relinquish her claim to being the only politician ever to defeat Scott Walker.

title: Late Rally for Doc Adams, a Jeter Before There Were Mitts
description: Before Derek Jeter made his mark as New Yorks most illustrious shortstop, there was another player, popularly known as Doc Adams, who in the mid-1800s invented the position while playing for a different local powerhouse, the Knickerbocker Base Ball Club.

title: Documenting Ukraine with a Different Visual Approach
description: Thomas de Wouterss square, black-and white images of Ukraine look as if they were made by a 1960s-era New York street photographer set loose on the modern-day front between Russia and Ukraine.

title: Pictures of the Day  Greece and Elsewhere
description: Greece and More: Pictures of the Day

title: September 22, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Greece, Cuba, Ukraine and India.

title: New York Prosecutor Accused of Attacking Woman at Bar Says She Was the Aggressor
description: On his first day back at work after Halloween last year, Eli Cherkasky, a prosecutor, told his co-workers at the Manhattan district attorneys office that his bruised eye had been caused by the glasses he had worn as part of his Clark Kent costume.

title: Brian Williams Back on Air After 7 Months
description: With little fanfare, Brian Williams returned to television Tuesday afternoon in his new position as a breaking-news anchor at MSNBC with coverage of Pope Franciss arrival in the United States.

title: Martin Shkreli, the Mercurial Man Behind the Drug Price Increase That Went Viral
description: Martin Shkreli is either the boy genius or the bad boy of pharmaceuticals, depending on ones point of view.

title: Judge Strikes Down New York Citys Ban on Foam Food Containers
description: New York Citys ban on plastic-foam food containers, the once-ubiquitous vessels for Chinese takeout and curbside halal food, has been overturned, rejecting a signature environmental initiative of two mayors and clearing the way for an industry-backed plan to buy and recycle the items.

title: Coke Discloses Millions in Grants for Health Research and Community Programs
description: Coca-Cola, the worlds largest maker of sugary beverages, has spent almost $120 million in the past five years to pay for academic health research, partnerships with major medical groups and community fitness programs aimed at curbing the obesity epidemic.

title: Clinton Breaks Silence on Keystone XL
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton came out in opposition to the oil pipeline at a campaign event in Des Moines.

title: Tribune Publishing Lowers Its Profit Expectations
description: Tribune Publishing executives said in a conference call to investors on Tuesday that the company had reduced its guidance for the year based on what was described as a review of its holdings in Southern California.

title: Alexis Tsipras Appoints New Greek Cabinet Much Like the Old
description: ATHENS  Greeces newly re-elected prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, decided on Tuesday on a new cabinet with few new faces and returned the critical job of finance minister to Euclid Tsakalotos, the low-key economist who made headway with his eurozone peers in bailout negotiations.

title: Pope Francis, in New York, Will Live Like a Diplomat
description: The signs of his arrival in the neighborhood will be less than subtle: a battalion of police officers, Secret Service agents and assorted security personnel monitoring every manhole and sidewalk crack; snipers on the rooftops; bomb-sniffing dogs at the ready.

title: Ryan Fitzpatrick Gets Vote of Confidence From Jets Coach
description: The Jets surprising 2-0 start appears to be going a long way toward helping Ryan Fitzpatrick supplant Geno Smith as the starting quarterback.

title: Volkswagens Diesel Fraud Makes Critic of Secret Code a Prophet
description: A Columbia University law professor stood in a hotel lobby one morning and noticed a sign apologizing for an elevator that was out of order. It had dropped unexpectedly three stories a few days earlier. The professor, Eben Moglen, tried to imagine what the world would be like if elevators were not built so that people could inspect them.

title: The Republican Attack on Muslims
description: The Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson is drawing criticism over the bigoted comments he has been making recently about Muslims. It is well deserved, and is not a matter of P.C. culture, as Mr. Carson has claimed. Nor does Mr. Carson represent some minor fringe element in the Republican Party.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,349 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Mayor Rahm Emanuel Urges Tax Increases to Mend Chicagos Finances
description: CHICAGO  Faced with a toxic combination of mounting pension payments and plunging credit ratings, Mayor Rahm Emanuel on Tuesday called for tax and fee increases unprecedented in this citys modern history, including a last resort property tax increase of more than $500 million to be put in place over four years.

title: Volkswagens Chief in the Vortex of the Storm
description: Striding past a car show model, Martin Winterkorn, trailed by aides, examined a Hyundai i30.

title: The Plot Twist: E-Book Sales Slip, and Print Is Far From Dead
description: Five years ago, the book world was seized by collective panic over the uncertain future of print.

title: Conflict Flavors Obamas Meeting With Chinese Leader
description: WASHINGTON  For the past two years, the critical question confronting the Obama administration about Xi Jinping, the Chinese president who defied American predictions by challenging the United States superpower status early and directly, has been how forcefully to respond.

title: Two Activists Visiting U.S. Call for Rights in Hong Kong
description: Two Hong Kong democracy activists  one young enough to be the others grandson  expressed deep distrust on Tuesday over Chinas intentions and urged President Obama to press their cause when meeting his Chinese counterpart this week.

title: Hillary Clinton Proposes Cap on Patients Drug Costs as Bernie Sanders Pushes His Plan
description: With voter fury rising over the high cost of prescription drugs, Hillary Rodham Clinton proposed capping out-of-pocket drug expenses at $250 a month on Tuesday while a rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, extolled his own plan and long record for pushing to lower drug costs.

title: A Former Employee Speaks

title: Retrophin Complaint Against Shkreli
description: The company filed a lawsuit alleging its former chief executive, Martin Shkreli, had breached his duty of loyalty to the company.

title: Iraq: Airstrike Kills an ISIS Leader
description: The Pentagon said Tuesday that coalition forces killed a senior leader of the Islamic State, Abu Bakr al-Turkmani, in an airstrike two weeks ago in northern Iraq. A Pentagon spokesman, Peter Cook, described Mr. Turkmani as an administrative emir of the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL, and a close associate of the groups leaders. Mr. Cook also confirmed the death of a French jihadist, David Drugeon, in an airstrike in July in Syria. Mr. Drugeon was a member of the Khorasan Group, an offshoot of Al Qaeda, and an explosives expert, Mr. Cook said. Mr. Drugeon trained other extremists in Syria and sought to plan other attacks against Western targets, Mr. Cook said.

title: Liberty Advance to Conference Finals
description: Epiphanny Prince missed 10 of her first 11 attempts from the field in Tuesday nights decisive Game 3 Eastern Conference semifinal against the Washington Mystics at Madison Square Garden. With the Libertys franchise record for wins and best regular-season record in the W.N.B.A. this year withering away in the fourth quarter, Prince had passed up open looks, her confidence nearly shot.

title: Sir David Willcocks, Conductor Who Influenced British Choral Music, Dies at 95
description: Sir David Willcocks, long considered Britains most esteemed choir director, who also led ensembles in the United States and even worked with the Rolling Stones, died on Thursday at his home in Cambridge, England. He was 95.

title: Gov. Scott Walker Goes Back to His Day Job
description: MADISON, Wis.  Gov. Scott Walker went back to his regular job on Tuesday, and it sounded like just another day. The governor was at work in the Capitol, his aides said, holding private meetings and receiving briefings from his executive staff.

The first was resiliency. His firm, West 8, knows a thing or two about flooding, given its headquarters in the Netherlands.

description: With a successful road trip and an eight-game winning streak, the Mets built their lead in the National League East to nine and a half games with only 17 to play. Even for a team with a recent history of shocking collapses, that should have been enough allow the Mets to glide joyfully into their first division title since 2006.

description: Dr. William E. Paul, an immunologist who was credited with focusing the federal governments disparate AIDS research programs in the 1990s on developing innovative therapies that saved millions of lives, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 79.

title: Dr. Leon Root, Orthopedic Surgeon Who Wrote Advice Books, Dies at 86
description: Dr. Leon Root, a widely known orthopedic surgeon whose advice books on back pain and osteoporosis reached a broad public, and who created an ambitious program to screen children in Manhattan and the Bronx for disorders of the bones and joints, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 86.

Instead, he reveals information that sends the police department reeling and forces Barba (Ral Esparza) to square off against two cutthroat defense lawyers in a trail that leads to blackmail, an incriminating confession, another victim and a fugitive suspect. He was 90.

It was too expensive for his parents, he said, but Mr. Martin never quite forgot that charming French Renaissance Revival house with its mansard roof.

title: Popemobiles Through Time
description: Pope Francis will travel this week in a modified Jeep. But many of his predecessors vehicles were the luxury models of their day.

title: Anne-Marie Slaughters Unfinished Business
description: Three years ago, Anne-Marie Slaughter wrote an article for The Atlantic about the difficulty of career advancement for professional women with children. Why Women Still Cant Have It All, which has now grown into Unfinished Business, electrified readers. Slaughters criticisms of workplace policies and attitudes were not new, but her article had the force of her own belated awakening to the problem. A law professor, author and Princeton University dean (now president of the nonpartisan think tank New America), Slaughter had just spent two years as director of policy planning in the State Department under Hillary Clinton  a dream job that she initially hoped would lead to further advancement within the agency. But after two years of punishing work hours and a weekly commute between Washington and Princeton, where her husband was taking care of their two sons, Slaughter was surprised to find herself declining more State Department stints. Sometimes a job just couldnt be squared with family responsibilities, she concluded. She returned to her full-time academic post at Princeton, which offered flexible hours more conducive to family life, and was more or less satisfied with her decision.

title: Starbucks Falls Short After Pledging Better Labor Practices
description: Last year, Starbucks  vowed to provide store employees with more consistent schedules from week to week, and to post their schedules at least 10 days in advance. The company said it would stop asking workers to endure the sleep-depriving ritual known as a clopening, which requires them to shut down a store at night only to return early the next morning to help open it.

Cabbage white butterflies skim over tomato plants that are ready for an end-of-summer harvest. Readers turn book pages idly. Lovers conspire in the shade of two abundant pear trees.

description: If you were born anywhere from the early 1990s to the mid-2000s, you are a member of Generation Z  of which there are approximately 60 million born in the United States.

title: Consumers Are Embracing Full-Fat Foods
description: Public health authorities have long urged Americans to cut back on foods high in saturated fat like butter, meat and whole milk. But a new report on dietary-fat consumption suggests that the public is increasingly eating more, not less, of these foods.

title: Margaret Atwoods The Heart Goes Last
description: The world of The Heart Goes Last starts out feeling familiarly post-apocalyptic: a destitute married couple, Charmaine and Stan, drift across a devastated landscape, forced to sleep in their car as roving bandits threaten attack each night. As the story expands, we see the novels reality is even more disturbing: This is not a different universe, just a slightly exaggerated version of our own. A world where the working class has been pushed off the edge of the economic cliff, and the middle-class dream is alive only as a living nightmare. One of the last sustainable industries is the prison system. Prisons used to be about punishment, and then reform and penitence, and then keeping dangerous offenders inside. Then, for quite a few decades, they were about crowd control  penning up the young, aggressive, marginalized guys to keep them off the streets. And then, when they started to be run as private businesses, they were about the profit margins for the prepackaged jail-meal suppliers and the hired guards and so forth.

title: Trevor Noah on The Daily Show and His Jewish Yoda, Jon Stewart
description: Like the mostly vacant canvas that once hung outside the Midtown Manhattan studios of The Daily Show, advertising his Sept. 28 debut date and not much else, the office that Trevor Noah works from was nearly barren on a recent visit. The walls were unadorned, and the bookshelves were unfilled, except for a sound system that Mr. Noah was setting up so he could listen to jazz while he worked on his material. Perhaps the rooms only other distinguishing feature was a row of three TV sets, tuned to the NY1, CNN and BBC news channels, inundating Mr. Noah, 31, with a stream of information from around the world.

title: In Europes Top Destinations, Hotels to Suit Your Wallet
description: A testament to the adage, You get what you pay for, high-end hotels lavishly indulge guests in everything from personal butlers to full-service spas, swimming pools and enough restaurants to take the guilt out of staying in. But luxury isnt limited to pampering hotels with bank-bleeding prices. Sometimes the extras  a bountiful breakfast buffet, historic settings or personal services like walking tours and hiking directions  provide equivalent value at cheaper lodgings. The following hotel pairs in six European destinations offer intriguing alternatives at either end of the budget spectrum.

title: Peer Pressure (not Parent Pressure) Helps Picky Eaters Try New Foods
description: Many parents struggle to persuade their school-aged children to take to heart the value of eating a healthy, varied diet, one that is colorful, full of vegetables and fruits and light on the bland, refined white grains like bread, pasta and pizza that go down so easily with children. Marlo and Corey, parents of Brooke, 10, and Hunter, 7, want the whole family to sit down to eat one, balanced meal together, but Brooke refuses to eat many foods, preferring pasta with butter and cheese or ramen noodles. Her younger brother almost always follows her lead, and Marlo and Corey have been willing to prepare something different for each child just to be sure that they eat enough.

title: 1915: Nurse Risks Gangrene Test
description: The most infectious, rapid and fatal of all diseases of the battlefield  gas gangrene  has probably been vanquished by science at the American Hospital at Neuilly. Through the heroism of a nurse, Miss Mary Davies, who inoculated herself with the bacilli, Dr. Kenneth Taylor, who recently announced in the Lancet successful experiments on guinea pigs with a new vaccine, was able to test the remedy for the first time on a human being. Although virulent gangrene symptoms rapidly developed in the young woman, Dr. Taylor has announced that she is now out of danger.  The New York Herald, European Edition, September 24, 1915

description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Drive through the sprawl of any big Brazilian city and there they are, the short-stay love motels beckoning with their neon lights and names like Magnata and Taj Mahal. Some resemble colossal medieval fortresses for trysts. Others evoke ancient Egypts Pharaonic excesses.

title: Text to Text | Why Do Americans Stink at Math? and How to Make Math Meaningful
description: Is there a crisis in math education? Lots of people seem to think so.

title: 1949: William F. Buckley Jr. Makes a Speech
description: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Leave a suggestion in the comments section.

title: Coming Soon to Checkouts: Microchip-Card Payment Systems
description: LEE PADGETT, the owner of Busted, a lingerie shop in Detroit, has spent the last two weeks wrestling with three different payment software systems and a pile of new hardware. She is determined that by Oct. 1, her store will be one of the first in the area to begin moving from the familiar swiping technology for processing credit and debit cards to the chip-card system that card networks are pressing retailers to adopt.

title: A Toxic Work World: Q. and A. With Anne-Marie Slaughter
description: In a recent Sunday Review essay, Anne-Marie Slaughter argued that intense and toxic competition in the workplace was driving talented women  and men  out of the office, often in favor of raising their families or caring for aging parents. More than 1,000 readers responded to the topic, commenting on Facebook and The Timess site. Here, Ms. Slaughter responds to a selection of reader questions and comments about her piece:

title: Xi Jinping on House of Cards and Hemingway
description: Here are a few excerpts from President Xi Jinping of Chinas speech to business leaders in Seattle on Tuesday night.

title: Gucci: Spring 2016 RTW
description: Alessandro Micheles latest collection.

title: 1965: French Reds Back Mitterrand
description: PARIS  The French Communist Party ended 17 years of political isolation today [Sept. 23] by endorsing the leftist presidential candidacy of Franois Mitterrand. The choice was necessary because a purely Communist candidacy against President Charles de Gaulle might have produced as little as half of its traditional 20 percent of the vote. With Communist, Socialist, and other leftist backing, Mr. Mitterrand can expect 5 to 6 million votes from an electorate of nearly 28 million. He has a good chance of getting more votes than any other candidate except Gen. de Gaulle in the Dec. 5 election.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 24, 1965

title: Spring Awakening, in Time for Fall
description: Though the 2015-16 Broadway season began in June, not many shows have opened yet. (Perhaps you have at least heard a bit about one of them, Hamilton?) But we theater nerds become pretty excited in the fall, when things really get going.

title: Pope Francis Speech to the Bishops of the United States of America
description: Following is the English translation of Pope Francis speech to United States bishops at St. Matthews Cathedral, as prepared for delivery and released by the Vatican:

description: Highlights of the popemobile parade around the Ellipse and a portion of the National Mall in Washington on Wednesday.

title: The Voyages Issue: Six Photographers on Their Dream Journeys
description: Photo essays from around the world by Bieke Depoorter, George Georgiou, Glenna Gordon, Alec Soth, George Steinmetz and Hiroshi Sugimoto.

title: Far Away From Here
description: Only a few slender strings were attached: two public readings and a commitment to spend the majority of the six months in the country. Beyond that, I would be left to my own devices. An apartment would be provided, and a stipend. I didnt think about it for very long. I wrote back: Yes.

title: Report on U.S. Dollar Debt in Emerging Markets
description: Tim Lee of Pi Economics says that emerging market borrowers have accumulated $3 trillion in cheap dollar-based loans in the last decade of extra loose central bank policies.

title: Sleepy Jones Goes Coast to Coast
description: The pajama brand released treasure-filled balloons into some of the nations most poetic environs.

title: F.A.A. Opens Inquiry After Baby Hurt in Drone Crash
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said it is stepping up its enforcement of commercial drone regulations after a growing number of dangerous incidents, including a crash earlier this month that injured an infant.

title: UBM in Highly Preliminary Talks to Sell PR Newswire
description: LONDON  UBM, the British owner of PR Newswire, said on Wednesday that it was in highly preliminary discussions with several parties to possibly sell the news release distribution service.

title: A Summer of Treasure-Filled Balloons
description: On this first official day of fall, we celebrate summers end with a look back at one particularly seasonal, cross-country road trip. Last month, Sleepy Jones  the brand known for pajamas that look as appropriate on the street as they do at the breakfast table  released big red balloons at some of the nations most breathtaking environs: from the beaches of Montauk and the dunes of White Sands National Monument in New Mexico to the rocky shores of Malibu and the lush vineyards of Napa. It was a treasure hunt of sorts, and the locations were announced on Instagram. Each one was filled with Sleepy Jones pieces, money for the lucky finders troubles and, in one case, a party invitation from Miranda July.

title: Cubs Jake Arrieta Keeps His View of the Playoffs Unobstructed
description: CHICAGO  Jake Arrieta does not bend the brim of his Chicago Cubs cap, not even a little. He said he would never change this.

title: Lila Neugebauer Directs Kill Floor, but the Cows Are Safe in Her Hands
description: No animals were harmed in the making of Kill Floor at Lincoln Center Theaters LCT3 space. But humans arent safe in Abe Kooglers tale of an ex-con who takes the only job she can get  at her hometown slaughterhouse  while trying to reconnect with her teenage son.

title: Pope Francis in Washington
description: On Wednesday, Pope Francis met with President Obama, prayed with bishops and canonized the Rev. Junpero Serra.

title: Hackers Took Fingerprints of 5.6 Million U.S. Workers, Government Says
description: WASHINGTON  Just a day before the arrival of President Xi Jinping here for a meeting with President Obama that will be focused heavily on limiting cyberespionage, the Office of Personnel Management saidWednesdaythat the hackers who stole security dossiers from the agency also got the fingerprints of 5.6 million federal employees.

title: Pope Francis Visit to America, in Pictures
description: Photographs of the popes first trip to the United States, as Catholics and non-Catholics alike will navigate crowds in three cities to catch a glimpse of the peoples pope.

title: In Fashion, Food and Night Life, a New Energy in Milan
description: Milan has, as far as reputations go, long been considered staid and provincial  a business town that empties on weekends. Apart from the influxes for fashion week and Aprils Salone del Mobile design fair, visitors passed it by. But now, the city is on the edge of something of a renaissance, with new designers taking over at leading fashion houses, independent designers gaining more recognition and a host of new restaurants, bars and cultural activities on offer.

title: A Lush Spot on the Los Angeles River
description: Despite its reputation as a concrete canal, the Los Angeles River is green in some spots. The city recently announced that the architect Frank Gehry would help revitalize the 51-mile waterway.

title: Pope Leads Prayer Service in Washington
description: Pope Francis attended a prayer service with American bishops at the Cathedral of St. Matthews the Apostle in Washington on Wednesday.

title: Kam Chancellor Ends Holdout and Reports to Seahawks
description: The Seattle Seahawks on Wednesday welcomed back the All-Pro safety Kam Chancellor, who missed training camp and the first two weeks of the regular season because he wanted his contract restructured.

title: Volkswagen Announces C.E.O. Resignation
description: Berthold Huber, a member of Volkswagens supervisory board, discussed on Wednesday the decision of Martin Winterkorn to resign as chief executive following the diesel emissions deception.

title: Sultry, Desert-Inspired Makeup, the Alberta Ferretti Way
description: I was thinking about a woman in the vast expanses of the desert. Unrestricted spaces allow a womans identity the freedom to emerge, said the designer Alberta Ferretti backstage at the 18th-century Palazzo Serbelloni, moments before sending her collection  folk-inspired dresses in sunburnt variations of organza and lace  out on a catwalk made of sand.

title: Real Life Does Not Include Trigger Warnings: Readers on a Campus Debate
description: Readers offered criticism of the expanding use of trigger warnings for college course material, and some defenses of the practice, in response to a recent op-ed that argued the warnings have deep value for some students.

title: New York City Ballet Gambles on Unknown Choreographers
description: Sara Mearns, balanced on one square inch of a pointe shoe, her other leg bent in front of her, swiveled under Tyler Angles outstretched arm, ducking her head. I cant get through! she shrieked as her neck caught under his elbow. Then both dancers fell out of the position, collapsing with laugher. Robert Binet, 24, smiled. Lets try a different way, he said.

title: Mayor de Blasio and Cardinal Dolan Highlight Plan to Add Beds for Homeless
description: A day before Pope Francis was to arrive in New York, Mayor Bill de Blasio and Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan said on Wednesday that a partnership between the Roman Catholic Church and the city would provide 150 beds this winter to homeless people who have been living on the street.

title: A Yankees Forgiveness Wont Be Forgotten
description: The overdue and gloriously unscripted sequel to Yogi Berras wonderful Yankees life began on a cold Tuesday evening in January 1999, when Berra, a Hall of Fame catcher, stood slightly hunched at the back-entrance doorstep of a recently opened museum named for him. He awaited the arrival of the man whose impulsive behavioral and operational tendencies had sent Berra into a 14-year self-imposed exile from his most cherished workplace, in the South Bronx.

title: A Home Designed by Studio KO
description: The design firms 19th-century Paris apartment is injected with a dash of Surrealism.

title: HowStudio KO Redefines Minimalism
