description: The new NBC show stars Wesley Snipes and Philip Winchester.

title: Paperback Row
description: WELCOME TO BRAGGSVILLE, by T. Geronimo Johnson. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $14.99.) This biting satire, which our reviewer, Rich Benjamin, called the funniest sendup of identity politics, the academy and white racial anxiety to hit the scene in years, follows a callow white teenager who leaves small-town Georgia for college at Berkeley. Newly steeped in academic political correctness, he and his new friends travel back to his hometown to stage a performative intervention  a mock lynching  with calamitous results.

title: A Sea of Geometric Patterns and Stripes at Prada
description: Scenes from backstage at the spring/summer collection.

title: Excerpt: Heroes Reborn
description: The new NBC series is a sequel to Heroes, which ran from 2006-2010.

title: Roland Emmerich on Stonewall
description: The director of Stonewall discusses his film.

title: Theater Listings for Sept. 25-Oct. 1
description: Theater

title: Editors Choice
description: THE COURT AND THE WORLD: American Law and the New Global Realities, by Stephen Breyer. (Knopf, $27.95.) The Supreme Court justice argues that American judges must increasingly understand and engage with foreign and international law.

title: A Francis Effect for a Broken System
description: The petty, the partisan, the hateful fell away  most of it. The bickering, the backbiting, the treachery was tamed  for now. No one shouted You lie! The powerful were made to look powerless. Words were used to uplift instead of to wound.

title: Queer Tango Brings Its Liberated Style to New York
New Books Analyze the Photographs of Frederick Douglass and Sojourner Truth
Review: Strangers Drowning Examines Extreme Do-Gooders
description: In the introduction to his book Class: A Guide Through the American Status System (1983), Paul Fussell noted that hed had trouble telling others what he was working on. Social class is a touchy subject. At parties, people edged away from him.

title: Review: In Tape, Performers Move Fluidly and Whimsically About a Grid
description: In craft circles, duct tape  in an array of patterns and colors  is all the rage. Slap it on a Ziploc bag and you have a dazzling neon zebra pouch. In Tape by Kenneth Kvarnstrom, a Finnish choreographer based in Sweden, the dancers use duct tape to create a grid of lines and squares on the stage. Alas, its just boring black, but Mr. Kvarnstroms idea of tape extends beyond the sticky stuff in this production.

title: Moschino Goes to the Carwash
description: The house introduced a kitschy, upbeat spring collection  filled with thick-cut fringe and reflective detailing.

title: Review: Adrin Villar Rojas Explores Space in New Show
description: Adrin Villar Rojas excels at site-specific works that oscillate among historical, symbolic and spatial effects. One brought him wide attention when he represented Argentina at the 2011 Venice Biennale. Since then, he has become a staple at these large international exhibitions. Working mostly in situ in cast concrete with a team of assistants, he may have single-handedly made a complement of festivalist art, originally a pejorative coined for the grandiose installations of such shows.

title: David Nelson Exhibition Illuminates Evolution of His Work
description: Biography isnt necessarily destiny, but it seems to have played a role in the work of the wonderful artist David Nelson (1960-2013), as this show attests. He studied art in New York in the late 1970s and 80s and began primarily as a painter. In 1990, he and his longtime partner, David Knudsvig, also an artist, tested positive for H.I.V. Mr. Knudsvig died of AIDS three years later, and Mr. Nelsons art began to change, moving from painting to distinctive forms of sculpture and photography.

title: Review: Stonewall Doesnt Distinguish Between Facts and Fiction
description: Stonewall, Roland Emmerichs would-be epic film about a turning point in the gay liberation movement in 1969, is far from the first historical movie to choke on its own noble intentions. For its two-hour-plus duration, the movie struggles to fuse incompatible concepts.

title: Review: Trisha Baga Mixes Orlando, Fla., With Orlando
description: In her second solo show at this gallery, Trisha Baga cultivates the ambitious sprawl of media and narratives prominent in her double New York debut here and at the Whitney Museum in 2012. Her previous efforts coalesced into disorienting surrounds of video projections on walls and nearby objects, whose patchwork of subjects included the popular artsplainer Sister Wendy and Plymouth Rock. Her latest works keep the media more distinct, though not the themes.

title: Movie Review: Stonewall
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Stonewall.

title: Review: The New Morality, a Vintage Play at the Mint
description: In the third act of Harold Chapins The New Morality, a prewar artifact excavated by the Mint Theater Company, our heroine, Betty, prepares a late summer cocktail called a hock cup: She mixes white wine with maraschino liqueur, Cointreau, brandy and a whisper of soda water, muddling the lot with strawberries and cucumber. Its a wonder audiences dont rush the stage for a glass.

title: Richard Prince Takes a New Approach to Cowboys
description: Richard Prince is circling back to familiar ground, on two counts, with the latest iteration of his cowboy theme, going on view on Saturday at the West 21st Street Chelsea gallery of Barbara Gladstone, who represented him from 1987 to 2008, when he left for Gagosian Gallery. This appears to be a rapprochement.

title: Best of France (Ooh-La-La!) and Brooklyns Atlantic Antic
description: France and Brooklyn, two capitals of culture revered for their gastronomy, ability to set trends and distinctive facial hair, will be on display this weekend at festivals around New York.

title: Review: Met Operas Turandot Reveals Layers of Humanity
description: For the first time since the 201213 season, Franco Zeffirellis production of Turandot has been buffed up and sent out to draw the crowds at the Metropolitan Opera. Crowned by a thoughtful assumption of the title role by the soprano Christine Goerke, it opened with a solid performance and to a satisfied reception on Wednesday evening.

title: When Shakespeare Is the Subject, Not the Scribe
description: Shakespeare in love? How about Shakespeare in a jam?

title: New York Film Festival Walks the Tightrope Between Art and Commerce
description: This years New York Film Festival opens with a couple of virtuosic balancing acts. One, The Walk, the latest from Robert Zemeckis, features Philippe Petits nosebleed stroll from one World Trade Center tower to its twin on Aug. 7, 1974. The other high-wire act is far less dangerous, but comes with its own hazards because it means pleasing constituencies as different as film society patrons and everyday cinephiles, critics who complain that its too elitist and those who sniff at the very idea of pleasurable, old-fashioned entertainment. Its a tough trick, one the festival pulls off by putting a crowd-pleaser like Mr. Zemeckis alongside the rarefied likes of Chantal Akerman.

title: Deutsche Bank Picks Goldman Executive as Bank and Insurance Adviser
description: Deutsche Bank said on Thursday that it had hired a senior banker from Goldman Sachs to serve as one of its top advisers for banks and insurance companies.

title: Pope Francis Arrives in New York
description: Francis arrived at Kennedy International Airport, where he was greeted by Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan.

title: Op-Photo: Making Way for Pope Francis
description: A truck filled with ballast blocked a street near St. Patricks Cathedral in New York City on Thursday, in advance of Pope Franciss visit.

title: Jamie Barton, Operas Nose-Studded Rock Star, Returns to the Met
description: Traditionalists dont have to worry: Jamie Barton, the galvanizing young mezzo-soprano, will take out her silver nose stud before she takes the Metropolitan Opera stage on Saturday in Donizettis Anna Bolena. After all, it doesnt exactly match the sumptuous Tudor costume she wears as the disloyal Jane Seymour in David McVicars moody production.

title: Review: Quantico Flips Between Jousting F.B.I. Recruits and a Terrorist Attack
description: Successful producers shape the TV business through the shows that they make. Monumental producers shape the TV business even through the shows that they dont.

title: Movie Review: The Intern
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The Intern.

title: Jos James Celebrates Billie Holiday at the Blue Note
description: When a youngish jazz singer pays homage to a major precursor, you can usually brace yourself for a particular sort of pageantry: a dutiful nod to the time period, a guided tour of the repertory and especially a demonstration of influence, which often boils down to mannerism. Jos James is finding intriguing ways to tweak this formula in his tribute to Billie Holiday, which runs at the Blue Note through Sunday.

title: Postal Service Failed to Protect Personal Data in Mail Surveillance, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  Employees of the United States Postal Service failed to properly safeguard documents that included the names, addresses and financial information used by its law enforcement arm to monitor the mail of people suspected of criminal activities or for national security purposes, an internal investigation found.

title: Movie Review: 99 Homes
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews 99 Homes.

title: With Ultrasound as Backdrop, Carly Fiorina Presses Attack on Planned Parenthood
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C.  As the sound of a fetal heartbeat filled the ultrasound room at a Christian pregnancy center here, Carly Fiorina grasped the elbow of the young woman on the table.

title: Robert Zemeckis, Master of Illusion, Returns
description: This fall is the season of Robert Zemeckis, the 63-year-old Chicago-born writer-director who began making movies in the 1970s and changed American history, at least metaphorically, with his two huge hits Back to the Future (1985) and Forrest Gump (1994).

title: Review: Trinity Restaurant, Italian Fare With Familys Touch
description: Some restaurants labor in the footsteps of legends. For decades, Timothys, just off the Trinity College campus in Hartford, served comfort food at bargain prices, winning a cadre of fiercely loyal customers. And while I still think of its successor, Trinity Restaurant, as a newcomer, it has been around for almost seven years now, offering the college and its mythical-sounding Behind the Rocks neighborhood a low-key, fine-dining option.

title: For Nathaniel Dorsky and Jerome Hiler, Film Is the Star
description: Every so often while watching the work of Nathaniel Dorsky, I let out a yelp of joy. Mr. Dorsky makes blissfully beautiful films that dont tell stories but instead explore the world, the medium and our relationship with each. Theyre short, averaging around 20 minutes, and visually dense, with layers of pulsing color, churning film grain, shifting light and mutating form. Their actors, as it were, are the objects, the flowers, trees, animals, people and cars that slip in and out of the frame, although it is film  fragile, alchemical, magical, lush and luminous  that is the star. Like the gold and silver used in illuminated manuscripts, film creates a radiant glow that suggests why Mr. Dorsky calls his art devotional cinema.

title: Restaurant Review: Artaux Fine Foods Mixes Elegant and Homey
description: Artaux Fine Foods in Sea Cliff offers creative and delicious food in two equally entertaining yet diverse settings.

title: Volunteers, Many Once Refugees Themselves, Help as Guides in Vienna
description: VIENNA  At the migration center in the east wing of the main train station here, Ragad al-Rachid, a petite 19-year-old psychology student and a Syrian Muslim, is immersed in the logistical details of helping dozens of people a day adjust to new lives in her adopted country.

title: Pope Francis Visits: Day 6
description: Pope Francis traveled from Washington to New York. Heres a roundup of the highlights on the sixth day of his trip to the United States and Cuba.

title: Jafar Panahi, Iranian Filmmaker, Persists Despite a Ban
description: PARIS  Theres a memorable scene in Taxi, the latest film by the Iranian dissident director Jafar Panahi, in which his vivacious, now 11-year-old niece recites the rules for making a movie in Iran. They include: Respect Islamic headscarves, avoid contact between men and women, avoid violence, avoid discussing political or economic issues, avoid sordid realism.

title: Brian De Palma Explains Himself in De Palma
description: In the documentary De Palma, a special event of the New York Film Festival on Wednesday, Sept. 30, the 75-year-old director who is its subject gives a film-by-film account of a career that includes such box-office triumphs as Carrie and The Untouchables, as well as a disastrous screen adaptation of Tom Wolfes The Bonfire of the Vanities. The film, by Noah Baumbach and Jake Paltrow, covers Brian De Palmas evolution from a high school science nerd to a Young Turk of Hollywood to a patriarch of sorts.

title: Terror and Corruption Prosecutor Leaves for Private Sector
description: For much of his 11-year career as an assistant United States attorney in the Southern District of New York, Jason P.W. Halperin straddled two worlds: public corruption and terrorism. He took 13 cases to trial and never lost one.

title: Bridge Turkish & Mediterranean Grill Offers Reasons to Take Your Time
description: The usual array of Middle Eastern kebabs and falafel was being offered at Bridge Turkish & Mediterranean Grill in Highland Park, N.J., but I was looking for the Turkish stuff.

title: 12 Indicted in Georgia in Crime Rings Run With Cellphones From Prisons
description: ATLANTA  Twelve people were indicted this week on suspicion of having roles in crime rings that the authorities said relied on cellphones that were smuggled into Georgia prisons and allowed inmates to order killings, sell drugs to customers hundreds of miles away and try to steal identities.

title: Central Park Fence for Pope Gets Strong Reactions
description: For days Upper West Siders saw signs of the impending visit to Central Park by the pope. There were the vendors hawking I  Pope Francis T-shirts at Columbus Circle, a parking ban along the lower half of Central Park West, the removal of Citi Bike rentals. But nothing prepared them for the fence.

title: President Xis Double Talk on Doing Business in China
description: At the start of his visit to the United States, President Xi Jinping of China sought to reassure American companies that his government was committed to protecting the interests of foreign companies and fighting cybercrime.

title: Pictures of the Day: Saudi Arabia and Elsewhere
description: Pictures of the Day  Saudi Arabia and More

title: Restaurant Review: Coming Home to Kellys Sea Level
description: Jerry McGuire, the co-owner of Kellys Sea Level in Rye, says that one of the reasons people enjoy the place so much is that its homey.

title: September 24, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Saudi Arabia, Greece, India and the United States.

title: For the Philharmonics Opening Night, a New Name and a Big Gift
description: The opening of the New York Philharmonics 174th season on Thursday felt like the start of a new chapter, as the orchestra played for the first time in the newly rechristened David Geffen Hall and announced that it was getting the largest individual donation in its history: a $25 million gift from Oscar S. Schafer, the chairman of its board, and his wife, Didi.

title: Review: The Good Old Tasteless Days in Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead
description: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of The National Lampoon looks longingly back at the 1970s when a smart, tasteless joke could make you laugh out loud without worrying about hurting someones feelings or being attacked on social media. Hedonism was in full sway and political correctness in its infancy.

title: In the Bronx, Photographing a Church for the Poor
description: For ngel Franco, photographing religious experience in New York allows him to set aside his own beliefs as he immerses himself in rituals and relationships that sustain communities of faith.

title: Pope Francis Homily at St. Patricks Cathedral
description: Following is the English translation of Pope Francis homily during vespers at St. Patricks Cathedral on Wednesday evening. His speech, delivered in Spanish, was prepared for delivery and released by the Vatican:

title: Review: Mississippi Grind Keeps Its Cards Close
description: Even if you are not a sucker, as I am, for any movie about gambling with an American geographical reference in the title  California Split, The Cincinnati Kid, Atlantic City  you will find a lot to like about Mississippi Grind, a low-key road movie written and directed by Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck. Who can resist a soundtrack full of well-chosen blues and country-and-western songs, many of which offer further testimony to the place of cards, poker chips, dice and racehorses in our national mythology? There is also a cameo from James Toback, screenwriter of The Gambler (the good one, from 1974, with James Caan), and as such a kind of tutelary deity of long odds and risky bets.

title: Review: Finders Keepers Finds Humor and Humanity in the Bizarre
description: An amputated leg leads everyone in a merry dance in Finders Keepers, the kind of documentary that makes you suspect that Christopher Guest is hiding behind the curtain. But this shockingly funny, weirdly touching custody battle between John Wood, the aggrieved amputee, and Shannon Whisnant, the fast-talking entrepreneur who unwittingly bought the appendage in a storage-unit auction, is as authentic as the North Carolina vernacular in which it unfolds.

title: Elizabeth M. Fink, a Lawyer for Attica Inmates and Radicals, Dies at 70
description: Elizabeth M. Fink, a fiery advocate for societys outcasts who devoted much of her law career to vindicating and compensating inmate victims of the 1971 Attica prison uprising, died on Tuesday in Brooklyn. She was 70.

title: Israel Acts to Combat Violence in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM  Israels security cabinet approved a series of measures on Thursday as part of a crackdown on rock throwing and firebombing by Palestinians in Jerusalem, including minimum sentences and greater leeway for the police to open fire  steps that opponents say contravene basic legal principles and may only escalate the violence.

title: Police Program Aims to Pinpoint Those Most Likely to Commit Crimes
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  At the request of his probation officer, Tyrone C. Brown came to a community auditorium here in June and sat alongside about 30 other mostly young black men with criminal records  men who were being watched closely by the police, just as he was.

title: Review: Mission to Lars Follows Siblings Quest to Fulfill Their Disabled Brothers Dream
description: Documentaries about disabilities dont come any smarter or more touching than Mission to Lars, a beautiful sibling road trip tale with a heavy-metal flourish.

title: Saudis Seek to Fend Off U.N. Inquiry on Yemen
description: GENEVA  As Saudi Arabia and its Arab allies pressed their military offensive against Houthi rebels in Yemen, Saudi diplomats were waging their own battle to fend off calls in the United Nations Human Rights Council for an international inquiry into abuses by all parties to the Yemeni conflict.

title: Review: A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story, One Womans Push for Acceptance
description: The makers of A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story leave a few too many questions unanswered, but their subjects immense optimism steamrolls through the documentarys shortcomings. Indeed, there seems to be little this woman cant vanquish.

title: Review: Western Chronicles Borderland Traditions, Both Charming and Violent
description: As TV and movies make abundantly clear, the western has evolved, the genre now updated as a setting for wars among murderous drug cartels and police agencies (the latest exhibit: Sicario).

title: Aide Recants Ordering Attack on Texas Referee
description: A high school football assistant coach told his supervisors that he had ordered the attack on a Texas referee that has been seen by millions, but later recanted, saying that he had taken the blame to protect the players who delivered the blows, school officials said Thursday.

title: A Confluence of Big Events for 3 Faiths
description: For Tony Carnes, editor and publisher of the web magazine A Journey Through NYC Religions, this week is like a World Series, he said. Or, offering another metaphor, he said, Its like the sun and the moon creating a high tide.

title: Iraq: Yazidis Turn to International Court
description: Members of Iraqs Yazidi minority on Thursday urged the International Criminal Court to investigate accusations of atrocities committed by militants of the Islamic State, which they said constituted genocide against their people. Murad Ismael, a member of the delegation, said the Free Yezidi Foundation and the Yazda group handed court prosecutors a report with accounts of killings, abductions of women and children, sexual enslavement and the destruction of religious sites. Luis Moreno Ocampo, the courts former chief prosecutor, served as the groups legal and strategic adviser, Mr. Ismael said. Fatou Bensouda, the courts current chief prosecutor, has condemned crimes by Islamic State militants in Syria and Iraq, but she has said that because those countries have not joined the court, it has no jurisdiction over matters that take place in Syria or Iraq. But Mr. Ismael said the involvement of Islamic State militants from countries that are court members, including Tunisia, Georgia and Australia, in such critical roles as training, fund-raising or organizing crimes against Yazidi women and girls might allow the court to proceed with an investigation.

title: Review: Wildlike Pits a Teenage Girl Against the Alaskan Wilderness
description: In Wildlike, Mackenzie (Ella Purnell), a 14-year-old from Seattle whose father has died and whose mother is in rehab, is sent to live with her uncle in Alaska for the summer. But when the creep starts molesting her, she runs away, alone and desperate in strange if beautiful country. Scrambling to stay ahead of her uncle, Mackenzie eventually attaches to Bartlett (Bruce Greenwood), a middle-aged backpacker headed to Denali National Park, in the unspoken hope that hell help her get home.

title: Antiquities Still at Risk, Experts Warn
description: The pillaging of antiquities by Islamic State militants is thriving in Syria and Iraq despite efforts to counter it, Middle East officials and archaeological experts saidThursdayat a conference on the illicit trafficking of artifacts. Irina Bokova, the director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, said all six Unesco World Heritage sites in Syria had been damaged in that countrys war, including the most recent destruction in the ancient city of Palmyra. Culture has always been a victim of war, but what were seeing today is new, Ms. Bokova said at the Asia Society in New York.

title: Review: In The Green Inferno, Eli Roth Turns Collegians Into Prey
description: Its a homage written in blood. Its an excursion into the forbidden land of unpalatable ideas, with the severed limbs and disemboweled bodies of idealistic young college students serving as signposts.

title: Review: Lost in Hong Kong Is Part Music Video, Part Buddy Film
description: Lost in Hong Kong is a very, very, very, long-feeling movie with identity problems: At times it seems like an extended, sappy pop-music video; at others, a buddy film, with no love lost between the buddies. An unresolved love lies at the center, and a tacked-on homicide unreels into an irrelevant side plot. Perhaps because it tries too hard to be too many things, the movie loses its punch.

title: Alabama Vote Is Rare Win in the South for the U.A.W.
description: When the results of a vote to join the United Automobile Workers union was announced late Wednesday at the Commercial Vehicle Group (C.V.G.) in Piedmont, Ala., the hollering and whooping echoed throughout the plant, said Alan Amos, a welder there.

title: Review: In Misunderstood, a Girl Seeks Relief From a Turbulent Household
description: Misunderstood, a buoyantly funny, sometimes desperately sad film about a child searching for love and home, could easily be titled The Girl, Her Bag and Her Beautiful Cat. These three are the films holy trinity and its defining image, one that is almost Chaplinesque in its graphic clarity and emotional punch. The director, Asia Argento, has a finely tuned sense of the absurd, but isnt afraid of tears. This may be because she once shared the name of the 9-year-old girl, Aria, who observes this turbulent world as if it were a drama she might one day stage.

title: Sharp Drop in Currency Adds to Growing List of Woes in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Since it was created in 1994, the Brazilian currency, the real, has been synonymous with the countrys return to financial stability and its subsequent ascent as an economic power.

title: Pomp and Prayers in New York
description: After arriving from Washington in the middle of his six-day trip to the United States, Pope Francis attended a prayer service at St. Patricks Cathedral.

title: Bernie Sanders Eclipses Hillary Clinton in New Hampshire Poll
description: As summer turned to fall, a chilly wind was blowing in New Hampshire for Hillary Rodham Clinton: A new poll on Thursday showed Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont surging ahead of Mrs. Clinton with 46 percent of the vote to 30 percent for her.

title: Port Authority Remains Divided on Plan to Replace Manhattan Bus Terminal
description: Two years after starting to plan for the replacement of the main bus terminal in Manhattan, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey still does not have a plan, its appointed leaders admitted on Thursday.

title: In Lunch for the Homeless, a Sacred Mission for Pope Francis
description: WASHINGTON  The residents of the Harriet Tubman Womens Shelter rose at 3 a.m. on Thursday to give everyone time to shower, fix their hair and get dressed in the best clothes they had after years on and off the streets, coping with evictions, abuse and jobs that disappeared.

title: Tensions Build as M.T.A. Chief Keeps Pressing New York City for More Money
description: A year after the Metropolitan Transportation Authority unveiled a capital plan to address the systems deteriorating infrastructure and increasing ridership, the chairman of the agency has grown increasingly combative toward New York City, faulting the mayor for not assuming more of the $29 billion proposals costs.

title: Review: At Hartford Stage, Expectations of Love and the Weight of Memory in An Opening in Time
description: HARTFORD  Though fall has only just begun according to the calendar, it is nearing its end at Hartford Stage, and winter is coming on fast. The mortal chill of waning days and lengthening nights pervades An Opening in Time, the anxiously wistful new play by Christopher Shinn that runs here through Oct. 11.

title: Darrelle Revis and Two Other Top Jets May Miss Game Against Eagles
description: The Jets could be without some prominent players Sunday when they try to defeat the Philadelphia Eagles for the first time in franchise history.

title: Review: In Sleepless in New York, the Misery of the Lovelorn
description: Cinema may be fluent in the language of romance, but breakups are another, excruciating story, and Christian Frei is happy to chronicle them in Sleepless in New York. Following three lovelorn city dwellers over an extended period, Mr. Freis raw documentary plumbs the soul-searching, pain and dark, obsessive thoughts that afflict these victims of lost love.

title: Review: In Hotel Transylvania 2, Dracula Yearns for a Little Monster of a Grandson
description: In the 2012 animated picture Hotel Transylvania, the comedy stalwart Adam Sandler voiced a Dracula who juggled concerns over his troubled spooky-lodging business with concerns over losing his vampire daughter, Mavis, to the outside world. Mr. Sandlers cronies and frequent co-stars in live-action movies voiced Draculas classic-monster cohort. As a homage to beloved old-movie myths, it fell into the each man kills the thing he loves category of tribute, setting a level of sacrilege so high that its sequel, Hotel Transylvania 2, directed by the returning Genndy Tartakovsky, is more tolerable simply by dint of inoculation.

title: Robert Streb, Tortoise Among Hares, Stands Out as PGA Tour Finale Begins
description: ATLANTA  Two players from a youth traveling hockey team in Oklahoma in the late 1990s grew up to be professional athletes. Even more mind-boggling, the first one to grace the playoffs in his sport was not Sam Bradford, the Philadelphia Eagles quarterback drafted by the St. Louis Rams with the No. 1 pick in 2010.

title: Review: In The Keeping Room, 3 Women Under Siege in the Civil War
description: The ravages of the Civil War shouldnt require much jazzing up for the movies, but the British director Daniel Barber labors to impress with his Southern period thriller The Keeping Room.

title: Daniel Levins, Dancer in Classical Ballet and Films, Dies at 61
description: Daniel Levins, a dancer sometimes known professionally as Daniel Levans, who gained notice as a teenager in Eliot Felds acclaimed American Ballet Company and as a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater in the 1970s, died on Sept. 15 in Brooklyn. He was 61.

title: Document Signed by Hillary Clinton in 2012 Regarding Huma Abedins New Job
description: The document, part of a process by which Huma Abedin, an aide to Hillary Rodham Clinton, became a special government employee at the State Department, describes Ms. Abedins new title as senior advisor.

title: Where Hercules Slew the Lion
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  I was of two minds about this puzzle.

title: Hillary Clinton Personally Signed Off on Job Change for Huma Abedin
description: Update: According to a document obtained by The New York Times, the certification of a new employment position for one of Hillary Rodham Clintons senior aides at the State Department was signed by Mrs. Clintons then chief of staff, Cheryl D. Mills, who was authorized to sign such documents for Mrs. Clinton.

title: Review: In Pay the Ghost, Nicolas Cage Is on a Mission
description: Good actors making poor choices  especially when the actor is Nicolas Cage  is nothing new, but I worry that the dross in his career ledger is rapidly outpacing the gold. A compellingly idiosyncratic performer, he has languished too long in movies unworthy of his commitment and with no room for the seat-of-the-pants improvisations that make him so riveting.

title: Review: Becoming Bulletproof Follows a Group of Disabled Adults in a Film Within a Film
description: The film inside the film seems a bit slapdash. But thats the only false note in Becoming Bulletproof, a wonderful documentary that follows a group of disabled adults who work together to make a movie.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Sept. 25
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include Pope Francis, the New York Military Academy and filming of Gotham in the Bronx.

title: Review: Ashby Pairs a Retired C.I.A. Killer With a High School Nerd
description: Mickey Rourke, who plays the title character in Ashby, is a bizarre sight in this overstuffed semicomedy, which has no idea what it wants to say. In his towering gray pompadour, Ashby suggests a vain, surgically altered Mafioso relocated to Virginia through the witness protection program. In fact, Ashby is something even more exotic: a retired C.I.A. assassin who by his own account killed 93 people in the line of duty. Is he a heroic patriot or a sociopath? The movie doesnt dare ask, but Mr. Rourkes gruff, sentimental performance suggests a little of both, tilting toward patriot.

title: An Email on Libya Sent to Hillary Clinton
description: This April 2011 email is among those that are being reviewed by F.B.I investigators to determine if aides of Hillary Rodham Clinton mishandled sensitive national security information when communicating with her via email while she was secretary of state.

title: Hillary Clinton Email Inquiry Weighs if Aides Erred at Send
description: WASHINGTON  The email described a deteriorating situation in Libya, with snipers shooting people in the streets as rebels tried to unseat President Muammar el-Qaddafi and worried American diplomats in the midst of a phased checkout from Benghazi. It arrived in the private email account of Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, one Sunday morning in April 2011, with unforeseen consequences.

title: Spare Times for Children for Sept. 25-Oct. 1
description: Museum of the Moving Image Fall Family Day

title: Spare Times for Sept. 25-Oct. 1
description: Museums and Sites

title: Pope Visits St. Patricks Cathedral
description: Pope Francis attends an evening prayer service at St. Patricks Cathedral in New York after a short procession down Fifth Avenue.

title: Jazz Listings for Sept. 25-Oct. 1
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events. Barry Altschul and the 3dom Factor (Saturday) Mr. Altschul, a drummer of deep experience in the post-1960s avant-garde, has a new album, Tales of the Unforeseen, with the excellent trio he calls 3dom Factor. Featuring the saxophonist Jon Irabagon and the bassist Joe Fonda, its a tough, elastic band that moves in and out of phase. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Cornelia Street Caf, 29 Cornelia Street, Greenwich Village; 212-989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com. (Nate Chinen)

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Sept. 25-Oct. 1
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for Sept. 25-Oct. 1
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Classical & Opera Listings for Sept. 25-Oct. 1
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pop Music Listings for Sept. 25-Oct. 1
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Bronx District Attorney and Judge May Trade Roles
description: Bronx Democratic power brokers executed a series of political moves on Thursday night, nominating District Attorney Robert T. Johnson for a judgeship and giving his spot on the November ballot to Justice Darcel D. Clark of the state appellate court.

title: Teaser Trailer: Freedom for the Wolf
description: Freedom for the Wolf is a new documentary directed by Rupert Russell about the rise of illiberal democracy.

title: Movie Listings for Sept. 25-Oct. 1
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Comedy Listings for Sept. 25-Oct. 1
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Hitting the Road, the Mets Regain Their Focus and Widen Their Lead
description: CINCINNATI  In the third inning, Daniel Murphy was racing toward home plate so fast and with such determination that when he slid in safely, his foot clipped the Reds catcher, and Murphy spun several feet past the base. Through all the commotion, Murphy missed the umpires call. When he looked up, a bit disoriented, he flung himself back toward the plate to make sure he had scored.

title: With One Swing, Yankees Solve Left-Handed Riddle of Chris Sale
description: On the strength of Carlos Beltrans three-run homer, the Yankees kept alive their hopes of winning the American League East as they defeated the Chicago White Sox, 3-2, at Yankee Stadium on Thursday.

title: Bill Proposed to Give Regulatory Protection to Puerto Rico Mutual Fund Investors
description: Seventy-five years ago, when the federal government set out to regulate mutual funds, investment firms in Puerto Rico were deemed too far off the beaten track to merit scrutiny. So mutual funds on the island, and other United States territories, were excluded from regulation under the Investment Company Act of 1940.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | ragamuffin
description: ragamuffin  \ra-g-m-fn\  noun

title: Giants Build a Fourth-Quarter Lead, and Win Nonetheless
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Entering the fourth quarter Thursday night, the Giants led the Washington Redskins by 12 points. The home crowd at MetLife Stadium would have been forgiven for feeling a sense of dread.

title: Whats on Television Friday
description: 3 P.M. (FXX) FLIGHT (2012) Its hard to take your eyes off Denzel Washington as Whip Whitaker, a crack airline pilot who manages to land a plane  at one point flying it upside down  after catastrophe strikes during a storm in this thriller from Robert Zemeckis. But Whips life takes a nose dive when an inquiry reveals his lust for drinking and drugs, and suggests that he may not have been sober during his heroic feat. Hes high as a kite, and you may be, too, lifted by the contact high that great filmmaking gives you, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. She added: Its no surprise that Flight has salvation in mind. The shock is how deep Mr. Zemeckis and Mr. Washington journey into the abyss and how long they stay there. It can be tough for stars to play such unrepentantly compromised characters, as Mr. Washington does brilliantly here.

title: Quotation of the Day

Later that week, after two surprise visits from the president of the National Assembly to my familys home, it was suggested to me that I should seek refuge in a foreign embassy.

title: How to Ask for Forgiveness, in Four Steps

The topic was not politics, film, fashion, celebrity or any other subject that could be expected to draw such a crowd. The topic was forgiveness. Sitting in the audience, I was wondering why so many people had turned out, when suddenly: an electrifying moment.

title: Pope Francis, in New York, Takes On Extremism and Inequality

He ended with a stirring homily that was both an ode to the city and a reminder to watch for glimpses of the presence of God among the poorest of the poor.

He stopped at one window depicting its patron on his deathbed, flanked by Mary and Jesus. The scene reassures the faithful that death should not be a time of sadness.

But lately the admiration has been spreading. In 2012, he was drafted into the American Academy of Arts and Letters; in 2013, 30 of his objects appeared in the Venice Biennale, prominently displayed with 36 anonymous Tantric paintings, also small, in a perfect harmony of intuitive shape and saturated color.

I caught it fast and I acted fast, but I must have looked away: By the time of my double mastectomy, the cancer had spread to five lymph nodes.

title: Owing to the Greeks
description: It is rare that a contemporary political state of affairs perfectly corresponds with a classical literary one  when the contours of the two align so entirely that not only does the latter help explain the former, but the new situation, with all its messy contingencies, seems to follow the carefully wrought logic of its aesthetic predecessor with such precision as to appear like a manifestation, or symptom, of it. Yet this is the case (I would argue) with the economic imbroglio between Germany and Greece.

title: Inside the List
description: His and Hers, Part I: You could think of Lauren Groffs third novel, Fates and Furies  new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 7  as a sort of Gone Girl minus the murderous psychopathology. Both tell the story of a marriage first from the husbands somewhat complacent perspective, then change course midway to reveal a wife far more active and vengeful than expected. But Fates and Furies is also, as the title suggests, a meditation on classical ideas of destiny and human agency, with the golden boy Lotto (short for Lancelot) representing submission to the Fates while his wife, Mathilde, rides with the Furies and shapes reality to her liking. I asked Groff which view she endorses, if either. I wobble between action and somewhat optimistic fatalism, she replied by email. In the middle of the night, I side more with Mathildes pragmatic anxiety; during the slow, hot Florida daylight hours, Im a little sunnier, a little more like Lotto. I thought, going into the book, that I was 89 percent Lotto, and this book is in some ways an elaborate apologia to my husband for often being wrapped up in my writing to the exclusion of actual life. But Mathilde is a terrifying sister of my heart, and I find myself in her in equal measure. Its not exactly Flauberts Madame Bovary, cest moi. In truth both Lotto and Mathilde, cest moi. I am both of them and neither of them in equal measure, and their lives and ambivalence and desires have elements of mine, all snarled up in this one big wild knot.

title: The Invention of Nature, by Andrea Wulf
description: Alexander von Humboldt was the pre-eminent scientist of his time. Contemporaries spoke of him as second in fame only to Napoleon. All over the Americas and the English-speaking world, towns and rivers are still named after him, along with mountain ranges, bays, waterfalls, 300 plants and more than 100 animals. There is a Humboldt glacier, a Humboldt asteroid, a Humboldt hog-nosed skunk. Off the coast of Peru and Chile, the giant Humboldt squid swims in the Humboldt Current, and even on the moon there is an area called Mare Humboldtianum. Darwin called him the greatest scientific traveler who ever lived.

title: The Contenders
description: With the advent of fall, publishing dusts off its red carpets, welcoming big new titles and honoring the best of the past year.

title: This Is Your Life, Harriet Chance! by Jonathan Evison
description: Its been more than 50 years since This Is Your Life, the early reality show after which Jonathan Evisons new novel is named, aired the final episode of its initial television run. The concept of the program might seem quaint to the generation that grew up on the Internet  the host, Ralph Edwards, would surprise his guests (some celebrities, some not) with a retrospective of their lives, accompanied by special appearances from friends and family members out of their pasts.

title: John Banvilles The Blue Guitar
description: Here is rufous-headed, roly-poly Oliver Orme, the hypochondriacs hypochondriac, a man with no fortitude, no sticking power; no grit, but inexplicable charisma. Im pushing 50, John Banvilles latest narrator announces, and feel a hundred. His heart is still beating, though: A thiefs heart is an impetuous organ, and Orme is compulsive. Hes been stealing since he pocketed a tube of zinc white paint as a child. Even though he is married to the youthful Gloria, he cannot keep his hands off the wife of his friend Marcus, the local watch repairman. I pinched Polly, he boasts. Polly I purloined.

title: David Maranisss Once in a Great City: A Detroit Story
description: David Maranisss Once in a Great City concerns Detroit in 1963  a crucial year, this book asserts, in the citys history, marking the end of its boom times and the beginning of its end times. Though my Detroit birth and upbringing were still a decade off, 1963 was a big year for me, too. My dad graduated from high school in the city that spring, and my mom would begin her senior year that fall. For their first date, they went to see Its a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World. The ingredients for the citys apocalypse would seem to have come together along with those of my existence.

Its a place so truly Milanese that it closes immediately after aperitivo at 9 p.m. Arbesser  the newly appointed creative director of Iceberg  was taking a break from preparing for his first collection for the house, which debuts today. It will be followed by the first runway presentation of his namesake line a few days later. Having already skipped lunch, it seemed that a glass of Franciacorta (Italian sparkling wine that has been called the official drink of Milan Fashion Week) and aperitivo snacks would constitute his dinner before returning to the studio.

description: Several years ago, the Argentine real-estate developer Alan Faena bought and gutted Miamis 1940s-era Saxony Hotel, in hopes of restoring it to its former glory. Now, with dramatic, tropical interiors by the filmmaker Baz Luhrmann and his wife, the costume designer Catherine Martin, it will reopen in November as the Faena Hotel Miami Beach, a lavish property with an opera-house-style theater and a South American-inspired spa.

title: Africa Is Crucial to Anheuser-Busch InBev Deal with SABMiller
description: Africa is Budweisers lost continent. For SABMiller, it is the jewel in the crown.

title: Charred Shallots With Labneh
description: Melissa Clark grills onions then chops them into a relish seasoned with preserved lemon and fresh herbs to serve with labneh.

title: Shallots Play It Cool on the Grill
description: In my backyard, summer grilling is hot, fast and furious. My aim is to cook dinner quickly so that I can close the grill and eliminate one of the heat sources in my already stifling garden.

title: Me and My Jetta: How VW Broke My Heart
description: THE day I went to pick up my new Volkswagen Jetta TDI in March 2009, the salesman had me sit in the drivers seat while he introduced the cars various features. The engine was softly idling, and as I reached to shut it off, he told me not to bother. The minimal amount of fuel this car burned  sipped, in the automotive argot  was its great selling point. That, and the almost complete removal of hazardous exhaust that had made earlier diesel vehicles notorious.

title: Volkswagen Names Matthias Mller, an Insider, as Chief Executive
description: FRANKFURT  Volkswagen on Friday tried to move beyond the emissions cheating scandal that has threatened to cripple it, naming Matthias Mller, the head of the companys Porsche unit, as chief executive.

title: Furtive Pleas to the Saints, Scribbled on Their Statues
description: St. Anthony of Padua lived eight centuries ago, a priest with the young Franciscan Order who preached the virtues of prayer and austerity. He was canonized within a year of his death in 1231, and today is revered as the patron saint of missing things and lost people.

title: Pentagon Says High-Profile Guantnamo Detainee Will Be Sent to Britain
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter has notified Congress that he has approved sending a high-profile detainee at the Guantnamo Bay prison to Britain, a move that will ease a point of diplomatic tension between the United States and a close ally.

title: Donald Trump Analyzes John Boehners Exit as Speaker: You Tell Me
description: John A. Boehners decision to resign as speaker of the House  the culmination of years of intraparty tensions that have cleaved Republicans during President Obamas administration  set off unrestrained glee at the Family Research Councils Values Voter conference in Washington on Friday, where it was all anyone wanted to talk about.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
John Boehner Successor Is Likely to Face Similar Problems
description: WASHINGTON  Hours after Republicans swept to victory in November 2010, catapulting John A. Boehner to the speakers chair, he was asked how he could possibly persuade House conservatives to do some of the tough jobs of governing like raising the federal debt limit.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  Googles regulatory problems have stretched across the globe. Now, they are coming back home.

title: The Best Way to Close Guantnamo: Reader Q&A
description: The Guantnamo prison camp is the most potent symbol of a disgraceful era of American history, the editorial board argued on Saturday, and its time for President Obama to close it. Below, Jesse Wegman, editorial writer on legal affairs, and Ernesto Londoo, editorial writer on foreign affairs, respond to reader comments on how the facility might be closed.

title: In Brooklyn, Fox Meets Its Match on the Soccer Pitch
description: Last spring David Stutt, a former banker at Goldman Sachs who now teaches middle-school math at the Community Partnership Charter School in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, opened up his childrens new soccer jerseys at his home in Park Slope to find that they had been demonstrably and, given his sensibilities, invidiously altered.

title: Speaker John Boehner Quits the Arena
description: Speaker John Boehners shocking decision to resign from Congress is a sorry measure of how far right-wing extremism has immobilized the Republican Party and undermined the process of healthy government.

title: Marco Rubio Proposes Tax Credit to Spur Paid Family Leave
description: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida vowed on Friday to stand up for a cause normally associated more with Democrats than with his own Republican Party: paid leave for workers who need time off to take care of their families.

title: At Marco de Vincenzo, a Technicolor Vision
description: For spring/summer 2016, the designer offered fringe, patterns on top of patterns and geometric shapes.

title: Obama Set to See Putin, Though Both Deny Asking
description: WASHINGTON  Who asked whom to the prom? Lets put it this way: This date has not even started, and it is not going well.

title: Eighty Years of Penguin Books
description: Before Allen Lane began his publishing house in 1935, good books were the purview of the privileged, costing more than many Londoners spent on a weeks rent. But that all changed when Lane, then managing director of the Bodley Head, bought the rights to 10 already popular hardcovers (including Ernest Hemingways A Farewell to Arms and Agatha Christies The Mysterious Affair at Styles), redesigning each with a uniform set of specs so simple that even small, inexperienced print shops could mass-produce them on the cheap. The color-coded, pocket-size paperbacks  numbered in the order of their release  were a hit, and Lanes house, Penguin, eventually became a favorite of collectors eager to snap up everything from coffee mugs to deck chairs bearing its logo. Eighty years on, a cover-to-cover look at the iconic publishers ongoing legacy.

title: Serena Williams MasterClass Excerpt
description: The tennis star discusses pronation in a clip from a new online learning platform.

title: James Patterson MasterClass Excerpt
description: The author discusses the story in a clip from a new online learning platform.

title: 6 Standoffs John Boehner Led
description: House Speaker John A. Boehner announced his resignation on Friday, saying that he would leave Congress at the end of October. Here is a look at some of the tumultuous times when he has presided over a gridlocked House of Representatives.

description: The musings, observations and procrastinations of Ts critic at large Jody Rosen.

title: Tsipras Pledges to End Crisis
description: In his first cabinet meeting since his recent re-election, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece promised on Friday to make changes and honor the bailout agreement to lead his country out of debt.

title: The World Heard by Hominins 2 Million Years Ago
description: Two million years ago, hominins heard the world very differently from modern humans, according to a new study.

title: Shaker Aamer, Last British Inmate at Guantnamo, to Be Transferred
description: LONDON  After 13 years of imprisonment without trial at the Guantnamo Bay detention camp in Cuba, Shaker Aamer, the last British resident to be held there, will be released to the British authorities, Britains government announced on Friday.

title: The FIFA Scandal: Whats Happened, and Whats to Come
description: From a dawn raid at a five-star hotel to a man hurling stacks of money at Sepp Blatter, the FIFA scandal has had it all. Heres a look at how the story began, and where it may go.

title: What Causes a Super Blood Moon?
description: A rare astronomical phenomenon Sunday night will produce a moon that will appear slightly bigger than usual and have a reddish hue, an event known as a super blood moon.

title: How to Take a Class From Serena Williams and Usher
description: Three years ago, David Rogier, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur with not much of a track record, had two things going for him: an idea for a start-up, and a friendship with Dustin Hoffmans daughter.

title: Whats That Mysterious Man Doing on Bostons Tallest Building?
description: BOSTON  Earlier this week, something strange happened to this citys tallest building. High in the air, on one side of the glimmering monolith known to most at the former John Hancock building, materialized a softly rendered figure, standing on some kind of platform.

title: Better Living Through Social Science Research
description: Academic work in the social sciences often elicits puzzlement from those outside the scholarly realm. Even after one cuts through the layers of technical jargon, the nature of the questions asked can be mystifying.

title: At Prada, Reinventing the Power Suit
description: When did the skirt suit fall out of favor?

title: Throwing the Book, Several Tons of It, at Brazils Tax Code
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  SOME tax lawyers in Brazil prefer to toil in obscurity, navigating a devilishly complex system that is added to nearly every day and then amended again, often in ways that contradict one another. On a continent known for its voluminous tax codes, Brazil stands out, ranking ahead of nations like Bolivia, Venezuela and Paraguay among contenders for the worlds most time-consuming tax regime.

title: The Fashion News to Know This Week
description: A chick who can hang (on your wall)

title: Sunnei, a Subversive New Italian Mens Wear Brand
description: Italian fashion is a bit stale, says the Milan-based designer Loris Messina, referring to what is often seen as a dearth of young talent in his country. But with his almost-two-year-old mens wear brand, Sunnei, Messina and his co-designer, Simon Rizzo, are seeking to change all that.

title: Effortless Cool at Sunnei
description: A look at Sunneis spring/ summer 2016 collection.

title: Boehner and the Belt
description: Travel day (domestic), which means that Im a captive audience for a lot of talking heads on TV. Lots of talk about the Boehner resignation. It was especially excruciating to hear pundits going on about the soon-to-be-ex Speakers motivations for not just stepping down, but actually leaving his seat. Is there some rule preventing them from saying the obvious: his extremely lucrative career as a lobbyist cant start until hes out of Congress?

title: Highlights from Boehners Tenure
description: Speaker John A. Boehner, who announced that he would resign his House seat at the end of October, has presided over an era of great partisan battling.

description: Matthias Mller, the new chief executive of Volkswagen, promised on Friday that he would work to regain the trust of employees, customers, business partners and the industry.

description: Ruth Reichl, the former editor in chief of Gourmet magazine, talks about her home kitchen in the Hudson Valley and the importance of cooking.

title: Nationalists in Finland Hurl Rocks at Iraqis Seeking Asylum
description: Dozens of Finnish nationalists, including a man dressed like a member of the Ku Klux Klan, hurled rocks and fireworks at a bus filled with Iraqis seeking asylum in Finland on Thursday night, the state broadcaster YLE reported.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Edmund White
description: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from the writer and T contributor Edmund White, who shares his picks exclusively with T.

description: Irans president and foreign minister dropped hints on Friday of movement toward a resolution in the fates of Americans imprisoned or missing in Iran.

title: A Government Shutdown Suddenly Looks Far Less Likely
description: John Boehners decision to resign as House Speaker is seen as sharply decreasing the likelihood that House Republicans will force a government shutdown over funding Planned Parenthood.

title: The Fragile Patchwork of Care for New Yorks Oldest Old
description: John Sorensen stood in the entryway of his Upper West Side apartment with a fresh bruise spreading over his upper arm and a blood-smeared bandage around one shin.

title: Review: West Side Story at the John W. Engeman Theater in Northport
description: From the first sinewy notes of Leonard Bernsteins music and the first hard-edged finger snaps of glowering young men prowling across the stage, its clear that the production of West Side Story at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport is on the right track.

title: A Composer Opens Up Her Creative Process, Online
description: As a professor at the Yale School of Music and a working harpist, Hannah Lash enjoys plenty of interaction with students, colleagues and the public. But when it comes time to compose, she typically holes up in her New Haven home late at night and keeps to herself.

title: Childrens Authors Sign On for Chappaqua Book Festival
description: The childrens book author and illustrator Peter Sis love of ice cream is no secret: The title of his most recent book is Ice Cream Summer. But as Mr. Sis mentioned before signing books for children at the Hall of Scoops ice cream shop here, Purple Pig Tales, a custom flavor being offered that combined the taste of cotton candy with swirls of vanilla and rainbow confetti, might not be his first choice.

title: Best Arms in Baseball Have No Bargaining Power
description: No one ever accused David Cone of being an innings-addled wimp.

title: New York Actor Defends Child Who Disrupted a Performance
description: The use of cellphones, the rustling of candy wrappers, and audible murmuring are some of the worst transgressions audience members can make during live theater performances in New York City.

title: What I Love | Jami Floyd
description: The new host of All Things Considered in New York, at home on the Upper West Side.

title: New Boerum Hill Condo: Less Glass, More Brick
description: For apartment hunters who think that Brooklyn has become too glassy in recent years, with some buildings that look like as if they had floated up from South Florida, a new condominium in Boerum Hill may come as a relief, particularly its lower floors.

title: Jami Floyd, WNYC Host, on the Upper West Side
description: Deadlines are sacrosanct to Jami Floyd, the new local host of the National Public Radio show All Things Considered on WNYC, a job she started last month. So when Ms. Floyd and her husband, Kurt Flehinger, a lawyer, bought a four-bedroom prewar apartment near Riverside Park a decade ago, they gave their contractor a strict six-week deadline to finish renovating it. They had to move in no later than Labor Day, they told him, so that their son and daughter would feel settled when they started school.

title: Big Ticket | 7 Harrison Street
description: A penthouse atop a converted warehouse was the sale of the week.

title: In TriBeCa, an Urban Oasis of Glass for $18.57 Million
description: A sleek glass penthouse perched atop a warehouse-turned-boutique condominium in TriBeCa, with an immense landscaped terrace and reflecting pool that provide a verdant urban oasis on the roof, sold for $18,574,000 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Jorge Ramoss Long Game
description: On a Tuesday morning earlier this month, Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County, Ariz., waited near a side entrance of the Tent City Jail, the open-air compound he operates in Phoenix. Several female inmates were lined up before him, hands behind their backs, ankles linked by chains. The women wore black-and-white-striped prison uniforms  the kind of throwbacks tourists don for photographs near Alcatraz  with the words Sheriffs Inmate on their backs. Arpaio wore a black suit, black shoes and a white shirt. He looked as if he had raided Johnny Cashs closet.

title: Threes a Trend: Under the Sea
description: In Milan, maritime looks have skewed more scuba than sailor. For his first Emilio Pucci collection, Massimo Giorgetti affixed sea creatures to mesh and other sheer fabrics; Fausto Puglisi created seashell-encrusted separates; and the Max Mara team paired midi skirts with lighthouse-print T-shirts  all taking the nautical theme a step further than the usual navy stripes.

title: Yale School of Architecture Selects Deborah Berke as New Dean
description: The architect Deborah Berke will be the next dean of the Yale School of Architecture, Peter Salovey, the president of Yale, announced on Friday.

description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2016 Fashion Week in Milan.

title: Neue Galerie Again Offering Lipstick Created by Co-Founders Daughter
description: The Neue Galerie has partnered with the daughter of its co-founder to release a lipstick pegged to its coming exhibition Berlin Metropolis: 1918-1933.

title: Tom Coughlins Even Keel Rescues Giants From the Depths
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A few minutes after midnight, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin bounded into the interview room at MetLife Stadium, made his way to the podium and addressed the assembled reporters.

title: Real Pope Meets Toy Pope
description: Pope Francis laughed on Thursday when he arrived at Kennedy International Airport and was presented with a toy pope by a member of the crowd.

description: The latest issue from T features sumptuous interiors, stunning landscapes and men and women of exceptional ambition.

description: The director discusses The Act of Seeing, his new book with Alan Jones that showcases exploitation movie posters.

title: John Boehner Fades Away
description: WASHINGTON  Shortly after the 2010 election, I encountered Representative John A. Boehner in the Capitol Building. His party had just won a majority in the House, which meant he would soon become speaker. Though hes a Republican and I was a longtime Democratic staff member, we got along well. Just wait, he told me. In six months, Ill be more popular in your caucus than in mine.

title: A Black-Tie Ball Fit for a Knight
description: The Order of Malta is more than nine centuries old, but that doesnt mean it cant try something new. Last Saturday at the Metropolitan Club, the organization, whose mission is to serve the poor and the sick, held its first White Cross Ball in New York, where it has some 150 knights and dames.

title: The Feds Confusing Message About Interest Rate Increases
description: Economists always warn, correctly, not to make too much of any single economic report, but rather to analyze new information in terms of longer-term trends.

title: Compensating Car Owners Will Be Big Test for Volkswagen
description: When Steve Berman, a plaintiffs lawyer in Seattle, heard about the Volkswagen scandal, he quickly posted a video on YouTube urging vehicle owners to contact him.

title: Rib-Crushing Throngs Press Toward Central Park to See Pope Francis
description: After hours of anticipation, the procession Pope Francis made through Central Park on Friday was a blur: Just as soon as it started, it was over. And officials took a bow, estimating that nearly everyone with a ticket had made it inside.

description: The United States and More  Pictures of the Day

title: A Manhattan Prosecutor Is Convicted of Assaulting a Woman at a Bar
description: A prosecutor in the Manhattan district attorneys office was found guilty on Friday of charges he assaulted a woman during a drunken argument at a bar on Halloween night last year.

title: All in the Family
description: BECAUSE THIS IS an especially large edition of T, requiring fairly heroic effort on the part of the staff, Id like to share a bit of the behind-the-scenes action here at The New York Times. The size of any magazine is generally a function of how many advertisers have bought space in it: the more ad pages, the more editorial stories. A couple of weeks before this issue was due to head off to the printer, ad-sales figures spiked 75 percent above what was expected  a fantastic boon in the beleaguered world of print journalism. Of course, we were excited by the news, but whereas we normally have several months to conceive, plan and execute ideas, we now had two weeks to make 40 additional pages.

title: September 25, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the United States, Hungary, Greece and India.

description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Kentucky Clerk in Gay Marriage Dispute, Kim Davis, Joining G.O.P.
description: Kim Davis, the clerk of Rowan County, Ky., who was embraced by Christian conservatives because of her resistance to same-sex marriage, said Friday that she would shun her Democratic Party roots and become a Republican.

title: The Pope in New York
description: On Friday, the pope spoke at the United Nations, visited the National September 11 Memorial, went to a school in East Harlem and celebrated Mass at Madison Square Garden.

title: Review: Lang Lang Opens Philharmonic Season, as Avery Fisher Hall Is Renamed
description: The New York Philharmonic opened its season on Thursday with a gala concert featuring the superstar pianist Lang Lang, in a flashy account of Griegs Piano Concerto, and Alan Gilbert, the orchestras music director, conducting an energetic, if not especially inspired, performance of Beethovens Seventh Symphony. This program of staples, which lasted less than 90 minutes (with no intermission), seemed calculated to go over easily and leave plenty of time for the many patrons attending to enjoy a post-concert dinner.

description: T plucks the best bags right off the runway.

title: Shelf, iPad, Bed Table: The Surprise of Poetry, September 2015
description: Does fall mark a transition for you in what and how you read? The publishing world thinks it does; now is the time for big releases and more serious fiction. Ive got a bit of a stack of new books, and there are even more tempting me on the front tables at my local bookstores.

title: Versace: Spring 2016 RTW
description: Donatella Versace presents her spring 2016 collection.

title: In Brooklyn, a Protest Mural Draws Its Own Protest
description: Wylie Goodman recalls sitting in her Brooklyn home in August when she thought she heard gunfire outside.

title: Reviving a Traditional Irish Womens Sport in New York
description: The Hoboken Guards are the first womens camogie team in New York in nearly 20 years. The photographer Jessica Bal spent a season with the team documenting the bond they found in the traditional Irish sport.

title: Citi Bike App Gets an Upgrade
description: When I last looked at the Citi Bike app, in June 2013, New Yorks bike-sharing program had just started. The app was rudimentary, consisting almost entirely of data about nearby docking stations and the availability of bicycles, information that was sometimes inaccurate. It was fitting for a program that quickly became notorious for faulty software and subpar customer service.

title: Preparing Pinstripes for New Players
description: Q. The Yankees often notify their principal farm team that a player must report to Yankee Stadium tonight or tomorrow for possible duty in the next game. How does the club outfit a player with a properly fitting uniform with his number on it so quickly?

title: Breakdown of U.N. Sustainable Development Goals
description: The Sustainable Development Goals adopted by the United Nations at a summit meeting in New York on Friday lay out a sweeping vision for improving the lives of people all over the world over the next 15 years.

title: U.N. Adopts Ambitious Global Goals After Years of Negotiations
description: UNITED NATIONS  The last time Amina J. Mohammed went home to see her extended family in northern Nigeria, her cousins asked her to skip her usual gifts of clothes and sweets and bring them something that they really needed: body scanners for the gates of the local mosque, to guard against suicide bombers sent by Boko Haram.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: New Drugs Prove More Effective in Treatment of Kidney Cancer, Studies Find
description: New studies of two drugs, showing that each works better than the standard treatment for advanced kidney cancer, should lead to changes in patient care, researchers said on Friday.

title: No End in Sight to Tide of Migrants Entering Europe, U.N. Says
description: LONDON  The flood of Syrian refugees pouring into the heart of Europe is unlikely to ease anytime soon, and worsening conditions in Iraq could send new waves of displaced people onto the Continent, United Nations officials warned on Friday.

title: Major Changes Under Rhode Island Pension Overhaul
description: As states and municipalities struggle with rising pension costs, the governor, legislature and labor organizations in Rhode Island were able to agree on reductions to pension obligations and avoid tax increases or other financial burdens. Here are some of the most significant changes.

title: Rhode Island Averts Pension Disaster Without Raising Taxes
description: Chicago is facing its biggest tax increase in memory, to raise money for pension payments. Illinois is stymied by a $110 billion pension shortfall. In New Jersey, public workers are in court over a failed pension deal. From Pennsylvania to California, pensions costs are crowding out aid for public education.

title: Ruffles, Lace and Crochet at Philosophy
description: For spring/summer 2016, Lorenzo Seraphini opted for a dreamy collection of flowing silhouettes.

title: Review: Zero One Plays With Difference at Danspace
description: Yasuko Yokoshis Zero One is a dance of twos: two alternating worlds, on screen and onstage; two performers at the center of each; two dance cultures mingling. This haunting new work, which opened Danspace Projects fall season on Thursday at St. Marks Church, layers a live duet by the identical twins Manami and Sawami Fukuoka with excerpts from Ms. Yokoshis film Hangman Takuzo, named for a 67-year-old Japanese performance artist who hangs himself  safely  each day in his garden.

title: For Dr. Ken, a Comic Returns to Medicine
description: Apparently the way to get a TV show these days is to be a stand-up comic and pitch a series about your life before you started telling jokes for a living. In recent weeks, NBC offered both Mr. Robinson, featuring Craig Robinson, and The Carmichael Show, with Jerrod Carmichael, and on Friday, Oct. 2, ABC unveils Dr. Ken, starring Ken Jeong, who was a doctor before he became a comic.

title: Review: In Indian Summers, British Expatriates Misbehave
description: With the end of Downton Abbey in sight  only nine more episodes, already being shown in Britain!  the search for a reasonable substitute takes on new urgency. PBS makes a major play to keep the Downton audience with the premiere of Indian Summers on Sunday night on Masterpiece. Its a different animal  leaning more toward sex-charged melodrama than genteel parlor comedy  but if you have a taste for good-looking British people misbehaving in beautiful surroundings, it may do just fine.

title: Review: ABCs Blood & Oil, Washing Away the Past
description: Petroleum, land, money, bravado, ego and intrafamily tensions, but about 1,200 miles north of Dallas. Its the new ABC drama Blood & Oil, which gets off to a tolerable start on Sunday, though, of course, drawing attention on televisions most jam-packed night is always tough.

title: Review: Disclosures, Bruno Isakovics Show and Tell
description: For about an hour on Wednesday night, six performers undressed and confessed in the Underground Theater at Abrons Arts Center. They talked about their relationships to their bodies, revealing everything from circumcisions and mastectomies to sexual fantasies and ruminations on gender. By the end, we knew all about them, their genitals and their lives, in selective but intimate detail.

title: How Lee Child, Author of the Jack Reacher Novels, Spends His Sundays
description: Lee Child, the author of the Jack Reacher crime novels, starts a new book each September and finishes sometime in spring, 20 books in 20 years. The most recent, Make Me, just took over the No. 1 spot on the New York Times best-seller list. He spends Sundays the way many writers do, in his own bubble. Its hard for others to understand, because youre living in this made-up zone of fantasy, where that seems real to you, and the real real stuff seems odd, he said. Mr. Child, 60, whose real name is Jim Grant, lives on the Upper West Side with his wife, Jane Grant.

title: Up and Away, for Young Audiences Who Dont Want Surprises
description: You arrive and are assigned your own cast member, who will escort you to the performance space  where five colorful life-size replicas of hot-air balloons fill the room  and sit right next to you throughout the show. Your personal attach will even walk you to the elevator and wave goodbye at the end.

title: At Ali Babas Terrace, Frequent Fliers With Gridlock in Mind
description: Midtown East is already a busy part of town, but on Tuesday, the neighborhood was especially abuzz. It was the first day of the United Nations General Assembly session, and representatives from around the world had descended on the area in droves. Traffic was at a standstill, helicopters hovered overhead and talk of Pope Francis arrival in two days was everywhere, including at Ali Babas Terrace, a Turkish restaurant just down the street from the United Nations headquarters.

title: Pope Francis Homily During Mass at Madison Square Garden
description: Following is the English translation of Pope Francis homily during Mass at Madison Square Garden on Friday evening. His homily, delivered in Spanish, was prepared for delivery and released by the Vatican:

description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Companies Hire New Lobbyist to Answer Critics
description: WASHINGTON  The drug industry chose a new top lobbyist Friday to help pharmaceutical companies defend themselves against criticism from patients, doctors and government officials who say they are charging exorbitant prices for many medicines.

description: To the Editor:
